361<link rel="stylesheet" media="all" href="/profiles/custom/cgov_site/themes/custom/ncids_trans/dist/css/ncids-common.css?s1d5be" />

362

805<article>

807 <div class="resize-content">

808

809 <h1>

810Genetics of Colorectal Cancer (PDQ®)–Health Professional Version</h1>

811

812 <div id="cgvBody">

813

814 <div class="summary-sections">

815

816 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

817

818 <h6>

819On This Page</h6>

820

821 <ul>

822

823 <li>

824<a href="#_2900">

825Executive Summary</a>

826</li>

827

828 <li>

829<a href="#_1">

830Introduction</a>

831</li>

832

833 <li>

834<a href="#_72">

835Colorectal Cancer Susceptibility Genes</a>

836</li>

837

838 <li>

839<a href="#_89">

840Major Genetic Syndromes</a>

841</li>

842

843 <li>

844<a href="#_189">

845Psychosocial Issues in Hereditary Colon Cancer Syndromes</a>

846</li>

847

848 <li>

849<a href="#_335">

850Changes to This Summary (09/08/2023)</a>

851</li>

852

853 <li>

854<a href="#_AboutThis_1">

855About This PDQ Summary</a>

856</li>

857

858 </ul>

859

860</nav>

861

862

863 <div class="accordion">

864

865

866

867 <section id="_2900">

868

869 <h2>

870Executive Summary</h2>

871

872 <div id="_section_2900" class="pdq-sections">

873<p id="_2901" tabindex="-1">

874This executive summary reviews the topics covered in the PDQ summary on the genetics of colorectal cancer (CRC), with hyperlinks to detailed sections below that describe the evidence on each topic.</p>

875<div class="pdq-content-list">

876<ul id="_2902">

877<li>

878<strong>

879Inheritance and Risk</strong>

880<p id="_2903" tabindex="-1">

881<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_18">

882Factors suggestive of a genetic contribution to CRC</a>

883 include the following: (1) a strong family history of CRC and/or polyps; (2) multiple primary cancers in a patient with CRC; (3) the existence of other cancers within the kindred consistent with known syndromes causing an inherited risk of CRC, such as endometrial cancer; and (4) early age at diagnosis of CRC. Hereditary CRC is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, although two syndromes are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern (<em class="gene-name">

884MUTYH</em>

885-associated polyposis and <em class="gene-name">

886NTHL1</em>

887). </p>

888<p id="_2904" tabindex="-1">

889At least three validated <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1101">

890computer models</a>

891 are available to estimate the probability that an individual affected with cancer carries a pathogenic variant in a mismatch repair (MMR) gene associated with Lynch syndrome, the most common inherited CRC syndrome. These include the MMRpro, MMRpredict, and PREMM5 (PREdiction Model for gene Mutations) prediction models. Individuals with a quantified risk of 2.5% or greater on PREMM5 or 5% or greater on MMRpro and MMRpredict are recommended for genetic evaluation referral and testing.</p>

892</li>

893<li>

894<strong>

895Associated Genes and Syndromes</strong>

896<p id="_2905" tabindex="-1">

897Hereditary CRC has two well-described forms: (1) polyposis (including <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3205">

898familial adenomatous polyposis [FAP]</a>

899 and <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_118">

900attenuated FAP</a>

901 [AFAP], which are caused by pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

902<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3210">

903APC</a>

904</em>

905 gene; and <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_433">

906MUTYH-associated polyposis</a>

907, which is caused by pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

908MUTYH</em>

909 gene); and (2) <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2986">

910Lynch syndrome</a>

911 (often referred to as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer), which is caused by germline pathogenic variants in DNA MMR genes (<em class="gene-name">

912<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1114">

913MLH1</a>

914</em>

915, <em class="gene-name">

916<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1118">

917MSH2</a>

918</em>

919, <em class="gene-name">

920<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3102">

921MSH6</a>

922</em>

923, and <em class="gene-name">

924<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1126">

925PMS2</a>

926</em>

927) and <em class="gene-name">

928<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1130">

929EPCAM</a>

930</em>

931. Other CRC syndromes and their associated genes include <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2642">

932oligopolyposis</a>

933 (<em class="gene-name">

934POLE</em>

935, <em class="gene-name">

936POLD1</em>

937), <em class="gene-name">

938NTHL1</em>

939, <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_647">

940juvenile polyposis syndrome</a>

941 (<em class="gene-name">

942<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2563">

943BMPR1A</a>

944</em>

945, <em class="gene-name">

946<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2563">

947SMAD4</a>

948</em>

949), <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2559">

950Cowden syndrome</a>

951 (<em class="gene-name">

952PTEN</em>

953), and <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2920">

954Peutz-Jeghers syndrome</a>

955 (<em class="gene-name">

956STK11</em>

957). Many of these syndromes are also associated with extracolonic cancers and other manifestations. <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_684">

958Serrated polyposis syndrome</a>

959, which is characterized by the appearance of hyperplastic polyps, appears to have a familial component, but the genetic basis remains unknown. The natural history of some of these syndromes is still being described. Many other families exhibit aggregation of CRC and/or adenomas, but with no apparent association with an identifiable hereditary syndrome, and are known collectively as <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_166">

960familial CRC</a>

961. In addition, most individuals with CRC diagnosed before age 50 years and without a family history of cancer do not have a pathogenic variant associated with an inherited cancer syndrome.</p>

962<p id="_2906" tabindex="-1">

963<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3375">

964Genome-wide searches</a>

965 are showing promise in identifying common, low-penetrance susceptibility alleles for many complex diseases, including CRCs, but the clinical utility of these findings remains uncertain.</p>

966</li>

967<li>

968<strong>

969Clinical Management</strong>

970<p id="_2907" tabindex="-1">

971It is becoming the standard of care at many centers that all individuals with newly diagnosed CRC are evaluated for Lynch syndrome through molecular diagnostic tumor testing assessing MMR deficiency. A <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1110">

972universal screening approach to tumor testing</a>

973 is supported, in which all CRC cases are evaluated regardless of age at diagnosis or fulfillment of existing clinical criteria for Lynch syndrome. A more cost-effective approach has been reported whereby all patients aged 70 years or younger with CRC and older patients who meet the revised Bethesda guidelines are tested for Lynch syndrome. Tumor evaluation often begins with <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1105">

974immunohistochemistry testing</a>

975 for the expression of the MMR proteins associated with Lynch syndrome or <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3119">

976microsatellite instability (MSI) testing</a>

977, <em class="gene-name">

978BRAF</em>

979 testing, and <em class="gene-name">

980MLH1</em>

981 hypermethylation analyses.</p>

982<p id="_2908" tabindex="-1">

983Colonoscopy for CRC screening and surveillance is commonly performed in individuals with hereditary CRC syndromes and has been associated with improved survival outcomes. For example, <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1144">

984surveillance of Lynch syndrome patients with colonoscopy</a>

985 every 1 to 2 years, and in one study up to 3 years, has been shown to reduce CRC incidence and mortality. <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2975">

986Extracolonic surveillance</a>

987 is also a mainstay for some hereditary CRC syndromes depending on the other cancers associated with the syndrome. For example, regular <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_613">

988endoscopic surveillance of the duodenum in FAP patients</a>

989 has been shown to improve survival.</p>

990<p id="_3117" tabindex="-1">

991Prophylactic surgery (colectomy) has also been shown to improve survival in <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_263">

992patients with FAP</a>

993. The timing and extent of risk-reducing surgery usually depends on the number of polyps, their size, histology, and symptomatology. For <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1147">

994patients with Lynch syndrome</a>

995 and a diagnosis of CRC, extended resection is associated with fewer metachronous CRCs and additional surgical procedures for colorectal neoplasia than in patients who undergo segmental resection for CRC. The surgical decision must consider the age of the patient, comorbidities, clinical stage of the tumor, sphincter function, and the patient&#8217;s wishes. </p>

996<p id="_2910" tabindex="-1">

997Chemopreventive agents have also been studied in the management of FAP and Lynch syndrome. In FAP patients, <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_265">

998celecoxib and sulindac</a>

999 have been associated with a decrease in polyp size and number. A double-blind, randomized, controlled trial evaluating the efficacy of sulindac plus an epidermal growth factor receptor inhibitor, <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2894">

1000erlotinib</a>

1001, versus placebo in FAP or AFAP patients with duodenal polyps suggested that erlotinib has the potential to inhibit duodenal polyps in FAP patients. An ongoing trial will determine whether lower doses of erlotinib alone will significantly reduce duodenal polyp burden. <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1148">

1002Aspirin</a>

1003 use (600 mg daily) was shown to have a preventive effect on cancer incidence in Lynch syndrome patients in a large randomized trial; lower doses are being examined in an ongoing study.</p>

1004<p id="_2912" tabindex="-1">

1005<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3076">

1006Novel therapies that stimulate the immune system</a>

1007 have been evaluated in MMR-deficient tumors, including those related to Lynch syndrome. The dense immune infiltration and cytokine-rich environment in MMR-deficient tumors may improve clinical outcomes. A critical pathway responsible for mediating tumor-induced immune suppression is the programmed cell death-1 (PD-1)&#8211;mediated checkpoint pathway. Two phase 2 studies using anti&#8211;PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitors (pembrolizumab and nivolumab) demonstrated favorable outcomes, including progression-free survival, radiographic response rates, and disease control rates in metastatic CRC with MMR deficiency and MSI that had progressed on prior cytotoxic chemotherapy. Pembrolizumab has shown similar benefit in other noncolorectal cancers with MMR deficiency and MSI, but not in tumors that are microsatellite stable.</p>

1008</li>

1009<li>

1010<strong>

1011Psychosocial and Behavioral Issues</strong>

1012<p id="_2911" tabindex="-1">

1013<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_189">

1014Psychosocial factors</a>

1015 influence decisions about genetic testing for inherited cancer risk and risk-management strategies. Uptake of genetic counseling and genetic testing for <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2924">

1016Lynch syndrome</a>

1017 and <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2942">

1018FAP</a>

1019 varies widely across studies. Factors that have been associated with genetic counseling and testing uptake in Lynch syndrome families include having children, the number of affected relatives, perceived risk of developing CRC, and frequency of thoughts about CRC. Psychological studies have shown <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2925">

1020low levels of distress</a>

1021, particularly in the long term, after genetic testing for Lynch syndrome in both carriers and noncarriers. However, other studies have demonstrated the possibility of increased distress following genetic testing for FAP. Colon and gynecologic cancer screening rates have been shown to increase or be maintained among carriers of MMR pathogenic variants within the year after disclosure of results, while screening rates decrease among noncarriers. The latter is expected as the screening recommendations for unaffected individuals are those that apply to the general population. Studies measuring quality-of-life variables in FAP patients show normal-range results; however, these studies suggest that risk-reducing surgery for FAP may have negative quality-of-life effects for at least some proportion of those affected. Patients' communication with their family members about an inherited risk of CRC is complex; gender, age, and the degree of relatedness are some elements that affect disclosure of this information. Research is ongoing to better understand and address psychosocial and behavioral issues in high-risk families.</p>

1022</li>

1023</ul>

1024</div>

1025</div>

1026

1027 </section>

1028

1029

1030

1031 <section id="_1">

1032

1033 <h2>

1034Introduction</h2>

1035

1036 <div id="_section_1" class="pdq-sections">

1037<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1038<h6>

1039In This Section</h6>

1040<ul>

1041<li>

1042<a href="#_2701_toc">

1043Colorectal Polyps as Precursors to Colorectal Cancer (CRC)</a>

1044</li>

1045<li>

1046<a href="#_12_toc">

1047Family History as a Risk Factor for CRC</a>

1048</li>

1049<li>

1050<a href="#_18_toc">

1051Inheritance of CRC Predisposition</a>

1052</li>

1053<li>

1054<a href="#_235_toc">

1055Identification of Individuals at High Genetic Risk of CRC<ul>

1056<li>

1057<a href="#_3393_toc">

1058Early-onset CRC</a>

1059</li>

1060</ul>

1061</a>

1062</li>

1063<li>

1064<a href="#_25_toc">

1065Difficulties in Identifying a Family History of CRC Risk</a>

1066</li>

1067<li>

1068<a href="#_1326_toc">

1069Molecular Events Associated With Colon Carcinogenesis<ul>

1070<li>

1071<a href="#_1328_toc">

1072Chromosomal instability (CIN) pathway</a>

1073</li>

1074<li>

1075<a href="#_1333_toc">

1076Microsatellite instability (MSI) pathway</a>

1077</li>

1078<li>

1079<a href="#_1337_toc">

1080CpG island methylator phenotype (CIMP) and the serrated polyposis pathway</a>

1081</li>

1082<li>

1083<a href="#_1431_toc">

1084Conclusion</a>

1085</li>

1086</ul>

1087</a>

1088</li>

1089</ul>

1090</nav>

1091<p id="_753" tabindex="-1">

1092[<em>

1093Note: Many of the medical and scientific terms used in this summary are found in the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/genetics-dictionary" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/genetics-dictionary">

1094NCI Dictionary of Genetics Terms</a>

1095. When a linked term is clicked, the definition will appear in a separate window.</em>

1096]</p>

1097<p id="_913" tabindex="-1">

1098[<em>

1099Note: Many of the genes and conditions described in this summary are found in the Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) catalog. Refer to <a href="https://www.omim.org/" title="https://www.omim.org/">

1100OMIM</a>

1101 for more information.</em>

1102]</p>

1103<p id="_2899" tabindex="-1">

1104[<em>

1105Note: A concerted effort is being made within the genetics community to shift terminology used to describe genetic variation. The shift is to use the term &#8220;variant&#8221; rather than the term &#8220;mutation&#8221; to describe a genetic difference that exists between the person or group being studied and the reference sequence, particularly for differences that exist in the germline. Variants can then be further classified as benign (harmless), likely benign, of uncertain significance, likely pathogenic, or pathogenic (disease causing). Throughout this summary, we will use the term pathogenic variant to describe a disease-causing mutation. Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/overview-pdq#_2676">

1106Cancer Genetics Overview</a>

1107 summary for more information about variant classification.</em>

1108]</p>

1109<p id="_1346" tabindex="-1">

1110Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most commonly diagnosed cancer in both men and women.</p>

1111<p id="_1347" tabindex="-1">

1112Estimated new cases and deaths from CRC in 2023 in the United States:[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

11131</a>

1114]</p>

1115<div class="pdq-content-list">

1116<ul id="_1348">

1117<li>

1118New cases: 153,020.</li>

1119<li>

1120Deaths: 52,550.</li>

1121</ul>

1122</div>

1123<p id="_1351" tabindex="-1">

1124About 75% of patients with CRC have

1125<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1126sporadic disease</a>

1127 with no apparent evidence of having inherited the disorder.

1128The remaining 10% to 30% of patients have a family history of CRC that

1129suggests a hereditary contribution, common exposures or shared risk factors among family members, or a

1130combination of both.[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

11312</a>

1132] <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1133Pathogenic variants</a>

1134 in high-<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1135penetrance</a>

1136 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1137genes</a>

1138 have been identified as the cause of

1139inherited cancer risk in some colon cancer&#8211;prone families; these are

1140estimated to account for only 5% to 6% of CRC cases overall.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

11413</a>

1142,<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

11434</a>

1144]</p>

1145<p id="_2972" tabindex="-1">

1146In addition, pathogenic variants in lower-penetrance genes may contribute to <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1147familial</a>

1148 colon cancer risk. In such cases, gene-gene and gene-environment interactions may contribute to the development of CRC. </p>

1149<p id="_1325" tabindex="-1">

1150(Refer to the PDQ summaries on <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-screening-pdq">

1151Colorectal Cancer Screening</a>

1152; <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-prevention-pdq">

1153Colorectal Cancer Prevention</a>

1154; <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colon-treatment-pdq">

1155Colon Cancer Treatment</a>

1156; and <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/rectal-treatment-pdq">

1157Rectal Cancer Treatment</a>

1158 for more information about sporadic CRC.)</p>

1159<section id="_2701">

1160<h3 id="_2701_toc">

1161Colorectal Polyps as Precursors to Colorectal Cancer (CRC)</h3>

1162<p id="_1352" tabindex="-1">

1163Colorectal tumors present with a broad spectrum of neoplasms, ranging from

1164benign growths to invasive cancer, and are predominantly epithelial-derived tumors (i.e., adenomas or adenocarcinomas).</p>

1165<p id="_3118" tabindex="-1">

1166Transformation of any polyp into cancer goes through the adenoma-carcinoma sequence.

1167Polyps that have traditionally been considered nonneoplastic include those of the hyperplastic, juvenile, hamartomatous, inflammatory, and

1168lymphoid types. However, in certain circumstances, hamartomatous and juvenile polyps can progress into cancer.

1169</p>

1170<p id="_1355" tabindex="-1">

1171Research, however, does suggest a substantial risk of colon cancer in individuals with juvenile polyposis syndrome and Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, although the nonadenomatous polyps associated with these syndromes have historically been viewed as nonneoplastic.[<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

11725</a>

1173-<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

11747</a>

1175]

1176</p>

1177<p id="_1356" tabindex="-1">

1178Epidemiological studies have shown that a personal history of colon adenomas

1179places one at an increased risk of developing colon cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

11808</a>

1181]</p>

1182<p id="_1357" tabindex="-1">

1183Two complementary

1184interpretations of this observation are as follows:</p>

1185<div class="pdq-content-list">

1186<ol id="_1358">

1187<li>

1188The adenoma may reflect an innate

1189or acquired tendency of the colon to form tumors.</li>

1190<li>

1191Adenomas are the

1192primary precursor lesion of colon cancer.</li>

1193</ol>

1194</div>

1195<p id="_1359" tabindex="-1">

1196More than 95% of CRCs are

1197carcinomas, and about 95% of these are adenocarcinomas. It is well recognized

1198that adenomatous polyps are benign tumors that may undergo malignant

1199transformation. They have been classified into three histologic types, with

1200increasing malignant potential: tubular, tubulovillous, and villous. Adenocarcinomas are generally considered to arise from

1201adenomas,[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

12029</a>

1203-<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

120413</a>

1205] based upon the following important observations:</p>

1206<div class="pdq-content-list">

1207<ol id="_1360">

1208<li>

1209Benign and

1210malignant tissue occur within colorectal tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

121114</a>

1212]</li>

1213<li>

1214When patients with

1215adenomas were followed for 20 years, the risk of cancer at the site of the

1216adenoma was 25%, a rate much higher than that expected in the normal

1217population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

121815</a>

1219]</li>

1220</ol>

1221</div>

1222<p id="_1361" tabindex="-1">

1223The following three characteristics of adenomas are highly correlated

1224with the potential to transform into cancer:[<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

122514</a>

1226]</p>

1227<div class="pdq-content-list">

1228<ol id="_1362">

1229<li>

1230Larger size.</li>

1231<li>

1232Villous

1233pathology.</li>

1234<li>

1235 The degree of dysplasia within the adenoma.</li>

1236</ol>

1237</div>

1238<p id="_1363" tabindex="-1">

1239 In addition,

1240removal of adenomatous polyps is associated with reduced CRC

1241incidence.[<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

124216</a>

1243,<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

124417</a>

1245] While most adenomas are polypoid, flat and depressed

1246lesions may be more prevalent than previously recognized. Large, flat, and

1247depressed lesions may be more likely to be severely dysplastic, although this remains to be clearly proven.[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

124818</a>

1249,<a href="#cit/section_2.19">

125019</a>

1251] Specialized

1252techniques may be needed to identify, biopsy, and remove such lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.20">

125320</a>

1254]</p>

1255</section>

1256<section id="_12">

1257<h3 id="_12_toc">

1258Family History as a Risk Factor for CRC</h3>

1259<p id="_13" tabindex="-1">

1260Some of the earliest studies of family history of CRC were those of

1261Utah families that reported a higher percentage of deaths from CRC

1262(3.9%) among the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1263first-degree relatives</a>

1264 (FDRs) of patients who had died from

1265CRC than among sex-matched and age-matched controls (1.2%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

126621</a>

1267] This

1268difference has since been replicated in numerous studies that have consistently

1269found that FDRs of affected cases are themselves at a twofold to

1270threefold increased risk of CRC. Despite the various study

1271designs (case-control, cohort), sampling frames, sample sizes, methods of data

1272verification, analytic methods, and countries where the studies originated, the

1273magnitude of risk is consistent.[<a href="#cit/section_2.22">

127422</a>

1275-<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

127627</a>

1277]

1278</p>

1279<p id="_786" tabindex="-1">

1280A systematic review and meta-analysis of familial CRC risk has been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

128128</a>

1282] Of 24 studies included in the analysis, all but one reported an increased risk of CRC if there was an affected FDR. The relative risk (RR) for CRC in the pooled study was 2.25 (95% confidence interval [CI], 2.00&#8211;2.53) if there was an affected FDR. In 8 of 11 studies, if the index cancer arose in the colon, the risk was slightly higher than if it arose in the rectum. The pooled analysis revealed an RR in relatives of colon and rectal cancer patients of 2.42 (95% CI, 2.20&#8211;2.65) and 1.89 (95% CI, 1.62&#8211;2.21), respectively. The analysis did not reveal a difference in RR for colon cancer based on location of the tumor (right side vs. left side).</p>

1283<p id="_787" tabindex="-1">

1284The number of affected family members and age at cancer diagnosis correlated with the CRC risk. In studies reporting more than one FDR with CRC, the RR was 3.76 (95% CI, 2.56&#8211;5.51). The highest RR was observed when the index case was diagnosed in individuals younger than 45 years (RR, 3.87; 95% CI, 2.40&#8211;6.22) compared with family members of index cases diagnosed at ages 45 to 59 years (RR, 2.25; 95% CI, 1.85&#8211;2.72), and to family members of index cases diagnosed at age 60 years or older (RR, 1.82; 95% CI, 1.47&#8211;2.25). In this meta-analysis, the familial risk of CRC associated with adenoma in an FDR was analyzed. The pooled analysis demonstrated an RR for CRC of 1.99 (95% CI, 1.55&#8211;2.55) in individuals who had an FDR with an adenoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

128528</a>

1286] This finding has been corroborated.[<a href="#cit/section_2.29">

128729</a>

1288] Other studies have reported that age at diagnosis of the adenoma influences the CRC risk, with younger age at adenoma diagnosis associated with higher RR.[<a href="#cit/section_2.30">

128930</a>

1290,<a href="#cit/section_2.31">

129131</a>

1292] As with any meta-analysis, there could be potential biases that might affect the results of the analysis, including incomplete and nonrandom ascertainment of studies included; publication bias; and heterogeneity between studies relative to design, target populations, and control selection. This study is reinforcement that there are significant associations between familial CRC risk, age at diagnosis of both CRC and adenomas, and multiplicity of affected family members.</p>

1293<table id="_326" class="table-default expandable-container">

1294<caption>

1295Table 1. Estimated Relative and Absolute Risk of Developing Colorectal Cancer (CRC)</caption>

1296<colgroup>

1297<col align="Left" width="33.33%">

1298<col align="Center" width="33.33%">

1299<col align="Center" width="33.33%">

1300</colgroup>

1301<THead>

1302<tr>

1303<th align="Center" scope="col">

1304Family History</th>

1305<th align="Center" scope="col">

1306Relative Risk of CRC [<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

130728</a>

1308]</th>

1311a</span>

1312</th>

1314</THead>

133128</a>

1332] and the absolute risk of CRC by age 79 years<span class="sup">

1333a</span>

1334.</td>

1335</tr>

1336</TFoot>

1337<tbody>

1338<tr>

1341<td align="Center" scope="col">

13421</td>

1343<td align="Center" scope="col">

13444<span class="sup">

1345a</span>

1346</td>

1347</tr>

1348<tr>

1349<td align="Left" scope="col">

1350One FDR with CRC</td>

1351<td align="Center" scope="col">

13522.3 (95% CI, 2.0&#8211;2.5)</td>

1353<td align="Center" scope="col">

13549<span class="sup">

1355b</span>

1356</td>

1357</tr>

1358<tr>

1359<td align="Left" scope="col">

1360More than one FDR with CRC</td>

1361<td align="Center" scope="col">

13624.3 (95% CI, 3.0&#8211;6.1)</td>

1363<td align="Center" scope="col">

136416<span class="sup">

1365b</span>

1366</td>

1367</tr>

1368<tr>

1369<td align="Left" scope="col">

1370One affected FDR diagnosed with CRC before age 45 y</td>

1371<td align="Center" scope="col">

13723.9 (95% CI, 2.4&#8211;6.2)</td>

1373<td align="Center" scope="col">

137415<span class="sup">

1375b</span>

1376</td>

1377</tr>

1378<tr>

1379<td align="Left" scope="col">

1380One FDR with colorectal adenoma</td>

1381<td align="Center" scope="col">

13822.0 (95% CI, 1.6&#8211;2.6)</td>

1383<td align="Center" scope="col">

13848<span class="sup">

1385b</span>

1386</td>

1387</tr>

1388</tbody>

1389</table>

1390<p id="_17" tabindex="-1">

1391When the family history includes two or more relatives with CRC,

1392the possibility of a genetic syndrome is increased substantially. The first

1393step in this evaluation is a detailed review of the family history to

1394determine the number of relatives affected, their relationship to each other,

1395the age at which the CRC was diagnosed, the presence of multiple

1396primary CRCs, and the presence of any other cancers (e.g., endometrial) consistent

1397with an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339343&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339343&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1398inherited CRC syndrome</a>

1399. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_89">

1400Major

1401Genetic Syndromes</a>

1402 section of this summary for more information.)

1403Computer models are now available to estimate the probability of developing CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_2.32">

140432</a>

1405]

1406 These models can be helpful in providing <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1407genetic counseling</a>

1408 to individuals at average risk and high risk of developing cancer. In addition, at least three validated models are also available for predicting the probability of carrying a pathogenic variant in a mismatch repair (MMR) gene.[<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

140933</a>

1410-<a href="#cit/section_2.35">

141135</a>

1412] </p>

1413<p id="_1399" tabindex="-1">

1414<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1397">

1415Figure 1</a>

1416 shows the proportion of CRC cases that arise in various family risk settings.[<a href="#cit/section_2.36">

141736</a>

1418] </p>

1419<figure id="figure_1397" class="image-center">

1420<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/733730.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1421Enlarge</a>

1422<img id="_1397" alt="Pie chart showing the fractions of colon cancer cases that arise in various family risk settings. The majority of colon cancer cases diagnosed in these settings are sporadic. The remaining cancer cases are: cases with familial risk (10%&#8211;30%); Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer) (2%&#8211;3%); familial adenomatous polyposis (&amp;lt;1%); and hamartomatous polyposis syndrome (&amp;lt;0.1%)." title="Pie chart showing the fractions of colon cancer cases that arise in various family risk settings. The majority of colon cancer cases diagnosed in these settings are sporadic. The remaining cancer cases are: cases with familial risk (10%&#8211;30%); Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer) (2%&#8211;3%); familial adenomatous polyposis (&amp;lt;1%); and hamartomatous polyposis syndrome (&amp;lt;0.1%)." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/733730-750.jpg">

1423<figcaption class="caption-container">

1424Figure 1. The fractions of colon cancer cases that arise in various family risk settings. Reprinted from <em>

1425Gastroenterology</em>

1426, Vol. 119, No. 3, Randall W. Burt, Colon Cancer Screening, Pages 837-853, Copyright (2000), with permission from Elsevier.</figcaption>

1427</figure>

1428</section>

1429<section id="_18">

1430<h3 id="_18_toc">

1431Inheritance of CRC Predisposition</h3>

1432<p id="_19" tabindex="-1">

1433Several genes associated with CRC risk have been identified;

1434these are described in detail in the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_72">

1435Colon Cancer Genes</a>

1436 section of this

1437summary. Almost all pathogenic variants known to cause a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460153&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460153&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1438predisposition</a>

1439 to CRC are inherited in an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1440autosomal dominant</a>

1441 fashion.[<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

144237</a>

1443] One example of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339339&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339339&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1444autosomal recessive inheritance</a>

1445, <em class="gene-name">

1446MUTYH</em>

1447-associated polyposis (MAP), has been identified. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_433">

1448MUTYH-Associated Polyposis [MAP]</a>

1449 section of this summary for more information.) Thus, the family

1450characteristics that suggest autosomal dominant inheritance of cancer

1451predisposition are important indicators of high risk and of the possible

1452presence of a cancer-predisposing pathogenic variant. These include the following:

1453</p>

1454<div class="pdq-content-list">

1455<ol id="_313">

1456<li>

1457Vertical transmission of cancer predisposition in autosomal dominant conditions. (Vertical transmission

1458refers to the presence of a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460153&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460153&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1459genetic predisposition</a>

1460 in sequential generations.)

1461</li>

1462<li>

1463Inheritance risk of 50% for both male and female children. When a parent carries

1464an autosomal dominant genetic predisposition, each child has a 50% chance of

1465inheriting the predisposition. The risk is the same for both male and female

1466children.

1467</li>

1468<li>

1469Other clinical characteristics also suggest the presence of a hereditary CRC syndrome:<div class="pdq-content-list">

1470<ul id="_23">

1471<li>

1472Cancers in people with a hereditary predisposition typically

1473occur at an earlier age than in sporadic cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.38">

147438</a>

1475]

1476</li>

1477<li>

1478A predisposition to CRC may include a

1479predisposition to other cancers, such as endometrial cancer, as detailed

1480in the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_89">

1481Major Genetic Syndromes</a>

1482 section of this summary.

1483</li>

1484<li>

1485In addition, two or more primary cancers may occur in a single individual.

1486These could be multiple primary cancers of the same type (e.g., two

1487separate primary CRCs) or primary cancer of different types

1488(e.g., colorectal and endometrial cancer in the same individual).

1489</li>

1490<li>

1491The presence of nonneoplastic extracolonic features may suggest a hereditary colon cancer predisposition syndrome (e.g., congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium and desmoid tumors in familial adenomatous polyposis [FAP]).</li>

1492<li>

1493An uncommon tumor (e.g., adrenocortical carcinoma, sebaceous adenoma or carcinoma, and trichilemmoma) may serve as a clue to the presence of a hereditary cancer syndrome.</li>

1494<li>

1495The presence of multiple polyps may suggest a hereditary colon cancer predisposition syndrome. As susceptibility to oligopolyposis (as few as 10&#8211;15 polyps) has become apparent, clinicians, and gastrointestinal endoscopists in particular, may consider <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1496multigene (panel) testing</a>

1497 of an ever-expanding list of genes associated with CRC. (Refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_686">

1498Table 2</a>

1499, Genes Associated with a High Susceptibility of Colorectal Cancer, for more information.) Because oligopolyposis also involves diverse pathology (including hamartomas, sessile serrated polyps, and sessile serrated adenomas), careful attention to polyp count and polyp histologies helps to determine whether genetic testing and/or further clinical evaluation is appropriate.</li>

1500</ul>

1501</div>

1502</li>

1503</ol>

1504</div>

1505<p id="_24" tabindex="-1">

1506The two most common causes of hereditary CRC are FAP (including AFAP), due to

1507<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1508germline</a>

1509 pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

1510APC</em>

1511 gene,[<a href="#cit/section_2.39">

151239</a>

1513-<a href="#cit/section_2.46">

151446</a>

1515] and Lynch syndrome (previously called hereditary nonpolyposis

1516colorectal cancer [HNPCC]), which is caused by <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1517germline pathogenic variants</a>

1518 in DNA MMR genes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

151947</a>

1520-<a href="#cit/section_2.50">

152150</a>

1522] (<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2756">

1523Figure 2</a>

1524 depicts a classic family with Lynch syndrome, highlighting some of the indicators of hereditary CRC that are described above.) Many other families exhibit aggregation of CRC and/or adenomas, but with no apparent association with an identifiable

1525hereditary syndrome, and are known collectively as familial CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

152637</a>

1527]

1528</p>

1529<figure id="figure_2756" class="image-center">

1530<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/766496.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1531Enlarge</a>

1532<img id="_2756" alt="Pedigree showing some of the classic features of a family with Lynch syndrome across three generations, including transmission occurring through maternal and paternal lineages and the presence of both colon and endometrial cancers." title="Pedigree showing some of the classic features of a family with Lynch syndrome across three generations, including transmission occurring through maternal and paternal lineages and the presence of both colon and endometrial cancers." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/766496-750.jpg">

1533<figcaption class="caption-container">

1534Figure 2. Lynch syndrome pedigree. This pedigree shows some of the classic features of a family with Lynch syndrome, including affected family members with colon cancer or endometrial cancer, a young age at onset in some individuals, and incomplete penetrance. Lynch syndrome families may exhibit some or all of these features. Lynch syndrome families may also include individuals with other gastrointestinal, gynecologic, and genitourinary cancers, or other extracolonic cancers. As an autosomal dominant syndrome, Lynch syndrome can be transmitted through maternal or paternal lineages, as depicted in the figure. Because the cancer risk is not 100%, individuals who have Lynch syndrome may not develop cancer, such as the mother of the female with colon cancer diagnosed at age 37 years in this pedigree (called incomplete penetrance).</figcaption>

1535</figure>

1536</section>

1537<section id="_235">

1538<h3 id="_235_toc">

1539Identification of Individuals at High Genetic Risk of CRC</h3>

1540<p id="_3133" tabindex="-1">

1541National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines are updated regularly to help identify patients who are appropriate for referral to a cancer genetic counseling service.[<a href="#cit/section_2.51">

154251</a>

1543] Historically, guidelines have existed from the American College of Medical Genetics and the National Society of Genetic Counselors, but these are not routinely updated.[<a href="#cit/section_2.52">

154452</a>

1545,<a href="#cit/section_2.53">

154653</a>

1547]</p>

1548<p id="_54" tabindex="-1">

1549When such persons are identified, options tailored to the patient situation are

1550considered. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_89">

1551Major Genetic Syndromes</a>

1552 section of this summary for

1553information on specific interventions for individual syndromes.)

1554</p>

1555<p id="_55" tabindex="-1">

1556At this time, the use of pathogenic variant testing to identify <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=256553&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000256553&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1557genetic susceptibility</a>

1558 to

1559CRC is not recommended as a screening measure in the general

1560population. The rarity of pathogenic variants in CRC-associated genes and the limited sensitivity of current testing strategies render

1561general population testing potentially misleading and not cost-effective.

1562</p>

1563<p id="_698" tabindex="-1">

1564Rather detailed recommendations for <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=496506&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000496506&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1565surveillance</a>

1566 in FAP and Lynch syndrome have been provided by several organizations representing various medical specialties and societies. These organizations include the following:</p>

1567<div class="pdq-content-list">

1568<ul id="_699">

1569<li>

1570American Cancer Society.[<a href="#cit/section_2.54">

157154</a>

1572]</li>

1573<li>

1574United States Multisociety (American Gastroenterological Association and American Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy) Task Force on Colorectal Cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.55">

157555</a>

1576]</li>

1577<li>

1578American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons.[<a href="#cit/section_2.56">

157956</a>

1580]</li>

1581<li>

1582NCCN.[<a href="#cit/section_2.57">

158357</a>

1584]</li>

1585<li>

1586 <a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gtr/" title="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gtr/">

1587Gene Reviews</a>

1588.</li>

1589<li>

1590American College of Gastroenterology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.58">

159158</a>

1592]</li>

1593<li>

1594<a href="https://www.sgo.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/2014-ACOG-bulletin.pdf" title="https://www.sgo.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/2014-ACOG-bulletin.pdf">

1595Society of Gynecologic Oncology and American College of Obstetrics &amp; Gynecology</a>

1596.</li>

1597</ul>

1598</div>

1599<p id="_700" tabindex="-1">

1600The evidence bases for recommendations are generally included within the statements or guidelines. In many instances, these guidelines reflect expert opinion resting on studies that are rarely randomized prospective trials.

1601

1602

1603</p>

1604<section id="_3393">

1605<h4 id="_3393_toc">

1606Early-onset CRC</h4>

1607<p id="_3394" tabindex="-1">

1608The epidemiology of CRC with regard to age at diagnosis is shifting, with individuals increasingly being diagnosed before age 50 years,[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

16091</a>

1610] often in the absence of polyposis and without a family history of CRC suggesting an inherited cancer syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.59">

161159</a>

1612-<a href="#cit/section_2.61">

161361</a>

1614] (Refer to the PDQ summary on <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-prevention-pdq">

1615Colorectal Cancer Prevention</a>

1616 for more information about CRC incidence trends in the general population.) One study that examined the prevalence of highly penetrant pathogenic variants in 450 individuals with early-onset CRC (mean age at diagnosis, 42.5 y) and a family history including at least one FDR with colon, endometrial, breast, ovarian, and/or pancreatic cancer identified 75 germline pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants in 72 patients (16%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.59">

161759</a>

1618] The spectrum of variants identified included Lynch syndrome and non-Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated genes, including several genes that have not traditionally been associated with CRC (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

1619BRCA1</em>

1620/<em class="gene-name">

1621BRCA2</em>

1622, <em class="gene-name">

1623ATM</em>

1624, <em class="gene-name">

1625CHEK2</em>

1626, <em class="gene-name">

1627PALB2</em>

1628, and <em class="gene-name">

1629CDKN2A</em>

1630). Given the high frequency and variety of hereditary cancer syndromes identified, the authors suggested that multigene (panel) testing in this population may be warranted.</p>

1631<p id="_3395" tabindex="-1">

1632In the absence of an additional family or personal history suggestive of Lynch syndrome, isolated cases of CRC diagnosed before age 36 years are uncommonly associated with MMR gene pathogenic variants. One study found MMR pathogenic variants in only 6.5% of such individuals,[<a href="#cit/section_2.60">

163360</a>

1634] whereas another study of patients with CRC younger than 50 years with no more than one FDR with CRC found abnormal <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=285933&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000285933&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1635microsatellite instability</a>

1636 (MSI) in 21% of tumors and overrepresentation of defects in the <em class="gene-name">

1637PMS2</em>

1638 and <em class="gene-name">

1639MSH6</em>

1640 genes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.61">

164161</a>

1642] Therefore, isolated cases of very early-onset CRC in the absence of polyposis should be offered tumor screening with MSI/immunohistochemistry rather than proceeding directly to germline pathogenic variant analysis.</p>

1643<p id="_3396" tabindex="-1">

1644The use of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=800513&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000800513&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1645polygenic risk scores</a>

1646 (PRS) is being studied in the context of early-onset CRC in individuals who have tested negative for common CRC susceptibility variants (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02863107">

1647NCT02863107</a>

1648), with data from one large analysis [<a href="#cit/section_2.62">

164962</a>

1650] demonstrating that the predictive capacity of a 95-gene PRS may be particularly strong in assessing for CRC risk among young individuals (age, &lt;50 y) who lack a family history of CRC in an FDR, and who would otherwise not be selected for early initiation of colonoscopic screening, by current practice. </p>

1651</section>

1652</section>

1653<section id="_25">

1654<h3 id="_25_toc">

1655Difficulties in Identifying a Family History of CRC Risk</h3>

1656<p id="_26" tabindex="-1">

1657The accuracy and completeness of family history data must be considered when using family history to assess individual risk in clinical practice and when

1658identifying families appropriate for cancer research. A reported family

1659history may be erroneous, or a person may be unaware of relatives with

1660cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.63">

166163</a>

1662] Increased use of colonoscopy may result in fewer CRCs and more precancerous colon polyps in a family history. Individuals are much less likely to know about their family history of polyps (i.e., type of polyps and total number of polyps in their relatives) than they are to know about their family history of cancer. In addition, small family sizes and premature deaths may limit how

1663informative a family history may be. Also, due to <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=792352&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000792352&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1664incomplete penetrance</a>

1665, some individuals may carry a genetic

1666predisposition to CRC but do not develop cancer, giving the

1667impression of skipped generations in a family tree.

1668</p>

1669<p id="_27" tabindex="-1">

1670Accuracy of patient-reported family history of colon cancer has been shown to be good, but it is not optimal. Patient report should be verified by obtaining medical records whenever possible, especially for reproductive tract cancers that may be relevant in identifying risk of Lynch syndrome and less reliably reported by some patients.

1671 (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_340">

1672Accuracy of the family history</a>

1673 section in the PDQ summary on <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq">

1674Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling</a>

1675 for more information.)</p>

1676<p id="_2847" tabindex="-1">

1677Several approaches are available to evaluate a patient with newly diagnosed CRC who may or may not be suspected of having a cancer genetics syndrome. The clinician may suspect a potential inherited disposition based on the family history and physical exam, and genetic tests are available to confirm these suspicions. The American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics has published guidelines for evaluating patients with suspected colon cancer susceptibility syndromes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.52">

167852</a>

1679] The guidelines aim to identify individuals whose clinical features warrant referral for genetics consultation. If an individual has multiple polyps (&gt;20), depending on the histology, specific gene-directed testing can be a useful diagnostic tool. Similarly, if a patient&#8217;s clinical presentation is suspicious for Lynch syndrome, germline genetic testing can be directed towards this syndrome. However, diagnosis is more challenging when the clinical picture is less clear. Currently, tumor screening for Lynch syndrome is the most commonly accepted approach. However, increasingly, panels characterizing somatic mutations in tumors are being utilized for a variety of clinical decisions.</p>

1680<p id="_2866" tabindex="-1">

1681A priori risk-assessment testing (which models risk based on a variety of factors, such as age at cancer onset and the spectrum of tumors in the family) may be an appropriate alternative in many cases. Application of such risk models does anticipate the use of multigene (panel) testing; however, their exact role remains to be established.</p>

1682</section>

1683<section id="_1326">

1684<h3 id="_1326_toc">

1685Molecular Events Associated With Colon Carcinogenesis</h3>

1686<p id="_1327" tabindex="-1">

1687Much of our initial understanding of the molecular pathogenesis of CRC derived from rare hereditary CRC syndromes and revealed heterogeneity of CRC both molecularly and clinically. It is well accepted that most CRCs develop from adenomas. The transition from normal epithelium to adenoma to carcinoma is associated

1688with acquired molecular events.[<a href="#cit/section_2.64">

168964</a>

1690-<a href="#cit/section_2.66">

169166</a>

1692] Presently, CRC can be separated into three categories based on similar molecular genetic features, suggesting divergent pathways of tumorigenesis: <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=796062&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000796062&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1693chromosomal instability</a>

1694 (CIN), MSI, and CpG island methylator phenotype (CIMP). The understanding of the molecular genetic pathways of colorectal tumorigenesis is still evolving, and each new level of understanding has occurred in the context of the preceding level of knowledge. In addition, these pathways emerged from important clinical and histological heterogeneity of colorectal polyps and cancers. Thus, the introduction below captures the chronological evolution of our current understanding of colorectal tumorigenesis.</p>

1695<section id="_1328">

1696<h4 id="_1328_toc">

1697Chromosomal instability (CIN) pathway</h4>

1698<p id="_2896" tabindex="-1">

1699The majority of CRCs develop through the CIN pathway. Key changes in CIN cancers include widespread alterations in <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1700chromosome</a>

1701 number (<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460126&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460126&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1702aneuploidy</a>

1703) and frequent detectable losses at the molecular level of portions of chromosomes (<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=464169&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000464169&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1704loss of heterozygosity</a>

1705), such as 5q, 18q, and 17p; and pathogenic variants of the <em class="gene-name">

1706KRAS</em>

1707 oncogene. The important genes involved in these chromosome losses are <em class="gene-name">

1708APC</em>

1709 (5q), <em class="gene-name">

1710DCC</em>

1711/<em class="gene-name">

1712MADH2</em>

1713/<em class="gene-name">

1714MADH4</em>

1715 (18q), and <em class="gene-name">

1716TP53</em>

1717 (17p).[<a href="#cit/section_2.65">

171865</a>

1719,<a href="#cit/section_2.67">

172067</a>

1721] These chromosomal losses are indicative of genetic instability at the molecular and chromosomal levels.[<a href="#cit/section_2.66">

172266</a>

1723] Among the earliest and most common events in the colorectal tumor progression pathway is loss or pathogenic variant&#8211;inactivation of the <em class="gene-name">

1724APC</em>

1725 gene. Pathogenic variant&#8211;inactivation of <em class="gene-name">

1726APC</em>

1727 was first shown to be important to CRC in FAP, a hereditary CRC syndrome in which affected individuals harbor germline <em class="gene-name">

1728APC</em>

1729 alterations, resulting in its loss of function and a dramatically increased incidence of colorectal polyps and cancers. Acquired or inherited pathogenic variants of DNA damage-repair genes, for example, base excision repair, nucleotide excision repair, double stranded repair, and MMR, also play a role in predisposing colorectal epithelial cells to pathogenic variants.</p>

1730</section>

1731<section id="_1333">

1732<h4 id="_1333_toc">

1733Microsatellite instability (MSI) pathway</h4>

1734<p id="_1334" tabindex="-1">

1735Soon thereafter, a subset (10%&#8211;15%) of CRCs was identified that lacked evidence of chromosomal instability but exhibited aberrations in microsatellite repeat sequences,[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

173668</a>

1737,<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

173869</a>

1739] a characteristic of tumors in patients with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.70">

174070</a>

1741] It was later found that hypermethylation of the <em class="gene-name">

1742MLH1</em>

1743 promoter is responsible for many sporadic CRCs with MSI. Germline variants in DNA MMR genes were discovered in patients with Lynch syndrome, whose CRCs frequently displayed MSI. Thus, the <strong>

1744microsatellite instability pathway</strong>

1745 (MSI, sometimes referred to as MIN) was proposed.</p>

1746<p id="_1335" tabindex="-1">

1747The key characteristics of MSI cancers are that they have a largely intact

1748chromosome complement and, as a result of defects in the DNA MMR system, more readily acquire pathogenic variants in important and often unique cancer-associated genes. These types of cancers are detectable at the molecular level by

1749alterations in repeating units of DNA that occur normally throughout the

1750genome, known as DNA microsatellites.</p>

1751<p id="_1366" tabindex="-1">

1752The rate of adenoma-to-carcinoma progression appears to be faster in microsatellite-unstable tumors than in microsatellite-stable tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.71">

175371</a>

1754] The foundation for this is the repeated reports of interval cancers in patients with recent, normal colonoscopy. Further support for this is seen in the serrated pathway (see below), in which high rates of interval cancer have also been observed.[<a href="#cit/section_2.72">

175572</a>

1756,<a href="#cit/section_2.73">

175773</a>

1758] Characteristic histologic changes, such as increased mucin production, can be seen in tumors that demonstrate MSI, intratumoral T lymphocyte infiltration/<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=681114&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000681114&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1759Crohn-like reaction</a>

1760, etc., distinguishing the colorectal tumors in this pathway.</p>

1761<p id="_1336" tabindex="-1">

1762The knowledge derived from the study of inherited CRC syndromes has provided important clues regarding the molecular events that mediate tumor initiation and tumor progression in people

1763without germline abnormalities. Among the earliest events in the colorectal

1764tumor progression pathway (both MSI and CIN) is loss of function of the <em class="gene-name">

1765APC</em>

1766

1767gene product.</p>

1768</section>

1769<section id="_1337">

1770<h4 id="_1337_toc">

1771CpG island methylator phenotype (CIMP) and the serrated polyposis pathway</h4>

1772<p id="_1338" tabindex="-1">

1773Beginning in the 1980s, studies began reporting an increased risk of CRC in patients with hyperplastic polyposis syndrome (HPS), now referred to as serrated polyposis syndrome (SPS).[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

17746</a>

1775,<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

17767</a>

1777,<a href="#cit/section_2.74">

177874</a>

1779-<a href="#cit/section_2.79">

178079</a>

1781] Only a minority of SPS appear to be familial, but no common germline variant has been identified in these families to date. A comparison of the hyperplastic polyps (HPs) found in SPS patients and controls revealed that SPS polyps are histologically distinct and are similar to previously described serrated adenomas, polyps with features of HPs and adenomatous polyps (APs).[<a href="#cit/section_2.80">

178280</a>

1783] This led to observations that these sessile serrated adenomas (SSA) tend to occur in the right colon, where they are frequently large and sessile, and exhibit increased proliferation, dilation and serration of the crypt bases, decreased endocrine cells, and lack of dysplasia.[<a href="#cit/section_2.81">

178481</a>

1785]</p>

1786<p id="_1339" tabindex="-1">

1787Further histological characterization of serrated polyps led to subtypes: traditional serrated adenomas (TSA), mixed serrated polyps (MP), and more recently, sessile serrated adenoma/sessile serrated polyp (SSA/SSP).[<a href="#cit/section_2.82">

178882</a>

1789] TSAs are characterized by a protuberant morphology, ectopic crypt formation (suggestive of deficient bone morphogenetic protein signaling), and villiform and dysplastic histopathology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.81">

179081</a>

1791,<a href="#cit/section_2.83">

179283</a>

1793] TSAs are not simply SSAs with dysplasia, and evidence that SSAs are precursors of TSAs is lacking. MPs have overlapping features of HPs, SSAs, and TSAs.</p>

1794<p id="_1340" tabindex="-1">

1795In colonoscopy screening studies, large serrated polyps were strongly and independently associated with the development of advanced colorectal neoplasms, while left-sided HPs were not. The term SSA has been a concern to clinicians as these characteristically lack nuclear atypia, the traditional hallmark of adenomas, but rather are termed adenomas due to other architectural features. The classification of SSA is supported by the knowledge that the molecular characteristics denote an increased cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.80">

179680</a>

1797,<a href="#cit/section_2.84">

179884</a>

1799,<a href="#cit/section_2.85">

180085</a>

1801]</p>

1802<p id="_1341" tabindex="-1">

1803While APs in Lynch syndrome patients can exhibit MSI, sporadic adenomas rarely do. However, serrated polyps with dysplasia can exhibit MSI with hypermethylation of the <em class="gene-name">

1804MLH1</em>

1805 promoter. Large (&gt;1 cm) serrated polyps carry greater cancer risk than do conventional hyperplastic polyps and, when developing into cancers, characteristically exhibit MSI.[<a href="#cit/section_2.83">

180683</a>

1807,<a href="#cit/section_2.86">

180886</a>

1809-<a href="#cit/section_2.88">

181088</a>

1811] In a review of resected serrated polyps with a malignant focus, all of the polyps originated in the right colon and were SSAs.[<a href="#cit/section_2.86">

181286</a>

1813] The malignant foci were MSI and demonstrated loss of MLH1 immunoreactivity, suggesting an association between SSAs and sporadic MSI colon cancers.</p>

1814<p id="_1342" tabindex="-1">

1815The MSI seen in sporadic CRCs is due to hypermethylation of the promoter of <em class="gene-name">

1816MLH1</em>

1817, which abrogates its expression. As promoter regions of other <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1818tumor suppressor genes</a>

1819 were &#8220;silenced&#8221; through hypermethylation, cancer genome studies of CRC ensued. These showed a consistent pattern of hypermethylation in the evaluated genes in approximately 50% of CRCs.[<a href="#cit/section_2.89">

182089</a>

1821] Studies of larger numbers of unselected CRC patients show that a minority of CRCs (20%&#8211;30%) demonstrate CIMP, defined as hypermethylation of two or more of the CpG islands in <em class="gene-name">

1822MINT1</em>

1823, <em class="gene-name">

1824MINT2</em>

1825, <em class="gene-name">

1826MINT31</em>

1827, <em class="gene-name">

1828CDKN2A</em>

1829 (<em class="gene-name">

1830p16</em>

1831), and <em class="gene-name">

1832MLH1</em>

1833.[<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

183490</a>

1835,<a href="#cit/section_2.91">

183691</a>

1837] The term <em>

1838CIMP</em>

1839 was coined to classify these cancers, which shared clinical features. Early attempts to differentiate CIMP-positive and CIMP-negative CRCs were unsuccessful.[<a href="#cit/section_2.92">

184092</a>

1841] However, subsequent studies using unbiased hierarchical cluster analysis of heavily methylated genes in CRCs and a population-based study design successfully identified unique clinical and molecular characteristics supporting a CIMP pathway.[<a href="#cit/section_2.89">

184289</a>

1843,<a href="#cit/section_2.93">

184493</a>

1845]</p>

1846<p id="_1428" tabindex="-1">

1847 CIMP-high CRCs were much more likely (82.1%; <em>

1848P</em>

1849 &lt; .0001) to express MSI than were microsatellite-stable CRCs (24.4%; <em>

1850P</em>

1851 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_2.89">

185289</a>

1853] In one study, microsatellite-stable, CIMP-high (&gt;2 CIMP markers mentioned <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1342">

1854above</a>

1855) colorectal tumors were significantly more associated with <em class="gene-name">

1856BRAF</em>

1857 V600E variants, <em class="gene-name">

1858KRAS2</em>

1859 variants, proximal site, higher American Joint Committee on Cancer stage, older patient age, poor differentiation, and mucinous histology than were CIMP-low (&lt;2 CIMP markers mentioned above) colorectal

1860tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.89">

186189</a>

1862] Microsatellite-unstable, CIMP-high colorectal tumors were significantly more associated with <em class="gene-name">

1863BRAF</em>

1864 V600E pathogenic variants, proximal site, older patient age, and absence of <em class="gene-name">

1865KRAS2</em>

1866 pathogenic variants than were microsatellite

1867unstable, CIMP-low tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.89">

186889</a>

1869] There was a significantly greater presence of <em class="gene-name">

1870BRAF</em>

1871 V600E pathogenic variants in CIMP-high colorectal tumors regardless of MSI.[<a href="#cit/section_2.89">

187289</a>

1873] Thus, unlike a previous study that questioned the biological significance of CIMP once unstable colorectal tumors were excluded,[<a href="#cit/section_2.92">

187492</a>

1875] this study demonstrated several clinicopathologic variables were indeed associated with CIMP in microsatellite-stable and microsatellite-unstable colorectal tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.89">

187689</a>

1877]</p>

1878<p id="_1343" tabindex="-1">

1879Studies of polyps revealed CIMP-positive polyps in SPS patients and most frequently in right-sided SSAs.[<a href="#cit/section_2.73">

188073</a>

1881,<a href="#cit/section_2.94">

188294</a>

1883-<a href="#cit/section_2.97">

188497</a>

1885] More recently, a hotspot <em class="gene-name">

1886BRAF</em>

1887 pathogenic variant (V600E) was found to be common in MSI colon cancers and serrated polyps.[<a href="#cit/section_2.98">

188898</a>

1889-<a href="#cit/section_2.100">

1890100</a>

1891] A <em class="gene-name">

1892BRAF</em>

1893 pathogenic variant is absent in CRCs from Lynch syndrome patients and is rare in sporadic adenomatous colorectal polyps, but it is present in the vast majority of serrated polyps, especially SSAs.[<a href="#cit/section_2.95">

189495</a>

1895,<a href="#cit/section_2.97">

189697</a>

1897,<a href="#cit/section_2.101">

1898101</a>

1899-<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

1900103</a>

1901] CIMP positivity is commonly found in microvesicular hyperplastic polyps (MVHP), suggesting progression of MVHP to SSA and then to colon cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.95">

190295</a>

1903]</p>

1904</section>

1905<section id="_1431">

1906<h4 id="_1431_toc">

1907Conclusion</h4>

1908<p id="_1344" tabindex="-1">

1909The characterization of CIMP CRCs and evidence that MSI occurs later in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence leads to modification of the previous colorectal tumorigenesis model, which was comprised of two pathways: MSI (MIN) and CIN. There is much overlap between the MSI and CIMP pathways. At the heart of the CIMP pathway are serrated polyps harboring <em class="gene-name">

1910BRAF</em>

1911 pathogenic variants. The CIN pathway is characterized by AP precursors of which the vast majority harbor <em class="gene-name">

1912APC</em>

1913 pathogenic variants that occur early in the pathway. </p>

1914</section>

1915</section>

2021[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2028Johns LE, Houlston RS: A systematic review and meta-analysis of familial colorectal cancer risk. 2029[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2030</li>

2031<li id="section_2.29">

2032Cottet V, Pariente A, Nalet B, et al.: Colonoscopic screening of first-degree relatives of patients with large adenomas: increased risk of colorectal tumors. Gastroenterology 133 (4): 1086-92, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17919484&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17919484&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2033[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2034</li>

2035<li id="section_2.30">

2036Winawer SJ, Zauber AG, Gerdes H, et al.: Risk of colorectal cancer in the families of patients with adenomatous polyps. National Polyp Study Workgroup. N Engl J Med 334 (2): 82-7, 1996.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8531963&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8531963&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2037[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2038</li>

2333

2334 <section id="_72">

2335

2336 <h2>

2337Colorectal Cancer Susceptibility Genes</h2>

2338

2339 <div id="_section_72" class="pdq-sections">

2340<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

2341<h6>

2342In This Section</h6>

2343<ul>

2344<li>

2345<a href="#_73_toc">

2346Major Genes</a>

2347</li>

2348<li>

2349<a href="#_2522_toc">

2350De Novo Pathogenic Variant Rate</a>

2351</li>

2352<li>

2353<a href="#_2574_toc">

2354Genetic Polymorphisms and CRC Risk</a>

2355</li>

2356</ul>

2357</nav>

2358<section id="_73">

2359<h3 id="_73_toc">

2360Major Genes</h3>

2361<p id="_74" tabindex="-1">

2362Major <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2363genes</a>

2364 are defined as those that are necessary and sufficient for disease

2365causation, with important <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2366pathogenic variants</a>

2367 (e.g., <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783965&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783965&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2368nonsense</a>

2369, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783964&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783964&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2370missense</a>

2371, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2372frameshift</a>

2373) of the gene

2374as causal mechanisms. Major genes are typically considered those that are involved in single-gene disorders, and the diseases caused by major genes are often relatively rare. Most pathogenic variants in major genes lead to a very high risk of disease, and environmental contributions are often difficult to recognize.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

23751</a>

2376] Historically, most major colon cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2377susceptibility genes</a>

2378 have been identified by <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=425374&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000425374&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2379linkage analysis</a>

2380 using high-risk families; thus,

2381these criteria were fulfilled by definition, as a consequence of the study

2382design.

2383</p>

2384<p id="_75" tabindex="-1">

2385The functions of the major colorectal (CRC) cancer genes have been reasonably well characterized over the past decade.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

23862</a>

2387] <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2388Tumor suppressor genes</a>

2389 constitute the most important class of genes responsible for hereditary cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339343&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339343&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2390syndromes</a>

2391 and represent the class of genes responsible for <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2392familial</a>

2393 adenomatous polyposis (FAP), Lynch syndrome, and juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS), among others. <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_686">

2394Table 2</a>

2395 summarizes the genes that confer a substantial risk of CRC, with their corresponding diseases.

2396</p>

2397<table id="_686" class="table-default expandable-container">

2398<caption>

2399Table 2. Genes Associated with a High Susceptibility of Colorectal Cancer</caption>

2400<colgroup>

2401<col width="25.00%">

2402<col width="25.00%">

2403<col width="25.00%">

2404<col width="25.00%">

2405</colgroup>

2406<THead>

2407<tr>

2408<th>

2409Gene</th>

2410<th>

2411Syndrome</th>

2412<th>

2413Hereditary Pattern</th>

2414<th>

2415Predominant Cancers</th>

2416</tr>

2417</THead>

2418<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2419<tr>

2420<td colspan="4">

2421FAP = familial adenomatous polyposis; JPS = juvenile polyposis syndrome; PJS = Peutz-Jeghers syndrome; PPAP = polymerase proofreading&#8211;associated polyposis.</td>

2422</tr>

2423</TFoot>

2424<tbody>

2425<tr>

2426<td>

2427<em class="gene-name">

2428APC</em>

2429</td>

2430<td>

2431<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3205">

2432FAP</a>

2433, AFAP </td>

2434<td>

2435Dominant</td>

2436<td>

2437Colorectal, small bowel, gastric, etc.</td>

2438</tr>

2439<tr>

2440<td>

2441<em class="gene-name">

2442TP53</em>

2443 (<em class="gene-name">

2444p53</em>

2445)</td>

2446<td>

2447Li-Fraumeni </td>

2448<td>

2449Dominant</td>

2450<td>

2451Multiple (including colorectal)</td>

2452</tr>

2453<tr>

2454<td>

2455 <em class="gene-name">

2456STK11</em>

2457 (<em class="gene-name">

2458LKB1</em>

2459)</td>

2460<td>

2461<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2606">

2462PJS</a>

2463</td>

2464<td>

2465Dominant</td>

2466<td>

2467Multiple (including colorectal, small bowel, pancreas)</td>

2468</tr>

2469<tr>

2470<td>

2472PTEN</em>

2476Cowden</a>

2477 </td>

2478<td>

2480<td>

2481Multiple (including colorectal)</td>

2482</tr>

2483<tr>

2484<td>
