2486BMPR1A</em>

2487, <em class="gene-name">

2488SMAD4</em>

2489 (<em class="gene-name">

2490MADH</em>

2491/<em class="gene-name">

2492DPC4</em>

2493)</td>

2494<td>

2496JPS</a>

2497 </td>

2498<td>

2499Dominant</td>

2500<td>

2501Gastric and colorectal</td>

2502</tr>

2503<tr>

2504<td>

2505<em class="gene-name">

2506MLH1</em>

2507, <em class="gene-name">

2508MSH2</em>

2509, <em class="gene-name">

2510MSH6</em>

2511, <em class="gene-name">

2512PMS2</em>

2513, <em class="gene-name">

2514EPCAM</em>

2518Lynch syndrome</a>

2519 </td>

2530MYH</em>

2546POLE</em>

2555</tbody>

2556</table>

2557</section>

2558<section id="_2522">

2559<h3 id="_2522_toc">

2560De Novo Pathogenic Variant Rate</h3>

2561<p id="_2523" tabindex="-1">

2562Until the 1990s, the diagnosis of genetically inherited polyposis syndromes was based on clinical manifestations and family history. Now that some of the genes involved in these syndromes have been identified, a few studies have attempted to estimate the spontaneous pathogenic variant rate (<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783882&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783882&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2563de novo pathogenic variant</a>

2564 rate) in these populations. Interestingly, FAP, JPS, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, Cowden syndrome, and Bannayan-Riley-Ruvalcaba syndrome are all thought to have high rates of spontaneous pathogenic variants, in the 25% to 30% range,[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

25653</a>

2566-<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

25675</a>

2568] while estimates of de novo pathogenic variants in the MMR genes associated with Lynch syndrome are thought to be low, in the 0.9% to 5% range.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

25696</a>

2570-<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

25718</a>

2572] These estimates of spontaneous pathogenic variant rates in Lynch syndrome seem to overlap with the estimates of nonpaternity rates in various populations (0.6% to 3.3%),[<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

25739</a>

2574-<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

257511</a>

2576] making the de novo pathogenic variant rate for Lynch syndrome seem quite low in contrast to the relatively high rates in the other polyposis syndromes.</p>

2577</section>

2578<section id="_2574">

2579<h3 id="_2574_toc">

2580Genetic Polymorphisms and CRC Risk</h3>

2581<p id="_2575" tabindex="-1">

2582It is widely acknowledged that the familial clustering of colon cancer also occurs outside of the setting of well-characterized colon cancer family syndromes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.12">

258312</a>

2584] Based on epidemiological studies, the risk of colon cancer in a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2585first-degree relative</a>

2586 (FDR) of an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2587affected</a>

2588 individual can increase an individual&#8217;s lifetime risk of colon cancer 2-fold to 4.3-fold.[<a href="#cit/section_3.13">

258913</a>

2590] The relative risk (RR) and absolute risk

2591of CRC for different family history categories is estimated in <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_326">

2592Table 1</a>

2593. In addition, the lifetime risk of colon cancer also increases in FDRs of individuals with colon adenomas.[<a href="#cit/section_3.14">

259414</a>

2595] The magnitude of risk depends on the age at diagnosis of the index case, the degree of relatedness of the index case to the at-risk case, and the number of affected relatives. It is currently believed that many of the moderate- and low-risk cases are influenced by alterations in single low-<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2596penetrance</a>

2597 genes or combinations of low-penetrance genes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.15">

259815</a>

2599] Given the public health impact of identifying the etiology of this increased risk, an intense search for the responsible genes is under way.</p>

2600<p id="_2576" tabindex="-1">

2601Each <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2602locus</a>

2603 would be expected to have a relatively small effect on CRC risk and would not produce the dramatic familial aggregation seen in Lynch syndrome or FAP. However, in combination with other common genetic loci and/or environmental factors, variants of this kind might significantly alter CRC risk. These types of genetic variations are often referred to as <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2604polymorphisms</a>

2605. Most loci that are polymorphic have no influence on disease risk or human traits (benign polymorphisms), while those that are associated with a difference in risk of disease or a human trait (however subtle) are sometimes termed disease-associated polymorphisms or functionally relevant polymorphisms. When such variation involves changes in single nucleotides of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45671&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045671&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2606DNA</a>

2607 they are referred to as <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=803525&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000803525&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2608single nucleotide variants</a>

2609 (SNVs).</p>

2610<p id="_3375" tabindex="-1">

2611Several <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=636779&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000636779&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2612genome-wide association studies</a>

2613 (GWAS) have been conducted with relatively large, unselected series of patients with CRC, who have been evaluated for patterns of polymorphisms in candidate and anonymous genes throughout the genome.[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

261416</a>

2615-<a href="#cit/section_3.19">

261619</a>

2617] The goal is to identify <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2618alleles</a>

2619 that, while not pathogenic variants, may confer an increase (or a potential decrease) in CRC risk. Identification of yet unknown aberrant CRC alleles would permit further stratification of at-risk individuals on a genetic basis. Such risk stratification would potentially enhance CRC <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46171&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046171&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2620screening</a>

2621. The use of genome-wide scans in thousands of CRC cases and controls has led to the discovery of multiple common low-risk CRC SNVs, which can be found in the <a href="https://www.ebi.ac.uk/gwas/" title="https://www.ebi.ac.uk/gwas/">

2622National Human Genome Research Institute GWAS catalog</a>

2623. Refer to the PDQ summary on <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/overview-pdq">

2624Cancer Genetics Overview</a>

2625 for a thorough discussion of GWAS. </p>

2626<section id="_2579">

2627<section id="_3324">

2628<h5 id="_3324_toc">

2629Polygenic risk scores for colorectal cancer</h5>

2630<p id="_3325" tabindex="-1">

2631There is increasing interest in using SNVs to expand <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2632germline</a>

2633 risk assessment from monogenic high-/moderate-penetrance forms of CRC predisposition to polygenic forms of CRC risk assessment that may have broader applicability to the general population. To that end, multiple studies have examined the utility of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=800513&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000800513&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2634polygenic risk scores</a>

2635 (PRSs) to personalize CRC risk assessment in individuals otherwise considered to be at average risk for CRC.</p>

2636<p id="_3326" tabindex="-1">

2637One study examined 36 different SNVs previously linked to CRC susceptibility by GWAS in 341 men with CRC and 329 controls from a population-based registry of Japanese individuals. Investigators ultimately identified six of these SNVs to be associated with CRC risk in this population and constructed a PRS, which had reasonable discriminatory capacity (area under the curve [AUC], 0.63) for assessing a 10-year absolute risk of CRC. The investigators found that the performance of the PRS was marginally superior to a previously validated nongenetic risk prediction score (AUC, 0.60) incorporating age, body mass index, and tobacco and alcohol use, and found that a combined model including both SNV data and these nongenetic factors had superior discriminatory capacity for assessing a 10-year absolute CRC risk (AUC, 0.66).[<a href="#cit/section_3.20">

263820</a>

2639] Likewise, another study examined the use of a PRS consisting of 48 SNVs previously linked to CRC risk by GWAS in 1,043 German individuals aged 50 to 79 years undergoing screening colonoscopy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.21">

264021</a>

2641] Investigators demonstrated that the PRS effectively discriminated between risk for advanced neoplasms (carcinoma or advanced adenomas) versus nonadvanced adenomas and normal colonoscopic findings. The study estimated that participants with the highest tertile of PRS have the same risk of advanced colorectal neoplasm as participants 17.5 years older from the lowest tertile of PRS, suggesting that such PRS data may help estimate individuals&#8217; risk sufficiently well to allow for personalized recommendations regarding age at initiation of colonoscopic screening in individuals previously considered at average risk for CRC. Interestingly, another case-control study of 2,363 patients with CRC and 2,198 controls demonstrated that a 53 SNV PRS and family history of CRC were both associated with increased CRC risk, but that these associations appeared to be independent of one another.[<a href="#cit/section_3.22">

264222</a>

2643] Investigators concluded that PRS may thus substantially augment family history&#8211;based CRC risk stratification, and that GWAS-identified SNVs associated with CRC risk may not be the factor underlying most familial CRC clustering.</p>

2644<p id="_3401" tabindex="-1">

2645Another study analyzed a 95-SNV PRS in 108,062 individuals from three large consortia. Subsequent validation in 72,573 individuals found that the PRS was significantly associated with both early-onset (age, &lt;50 y) and late-onset (age, &#8805;50 y) CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_3.23">

264623</a>

2647] Interestingly, the association was significantly stronger for early-onset CRC, particularly among individuals lacking a family history of CRC in an FDR (odds ratio of the highest- vs. lowest-quartile PRS, 4.26; 95% confidence interval [CI], 3.61&#8211;5.01 for early-onset CRC and 2.85; 95% CI, 2.70&#8211;3.00 for late-onset CRC). Such intriguing PRS data raise the possibility of utilizing personalized prediction strategies to identify individuals who might benefit from early colonoscopic screening, while providing potential insight as to the biologic underpinnings of the rising incidence of early-onset CRC.</p>

2648<p id="_3327" tabindex="-1">

2649Despite such promising data, however, it is important to emphasize that such PRSs are not currently used in routine clinical settings and are not currently considered to be clinically actionable. Formal implementation studies examining the use of such PRSs to guide CRC risk assessment and screening in routine clinical care are warranted, on the basis of these encouraging data.</p>

2650</section>

2651<section id="_2599">

2652<h5 id="_2599_toc">

2653<em class="gene-name">

2654APC</em>

2655 I1307K</h5>

2656<p id="_2600" tabindex="-1">

2657The <em class="gene-name">

2658APC</em>

2659 I1307K polymorphism deserves special mention, given that it is commonly identified in individuals of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460127&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460127&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2660Ashkenazi Jewish</a>

2661 ancestry undergoing <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2662multigene (panel) testing</a>

2663 [<a href="#cit/section_3.24">

266424</a>

2665,<a href="#cit/section_3.25">

266625</a>

2667] and is associated with an increased risk of CRC; however, it does not cause colonic polyposis. The I1307K polymorphism occurs almost exclusively in people of Ashkenazi Jewish descent and results in a twofold increased risk of colonic adenomas and adenocarcinomas compared with the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_3.26">

266826</a>

2669,<a href="#cit/section_3.27">

267027</a>

2671] The I1307K polymorphism results from a transition from T to A at nucleotide 3920 in the <em class="gene-name">

2672APC</em>

2673 gene and appears to create a region of hypermutability by virtue of the fact that this results in an A<sub>

26748</sub>

2675 microsatellite coding sequence.[<a href="#cit/section_3.26">

267626</a>

2677] Although clinical assays to assess for the <em class="gene-name">

2678APC</em>

2679 I1307K polymorphism are currently available, the associated CRC risk is not high enough to support their routine use. On the basis of currently available data, it is not yet known whether the I1307K <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2680carrier</a>

2681 status should guide decisions regarding the age to initiate screening, the frequency of screening, or the choice of screening strategy.</p>

2682</section>

2683</section>

2684</section>

2736</li>

2737<li id="section_3.13">

2738Butterworth AS, Higgins JP, Pharoah P: Relative and absolute risk of colorectal cancer for individuals with a family history: a meta-analysis. Eur J Cancer 42 (2): 216-27, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16338133&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16338133&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2739[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2740</li>

2741<li id="section_3.14">

2742Johns LE, Houlston RS: A systematic review and meta-analysis of familial colorectal cancer risk. Am J Gastroenterol 96 (10): 2992-3003, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11693338&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11693338&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2743[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2744</li>

2745<li id="section_3.15">

2746Wei C, Peng B, Han Y, et al.: Mutations of HNRNPA0 and WIF1 predispose members of a large family to multiple cancers. Fam Cancer 14 (2): 297-306, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25716654&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25716654&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2747[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2748</li>

2749<li id="section_3.16">

2750Houlston RS, Webb E, Broderick P, et al.: Meta-analysis of genome-wide association data identifies four new susceptibility loci for colorectal cancer. Nat Genet 40 (12): 1426-35, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19011631&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19011631&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2751[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2752</li>

2753<li id="section_3.17">

2754Houlston RS, Cheadle J, Dobbins SE, et al.: Meta-analysis of three genome-wide association studies identifies susceptibility loci for colorectal cancer at 1q41, 3q26.2, 12q13.13 and 20q13.33. Nat Genet 42 (11): 973-7, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20972440&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20972440&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2755[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2756</li>

2757<li id="section_3.18">

2758Whiffin N, Hosking FJ, Farrington SM, et al.: Identification of susceptibility loci for colorectal cancer in a genome-wide meta-analysis. Hum Mol Genet 23 (17): 4729-37, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24737748&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24737748&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2759[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2760</li>

2761<li id="section_3.19">

2762Peters U, Jiao S, Schumacher FR, et al.: Identification of Genetic Susceptibility Loci for Colorectal Tumors in a Genome-Wide Meta-analysis. Gastroenterology 144 (4): 799-807.e24, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23266556&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23266556&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2763[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

2764</li>

2765<li id="section_3.20">

2766Iwasaki M, Tanaka-Mizuno S, Kuchiba A, et al.: Inclusion of a Genetic Risk Score into a Validated Risk Prediction Model for Colorectal Cancer in Japanese Men Improves Performance. Cancer Prev Res (Phila) 10 (9): 535-541, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28729251&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28729251&amp;dopt=Abstract">

2768</li>

2772</li>

2796</li>

2797</ol>

2798</div>

2799

2800 </section>

2963</nav>

2964<section id="_351">

2965<h3 id="_351_toc">

2966Introduction</h3>

2967<p id="_352" tabindex="-1">

2968Originally described in the 1800s and 1900s by their clinical findings, the colon cancer susceptibility syndrome names often reflected the physician or patient and family associated with the syndrome (e.g., Gardner syndrome, Turcot syndrome, Muir-Torre syndrome, <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2986">

2969Lynch syndrome</a>

2970, <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2920">

2971Peutz-Jeghers syndrome [PJS]</a>

2972, Bannayan-Riley-Ruvalcaba syndrome, and <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2559">

2973Cowden syndrome</a>

2974). These syndromes were associated with an increased lifetime risk of colorectal adenocarcinoma. They were mostly thought to have <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2975autosomal dominant</a>

2976 inheritance patterns. Adenomatous colonic polyps were characteristic of the first four, while hamartomas were found to be characteristic in the last three.</p>

2977<p id="_1098" tabindex="-1">

2978With the development of the Human Genome Project and the identification in 1990 of the adenomatous polyposis coli (<em class="gene-name">

2979APC</em>

2980) <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2981gene</a>

2982 on <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2983chromosome</a>

2984 5q, overlap and differences between these <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2985familial</a>

2986 syndromes became apparent. Gardner syndrome and familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) were shown to be synonymous, both caused by <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2987pathogenic variants</a>

2988 in the <em class="gene-name">

2989APC</em>

2990 gene. Attenuated FAP (AFAP) was recognized as a syndrome with less adenomas and extraintestinal manifestations due to an <em class="gene-name">

2991APC</em>

2992 pathogenic variant at the 3&#8217; or 5&#8217; ends of the gene. <em class="gene-name">

2993MUTYH</em>

2994-associated polyposis (MAP) was recognized as a separate adenomatous polyp syndrome with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339339&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339339&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2995autosomal recessive inheritance</a>

2996. Once the pathogenic variants were identified, the absolute risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) could be better assessed for <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2997carriers</a>

2998 of pathogenic variants (refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_417">

2999Table 3</a>

3000).</p>

3001<table id="_417" class="table-default expandable-container">

3002<caption>

3003Table 3. Absolute Risks of Colorectal Cancer (CRC) for Carriers of Pathogenic Variants in Hereditary CRC Syndromes</caption>

3004<colgroup>

3005<col width="50.00%">

3006<col width="50.00%">

3007</colgroup>

3008<THead>

3009<tr>

3010<th>

3011Syndrome</th>

3012<th>

3013Absolute Risk of CRC in Carriers of a Pathogenic Variant</th>

3014</tr>

3015</THead>

3016<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

3017<tr>

3018<td colspan="2">

3019FAP = familial adenomatous polyposis; JPS = juvenile polyposis syndrome; PJS = Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.</td>

3020</tr>

3021<tr>

3022<td colspan="2">

3023<span class="sup">

3024a</span>

3025Cancer risk estimates quoted here predate the widespread use of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=496506&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000496506&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3026surveillance</a>

3027 and prophylactic surgery.</td>

3028</tr>

3029<tr>

3030<td colspan="2">

3031

3032</td>

3033</tr>

3034</TFoot>

3035<tbody>

3036<tr>

3037<td>

3038<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3205">

3039FAP</a>

3040&#160;<span class="sup">

3041a</span>

3042</td>

3043<td>

304490% by age 45 y [<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

30451</a>

3046]</td>

3047</tr>

3048<tr>

3049<td>

3050<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_118">

3051Attenuated FAP</a>

3052</td>

3053<td>

305469% by age 80 y [<a href="#cit/section_4.2">

30552</a>

3056]

3057</td>

3058</tr>

3059<tr>

3060<td valign="Top">

3061<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2986">

3062Lynch syndrome</a>

3063 </td>

3064<td>

306510% to 56% by age 75 y, depending on the gene involved [<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

30663</a>

3067-<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

30686</a>

3069]</td>

3070</tr>

3071<tr>

3072<td valign="Top">

3073<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_433">

3074MUTYH-associated polyposis</a>

3075</td>

3076<td>

307735% to 53% [<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

30787</a>

3079]</td>

3080</tr>

3081<tr>

3082<td>

3083<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2920">

3084PJS</a>

3085 </td>

3086<td>

308739% by age 70 y [<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

30888</a>

3089]</td>

3090</tr>

3091<tr>

3092<td>

3093<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_647">

3094JPS</a>

3095 </td>

3096<td>

309717% to 68% by age 60 y [<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

30989</a>

3099,<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

310010</a>

3101]</td>

3102</tr>

3103</tbody>

3104</table>

3105<p id="_1122" tabindex="-1">

3106With these discoveries genetic testing and risk management became possible. Genetic testing refers to searching for variants in known cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3107susceptibility genes</a>

3108 using a variety of techniques. Comprehensive genetic testing includes sequencing the entire coding region of a gene, the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=660737&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000660737&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3109intron</a>

3110-<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460146&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460146&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3111exon</a>

3112 boundaries (splice sites), and assessment of rearrangements, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460141&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460141&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3113deletions</a>

3114, or other changes in copy number (with techniques such as <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=687002&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000687002&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3115multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification</a>

3116 [MLPA] or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460219&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460219&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3117Southern blot</a>

3118). Despite extensive accumulated experience that helps distinguish pathogenic variants from benign variants and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3119polymorphisms</a>

3120, genetic testing sometimes identifies <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=556495&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000556495&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3121variants of uncertain significance</a>

3122 (VUS) that cannot be used for predictive purposes.</p>

3123</section>

3124<section id="_3205">

3125<h3 id="_3205_toc">

3126Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP)</h3>

3127<section id="_3206">

3128<h4 id="_3206_toc">

3129Introduction</h4>

3130<p id="_3207" tabindex="-1">

3131By 1900, several reports had demonstrated that patients with a large number of polyps (later subclassified as adenomas) were at very high risk of CRC and that the pattern of transmission in families was autosomal dominant. In the 20th century, the adenoma-to-carcinoma progression was confirmed, and FAP was recognized as the prototypical model for this progression.[<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

313211</a>

3133]

3134 Classic FAP is characterized by numerous (hundreds to thousands) adenomatous polyps in the

3135colon and rectum developing after the first decade of life (refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3328">

3136Figure 3</a>

3137).</p>

3138<figure id="figure_3328" class="image-center-medium">

3139<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/772344.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

3140Enlarge</a>

3141<img id="_3328" alt="Many polyps protrude from the inner lining of the colon." title="Many polyps protrude from the inner lining of the colon." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/772344-750.jpg">

3142<figcaption class="caption-container">

3143Figure 3. Familial adenomatous polyposis is characterized by multiple (&gt;100) adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum developing after the first decade of life.</figcaption>

3144</figure>

3145<p id="_3251" tabindex="-1">

3146There is also a subset of classic FAP that has an attenuated <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3147phenotype</a>

3148. AFAP is a heterogeneous clinical entity characterized by fewer adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum than in classic FAP. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_118">

3149Attenuated Familial Adenomatous Polyposis [AFAP]</a>

3150 section of this summary for more information.)</p>

3151<p id="_3208" tabindex="-1">

3152FAP is one of the most clearly defined and well understood of the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339343&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339343&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3153inherited</a>

3154

3155colon cancer syndromes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

31561</a>

3157,<a href="#cit/section_4.12">

315812</a>

3159,<a href="#cit/section_4.13">

316013</a>

3161] It is an autosomal dominant condition, and the reported incidence varies from 1 in 7,000 to 1 in 22,000 live births.[<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

316214</a>

3163] The presence of ethnic differences in the prevalence of FAP has been suggested [<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

316414</a>

3165] but a large study did not find significant differences in ethnic variation in more than 6,169 individuals with a personal and/or family history of CRC and polyps who were referred for genetic testing at a large reference laboratory.[<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

316615</a>

3167] Most cases of FAP result from <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3168pathogenic variants</a>

3169 in the <em class="gene-name">

3170APC</em>

3171 gene on chromosome 5q21.

3172(Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3253">

3173Genetics of FAP</a>

3174 section of this summary for more information about the <em class="gene-name">

3175APC</em>

3176 gene and genetic testing.)</p>

3177<p id="_3321" tabindex="-1">

3178In addition to a high risk of colon adenomas in FAP patients, various extracolonic manifestations have also been described, including upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract adenomas and adenocarcinomas; fundic gland stomach polyps; nonepithelial benign tumors (osteomas, epidermal cysts, dental abnormalities); desmoid tumors; congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE); and malignant tumors (thyroid and brain tumors, hepatoblastoma). Refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_723">

3179Table 4</a>

3180 for the risks of these extracolonic manifestations in FAP.</p>

3181<table id="_723" class="table-default expandable-container">

3182<caption>

3183Table 4. Extracolonic Tumor Risks in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis</caption>

3184<colgroup>

3185<col width="33.33%">

3186<col width="33.33%">

3187<col width="33.33%">

3188</colgroup>

3189<THead>

3190<tr>

3191<th>

3192Malignancy</th>

3193<th>

3194Relative Risk</th>

3195<th>

3196Absolute Lifetime Risk (%)</th>

3197</tr>

3198</THead>

3199<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

3200<tr>

3201<td colspan="3">

3202Adapted from Giardiello et al.,[<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

320316</a>

3204] Jagelman et al.,[<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

320517</a>

3206] Sturt et al.,[<a href="#cit/section_4.18">

320718</a>

3208] Lynch et al.,[<a href="#cit/section_4.19">

320919</a>

3210] B&#252;low et al.,[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

321120</a>

3212] Burt et al.,[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

321321</a>

3214] and Galiatsatos et al.[<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

321522</a>

3216]</td>

3217</tr>

3218<tr>

3219<td colspan="3">

3220<span class="sup">

3221a</span>

3222The Leeds Castle Polyposis Group.</td>

3223</tr>

3224</TFoot>

3225<tbody>

3226<tr>

3227<td>

3228Desmoid tumor</td>

3229<td>

3230852.0</td>

3231<td>

323215.0</td>

3233</tr>

3234<tr>

3235<td>

3236Duodenal tumors and cancer</td>

3237<td>

3238330.8</td>

3239<td>

32405.0&#8211;12.0</td>

3241</tr>

3242<tr>

3243<td>

3244Thyroid cancer</td>

3245<td>

32467.6</td>

3247<td>

32482.0</td>

3249</tr>

3250<tr>

3251<td>

3252Brain cancer</td>

3253<td>

32547.0</td>

3255<td>

32562.0</td>

3257</tr>

3258<tr>

3259<td>

3260Ampullary cancer</td>

3261<td>

3262123.7</td>

3263<td>

32641.7</td>

3265</tr>

3266<tr>

3267<td>

3268Pancreatic cancer</td>

3269<td>

32704.5</td>

3271<td>

32721.7</td>

3273</tr>

3274<tr>

3275<td>

3276Hepatoblastoma</td>

3277<td>

3278847.0</td>

3279<td>

32801.6</td>

3281</tr>

3282<tr>

3283<td>

3284Gastric cancer</td>

3285<td>

3286Not defined</td>

3287<td>

32880.6<span class="sup">

3289a</span>

3290</td>

3291</tr>

3292</tbody>

3293</table>

3294<p id="_93" tabindex="-1">

3295FAP has also been known as familial polyposis coli or adenomatous polyposis coli (APC).

3296Gardner syndrome was previously the diagnosis for FAP

3297patients who manifested with colorectal polyposis, osteomas, and soft tissue tumors.

3298However, Gardner syndrome has been shown genetically to be a variant of FAP, and thus the term Gardner syndrome is essentially obsolete in clinical practice.[<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

329923</a>

3300]</p>

3301</section>

3302<section id="_3211">

3303<h4 id="_3211_toc">

3304Clinical phenotype</h4>

3305<section id="_3252">

3306<h5 id="_3252_toc">

3307Colon adenomas and CRC</h5>

3308<p id="_94" tabindex="-1">

3309Individuals who inherit a pathogenic variant in the <em class="gene-name">

3310APC</em>

3311 gene have a very high likelihood of

3312developing colonic adenomas; the risk has been estimated to be more than 90%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

33131</a>

3314,<a href="#cit/section_4.12">

331512</a>

3316,<a href="#cit/section_4.13">

331713</a>

3318]

3319The age at onset of adenomas in the colon is variable, and the median age for the appearance of colorectal adenomas is 16 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.24">

332024</a>

3321] By age 10 years, only 15% of

3322carriers of the <em class="gene-name">

3323APC</em>

3324 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3325germline variant</a>

3326 manifest adenomas; by age 20 years, the probability rises to 75%;

3327and by age 30 years, 90% will have presented with FAP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

33281</a>

3329,<a href="#cit/section_4.12">

333012</a>

3331,<a href="#cit/section_4.13">

333213</a>

3333,<a href="#cit/section_4.24">

333424</a>

3335,<a href="#cit/section_4.25">

333625</a>

3337] The exception is AFAP, in which <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3338affected</a>

3339 individuals typically have fewer colon polyps, which are predominantly in the right colon, and later onset of CRC. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_118">

3340Attenuated Familial Adenomatous Polyposis [AFAP]</a>

3341 section of this summary for more information.) Without any

3342intervention, most individuals with FAP will develop CRC by the

3343fourth decade of life.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

33441</a>

3345,<a href="#cit/section_4.12">

334612</a>

3347,<a href="#cit/section_4.13">

334813</a>

3349] Thus, surveillance and intervention for carriers of an <em class="gene-name">

3350APC</em>

3351 pathogenic variant and at-risk

3352individuals have conventionally consisted of annual colonoscopy beginning around

3353puberty for early detection of colonic polyps and to help plan when to perform colectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.26">

335426</a>

3355,<a href="#cit/section_4.27">

335627</a>

3357]

3358(Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_260">

3359Interventions for FAP</a>

3360 section of this summary for more information.)</p>

3361</section>

3362<section id="_251">

3363<h5 id="_251_toc">

3364Extracolonic manifestations</h5>

3365<section id="_3305">

3366<h6 id="_3305_toc">

3367Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE)</h6>

3368<p id="_3306" tabindex="-1">

3369CHRPE are flat, darkly pigmented lesions in the retina that are present in approximately 75% of patients with FAP [<a href="#cit/section_4.28">

337028</a>

3371,<a href="#cit/section_4.29">

337229</a>

3373] compared with a general population frequency of 1.2%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.30">

337430</a>

3375] The lesions are often present at birth or in early childhood and are frequently multiple or bilateral in FAP patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.31">

337631</a>

3377] A study of 17 individuals diagnosed with FAP and 13 at-risk family members reported a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=322883&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000322883&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3378sensitivity</a>

3379 of the presence of a CHRPE lesion in association with colonic polyps in FAP of 76%, a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=322884&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000322884&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3380specificity</a>

3381 of 92%, a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460206&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460206&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3382positive predictive value</a>

3383 of 93%, and a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460198&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460198&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3384negative predictive value</a>

3385 of 75%; thus, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46171&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046171&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3386screening</a>

3387 at-risk individuals for CHRPE can be a reasonable method of detecting FAP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.28">

338828</a>

3389]</p>

3390</section>

3391<section id="_602">

3392<h6 id="_602_toc">

3393Desmoid tumors</h6>

3394<p id="_603" tabindex="-1">

3395Desmoid tumors are proliferative, locally invasive, nonmetastasizing,

3396fibromatous tumors in a collagen matrix. Although they do not metastasize,

3397they can grow very aggressively and be life threatening.[<a href="#cit/section_4.32">

339832</a>

3399] Desmoids may

3400occur <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3401sporadically</a>

3402, as part of classical FAP, or in a hereditary manner without the colon findings of

3403FAP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.19">

340419</a>

3405,<a href="#cit/section_4.33">

340633</a>

3407] Desmoids have been associated with hereditary <em class="gene-name">

3408APC</em>

3409 pathogenic variants

3410even when not associated with typical adenomatous polyposis of the colon.[<a href="#cit/section_4.33">

341133</a>

3412,<a href="#cit/section_4.34">

341334</a>

3414]

3415</p>

3416<p id="_604" tabindex="-1">

3417Most studies have found that 10% of FAP patients develop desmoids, with

3418reported ranges of 8% to 38%. The incidence varies with the means of

3419ascertainment and the location of the pathogenic variant in the <em class="gene-name">

3420APC</em>

3421 gene.[<a href="#cit/section_4.33">

342233</a>

3423,<a href="#cit/section_4.35">

342435</a>

3425,<a href="#cit/section_4.36">

342636</a>

3427] <em class="gene-name">

3428APC</em>

3429 pathogenic variants occurring between <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460135&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460135&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3430codons</a>

3431 1445 and 1578 have been associated with an increased incidence of desmoid tumors in FAP patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.34">

343234</a>

3433,<a href="#cit/section_4.37">

343437</a>

3435-<a href="#cit/section_4.39">

343639</a>

3437] Desmoid tumors with a late onset and a milder intestinal polyposis phenotype (hereditary desmoid disease) have been described in patients with pathogenic variants at codon 1924.[<a href="#cit/section_4.33">

343833</a>

3439]</p>

3440<p id="_1070" tabindex="-1">

3441A desmoid risk factor scale has been described in an attempt to identify patients who are likely to develop desmoid tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.40">

344240</a>

3443] The desmoid risk factor scale was based on gender, presence or absence of extracolonic manifestations, family history of desmoids, and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=660739&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000660739&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3444genotype</a>

3445, if available. By utilizing this scale, it was possible to stratify FAP patients into low-, medium-, and high-risk groups for developing desmoid tumors. The authors concluded that the desmoid risk factor scale could be used for surgical planning. Validation of the risk factors comprising this scale was supported by a large, multiregistry, retrospective study from Europe.[<a href="#cit/section_4.41">

344641</a>

3447]</p>

3448<p id="_605" tabindex="-1">

3449The natural history of desmoids is variable. Some authors have proposed a model for desmoid tumor formation whereby abnormal fibroblast function leads to mesenteric, plaque-like desmoid precursor lesions, which in some cases occur before surgery and progress to mesenteric fibromatosis after surgical trauma, ultimately giving rise to desmoid tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.42">

345042</a>

3451] It is estimated that 10% of desmoids resolve,

345250% remain stable for prolonged periods, 30% fluctuate, and 10% grow

3453rapidly.[<a href="#cit/section_4.43">

345443</a>

3455] Desmoids often occur after surgical or physiological trauma, and

3456both endocrine and genetic factors have been implicated. Approximately 80% of intra-abdominal desmoids in FAP occur after surgical trauma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.44">

345744</a>

3458,<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

345945</a>

3460] </p>

3461<p id="_687" tabindex="-1">

3462The desmoids in FAP are often intra-abdominal, may present early, and can lead to intestinal obstruction or infarction and/or obstruction of the ureters.[<a href="#cit/section_4.36">

346336</a>

3464] In some series, desmoids are the second most common cause of death after CRC in FAP patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.46">

346546</a>

3466,<a href="#cit/section_4.47">

346747</a>

3468] A staging system has been proposed to facilitate the stratification of intra-abdominal desmoids by disease severity.[<a href="#cit/section_4.48">

346948</a>

3470] The proposed staging system for intra-abdominal desmoids is as follows: stage I for asymptomatic nongrowing desmoids; stage II for symptomatic nongrowing desmoids of 10 cm or less in maximum diameter; stage III for symptomatic desmoids of 11 cm to 20 cm or for asymptomatic slow-growing desmoids; and stage IV for desmoids larger than 20 cm, or rapidly growing, or with life-threatening complications.[<a href="#cit/section_4.48">

347148</a>

3472]</p>

3473<p id="_606" tabindex="-1">

3474These data suggest that genetic testing could be of value in the

3475medical management of patients with FAP and/or multiple desmoid tumors. Those

3476with <em class="gene-name">

3477APC</em>

3478 genotypes predisposing to desmoid formation (e.g., at the

34793&#8217; end or codon 1445 of the <em class="gene-name">

3480APC</em>

3481 gene) appear to be at high risk of developing desmoids

3482after any surgery, including risk-reducing colectomy and

3483surgical surveillance procedures such as laparoscopy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.35">

348435</a>

3485,<a href="#cit/section_4.43">

348643</a>

3487,<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

348849</a>

3489] </p>

3490</section>

3491<section id="_689">

3492<h6 id="_689_toc">

3493Stomach tumors</h6>

3494<p id="_690" tabindex="-1">

3495The most common FAP-related gastric polyps are fundic gland polyps (FGPs). FGPs are often diffuse and not amenable to endoscopic removal. The incidence of FGPs has been estimated to be as high as 60% in patients with FAP, compared with 0.8% to 1.9% in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

349620</a>

3497,<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

349822</a>

3499,<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

350050</a>

3501-<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

350254</a>

3503] These polyps consist of distorted fundic glands containing microcysts lined with fundic-type epithelial cells or foveolar mucous cells.[<a href="#cit/section_4.55">

350455</a>

3505,<a href="#cit/section_4.56">

350656</a>

3507] </p>

3508<p id="_845" tabindex="-1">

3509The hyperplastic surface epithelium is, by definition, nonneoplastic. Accordingly, FGPs have not been considered precancerous. However, case reports of stomach cancer appearing to arise from FGPs have led to a reexamination of this issue.[<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

351022</a>

3511,<a href="#cit/section_4.57">

351257</a>

3513] In one FAP series, focal dysplasia was evident in the surface epithelium of FGPs in 25% of patients versus 1% of sporadic FGPs.[<a href="#cit/section_4.56">

351456</a>

3515] In a prospective study of patients with FAP undergoing surveillance with esophagogastroduodenoscopy, FGPs were detected in 88% of the patients. Low-grade dysplasia was detected in 38% of these patients, whereas high-grade dysplasia was detected in 3% of these patients. The study's authors recommended that, if a polyp with high-grade dysplasia is identified, polypectomy be considered with repeat endoscopic surveillance in 3 to 6 months.[<a href="#cit/section_4.58">

351658</a>

3517]</p>

3518<p id="_783" tabindex="-1">

3519 Complicating the issue of differential diagnosis, FGPs have been increasingly recognized in non-FAP patients consuming proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).[<a href="#cit/section_4.56">

352056</a>

3521,<a href="#cit/section_4.59">

352259</a>

3523] FGPs in this setting commonly show a PPI effect consisting of congestion of secretory granules in parietal cells, leading to irregular bulging of individual cells into the lumen of glands. To the trained eye, the presence of dysplasia and the concomitant absence of a characteristic PPI effect can be considered highly suggestive of the presence of underlying FAP. The number of FGPs tends to be greater in FAP than that seen in patients consuming PPIs, although there is some overlap.</p>

3524<p id="_691" tabindex="-1">

3525Gastric adenomas also occur in patients with FAP. The incidence of gastric adenomas in Western patients is reported to be between 2% and 12%, whereas in Japan, incidence is reported to be between 39% and 50%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.60">

352660</a>

3527-<a href="#cit/section_4.63">

352863</a>

3529] These adenomas can progress to carcinoma. Patients with FAP in Korea and Japan have a threefold to fourfold increased risk of gastric cancer when compared with individuals in the general population in these countries. This finding was not observed in Western populations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.64">

353064</a>

3531-<a href="#cit/section_4.68">

353268</a>

3533] The increased prevalence of gastric adenomas in Asian patients with FAP may be due to the high prevalence of <em>

3534Helicobacter pylori</em>

3535 infections in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.61">

353661</a>

3537]</p>

3538<p id="_3322" tabindex="-1">

3539More recently, a rise in incidence of gastric adenocarcinoma was observed in a Western FAP database.[<a href="#cit/section_4.69">

354069</a>

3541] Alterations in the promoter (1B) of <em class="gene-name">

3542APC</em>

3543 were discovered in families with gastric adenocarcinoma and proximal polyposis of the stomach (GAPPS), who express numerous, predominantly fundic gland, gastric polyps restricted to the body and fundus with regions of dysplasia or gastric adenocarcinoma, and no evidence of colorectal or duodenal polyposis. These variants segregated with the gastric phenotype in multiple GAPPS families. Although <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3544penetrance</a>

3545 of the gastric polyposis phenotype is high, the phenotype can vary ranging from asymptomatic adults to teenagers presenting with massive symptomatic gastric polyposis, as well as <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460224&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460224&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3546unaffected</a>

3547 carriers who had clean endoscopies at ages ranging from 42 to 77 years. However, the penetrance for gastric cancer is less clear. Promoter 1B <em class="gene-name">

3548APC</em>

3549 alterations rarely occur in FAP families with gastric fundic gland polyps and colonic polyposis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.70">

355070</a>

3551]</p>

3552</section>

3553<section id="_613">

3554<h6 id="_613_toc">

3555Duodenum/small bowel tumors</h6>

3556<p id="_614" tabindex="-1">

3557Whereas the incidence of duodenal adenomas is only 0.4% in unselected patients undergoing upper GI endoscopy,[<a href="#cit/section_4.71">

355871</a>

3559] duodenal adenomas are found in 80% to 100% of FAP patients. Most are located in the first and second portions of the duodenum, especially in the periampullary region.[<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

356050</a>

3561,<a href="#cit/section_4.51">

356251</a>

3563,<a href="#cit/section_4.72">

356472</a>

3565] There is a 4% to 12% lifetime incidence of duodenal adenocarcinoma in FAP patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

356617</a>

3567,<a href="#cit/section_4.66">

356866</a>

3569,<a href="#cit/section_4.73">

357073</a>

3571,<a href="#cit/section_4.74">

357274</a>

3573] In a prospective multicenter surveillance study of duodenal adenomas in 368 participants from northern Europe with FAP, 65% had adenomas at baseline evaluation (mean age, 38 y), with cumulative prevalence reaching 90% by age 70 years. In contrast to earlier beliefs regarding an indolent clinical course, the adenomas increased in size and degree of dysplasia during the 8 years of average surveillance, although only 4.5% developed cancer while under prospective surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

357420</a>

3575] This is a large study; however, it is limited by the use of forward-viewing rather than side-viewing endoscopy and the large number of investigators involved in the study. Intestinal polyps can also be assessed in FAP patients using capsule endoscopy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.75">

357675</a>

3577-<a href="#cit/section_4.77">

357877</a>

3579] One study of computed tomography (CT) duodenography found that larger adenoma size could be accurately measured but smaller, flatter adenomas could not be accurately counted.[<a href="#cit/section_4.78">

358078</a>

3581]</p>

3582<p id="_615" tabindex="-1">

3583A retrospective review of FAP patients suggested that the adenoma-carcinoma sequence occurred in a temporal fashion for periampullary adenocarcinomas with a diagnosis of adenoma at a mean age of 39 years, high-grade dysplasia at a mean age of 47 years, and adenocarcinoma at a mean age of 54 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.79">

358479</a>

3585] A decision analysis of 601 FAP patients suggested that the benefit of periodic surveillance starting at age 30 years led to an increased life expectancy of 7 months.[<a href="#cit/section_4.73">

358673</a>

3587] Although polyps in the duodenum can be difficult to treat, small series suggest that they can be managed successfully with endoscopy but with potential morbidity&#8212;primarily from pancreatitis, bleeding, and duodenal perforation.[<a href="#cit/section_4.80">

358880</a>

3589,<a href="#cit/section_4.81">

359081</a>

3591]

3592 </p>

3593<p id="_616" tabindex="-1">

3594FAP patients with particularly severe duodenal polyposis, sometimes called <em>

3595dense polyposis</em>

3596, or with histologically advanced duodenal adenomas appear to be at the highest risk of developing duodenal adenocarcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

359720</a>

3598,<a href="#cit/section_4.74">

359974</a>

3600,<a href="#cit/section_4.82">

360182</a>

3602,<a href="#cit/section_4.83">

360383</a>

3604] Because the risk of duodenal adenocarcinoma is correlated with the number and size of polyps and the severity of dysplasia of the polyps, a stratification system that incorporates these features was developed to attempt to identify those individuals with FAP at the highest risk of developing duodenal adenocarcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.83">

360583</a>

3606] According to this system, known as the Spigelman classification (refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1120">

3607Table 5</a>

3608), 36% of patients with the most advanced stage will develop carcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.74">

360974</a>

3610]</p>

3611<p id="_3402" tabindex="-1">

3612The predictive utility of the Spigelman classification has been called into question. The point system for dysplasia classifies dysplasia as mild, moderate, or severe, yet pathologists do not customarily attempt to distinguish moderate dysplasia from low-grade. There are no studies validating interobserver concordance in classifying a villous component or interpretation of the degree of dysplasia. A study from the Cleveland Clinic comparing Spigelman classification and its components in patients with FAP with and without cancer found neither adenoma count nor villous component to be predictive of cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_4.84">

361384</a>

3614] While patients with advanced (Spigelman IV) classification were more likely to develop cancer, nearly half of those with cancer did not meet Spigelman IV criteria.</p>

3615<table id="_1120" class="table-default expandable-container">

3616<caption>

3617Table 5. Spigelman Classification</caption>

3618<colgroup>

3619<col width="20.00%">

3620<col width="20.00%">

3621<col width="20.00%">

3622<col width="20.00%">

3623<col width="20.00%">

3624</colgroup>

3625<THead>

3626<tr>

3627<th>

3628Points</th>

3629<th>

3630Polyp Number</th>

3631<th>

3632Polyp Size (mm)</th>

3633<th>

3634Histology</th>

3635<th>

3636Dysplasia</th>

3637</tr>

3638</THead>

3639<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

3640<tr>

3641<td colspan="5">

3642Stage I, 1&#8211;4 points; Stage II, 5&#8211;6 points; Stage III, 7&#8211;8 points; Stage IV, 9&#8211;12 points.[<a href="#cit/section_4.83">

364383</a>

3644]</td>

3645</tr>

3646</TFoot>

3647<tbody>

3648<tr>

3649<td>

36501</td>

3651<td>

36521&#8211;4</td>

3653<td>

36541&#8211;4</td>

3655<td>

3656Tubular</td>

3657<td>

3658Mild</td>

3659</tr>

3660<tr>

3661<td>

36622</td>

3663<td>

36645&#8211;20</td>

3665<td>

36665&#8211;10</td>

3667<td>

3668Tubulovillous</td>

3669<td>

3670Moderate</td>

3671</tr>

3672<tr>

3673<td>

36743</td>

3675<td>

3676&gt;20</td>

3677<td>

3678&gt;10</td>

3679<td>

3680Villous</td>

3681<td>

3682Severe</td>

3683</tr>

3684</tbody>

3685</table>

3686</section>

3687<section id="_618">

3688<h6 id="_618_toc">

3689Other tumors</h6>

3690<p id="_712" tabindex="-1">

3691Other extracolonic tumors arising in FAP patients include papillary thyroid cancer, adrenal tumors, hepatoblastoma, and brain tumors.</p>

3692<p id="_620" tabindex="-1">

3693Papillary thyroid cancer (cribriform morular type) has been reported to affect 1% to 2% of patients with FAP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.85">

369485</a>

3695] However, a study [<a href="#cit/section_4.86">

369686</a>

3697] of papillary thyroid cancers in six women with FAP failed to demonstrate <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=486444&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000486444&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3698loss of heterozygosity </a>

3699(LOH) or pathogenic variants of the wild-type <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3700allele</a>

3701 in codons 545 and 1061 to 1678 of the six tumors. In addition, four of five of these patients had detectable <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781854&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781854&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3702somatic</a>

3703 <em class="gene-name">

3704RET/PTC</em>

3705 chimeric genes. This pathogenic variant is generally restricted to sporadic papillary thyroid carcinomas, suggesting the involvement of genetic factors other than <em class="gene-name">

3706APC</em>

3707 pathogenic variants. Further studies are needed to show whether other genetic factors such as the <em class="gene-name">

3708RET/PTC</em>

3709 chimeric gene are independently responsible for or cooperative with <em class="gene-name">

3710APC</em>

3711 variants in causing papillary thyroid cancers in FAP patients. </p>

3712<p id="_621" tabindex="-1">

3713Adrenal tumors have been reported in FAP patients, and one study demonstrated LOH at the <em class="gene-name">

3714APC</em>

3715 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3716locus</a>

3717 in an adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) in an FAP patient.[<a href="#cit/section_4.87">

371887</a>

3719]

3720In a study of 162 FAP patients who underwent abdominal CT for evaluation of intra-abdominal desmoid tumors, 15 patients (11 women) were found to have adrenal tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.88">

372188</a>

3722] Of these, two had symptoms attributable to cortisol hypersecretion. Three of these patients underwent subsequent surgery and were found to have ACC, bilateral nodular hyperplasia, or adrenocortical adenoma. The prevalence of an unexpected adrenal neoplasia in this cohort was 7.4%, which compares with a prevalence of 0.6% to 3.4% (<em>

3723P</em>

3724 &lt; .001) in non-FAP patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.88">

372588</a>

3726] No molecular genetic analyses were provided for the tumors resected in this series.

3727A subsequent study identified adrenal lesions in 26% (23 of 90) of patients with FAP, 18% (2 of 11) of patients with AFAP, and 24% (5 of 21) of patients with MAP. Most lesions in this series followed a benign and slowly progressive course; no cases of ACC were reported.[<a href="#cit/section_4.89">

372889</a>

3729] </p>

3730<p id="_622" tabindex="-1">

3731Hepatoblastoma is a rare, rapidly progressive, and usually fatal childhood malignancy that, if confined to the liver, can be cured by radical surgical resection. Multiple cases of hepatoblastoma have been described in children with an <em class="gene-name">

3732APC</em>

3733 pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_4.90">

373490</a>

3735-<a href="#cit/section_4.99">

373699</a>

3737] Some series have also demonstrated LOH of <em class="gene-name">

3738APC</em>

3739 in these tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.91">

374091</a>

3741,<a href="#cit/section_4.93">

374293</a>

3743,<a href="#cit/section_4.100">

3744100</a>

3745] No specific genotype-phenotype correlations have been identified in FAP patients with hepatoblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.101">

3746101</a>

3747] (Refer to the <a href="/types/liver/hp/child-liver-treatment-pdq#_567">

3748Hepatoblastoma</a>

3749 section in the PDQ summary on <a href="/types/liver/hp/child-liver-treatment-pdq">

3750Childhood Liver Cancer Treatment</a>

3751 for more information.)</p>

3752<p id="_623" tabindex="-1">

3753The constellation of CRC and brain tumors has been referred to as Turcot syndrome; however, Turcot syndrome is molecularly heterogeneous. Molecular studies have demonstrated that colon polyposis and medulloblastoma are associated with pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

3754APC</em>

3755 (thus representing FAP), while colon cancer and glioblastoma are associated with pathogenic variants in mismatch repair (MMR) genes (thus representing Lynch syndrome).[<a href="#cit/section_4.102">

3756102</a>

3757]</p>

3758<p id="_3307" tabindex="-1">

3759Medulloblastoma, a highly malignant embryonal central nervous system tumor, accounts for approximately 80% of the brain tumors found in FAP and primarily occurs in children with 70% diagnosed before age 16 years. High-grade astrocytomas and ependymomas have also been described in FAP patients. Although the relative lifetime risk of any brain tumor among members of an FAP family is increased 7-fold and that of medulloblastoma 90-fold, the absolute lifetime risk of any brain tumor is approximately 1% to 2%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.102">

3760102</a>

3761]</p>

3762</section>

3763</section>

3764</section>

3765<section id="_3253">

3766<h4 id="_3253_toc">

3767Genetics of FAP</h4>

3768<section id="_3210">

3769<h5 id="_3210_toc">

3770The adenomatous polyposis coli (<em class="gene-name">

3771APC</em>

3772) gene</h5>

3773<p id="_2552" tabindex="-1">

3774The <em class="gene-name">

3775APC</em>

3776 gene on chromosome 5q21 encodes a 2,843-amino acid protein that is

3777important in cell adhesion and signal transduction; the main function of the APC protein is to regulate intracellular concentrations of beta-catenin, a major mediator of the Wnt signal transduction pathway. <em class="gene-name">

3778APC</em>

3779 is a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3780tumor suppressor gene</a>

3781, and the loss of <em class="gene-name">

3782APC</em>

3783 is among the earliest events in the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=796062&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000796062&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3784chromosomal instability</a>

3785 colorectal tumor pathway. FAP and AFAP can be diagnosed genetically by

3786testing for germline pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

3787APC</em>

3788 gene in <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45671&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045671&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3789DNA</a>

3790 from peripheral blood

3791leukocytes. More than 300 different disease-associated pathogenic variants of the <em class="gene-name">

3792APC</em>

3793 gene have been

3794reported.[<a href="#cit/section_4.103">

3795103</a>

3796] Most of these changes are <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781204&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781204&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3797insertions</a>

3798, deletions, and

3799<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783965&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783965&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3800nonsense variants</a>

3801 that lead to <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3802frameshifts</a>

3803 and/or premature stop codons in the

3804resulting transcript of the gene. The most common <em class="gene-name">

3805APC</em>

3806 pathogenic variant (10% of FAP

3807patients) is a deletion of AAAAG in codon 1309; no other pathogenic variants appear to

3808predominate.

3809Variants that reduce rather than eliminate production of the APC protein may also lead to FAP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.104">

3810104</a>

3811]</p>

3812</section>

3813<section id="_3213">

3814<h5 id="_3213_toc">

3815Genotype-phenotype correlations</h5>

3816<p id="_3214" tabindex="-1">

3817Most <em class="gene-name">

3818APC</em>

3819 pathogenic variants that occur between codon 169 and codon 1249 result in the

3820classic FAP phenotype.[<a href="#cit/section_4.105">

3821105</a>

3822-<a href="#cit/section_4.107">

3823107</a>

3824] There has been much interest in correlating the

3825location of the pathogenic variant within the gene with the clinical phenotype:</p>

3826<div class="pdq-content-list">

3827<ul id="_3215">

3828<li>

3829Researchers have found that dense carpeting of colonic polyps, a feature of

3830classic FAP, is seen in most patients with <em class="gene-name">

3831APC</em>

3832 pathogenic variants, particularly

3833those variants that occur between codons 1250 and 1464. AFAP is associated with pathogenic variants that occur in or upstream of exon 4 and in the latter two-thirds of exon 15.[<a href="#cit/section_4.105">

3834105</a>

3835-<a href="#cit/section_4.108">

3836108</a>

3837] (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_118">

3838Attenuated Familial Adenomatous Polyposis [AFAP]</a>

3839 section of this summary for more information.)</li>

3840<li>

3841CHRPE are rarely associated with pathogenic variants that occur before exon 9.[<a href="#cit/section_4.39">

384239</a>

3843,<a href="#cit/section_4.107">

3844107</a>

3845] Individuals with exon 9 variants tend not to have duodenal adenomas.[<a href="#cit/section_4.70">

384670</a>

3847,<a href="#cit/section_4.109">

3848109</a>

3849]</li>

3850<li>

3851Families with GAPPS, who express numerous, predominantly fundic gland gastric polyps restricted to the body and fundus with regions of dysplasia or gastric adenocarcinoma, and no evidence of colorectal or duodenal polyposis, were found to possess variants in the promoter (1B) of <em class="gene-name">

3852APC</em>

3853.[<a href="#cit/section_4.70">

385470</a>

3855]</li>

3856<li>

3857<em class="gene-name">

3858APC</em>

3859 pathogenic variants occurring between codons 1445 and 1578 have been associated with an increased incidence of desmoid tumors in FAP patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.34">

386034</a>

3861,<a href="#cit/section_4.37">

386237</a>

3863-<a href="#cit/section_4.39">

386439</a>

3865]</li>

3866</ul>

3867</div>

3868<p id="_3313" tabindex="-1">

3869A low-penetrance <em class="gene-name">

3870APC</em>

3871 variant, I1307K, has been studied for its association with CRC. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2599">

3872APC I1307K</a>

3873 section in the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_72">

3874Colorectal Cancer Susceptibility Genes</a>

3875 section of this summary for more information.)</p>

3876</section>

3877<section id="_256">

3878<h5 id="_256_toc">

3879Genetic testing for FAP</h5>

3880<section id="_3295">

3881<h6 id="_3295_toc">

3882Probands</h6>

3883<p id="_3296" tabindex="-1">

3884Individuals who present with a classic FAP phenotype are candidates for <em class="gene-name">

3885APC</em>

3886 testing. However, in many <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460211&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460211&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3887probands</a>

3888 with a personal or family history of polyposis, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=763019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000763019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3889multigene panel testing</a>

3890 is an appropriate option to consider given the genetic heterogeneity of polyposis conditions and the phenotypic overlap among associated syndromes.</p>

3891<p id="_3297" tabindex="-1">

3892In particular, patients who develop fewer than 100 colorectal adenomatous polyps may pose a diagnostic challenge. The differential diagnosis includes AFAP, MAP, polymerase proofreading&#8211;associated polyposis (PPAP), and constitutional mismatch repair deficiency (CMMRD).[<a href="#cit/section_4.110">

3893110</a>

3894] AFAP can be diagnosed by testing for germline <em class="gene-name">

3895APC</em>

3896 pathogenic variants. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_118">

3897Attenuated Familial Adenomatous Polyposis [AFAP]</a>

3898 section of this summary for more information.) MAP is caused by biallelic germline pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

3899MUTYH</em>

3900 gene, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.[<a href="#cit/section_4.111">

3901111</a>

3902] PPAP is caused by <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339341&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339341&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3903heterozygous</a>

3904 pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

3905POLE</em>

3906 and <em class="gene-name">

3907POLD1</em>

3908.[<a href="#cit/section_4.112">

3909112</a>

3910,<a href="#cit/section_4.113">

3911113</a>

3912] CMMRD is a condition in which individuals inherit pathogenic variants in both alleles of one MMR gene (<em class="gene-name">

3913MLH1</em>

3914, <em class="gene-name">

3915MSH2</em>

3916, <em class="gene-name">

3917MSH6</em>

3918, <em class="gene-name">

3919PMS2</em>

3920, or <em class="gene-name">

3921EPCAM</em>

3922).[<a href="#cit/section_4.114">

3923114</a>

3924] For more information, see the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_433">

3925<em class="gene-name">

3926MUTYH</em>

3927-Associated Polyposis (MAP)</a>

3928, <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2642">

3929Oligopolyposis</a>

3930, and <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3012">

3931IHC in constitutional mismatch repair deficiency (CMMRD) syndrome</a>

3932 sections.</p>

3933<p id="_3298" tabindex="-1">

3934For example, in a large cross-sectional study, pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

3935APC</em>
