3936 were found in 80% (95% confidence interval [CI], 71%&#8211;87%) of individuals with more than 1,000 adenomas, 56% (95% CI, 54%&#8211;59%) in those with 100 to 999 adenomas, 10% (95% CI, 9%&#8211;11%) in those with 20 to 99 adenomas, and 5% (95% CI, 4%&#8211;7%) in those with 10 to 19 adenomas.[<a href="#cit/section_4.115">

3937115</a>

3938] In this same study, the prevalence of biallelic <em class="gene-name">

3939MUTYH</em>

3940 pathogenic variants was similar to <em class="gene-name">

3941APC</em>

3942 for those with the attenuated phenotype (20&#8211;99 adenomas), but <em class="gene-name">

3943MUTYH</em>

3944 pathogenic variants were also observed in a small minority (2%) of those with classic polyposis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.115">

3945115</a>

3946]</p>

3947<p id="_3299" tabindex="-1">

3948Most commercial laboratories perform not only full gene sequencing but also deletion/duplication analysis of the <em class="gene-name">

3949APC</em>

3950 and other genes. However, it is important to verify the testing methodology with each laboratory. Deletion analysis is especially important for individuals with FAP because 8% to 12% of affected individuals have a whole exon deletion or promoter 1B deletion in the <em class="gene-name">

3951APC</em>

3952 gene, which would not be detected with sequencing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.116">

3953116</a>

3954-<a href="#cit/section_4.119">

3955119</a>

3956] As mentioned, for patients who present with polyposis, multigene panels that include multiple polyposis genes are often ordered, which simplifies and lowers the cost of testing by assessing all genes at the same time. (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_1320">

3957Multigene [panel] testing</a>

3958 section in the PDQ summary on <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq">

3959Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling</a>

3960 for more information.) </p>

3961</section>

3962<section id="_3300">

3963<h6 id="_3300_toc">

3964Cascade testing</h6>

3965<p id="_3301" tabindex="-1">

3966In families in which a pathogenic variant in the <em class="gene-name">

3967APC</em>

3968 gene is identified, predictive testing for at-risk relatives can definitively identify or rule out the variant. Such testing is important to determine whether at-risk relatives need to undergo aggressive screening or whether such procedures are not necessary or can be discontinued (i.e., in relatives who test negative for the familial pathogenic variant).</p>

3969<p id="_3302" tabindex="-1">

3970Most patients with FAP have an affected parent, and a pattern of autosomal dominant inheritance may be observed in the family. Accordingly, cascade <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3971genetic counseling</a>

3972 and testing may then be extended to at-risk family members.

3973However, it is estimated that 25% of patients with FAP have a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783882&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783882&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3974de novo</a>

3975 pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

3976APC</em>

3977, meaning that the variant does not appear to be inherited from either parent.[<a href="#cit/section_4.120">

3978120</a>

3979] In cases where the variant cannot be identified in leukocyte DNA of either parent, it is possible that <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3980germline</a>

3981 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460197&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460197&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3982mosaicism</a>

3983 may explain the finding. Thus, siblings of an individual should always be offered <em class="gene-name">

3984APC</em>

3985 testing, but testing aunts, uncles, and cousins of the proband would not be indicated.</p>

3986<p id="_3303" tabindex="-1">

3987The early appearance of FAP clinical features and the subsequent recommendations for surveillance beginning at puberty raise special considerations relating to the genetic testing of minors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.121">

3988121</a>

3989] Hereditary cancer genetic testing is not recommended for minors unless results will affect medical management in childhood. Thus, FAP presents an example in which possible medical benefit justifies genetic testing of minors in families with a known pathogenic variant, especially for the anticipated 50% of at-risk children who will be found not to be carriers of pathogenic variants and who can thus be spared surveillance. In addition, testing infants for FAP can allow for hepatoblastoma surveillance until age 5 years. Otherwise, if at-risk minors are not tested, colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy is initiated between ages 10 to 15 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

3990122</a>

3991] The psychological impact of such testing is addressed in the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_189">

3992Psychosocial Issues in Hereditary Colon Cancer Syndromes</a>

3993 section of this summary. </p>

3994</section>

3995</section>

3996</section>

3997<section id="_260">

3998<h4 id="_260_toc">

3999Interventions for FAP</h4>

4000<section id="_3246">

4001<h5 id="_3246_toc">

4002Colon surveillance</h5>

4003<p id="_538" tabindex="-1">

4004Individuals at risk of FAP, because of a known <em class="gene-name">

4005APC</em>

4006 pathogenic variant in either the family or themselves, are evaluated for onset of polyposis by flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy. Once an FAP family member is found to manifest polyps, the only effective management to prevent CRC is colectomy. Prophylactic surgery has been shown to improve survival in patients with FAP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.123">

4007123</a>

4008] If feasible, the patient and his/her family members should be included in a registry because it has been shown retrospectively that registration and surveillance reduce CRC incidence and mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_4.124">

4009124</a>

4010] In patients with classic FAP identified very early in their course, the surgeon, endoscopist, and family may choose to delay surgery for several years in the interest of achieving social milestones. In addition, in carefully selected patients with AFAP (those with minimal polyp burden and advanced age), deferring a decision about colectomy may be reasonable with surgery performed only in the face of advancing polyp burden or dysplasia. </p>

4011<p id="_2974" tabindex="-1">

4012A Finnish nationwide, population-based, retrospective study evaluating whether surveillance of family members with FAP reduced overall mortality and improved survival demonstrated that family members of probands who were recruited to the screening

4013program had equivalent survival to the general population up to 20 years after diagnosis of FAP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.125">

4014125</a>

4015] The study included 154 families with at least one family member clinically diagnosed with FAP from 1963 to 2015. There were 194 probands and 225 family members (83 diagnosed by genetic testing and 142 by endoscopy) with a median time of follow-up of 11.8 years. In this study, the survival analysis of members of FAP families was calculated using the relative survival estimate.[<a href="#cit/section_4.126">

4016126</a>

4017]

4018 This estimate compares survival among FAP probands and family members with the survival expected in the absence of FAP among individuals of the same gender and age in each calendar year. The relative survival rate was 67% for probands (95% CI, 60%&#8211;75%) at 10 years of follow-up and 66% (95% CI, 58%&#8211;76%) at 20 years of follow-up. For family members, the relative survival rate was 98% (95% CI, 95%&#8211;101%) at 10 years of follow-up and 94% (95% CI, 88%&#8211;100%) at 20 years of follow-up. The relative survival rate was 87% (95% CI, 79%&#8211;96%) for family members at 25 years of follow-up. The relative survival rate for probands was significantly lower than the relative survival rate for family members (<em>

4019P</em>

4020 &lt; .001). The standardized mortality ratio was elevated in probands in both the 0- to 5-year and 5- to 10-year periods of follow-up whereas it remained stable for family members until 20 years of follow-up. This difference was more marked in the beginning of follow-up for probands, considering that most of them were probably symptomatic and most likely had CRC when they were diagnosed with FAP. The authors mentioned that if the CRC was treated successfully without recurrence, the survival of the probands approached that of the family members. </p>

4021<p id="_1143" tabindex="-1">

4022Colonoscopic surveillance usually begins at an early age (10&#8211;15 y) in individuals with FAP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

4023122</a>

4024] (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_189">

4025Psychosocial Issues in Hereditary Colon Cancer Syndromes</a>

4026 section of this summary for more information on the social and emotional implications of early surveillance.) Colonoscopy is the screening tool of choice for individuals with FAP for the following reasons: (a) improved instrumentation for full colonoscopy, (b) sedation, (c) recognition of AFAP, in which the disease typically manifests in the right colon, and (d) the growing tendency to defer surgery for a number of years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

4027122</a>

4028] The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) recommends that individuals who test negative for a known familial <em class="gene-name">

4029APC</em>

4030 pathogenic variant undergo average-risk population screening. However, clinical surveillance is warranted in families in which an <em class="gene-name">

4031APC </em>

4032pathogenic variant has not been identified in an affected individual. NCCN also recommends that individuals with an <em class="gene-name">

4033APC</em>

4034 pathogenic variant continue colon cancer screening, even if they have not developed colon polyps, since adenomas may not manifest until later in life.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

4035122</a>

4036] (Refer to the PDQ summary on <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-screening-pdq">

4037Colorectal Cancer Screening</a>

4038 for more information on these methods.)</p>

4039</section>

4040<section id="_3247">

4041<h5 id="_3247_toc">

4042Colorectal surgery</h5>

4043<p id="_259" tabindex="-1">

4044 Colon adenomas will develop in nearly 100% of individuals who are <em class="gene-name">

4045APC</em>

4046

4047pathogenic variant&#8211;positive; risk-reducing surgery comprises the standard of care to prevent CRC after polyps have appeared and are too numerous or histologically advanced to monitor safely using endoscopic resection.</p>

4048<p id="_263" tabindex="-1">

4049FAP patients and their doctors should have an

4050individualized discussion to decide when surgery will be performed. It is useful

4051to incorporate into the discussion the risk of developing desmoid tumors

4052after surgery, as well as fecundity for women. Timing of risk-reducing surgery usually depends on the

4053number of polyps, their size, histology, and symptomatology.[<a href="#cit/section_4.127">

4054127</a>

4055] Once numerous polyps have developed,

4056surveillance colonoscopy is no longer useful in timing the colectomy because polyps

4057are so numerous that it is not possible to biopsy or remove all of them.

4058At this time, it is appropriate for patients to consult with a surgeon who is experienced with available options, including total colectomy and restorative proctocolectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.128">

4059128</a>

4060] Rectum-sparing surgery, with sigmoidoscopic surveillance of the remaining

4061rectum, is a reasonable alternative to total colectomy in those compliant individuals with relative rectal sparing of polyps who understand

4062the consequences and make an informed decision to accept the residual risk of rectal cancer occurring despite periodic surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.129">

4063129</a>

4064]</p>

4065<p id="_264" tabindex="-1">

4066Surgical options include restorative proctocolectomy with ileal pouch&#8211;anal anastomosis (IPAA), total colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA), or total proctocolectomy with ileostomy (TPC). TPC is reserved for patients with low rectal cancer in which the sphincter cannot be spared or for patients on whom an IPAA cannot be performed because of technical problems. There is no risk of developing rectal cancer after TPC because the whole mucosa at risk is removed. These procedures can be performed utilizing minimally invasive techniques. </p>

4067<p id="_3323" tabindex="-1">

4068Irrespective of whether a colectomy and an IRA or a restorative proctocolectomy is performed, most experts suggest that periodic and lifelong surveillance of

4069the rectum or the ileal pouch be performed to remove or ablate any polyps. In earlier unselected studies, the risk of rectal cancer after total colectomy 20 years after IRA was reported to be as high as 25%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

4070130</a>

4071,<a href="#cit/section_4.131">

4072131</a>

4073] This risk has been reported to be much lower with better selection of patients for IRA.[<a href="#cit/section_4.128">

4074128</a>

4075,<a href="#cit/section_4.132">

4076132</a>

4077] Factors that have been reported to increase rectal cancer risk after IRA include the number of polyps throughout the colon, the number of polyps in the rectum, the presence of colon cancer at the time of IRA, the length of the rectal stump, the duration of follow-up after IRA, and the genotype.[<a href="#cit/section_4.39">

407839</a>

4079,<a href="#cit/section_4.133">

4080133</a>

4081-<a href="#cit/section_4.135">

4082135</a>

4083] An abdominal colectomy with IRA as the primary surgery for FAP does not preclude later conversion to an IPAA for uncontrolled rectal polyps and/or rectal cancer. In the Danish Polyposis Registry, the morbidity and functional results of a secondary IPAA (after a previous IRA) in 24 patients were reported to be similar to those of 59 patients who underwent primary IPAA.[<a href="#cit/section_4.136">

4084136</a>

4085]</p>

4086<p id="_968" tabindex="-1">

4087In most cases, the clinical polyp burden in the rectum at the time of surgery dictates the type of surgical intervention, namely, restorative proctocolectomy with IPAA versus IRA. Patients with a mild phenotype (&lt;1,000 colonic adenomas) and fewer than 20 rectal polyps may be candidates for IRA at the time of prophylactic surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_4.137">

4088137</a>

4089] In some cases, however, the polyp burden is equivocal, and in such cases, investigators have considered the role of genotype in predicting subsequent outcomes with respect to the rectum.[<a href="#cit/section_4.138">

4090138</a>

4091] Several <em class="gene-name">

4092APC</em>

4093 pathogenic variants can increase an individual's rectal cancer risk and can therefore increase an individual's risk for eventual completion proctectomy after IRA. These <em class="gene-name">

4094APC</em>

4095 pathogenic variants are located in exon 15 in codon 1250, codon 1309, codon 1328, and between codons 1250 and 1464.[<a href="#cit/section_4.139">

4096139</a>

4097,<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

4098130</a>

4099,<a href="#cit/section_4.140">

4100140</a>

4101,<a href="#cit/section_4.141">

4102141</a>

4103] A meta-analysis examined quality of life after restorative proctocolectomy and IPAA in patients with ulcerative colitis and FAP. The results suggested that patients with FAP do marginally better than patients with ulcerative colitis regarding fistula formation, pouchitis, stool frequency, and seepage.[<a href="#cit/section_4.142">

4104142</a>

4105]</p>

4106<p id="_3446" tabindex="-1">

4107It is important to continue annual surveillance of the ileal pouch in patients who have undergone IPAA because they are at risk of developing neoplasia in the anal transitional zone/residual rectal mucosa and in the ileal pouch. The cumulative risk of developing adenomas in the ileal pouch can be up to 75% for 15 years after surgery has been completed.[<a href="#cit/section_4.143">

4108143</a>

4109,<a href="#cit/section_4.144">

4110144</a>

4111] A retrospective study from the Cleveland Clinic Registry followed patients with FAP who underwent IPAA. After a median follow-up period of 10.1 years and a median of four pouchoscopies, 47% of patients (78 of 165) developed rectal mucosa/transitional zone adenomas. Adenomas were more frequently diagnosed in patients who had undergone stapled IPAA (52.3% [72 of 137]) when compared with those who had undergone mucosectomy and handsewn IPAA (21.4% [6 of 28]; <em>

4112P</em>

4113 &lt; .005).[<a href="#cit/section_4.145">

4114145</a>

4115] Although they are rare, carcinomas have been reported in the ileal pouch and anal transition zone after restorative proctocolectomy in patients with FAP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.146">

4116146</a>

4117] In the Cleveland Clinic study, six patients developed cancer after IPAA (three patients developed cancer while under surveillance, and three patients developed cancer after missing surveillance pouchoscopies).[<a href="#cit/section_4.145">

4118145</a>

4119]</p>

4120</section>

4121<section id="_3248">

4122<h5 id="_3248_toc">

4123Chemoprevention</h5>

4124<p id="_265" tabindex="-1">

4125Celecoxib, a specific cyclooxygenase 2 (COX-2)

4126inhibitor, and nonspecific COX-2

4127inhibitors, such as sulindac (a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug [NSAID]), have been associated with a decrease in polyp size and number in FAP patients, suggesting a role for chemopreventive agents in the treatment of this disorder.[<a href="#cit/section_4.147">

4128147</a>

4129,<a href="#cit/section_4.148">

4130148</a>

4131] Although celecoxib had been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), its license was voluntarily withdrawn by the manufacturer. Currently, there are no FDA-approved drugs for chemoprevention in FAP. Nevertheless, agents such as celecoxib and sulindac are used so commonly that chemopreventive clinical trials typically utilize one of these agents as a control. A randomized trial showed possible marginal improvement in polyp burden with the combination of celecoxib and eflornithine (i.e., difluoromethylornithine [DFMO]) when compared with celecoxib alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.149">

4132149</a>

4133] An international randomized trial analyzed the use of daily sulindac, eflornithine, or sulindac plus eflornithine in 171 individuals with FAP. In the three study arms, there were no significant differences between the frequencies of <em>

4134FAP-related events</em>

4135 (i.e., primary endpoints), which were composites of major surgeries (colectomies/proctocolectomies/pouchectomies/duodenal resections), excisions of advanced adenomas, diagnoses of cancer/high-grade dysplasia, and/or progressions of duodenal polyposis by more than one Spigelman stage.[<a href="#cit/section_4.150">

4136150</a>

4137] A post-hoc analysis was performed on 158 participants with FAP who were at risk for lower GI neoplasia. Results demonstrated a significant, marked reduction in the likelihood of lower GI tract polyposis progression (hazard ratio [HR], &lt;0.2) in the sulindac plus eflornithine arm versus sulindac alone (HR, 0.195; 95% CI, 0.048&#8211;0.803) and versus eflornithine alone (HR, 0.171; 95% CI, 0.042&#8211;0.698). Lower GI tract polyposis progression was defined as the need for colectomy, proctocolectomy, proctectomy, pouchectomy, the excision of any polyp that was more than 10 mm, and/or the diagnosis of cancer/high-grade dysplasia. Moreover, 0 of 54 participants randomly assigned to the sulindac plus eflornithine arm required major surgery, versus 7 of 53 (13.2%) in the sulindac-only arm, and 8 of 51 (15.7%) in the eflornithine-only arm (<em>

4138P</em>

4139 &#8804; .005).[<a href="#cit/section_4.151">

4140151</a>

4141]</p>

4142<p id="_1167" tabindex="-1">

4143 A small, randomized, placebo-controlled, dose-escalation trial of celecoxib in a pediatric population (aged 10&#8211;14 y) demonstrated the safety of celecoxib at all dosing levels when administered over a 3-month period.[<a href="#cit/section_4.152">

4144152</a>

4145] This study found a dose-dependent reduction in adenomatous polyp burden. At a dose of 16 mg/kg/day, which approximates the approved dose of 400 mg twice daily in adults, the reduction in polyp burden paralleled that demonstrated with celecoxib in adults. </p>

4146<p id="_1181" tabindex="-1">

4147Omega-3-polyunsaturated fatty acid eicosapentaenoic acid in the free fatty acid form has been shown to reduce rectal polyp number and size in a small study of patients with FAP after subtotal colectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.153">

4148153</a>

4149] Although not directly compared in a randomized trial, the effect appeared to be similar in magnitude to that previously observed with celecoxib.</p>

4150<p id="_450" tabindex="-1">

4151It is unclear at present how to incorporate COX-2 inhibitors into the

4152management of FAP patients who have not yet undergone risk-reducing surgery. A double-blind placebo-controlled trial of 41 child and young adult carriers of <em class="gene-name">

4153APC</em>

4154 pathogenic variants who had not yet manifested polyposis

4155demonstrated that sulindac may not be effective as a primary

4156treatment in FAP. There were no statistically

4157significant differences between the sulindac and placebo groups over 4 years of treatment in incidence, number, or size

4158of polyps.[<a href="#cit/section_4.148">

4159148</a>

4160]</p>

4161<p id="_323" tabindex="-1">

4162Consistent with the effects of COX-2 inhibitors on colonic polyps, in a randomized, prospective, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial, celecoxib reduced, but did not eliminate, the number of duodenal polyps in 32 patients with FAP after a 6-month course of treatment. Of importance, a statistically significant effect was seen only in individuals who had more than 5% of the duodenum involved with polyps at baseline and with an oral dose of 400 mg, given twice daily.[<a href="#cit/section_4.154">

4163154</a>

4164] A previous randomized study of 24 FAP patients treated with sulindac for 6 months showed a nonsignificant trend in the reduction of duodenal polyps.[<a href="#cit/section_4.155">

4165155</a>

4166] The same issues surrounding the use of COX-2 inhibitors for the treatment of colonic polyps apply to their use for the treatment of duodenal polyps (e.g., only partial elimination of the polyps, complications secondary to the COX-2 inhibitors, and loss of effect after the medication is discontinued).[<a href="#cit/section_4.154">

4167154</a>

4168]</p>

4169<p id="_2754" tabindex="-1">

4170Because of the common clustering of adenomatous polyps around the duodenal papilla (where bile enters the intestine) and preclinical data suggesting that ursodeoxycholate inhibits intestinal adenomas in mice that harbor an <em class="gene-name">

4171Apc</em>

4172 germline variant,[<a href="#cit/section_4.156">

4173156</a>

4174] two trials that employ ursodeoxycholate have been performed.[<a href="#cit/section_4.157">

4175157</a>

4176,<a href="#cit/section_4.158">

4177158</a>

4178] In both studies, ursodeoxycholate did not have a significant chemopreventive effect on duodenal polyps; paradoxically, in one study, ursodeoxycholate in combination with celecoxib appeared to promote polyp density in patients with FAP.</p>

4179<p id="_451" tabindex="-1">

4180Because of reports demonstrating an increase in cardiac-related events in patients taking rofecoxib and celecoxib,[<a href="#cit/section_4.159">

4181159</a>

4182-<a href="#cit/section_4.161">

4183161</a>

4184] it is unclear whether this class of agents will be safe for long-term use for patients with FAP and in the general population. Also, because of the short-term (6 months) nature of these trials, there is currently no clinical information about cardiac events in FAP patients taking COX-2 inhibitors on a long-term basis.</p>

4185<p id="_2788" tabindex="-1">

4186<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=538265&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000538265&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4187Level of evidence (celecoxib): 1b</a>

4188</p>

4189<p id="_267" tabindex="-1">

4190One cohort study has demonstrated regression of colonic and rectal adenomas

4191with sulindac treatment in FAP. The

4192reported outcome of this trial was the number and size of polyps, a surrogate for the

4193clinical outcome of main interest, CRC incidence.[<a href="#cit/section_4.162">

4194162</a>

4195]

4196</p>

4197<p id="_2789" tabindex="-1">

4198<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=538265&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000538265&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4199Level of evidence (sulindac): 1b</a>

4200</p>

4201<p id="_2894" tabindex="-1">

4202Preclinical studies of a small-molecule epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) inhibitor and low-dose sulindac in the Apc<span class="sup">

4203min/+</span>

4204 mouse diminished intestinal adenoma development by 87% [<a href="#cit/section_4.163">

4205163</a>

4206]

4207suggesting that EGFR inhibitors had the potential to inhibit duodenal polyps in FAP patients. A 6-month double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial tested the efficacy of sulindac, 150 mg twice daily, and erlotinib, 75 mg daily, versus placebo in FAP or AFAP patients with duodenal polyps.[<a href="#cit/section_4.164">

4208164</a>

4209] Ninety-two patients with FAP or AFAP were randomly assigned to receive study drugs or placebo and underwent pretreatment and posttreatment upper endoscopies to determine the changes in the sum diameter of the polyps and number of polyps in a 10 cm segment of proximal duodenum. The trial was terminated prematurely because the primary endpoint was met. The intent-to-treat analysis demonstrated a median decrease in duodenal polyp burden (sum of diameters) of 8.5 mm in the sulindac/erlotinib arm while there was an 8 mm increase in the placebo arm (<em>

4210P</em>

4211 &lt; .001). Significantly higher rates of grade 1 and grade 2 adverse events occurred in the treatment arm than in the placebo arm: in the treatment arm, 60.9% developed an acneiform rash and 32.6% developed oral mucositis; in the placebo arm, 19.6% developed an acneiform rash and 10.9% developed oral mucositis. A 2018 trial in 82 individuals with FAP found that combination treatment with sulindac (150 mg twice daily) and erlotinib (75 mg daily) compared with placebo resulted in a significantly lower (69.4%) colorectal polyp burden after 6 months of treatment (95% CI, 28.8%&#8211;109.2%; <em>

4212P</em>

4213 = .009).[<a href="#cit/section_4.165">

4214165</a>

4215] There was a reduction in polyp burden in both those with an entire colorectum and those with only a rectal pouch or rectum. However, it is unclear to what extent erlotinib contributed to this reduction given that sulindac has been proven effective in the lower GI tract. </p>

4216<p id="_3406" tabindex="-1">

4217On the basis of the previously modest effects of sulindac and celecoxib on duodenal polyps in patients with FAP [<a href="#cit/section_4.148">

4218148</a>

4219,<a href="#cit/section_4.162">

4220162</a>

4221] and the dramatic effect of genetic EGFR inhibition on intestinal adenoma development in the Apc<span class="sup">

4222min/+</span>

4223 mouse,[<a href="#cit/section_4.166">

4224166</a>

4225] it is likely that erlotinib was responsible for the success of these trials. An ongoing clinical trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02961374">

4226NCT02961374</a>

4227) is determining whether lower doses of erlotinib alone are sufficient for significantly reducing duodenal polyp burden in patients with FAP and AFAP.

4228</p>

4229<p id="_2895" tabindex="-1">

4230<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=538265&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000538265&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4231Level of evidence (sulindac + erlotinib): 1b</a>

4232</p>

4233</section>

4234<section id="_3249">

4235<h5 id="_3249_toc">

4236Management of extracolonic tumors</h5>

4237<p id="_3262" tabindex="-1">

4238Patients who carry <em class="gene-name">

4239APC</em>

4240 germline pathogenic variants are at increased risk of other types of malignancies, including desmoid tumors, gastric tumors, duodenal cancer, small bowel cancer, hepatoblastoma, thyroid cancer, and brain tumors. The management of these extracolonic tumors is described below.</p>

4241<section id="_3254">

4242<h6 id="_3254_toc">

4243Desmoid tumors</h6>

4244<p id="_607" tabindex="-1">

4245The management of

4246desmoids in FAP can be challenging and can complicate prevention efforts. There is no accepted standard treatment for desmoid tumors. Multiple medical treatments have generally been unsuccessful in the management of desmoids. Treatments have included antiestrogens, NSAIDs, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy, among others. Studies have evaluated the use of raloxifene alone, tamoxifen or raloxifene combined with sulindac, and pirfenidone alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.167">

4247167</a>

4248-<a href="#cit/section_4.169">

4249169</a>

4250] </p>

4251<p id="_608" tabindex="-1">

4252Thirteen patients with intra-abdominal desmoids and/or unfavorable response to other medical treatments who had expression of estrogen-alpha receptors in their desmoid tissues were included in a prospective study of raloxifene, given in doses of 120 mg daily.[<a href="#cit/section_4.167">

4253167</a>

4254] Six patients had been on tamoxifen or sulindac before treatment with raloxifene, and seven patients were previously untreated. All 13 patients with intra-abdominal desmoid disease had either a partial or a complete response 7 months to 35 months after starting treatment, and most desmoids decreased in size at 4.7 months (&#177; 1.8 mo) after treatment. Response occurred in patients with desmoid plaques and with distinct lesions. Study limitations include small sample size and the clinical evaluation of response, which was not consistent in all patients. Several questions remain concerning the outcomes of patients with desmoid tumors not expressing estrogen-alpha receptors who have received raloxifene, as well as which patients may benefit from this potential treatment.</p>

4255<p id="_609" tabindex="-1">

4256A second study of 13 patients with FAP-associated desmoid tumors, who were treated with tamoxifen 120 mg/day or raloxifene 120 mg/day in combination with sulindac 300 mg/day, reported that ten patients had either stable disease (n = 6) or a partial or complete response (n = 4) for more than 6 months and that three patients had stable disease for more than 30 months.[<a href="#cit/section_4.168">

4257168</a>

4258] These results suggest that the combination of these agents may be effective in slowing the growth of desmoid tumors. However, the natural history of desmoids is variable, with both spontaneous regression and variable growth rates.</p>

4259<p id="_610" tabindex="-1">

4260A third study reported mixed results in 14 patients with FAP-associated desmoid tumors treated with pirfenidone for 2 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.169">

4261169</a>

4262] In this study, some patients had disease regression, some patients had disease progression, and some patients had stable disease.</p>

4263<p id="_3212" tabindex="-1">

4264There are reports of using imatinib mesylate to treat desmoid tumors in FAP patients with some success.[<a href="#cit/section_4.170">

4265170</a>

4266,<a href="#cit/section_4.171">

4267171</a>

4268] Nilotinib demonstrated potential to stabilize desmoid tumor growth after treatment failure with imatinib in patients with desmoid tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.172">

4269172</a>

4270]</p>

4271<p id="_788" tabindex="-1">

4272<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531845&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531845&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4273Level of evidence: 4</a>

4274</p>

4275<p id="_3314" tabindex="-1">

4276The benefit of the tyrosine kinase inhibitor sorafenib in the treatment of desmoid tumors was demonstrated in a phase III randomized trial comparing sorafenib (400 mg daily) with placebo in 87 patients with unresectable progressive or symptomatic desmoid tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.173">

4277173</a>

4278] Crossover to the sorafenib group was permitted for patients in the placebo group who had disease progression on the placebo arm of the study. Objective responses were demonstrated in 16 of 49 patients treated with sorafenib (33%) compared with 7 of 35 placebo-treated patients (20%). Additionally, the two-year progression-free survival (PFS) rate was significantly higher for sorafenib (81%) than placebo (36%); the HR for progression or death was 0.13 (95% CI, 0.05&#8211;0.31; <em>

4279P</em>

4280 &lt; .001). The most frequently reported adverse events were grade 1 or grade 2 rash (73%), fatigue (67%), hypertension (55%), and diarrhea (51%). Despite a relatively favorable toxicity profile, approximately 20% of patients discontinued sorafenib due to toxicity, emphasizing the importance of appropriate dose delays and interruptions for the treatment of adverse events.</p>

4281<p id="_3315" tabindex="-1">

4282<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531829&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531829&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4283Level of evidence: 1</a>

4284</p>

4285<p id="_765" tabindex="-1">

4286Because of the high rates of morbidity and recurrence, in general, surgical resection is not recommended in the treatment of intra-abdominal desmoid tumors. A review of experiences at one hospital suggested that surgical outcomes with intra-abdominal desmoids may be better than previously believed.[<a href="#cit/section_4.174">

4287174</a>

4288,<a href="#cit/section_4.175">

4289175</a>

4290] Issues of subject selection are critical in evaluating surgical outcome data.[<a href="#cit/section_4.174">

4291174</a>

4292] Abdominal wall desmoids can be treated with surgical resection, but the recurrence rate is high. </p>

4293</section>

4294<section id="_3255">

4295<h6 id="_3255_toc">

4296Stomach tumors</h6>

4297<p id="_3250" tabindex="-1">

4298It is not clear what should be done with gastric adenomas. Only retrospective case series are available and point to a relatively low prevalence of gastric adenocarcinoma development in FAP patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.176">

4299176</a>

4300,<a href="#cit/section_4.177">

4301177</a>

4302] More recently, a rise in incidence of gastric adenocarcinoma was observed in a Western FAP database [<a href="#cit/section_4.69">

430369</a>

4304] suggesting that a possible change in the management of gastric tumorigenesis in FAP may be in order. One group recommends endoscopic polypectomy for the management of gastric adenomas.[<a href="#cit/section_4.69">

430569</a>

4306] The management of adenomas in the stomach is usually individualized on the basis of the size of the adenoma and the degree of dysplasia. </p>

4307<p id="_2785" tabindex="-1">

4308<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531846&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531846&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4309Level of evidence: 5</a>

4310</p>

4311</section>

4312<section id="_3257">

4313<h6 id="_3257_toc">

4314Duodenum/small bowel tumors</h6>

4315<p id="_692" tabindex="-1">

4316Endoscopic surveillance usually begins between ages 20 to 25 years in patients with FAP. Baseline upper endoscopy may be performed at an earlier age if the patient has a family history of large duodenal adenoma burden or duodenal/ampullary cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.67">

431767</a>

4318] The subsequent intervals between endoscopy vary according to the findings of the previous endoscopy, often based on Spigelman stage. Recommended intervals are based on expert opinion although the relatively liberal intervals for stage 0 to stage II disease are based in part on the natural history data generated by the Dutch/Scandinavian duodenal surveillance trial (refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1254">

4319Table 6</a>

4320 for available recommendations regarding screening frequency by Spigelman stage).[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

432120</a>

4322]</p>

4323<p id="_1238" tabindex="-1">

4324The main advantages of the Spigelman classification are its long-standing familiarity to and usage by those in the field, which allows reasonable standardization of outcome comparisons across studies.[<a href="#cit/section_4.63">

432563</a>

4326,<a href="#cit/section_4.178">

4327178</a>

4328] However, the following are limitations of application of the Spigelman classification: </p>

4329<div class="pdq-content-list">

4330<ul id="_1239">

4331<li>

4332Most pathologists do not employ the term <em>

4333moderate dysplasia</em>

4334, preferring a simpler low- versus high-grade dysplasia system. </li>

4335<li>

4336Because of the villous nature of normal duodenal epithelium, pathologists commonly disagree over the classification of <em>

4337tubular</em>

4338, <em>

4339tubulovillous</em>

4340, and <em>

4341villous.</em>

4342</li>

4343<li>

4344Spigelman staging requires biopsy, which is not always essential when only a few small plaques are present; conversely, for larger adenomas, sampling variation leads to understaging.[<a href="#cit/section_4.179">

4345179</a>

4346,<a href="#cit/section_4.180">

4347180</a>

4348]</li>

4349</ul>

4350</div>

4351<table id="_1254" class="table-default expandable-container">

4352<caption>

4353Table 6. Recommended Screening Intervals and Interventions by Spigelman Stage</caption>

4354<colgroup>

4355<col width="16.10%">

4356<col width="50.24%">

4357<col width="33.65%">

4358</colgroup>

4359<THead>

4360<tr>

4361<th>

4362Spigelman Stage </th>

4363<th>

4364NCCN (2022) [<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

4365122</a>

4366]</th>

4367<th>

4368ESMO (2013) [<a href="#cit/section_4.181">

4369181</a>

4370]</th>

4371</tr>

4372</THead>

4373<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

4374<tr>

4375<td colspan="3">

4376ESMO = European Society of Medical Oncology; NCCN = National Comprehensive Cancer Network.</td>

4377</tr>

4378<tr>

4379<td colspan="3">

4380See <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_617">

4381below</a>

4382 for additional information about the use of surgical resection in Spigelman stage IV disease.</td>

4383</tr>

4384</TFoot>

4385<tbody>

4386<tr>

4387<td>

43880 (no polyps) </td>

4389<td>

4390Endoscopy every 3&#8211;5 y </td>

4391<td>

4392Not specified</td>

4393</tr>

4394<tr>

4395<td>

4396I</td>

4397<td>

4398Endoscopy every 2&#8211;3 y </td>

4399<td>

4400Endoscopy every 5 y</td>

4401</tr>

4402<tr>

4403<td>

4404II</td>

4405<td>

4406Endoscopy every 1&#8211;2 y </td>

4407<td>

4408Endoscopy every 3 y

4409</td>

4410</tr>

4411<tr>

4412<td>

4413III</td>

4414<td>

4415Endoscopy every 6&#8211;12 mo </td>

4416<td>

4417Endoscopy every 1&#8211;2 y

4418

4419</td>

4420</tr>

4421<tr>

4422<td rowspan="3">

4423IV</td>

4424<td>

4425Expert endoscopic surveillance every 3&#8211;6 mo</td>

4426<td rowspan="2">

4427Endoscopy every 6-12 mo</td>

4428</tr>

4429<tr>

4430<td>

4431 Excision/ablation of resectable large or villous adenomatous polyps and endoscopic ampullectomy are options that may help individuals avoid surgery</td>

4432</tr>

4433<tr>

4434<td>

4435Surgical evaluation and counseling for individuals with high-grade dysplasia, invasive carcinoma, or a large polyp burden that cannot be removed endoscopically</td>

4436<td>

4437Surgical options include duodenotomy with polypectomy, pancreas-sparing duodenectomy and pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure)</td>

4438</tr>

4439</tbody>

4440</table>

4441<p id="_2822" tabindex="-1">

4442The results of long-term duodenal adenoma surveillance of FAP patients in Nordic countries and the Netherlands revealed significant duodenal cancer risk in FAP patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.182">

4443182</a>

4444] According to the protocol, biennial frontal-viewing endoscopy was performed from 1990 through 2000. Subsequently, patients were followed up with surveillance according to international guidelines. The study group comprised 261 of 304 patients (86%) who had more than one endoscopy. Median follow-up was 14 years (range, 9&#8211;17 y). The lifetime risk of duodenal adenomatosis was 88%. Forty-four percent of patients had worsening Spigelman stage over time, whereas 12% improved and 34% remained unchanged. Twenty patients (7%) developed duodenal cancer at a median age of 56 years (range, 44&#8211;82 y). The cumulative cancer incidence was 18% at age 75 years (95% CI, 8%&#8211;28%). Survival in patients with symptomatic cancers was worse than those diagnosed at surveillance endoscopy. </p>

4445<p id="_2828" tabindex="-1">

4446<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531825&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531825&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4447Level of evidence (screening for duodenum/small bowel tumors): 3</a>

4448</p>

4449<p id="_617" tabindex="-1">

4450Many factors, including severity of polyposis, comorbidities, patient preferences, and availability of adequately trained physicians, determine whether surgical or endoscopic therapy is selected for polyp management. Endoscopic resection or ablation of large or histologically advanced adenomas appears to be safe and effective in reducing the short-term risk of developing duodenal adenocarcinoma;[<a href="#cit/section_4.80">

445180</a>

4452,<a href="#cit/section_4.81">

445381</a>

4454,<a href="#cit/section_4.183">

4455183</a>

4456] however, patients managed with endoscopic resection of adenomas remain at substantial risk of developing recurrent adenomas in the duodenum.[<a href="#cit/section_4.179">

4457179</a>

4458] The most definitive procedure for reducing the risk of adenocarcinoma is surgical resection of the ampulla and duodenum, although these procedures also have higher morbidity and mortality associated with them than do endoscopic treatments. Duodenotomy and local resection of duodenal polyps or mucosectomy have been reported, but invariably, the polyps recur after these procedures.[<a href="#cit/section_4.184">

4459184</a>

4460] In a series of 47 patients with FAP and Spigelman stage III or stage IV disease who underwent definitive radical surgery, the local recurrence rate was reported to be 9% after a mean follow-up period of 44 months. This local recurrence rate was dramatically lower than any local endoscopic or surgical approach from the same study.[<a href="#cit/section_4.179">

4461179</a>

4462] Pancreaticoduodenectomy and pancreas-sparing duodenectomy are appropriate surgical therapies that are believed to substantially reduce the risk of developing periampullary adenocarcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.180">

4463180</a>

4464,<a href="#cit/section_4.184">

4465184</a>

4466-<a href="#cit/section_4.186">

4467186</a>

4468] If such surgical options are considered, preservation of the pylorus will benefit this patient group because most will have undergone a subtotal colectomy with IRA or total colectomy with IPAA. A matched case-control study of 32 people with FAP (all patients had pancreaticoduodenectomy after IPAA) found that pancreaticoduodenectomy did not impact quality of life.[<a href="#cit/section_4.187">

4469187</a>

4470] As noted in a Northern European study,[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

447120</a>

4472] and others,[<a href="#cit/section_4.188">

4473188</a>

4474,<a href="#cit/section_4.189">

4475189</a>

4476] most patients with duodenal adenomas will not develop cancer and can be followed with endoscopy. However, individuals with advanced adenomas (Spigelman stage III or stage IV disease) generally require endoscopic or surgical treatment of the polyps. Chemoprevention studies for duodenal adenomas in FAP patients are under way and may offer an alternate strategy in the future. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3248">

4477Chemoprevention</a>

4478 section of this summary for more information.)</p>

4479<p id="_1240" tabindex="-1">

4480The endoscopic approach to larger and/or flatter adenomas of the duodenum depends on whether the ampulla is involved. Endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) after submucosal injection of saline, with or without epinephrine and/or dye, such as indigo carmine, can be employed for nonampullary lesions. Ampullary lesions require even greater care including endoscopic ultrasound evaluation for evidence of bile or pancreatic duct involvement. Stenting of the pancreatic duct is commonly performed to prevent stricturing and pancreatitis. The stents require endoscopic removal at an interval of 1 to 4 weeks. Because the ampulla is tethered at the ductal orifices, it typically does not uniformly lift with injection, so injection is commonly not used. Any consideration of EMR or ampullectomy requires great experience and judgment, with careful consideration of the natural history of untreated lesions and an appreciation of the high rate of adenoma recurrence despite aggressive endoscopic intervention.[<a href="#cit/section_4.81">

448181</a>

4482,<a href="#cit/section_4.179">

4483179</a>

4484,<a href="#cit/section_4.180">

4485180</a>

4486,<a href="#cit/section_4.185">

4487185</a>

4488,<a href="#cit/section_4.190">

4489190</a>

4490-<a href="#cit/section_4.193">

4491193</a>

4492] The literature uniformly supports duodenectomy for Spigelman stage IV disease. For Spigelman stage II and stage III disease, there is a role for endoscopic treatment invariably focusing on the one or two worst lesions that are present.</p>

4493<p id="_1241" tabindex="-1">

4494Reluctance to consider surgical resection is related to the short-term morbidity and mortality and the long-term complications related to surgery. Although these concerns are likely overstated,[<a href="#cit/section_4.179">

4495179</a>

4496,<a href="#cit/section_4.180">

4497180</a>

4498,<a href="#cit/section_4.186">

4499186</a>

4500,<a href="#cit/section_4.190">

4501190</a>

4502,<a href="#cit/section_4.194">

4503194</a>

4504-<a href="#cit/section_4.200">

4505200</a>

4506] fear of surgical intervention can lead to aggressive and somewhat ill-advised endoscopic interventions. In some circumstances, endoscopic resection of ampullary and/or other duodenal adenomas cannot be accomplished completely or safely by endoscopic means, and duodenectomy cannot be accomplished without risking a short-gut syndrome or cannot be done at all because of mesenteric fibrosis. In such cases, surgical transduodenal ampullectomy/polypectomy can be performed. However, this is associated with a high risk of local recurrence similar to that of endoscopic treatment.</p>

4507<p id="_2819" tabindex="-1">

4508<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531845&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531845&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4509Level of evidence (treatment of duodenum/small bowel tumors): 4</a>

4510</p>

4511</section>

4512<section id="_3259">

4513<h6 id="_3259_toc">

4514Other tumors</h6>

4515<p id="_3260" tabindex="-1">

4516Although <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531823&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531823&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4517level 1 evidence</a>

4518 is lacking for the following surveillance methods, they are based on expert opinion. NCCN recommends baseline thyroid ultrasound beginning in the late teenage years to screen for papillary thyroid cancer in patients with FAP, with a repeat ultrasound every 2 to 5 years if results are normal. When individuals have a family history of thyroid cancer, shorter screening intervals can be used.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

4519122</a>

4520,<a href="#cit/section_4.201">

4521201</a>

4522,<a href="#cit/section_4.202">

4523202</a>

4524]</p>

4525<p id="_2786" tabindex="-1">

4526<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531827&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531827&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4527Level of evidence (thyroid cancer ultrasound screening): 4</a>

4528</p>

4529<p id="_3261" tabindex="-1">

4530 Although <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531823&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531823&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4531level 1 evidence</a>

4532 is lacking for the following surveillance methods, they are based on expert opinion. NCCN has suggested that the following be considered for children with a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460208&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460208&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4533predisposition</a>

4534 to FAP: liver palpation, abdominal ultrasound, and measurement of serum alpha-fetoprotein every 3 to 6 months for the first 5 years of life.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

4535122</a>

4536,<a href="#cit/section_4.203">

4537203</a>

4538] It is not necessary to continue screening after age 5 years.</p>

4539<p id="_2787" tabindex="-1">

4540<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4541Level of evidence (hepatoblastoma or adrenal cancer screening): 5</a>

4542</p>

4543<p id="_3308" tabindex="-1">

4544Although <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531823&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531823&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4545level 1 evidence</a>

4546 is lacking for the following surveillance methods, they are based on expert opinion. Medulloblastoma is a highly malignant tumor that is usually only symptomatic 6 months or less before diagnosis; annual surveillance of asymptomatic patients may be insufficient. Thus, surveillance by means of regular CT or magnetic resonance imaging cannot be advocated. FAP family members who do not yet have polyposis but have signs or symptoms suggestive of a brain tumor should be evaluated with neuroimaging because brain tumors present before polyposis in more than half of FAP patients. Careful evaluation is also important among FAP families in which one member already has a brain tumor because familial clustering occurs. Of such families with FAP-associated brain tumors, 40% had two affected members.[<a href="#cit/section_4.102">

4547102</a>

4548]</p>

4549</section>

4550</section>

4551</section>

4552</section>

4553<section id="_118">

4554<h3 id="_118_toc">

4555Attenuated Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (AFAP)</h3>

4556<section id="_3309">

4557<h4 id="_3309_toc">

4558Clinical phenotype</h4>

4559<p id="_694" tabindex="-1">

4560AFAP was first described clinically in 1990 in a large <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460158&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460158&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4561kindred</a>

4562 with a variable number of adenomas. The average number of adenomas in this kindred was 30, although they ranged in number from a few to hundreds.[<a href="#cit/section_4.204">

4563204</a>

4564] It has been recommended that the management of AFAP patients include colonoscopy rather than flexible sigmoidoscopy because the adenomas can be predominantly right-sided.[<a href="#cit/section_4.205">

4565205</a>

4566] Adenomas in AFAP are believed to form around the age of mid-twenties to late twenties.[<a href="#cit/section_4.57">

456757</a>

4568] Similar to classic FAP, the risk of CRC is higher in individuals with AFAP; the average age at diagnosis, however, is older than classic FAP at 56 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.105">

4569105</a>

4570,<a href="#cit/section_4.106">

4571106</a>

4572,<a href="#cit/section_4.206">

4573206</a>

4574] Affected family members have developed CRCs with very few synchronous polyps.[<a href="#cit/section_4.2">

45752</a>

4576] Extracolonic manifestations similar to those in classic FAP also occur in AFAP. These manifestations include upper GI polyps (FGPs, duodenal adenomas, and duodenal adenocarcinoma), osteomas, epidermoid cysts, and desmoid tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.57">

457757</a>

4578] Because of the specific sites of <em class="gene-name">

4579APC</em>

4580 pathogenic variants causing AFAP, these patients typically lack CHRPE lesions. </p>

4581</section>

4582<section id="_3310">

4583<h4 id="_3310_toc">

4584Genetics of AFAP</h4>

4585<p id="_695" tabindex="-1">

4586AFAP is associated with particular subsets of <em class="gene-name">

4587APC</em>

4588 pathogenic variants. Three groups of site-specific <em class="gene-name">

4589APC</em>

4590 pathogenic variants causing AFAP have been characterized:[<a href="#cit/section_4.105">

4591105</a>

4592-<a href="#cit/section_4.108">

4593108</a>

4594,<a href="#cit/section_4.207">

4595207</a>

4596,<a href="#cit/section_4.208">

4597208</a>

4598]</p>

4599<div class="pdq-content-list">

4600<ul id="_720">

4601<li>

4602Pathogenic variants associated with the 5&#8217; end of <em class="gene-name">

4603APC</em>

4604 and exon 4 in which patients can manifest 2 to more than 500 adenomas, including the classic FAP phenotype and upper GI polyps. Any pathogenic variant in the first four exons,[<a href="#cit/section_4.105">

4605105</a>

4606] as there is an internal ribosomal entry site in exon 4 that permits the ribosome to skip premature truncation pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.209">

4607209</a>

4608]</li>

4609<li>

4610Exon 9&#8211;associated phenotypes in which patients may have 1 to 150 adenomas but no upper GI manifestations.</li>

4611<li>

46123&#8217; region pathogenic variants in which patients have very few adenomas (&lt;50).</li>

4613</ul>

4614</div>

4615<p id="_3311" tabindex="-1">

4616In the absence of family history of similarly affected relatives, the differential diagnosis may include AFAP (including MAP), Lynch syndrome, CMMRD, germline variants in the DNA polymerase proofreading subunits (<em class="gene-name">

4617POLD1</em>

4618 or <em class="gene-name">

4619POLE</em>

4620), or an otherwise unclassified sporadic or genetic problem. A careful family history may implicate AFAP or Lynch syndrome.</p>

4621<p id="_716" tabindex="-1">

4622<em class="gene-name">

4623APC</em>

4624 testing is an important component of the evaluation of patients suspected of having AFAP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.205">

4625205</a>

4626] If germline <em class="gene-name">

4627APC</em>

4628 pathogenic variant testing is negative in suspected AFAP individuals, genetic testing for <em class="gene-name">

4629MUTYH</em>

4630, <em class="gene-name">

4631POLE</em>

4632, and <em class="gene-name">

4633POLD1</em>

4634 pathogenic variants may be warranted.[<a href="#cit/section_4.116">

4635116</a>

4636]</p>

4637</section>

4638<section id="_3312">

4639<h4 id="_3312_toc">

4640Clinical management</h4>

4641<p id="_791" tabindex="-1">

4642Patients found to have an unusually or unacceptably high adenoma count at an age-appropriate colonoscopy pose a differential diagnostic challenge.[<a href="#cit/section_4.210">

4643210</a>

4644,<a href="#cit/section_4.211">

4645211</a>

4646] The role for and timing of risk-reducing colectomy in AFAP is controversial.[<a href="#cit/section_4.212">

4647212</a>

4648]</p>

4649<p id="_2697" tabindex="-1">

4650<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2699">

4651Table 7</a>

4652 summarizes the clinical practice guidelines from different professional societies regarding surveillance of AFAP.</p>

4653<table id="_2699" class="table-default expandable-container">

4654<caption>

4655Table 7. Clinical Practice Guidelines for Colon Surveillance of Attenuated Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (AFAP)</caption>

4656<colgroup>

4659<col width="18.09%">

4660<col width="12.68%">

4661<col width="7.50%">

4662<col width="29.27%">

4663</colgroup>

4773</tbody>

4774</table>

4775</section>

4776</section>

4777<section id="_433">

4778<h3 id="_433_toc">

4779<em class="gene-name">

4780MUTYH</em>

4781-Associated Polyposis (MAP)</h3>

4782<p id="_1220" tabindex="-1">

4783MAP is an autosomal recessively inherited polyposis syndrome caused by pathogenic variants in the Mut Y homolog gene. The Mut Y homolog gene, which is known as <em class="gene-name">

4784MUTYH</em>

4785, was initially called <em class="gene-name">

4786MYH</em>

4787, but was subsequently corrected because the myosin heavy chain gene already had that designation. <em class="gene-name">

4788MUTYH</em>

4789 is located on chromosome 1p34.3-32.1.[<a href="#cit/section_4.214">

4790214</a>

4791] The protein encoded by <em class="gene-name">

4792MUTYH</em>

4793 is a base excision repair glycosylase, which repairs one of the most common forms of oxidative damage. Over one hundred unique sequence variants of <em class="gene-name">

4794MUTYH</em>

4795 have been reported. A <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783962&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783962&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4796founder pathogenic variant</a>

4797 with ethnic differentiation is assumed for <em class="gene-name">

4798MUTYH</em>

4799 pathogenic variants. In White populations of northern European descent, two major variants, Y179C and G396D (formerly known as Y165C and G382D), account for 70% of biallelic pathogenic variants in MAP patients; 90% of these patients carry at least one of these pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.215">

4800215</a>

4801] Other causative variants that have been found include P405L (formerly known as P391L) (Netherlands),[<a href="#cit/section_4.216">

4802216</a>

4803,<a href="#cit/section_4.217">

4804217</a>

4805] E480X (India),[<a href="#cit/section_4.218">

4806218</a>

4807] Y104X (Pakistan),[<a href="#cit/section_4.219">

4808219</a>

4809] 1395delGGA (Italy),[<a href="#cit/section_4.220">

4810220</a>

4811,<a href="#cit/section_4.221">

4812221</a>

4813] 1186-1187insGG (Portugal),[<a href="#cit/section_4.222">

4814222</a>

4815] and p.A359V (Japan and Korea).[<a href="#cit/section_4.223">

4816223</a>

4817-<a href="#cit/section_4.225">

4818225</a>

4819]</p>

4820<p id="_1218" tabindex="-1">

4821The <em class="gene-name">

4822MUTYH</em>

4823 gene was first linked to polyposis in 2002 in three siblings with multiple colonic adenomas and CRC but no <em class="gene-name">

4824APC</em>

4825 pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_4.111">

4826111</a>

4827] MAP has a broad clinical spectrum. Most often it resembles the clinical picture of AFAP, but it has been reported in individuals with phenotypic resemblance to classical FAP and Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.226">

4828226</a>

4829] MAP patients tend to develop fewer adenomas at a later age than patients with <em class="gene-name">

4830APC</em>

4831 pathogenic variants [<a href="#cit/section_4.227">

4832227</a>

4833,<a href="#cit/section_4.228">

4834228</a>

4835] but still carry a high risk of CRC (35%&#8211;75%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

48367</a>

4837,<a href="#cit/section_4.229">

4838229</a>

4839,<a href="#cit/section_4.230">

4840230</a>

4841] A 2012 study of colorectal adenoma burden in 7,225 individuals reported a prevalence of biallelic <em class="gene-name">

4842MUTYH</em>

4843 pathogenic variants of 4% (95% CI, 3%&#8211;5%) among those with 10 to 19 adenomas, 7% (95% CI, 6%&#8211;8%) among those with 20 to 99 adenomas, and 7% (95% CI, 6%&#8211;8%) among those with 100 to 999 adenomas.[<a href="#cit/section_4.115">

4844115</a>

4845] This broad clinical presentation results from the <em class="gene-name">

4846MUTYH</em>

4847 gene's ability to cause disease in its homozygous or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=766214&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000766214&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4848compound heterozygous</a>

4849 forms. Based on studies from multiple FAP registries, approximately 7% to 19% of patients with an FAP phenotype and without a detectable <em class="gene-name">

4850APC</em>

4851 germline pathogenic variant carry biallelic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

4852MUTYH</em>

4853 gene.[<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

48547</a>

4855,<a href="#cit/section_4.218">

4856218</a>

4857,<a href="#cit/section_4.228">

4858228</a>

4859,<a href="#cit/section_4.231">

4860231</a>

4861]</p>

4862<p id="_1219" tabindex="-1">

4863Adenomas, serrated adenomas, and hyperplastic polyps can be seen in MAP patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.232">

4864232</a>

4865] The CRCs tend to be right-sided and synchronous at presentation and seem to carry a better prognosis than sporadic CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.214">

4866214</a>

4867] Clinical management guidelines for MAP recommend screening with colonoscopy and polypectomy every 1 to 2 years if fewer than 20 adenomas are found. Colonoscopy begins no later than age 25 to 30 years (although, screening at a younger age may be considered based on family history).[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

4868122</a>

4869,<a href="#cit/section_4.213">

4870213</a>

4871,<a href="#cit/section_4.229">

4872229</a>

4873] Upper endoscopic surveillance begins at age 30 to 35 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.213">

4874213</a>

4875] (Refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2700">

4876Table 8</a>

4877 for more information about available clinical practice guidelines for colon surveillance in MAP patients.) The recommended upper endoscopic surveillance interval can be based on the burden of involvement according to Spigelman criteria.[<a href="#cit/section_4.213">

4878213</a>

4879] Total colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis or subtotal colectomy may be necessary for patients with <em class="gene-name">

4880MUTYH</em>

4881-associated polyposis depending on overall polyp burden.[<a href="#cit/section_4.229">

4882229</a>

4883,<a href="#cit/section_4.233">

4884233</a>

4885]</p>

4886<p id="_2757" tabindex="-1">

4887Although MAP is the only known biallelic (recessive) adenoma cancer predisposition syndrome described to date, there are examples of biallelic cases presenting with childhood tumors in which MMR genes are involved. For more information, see the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3012">

4888IHC in constitutional mismatch repair deficiency (CMMRD) syndrome</a>

4889 section.</p>

4890<p id="_2698" tabindex="-1">

4891<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2700">

4892Table 8</a>

4893 summarizes the clinical practice guidelines from different professional societies regarding colon surveillance of biallelic MAP.</p>

4894<table id="_2700" class="table-default expandable-container">

4895<caption>

4896Table 8. Clinical Practice Guidelines for Colon Surveillance of <em class="gene-name">

4897MUTYH</em>

4898-Associated Polyposis (MAP)</caption>

4899<colgroup>

4900<col width="19.69%">

4901<col width="16.90%">

4902<col width="19.69%">

4903<col width="12.78%">

4904<col width="10.30%">

4905<col width="20.61%">

4906</colgroup>

4927</tr>

4928<tr>

4929<td colspan="6">

4935<tbody>

4939229</a>

4940]</td>

4941<td>

4943MUTYH</em>

4945MUTYH</em>

4946 heterozygote)</td>

4955</tr>

4956<tr>

4958NCCN (2022) [<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

4959122</a>

4960] </td>

4961<td rowspan="2">

4963a</span>

4964</td>

4966Colonoscopy and polypectomy </td>

4967<td rowspan="2">

4968Every 1&#8211;2 y</td>

4969<td rowspan="2">

4970No later than age 25 to 30 y</td>

4971<td>

4973patient had colectomy with IRA, endoscopic evaluation every 6&#8211;12 mo, depending on the patient's polyp burden </td>

4974</tr>

4975<tr>

4976<td>

4977Chemoprevention may be considered in certain individuals (especially those with a high polyp burden postcolectomy), but data are limited in patients with MAP; consider referring patients to a center that has experience with MAP to discuss chemoprevention and surgery options</td>

4978</tr>

4979<tr>

4980<td>

4981Personal history of MAP with adenoma burden that cannot be managed endoscopically</td>

4982<td>

4986<td>

4988<td>
