4990colectomy with IRA,

4991endoscopic evaluation of

4992the rectum may be done every 6&#8211;12 mo

4993based on polyp burden

4994</td>

4995</tr>

4996<tr>

4997<td>

4998Asymptomatic, at-risk family member; familial pathogenic variant known; <em class="gene-name">

4999MUTYH</em>

5000 pathogenic variant status unknown or positive (biallelic) </td>

5001<td>

5002Colonoscopy</td>

5003<td>

5004Every 1&#8211;2 y </td>

5005<td>

5006No later than age 25&#8211;30 y</td>

5007<td>

5008Repeat screening every 1&#8211;2 years if polyps are not found; the screening interval can be lengthened if an individual does not have polyps on multiple subsequent colonoscopies, based on a provider's judgment; if polyps are found, use MAP screening guidelines. Discuss benefits of genetic testing if the patient's pathogenic variant status is unknown </td>

5009</tr>

5010<tr>

5011<td>

5012One <em class="gene-name">

5013MUTYH</em>

5014 pathogenic variant (monoallelic/<em class="gene-name">

5015MUTYH </em>

5016heterozygote); patient does not have CRC but has an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5017FDR</a>

5018 with CRC </td>

5019<td>

5020Colonoscopy</td>

5021<td>

5022Every 5 y </td>

5023<td>

502440 y or 10 y younger than an FDR's age at diagnosis (if it occurred at age 49 y or younger)</td>

5025<td>

5026&#160;</td>

5027</tr>

5028<tr>

5029<td>

5030One <em class="gene-name">

5031MUTYH</em>

5032 pathogenic variant (monoallelic/<em class="gene-name">

5033MUTYH </em>

5034heterozygote); patient does not have a personal or family history of CRC</td>

5035<td>

5036It is unclear if specialized CRC screening is needed</td>

5037<td>

5038Not applicable</td>

5039<td>

5040Not applicable</td>

5041<td>

5042&#160;</td>

5043</tr>

5044</tbody>

5045</table>

5046<p id="_1222" tabindex="-1">

5047Many extracolonic cancers have been reported in patients with MAP including gastric, small intestinal, endometrial, liver, ovarian, bladder, thyroid, and skin cancers (melanoma, squamous epithelial, and basal cell carcinomas).[<a href="#cit/section_4.234">

5048234</a>

5049,<a href="#cit/section_4.235">

5050235</a>

5051] Additionally, noncancerous extracolonic manifestations have been reported in a few MAP patients including lipomas, congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium, osteomas, and desmoid tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.220">

5052220</a>

5053,<a href="#cit/section_4.228">

5054228</a>

5055,<a href="#cit/section_4.235">

5056235</a>

5057,<a href="#cit/section_4.236">

5058236</a>

5059] Female MAP patients have an increased risk of breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.237">

5060237</a>

5061] These extracolonic manifestations seem to occur less frequently in MAP than in FAP, AFAP, or Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.238">

5062238</a>

5063,<a href="#cit/section_4.239">

5064239</a>

5065]</p>

5066<section id="_3240">

5067<h4 id="_3240_toc">

5068Duodenal polyps in MAP</h4>

5069<p id="_3241" tabindex="-1">

5070Similar to FAP, individuals with MAP often develop duodenal adenomas, and are at risk of developing duodenal cancer. Given the relatively recent identification of MAP compared with FAP, the incidence of duodenal polyps and risk of duodenal cancer in MAP is less well defined. Small case series have suggested the incidence of duodenal polyps in MAP to be approximately 30%, considerably lower than that of FAP. In a registry-based study the prevalence of duodenal polyps was 17%; however, only 50% of individuals in this study had undergone an upper GI endoscopy, suggesting the incidence of duodenal polyps was likely underestimated. The lifetime risk of duodenal cancer was estimated to be 4%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.235">

5071235</a>

5072]</p>

5073<p id="_3242" tabindex="-1">

5074 A registry study from the United Kingdom and the Netherlands explored incidence of duodenal polyps and duodenal cancer in a group of patients with MAP who were undergoing regular duodenal surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.240">

5075240</a>

5076] Of 92 patients, 31 (34%) had evidence of duodenal polyps. The median age at duodenal adenoma detection was 50 years, and in 65% of patients duodenal adenomas were diagnosed at baseline endoscopy. Eighty-four percent of patients had Spiegelman stage I or stage II polyposis at first detection of polyps, with no patients with stage IV polyposis and no high-grade dysplasia detected. In subsequent surveillance only two patients progressed to Spiegelman stage IV polyposis, after 3.6 and 7.0 years, respectively. There additionally appeared to be sparing of the ampulla, with only two individuals having diminutive polyps without dysplasia in the ampulla. No cancers were detected in patients enrolled in upper GI surveillance programs within these registries. Two individuals with MAP were diagnosed with ampullary and duodenal cancer respectively at ages 83 and 63 years at the time of first-ever upper GI endoscopies. Therefore, duodenal polyps appear less frequently in MAP when compared with FAP; duodenal polyps also appear at a later age in MAP. On the basis of these results, the authors suggest upper GI endoscopic screening in MAP be initiated at age 35 years.</p>

5077</section>

5078<p id="_1223" tabindex="-1">

5079Because MAP has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, siblings of an affected patient have a 25% chance of also carrying biallelic <em class="gene-name">

5080MUTYH</em>

5081 pathogenic variants and should be offered genetic testing. Similarly, testing can be offered to the partner of an affected patient so that the risk in their children can be assessed.

5082

5083</p>

5084<p id="_1224" tabindex="-1">

5085The clinical phenotype of monoallelic <em class="gene-name">

5086MUTYH</em>

5087 pathogenic variants is less well characterized with respect to incidence and associated clinical phenotypes, and its role in susceptibility to polyposis and colorectal carcinoma remains unclear. Approximately 1% to 2% of the general population carry a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

5088MUTYH</em>

5089.[<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

50907</a>

5091,<a href="#cit/section_4.111">

5092111</a>

5093,<a href="#cit/section_4.228">

5094228</a>

5095] A 2011 meta-analysis found that carriers of monoallelic <em class="gene-name">

5096MUTYH</em>

5097 pathogenic variants are at modestly increased risk of CRC (odds ratio [OR], 1.15; 95% CI, 0.98&#8211;1.36); however, given the rarity of carriers of monoallelic pathogenic variants, they account for only a trivial proportion of all CRC cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.241">

5098241</a>

5099] A large study of 2,332 heterozygotes among 9,504 relatives of 264 CRC cases with a <em class="gene-name">

5100MUTYH</em>

5101 pathogenic variant found that the risk of CRC at age 70 years was 7.2% for men and 5.6% for women, irrespective of family history. Among those with an FDR with a CRC diagnosis before age 50 years, the risk at age 70 years was 12.5% for men and 10% for women.[<a href="#cit/section_4.230">

5102230</a>

5103] Caution should be exercised in the interpretation of this study as the vast majority of carrier status from this study was imputed and not based on genotype. The authors felt the risk for <em class="gene-name">

5104MUTYH</em>

5105 heterozygotes with an FDR with CRC was sufficiently high to warrant more intensive surveillance than the general population (but the same as for anyone with an FDR with CRC diagnosed before age 50 y).[<a href="#cit/section_4.227">

5106227</a>

5107,<a href="#cit/section_4.230">

5108230</a>

5109]</p>

5110<p id="_1182" tabindex="-1">

5111 MMR genes may interact with MUTYH and increase the risk of CRC. An association between MUTYH and MSH6 has been reported. Both proteins interact together in base excision repair processes. A study reported a significant increase of <em class="gene-name">

5112MSH6</em>

5113 pathogenic variants in carriers of monoallelic <em class="gene-name">

5114MUTYH</em>

5115 pathogenic variants with CRC compared with noncarriers with CRC (11.5% vs. 0%; <em>

5116P</em>

5117 = .037).[<a href="#cit/section_4.242">

5118242</a>

5119] However, a German study failed to duplicate these findings.[<a href="#cit/section_4.243">

5120243</a>

5121] Additionally, a larger study found no increased cancer risk for carriers of MMR pathogenic variants with a <em class="gene-name">

5122MUTYH</em>

5123 variant compared with those with a MMR pathogenic variant alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.244">

5124244</a>

5125] </p>

5126</section>

5127<section id="_2642">

5128<h3 id="_2642_toc">

5129Oligopolyposis</h3>

5130<p id="_2643" tabindex="-1">

5131Oligopolyposis is a term that is used to describe a polyp count that is greater than anticipated in average-risk patients but falls short of the polyp count that is required for an FAP diagnosis. Thus, <em>

5132oligo-</em>

5133, Greek for few, can mean different things to different observers. Here, the term <em>

5134oligopolyposis</em>

5135 will be used to describe situations in which the patient's polyp count (generally adenoma) is large enough (with or without family history) to make an endoscopist suspect a hereditary polyposis syndrome. Most patients with oligopolyposis (including adenomas) do not have a known underlying predisposition to polyposis (i.e., pathogenic variants in known polyposis predisposition genes). Such cases are generally managed as if they are at an increased risk for recurrent adenomas, even when the colon can be cleared of polyps endoscopically.</p>

5136<p id="_3465" tabindex="-1">

5137Current NCCN guidelines recommend that patients with 10 or more cumulative adenomatous polyps consider genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

5138122</a>

5139] A cross-sectional study included 3,789 patients with 10 or more colorectal polyps who underwent multigene panel testing for the following genes: <em class="gene-name">

5140APC</em>

5141, <em class="gene-name">

5142BMPR1A</em>

5143, <em class="gene-name">

5144CDH1</em>

5145, <em class="gene-name">

5146CHEK2</em>

5147, <em class="gene-name">

5148EPCAM</em>

5149, <em class="gene-name">

5150MLH1</em>

5151, <em class="gene-name">

5152MSH2</em>

5153, <em class="gene-name">

5154MSH6</em>

5155, <em class="gene-name">

5156MUTYH</em>

5157, <em class="gene-name">

5158PMS2</em>

5159, <em class="gene-name">

5160PTEN</em>

5161, <em class="gene-name">

5162SMAD4</em>

5163, <em class="gene-name">

5164STK11</em>

5165, and <em class="gene-name">

5166TP53</em>

5167.[<a href="#cit/section_4.245">

5168245</a>

5169] Pathogenic variants were found in 5% of participants, regardless of the participant's age or polyp cohort. <em class="gene-name">

5170GREM1</em>

5171, <em class="gene-name">

5172POLD1</em>

5173, and <em class="gene-name">

5174POLE</em>

5175 were only evaluated in 2,353 patients because these genes were added to the multigene panel testing assay during the study period. Pathogenic variants in adenomatous polyposis genes decreased as participants increased in age in all polyp-count groups in the adenoma cohort. This, however, was not true for the nonpolyposis-related CRC genes. The prevalence of pathogenic variants in hamartomatous polyposis genes was high in the hamartoma cohort, regardless of polyp count (40% of participants had 10&#8211;19 polyps, 72.1% of participants had 20&#8211;99 polyps, and 50% of participants had 100 or more polyps). The study concluded that multigene panel testing of polyposis and nonpolyposis-related CRC genes may benefit patients with 10 or more CRC polyps, given that more than 5% of patients had pathogenic variants in all age groups. For more information about genetic testing for polyposis, see the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_256">

5176Genetic testing for FAP </a>

5177section.</p>

5178<p id="_2646" tabindex="-1">

5179AFAP resulting from pathogenic germline <em class="gene-name">

5180APC</em>

5181 variants may be the most common cause of oligopolyposis where a specific causative germline alteration cancer has been identified. Some AFAP cases with oligopolyposis will eventually develop more than 100 adenomas, albeit at a later age and often with a predominance of microadenomas of the right colon and with fewer, larger polyps in the left colon. Cases with a positive family history and an <em class="gene-name">

5182APC</em>

5183 pathogenic variant are clearly variant cases of FAP, as the term AFAP implies.[<a href="#cit/section_4.246">

5184246</a>

5185] However, patients with no immediate family history and a lesser adenoma burden may not be found to have an <em class="gene-name">

5186APC</em>

5187 pathogenic variant. The lower the polyp count the lower the probability of having an <em class="gene-name">

5188APC</em>

5189 pathogenic variant. Some of these cases are now known to carry biallelic <em class="gene-name">

5190MUTYH</em>

5191 pathogenic variants or variants in other genes linked to oligopolyposis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.247">

5192247</a>

5193]</p>

5194<p id="_2648" tabindex="-1">

5195Pathogenic variants in related DNA polymerase genes <em class="gene-name">

5196POLE</em>

5197 and <em class="gene-name">

5198POLD1</em>

5199 have been described in families with oligopolyposis, CRC, and endometrial cancer, and this condition has come to be known as <em>

5200polymerase proofreading&#8211;associated polyposis</em>

5201 (PPAP).[<a href="#cit/section_4.248">

5202248</a>

5203,<a href="#cit/section_4.249">

5204249</a>

5205] An elegant approach was employed using whole-genome sequencing in 15 selected patients with more than ten adenomas before age 60 years. Several had a close relative with at least five adenomas who could also have whole-genome sequencing performed. All tested patients had CRC or a first-degree relative (FDR) with CRC. All had negative <em class="gene-name">

5206APC</em>

5207, <em class="gene-name">

5208MUTYH</em>

5209, and MMR gene pathogenic variant test results. No variants were found to be in common among the evaluated families. In one family, however, linkage had established shared regions, in which one shared variant was found (<em class="gene-name">

5210POLE</em>

5211 p.Leu424Val; c.1270C&gt;G), with a predicted major derangement in protein structure and function. In a validation phase, nearly 4,000 affected cases enriched for the presence of multiple adenomas were tested for this variant and compared with nearly 7,000 controls. In this exercise, 12 additional unrelated cases were found to have the L424V variant, with none of the controls having the variant. In the affected families, inheritance of multiple-adenoma risk appeared to be autosomal dominant. </p>

5212<p id="_3128" tabindex="-1">

5213A similar approach, whole-genome testing for shared variants, with further &#8220;filtering&#8221; by linkage analysis identified a variant in the <em class="gene-name">

5214POLD1</em>

5215 gene (p.Ser478Asn; c.1433G&gt;A). This S478N variant was identified in two of the originally evaluated families, suggesting evidence of common ancestry. The validation exercise showed one patient with polyps with the variant but no controls with the variant. Somatic mutation patterns were similar to the <em class="gene-name">

5216POLE</em>

5217 variant. Several cases of early-onset endometrial cancer were seen. The mechanism underlying adenoma and carcinoma formation resulting from the <em class="gene-name">

5218POLE</em>

5219 L424V variant appeared to be a decrease in the fidelity of replication-associated polymerase proofreading. This in turn appeared to lead to variants related to base substitution. A subsequent study confirmed that <em class="gene-name">

5220POLE</em>

5221 pathogenic variants are a rare cause of oligopolyposis and early-onset CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.250">

5222250</a>

5223] All individuals in this study were negative for germline pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

5224APC</em>

5225, <em class="gene-name">

5226MUTYH</em>

5227, and the MMR genes. The <em class="gene-name">

5228POLE</em>

5229 variant L424V was found in 3 of 485 index cases with colorectal polyposis and early-onset CRC. Tumors showed <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=285933&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000285933&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5230microsatellite instability</a>

5231 (MSI) and were deficient of one or more MMR proteins in two of three index cases. Somatic mutations in MMR genes, possibly the result of hypermutability secondary to POLE deficiency, were detected in these two cases. The Cancer Genome Atlas Network performed extensive sequencing analysis of 276 CRCs, and found that the presence of somatic <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46063&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046063&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5232mutations</a>

5233 in the <em class="gene-name">

5234POLE</em>

5235 gene was associated with a hypermutated phenotype with a substantially greater mutational burden than present in CRCs with MSI. Thus, polymerase variants appear to generate an ultra-hypermutated genotype in the tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_4.251">

5236251</a>

5237]</p>

5238<p id="_2827" tabindex="-1">

5239A study utilizing <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=740459&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000740459&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5240whole-exome sequencing</a>

5241 in 51 individuals with multiple colonic adenomas from 48 families identified a homozygous germline nonsense pathogenic variant in seven affected individuals from three unrelated families in the base-excision repair gene <em class="gene-name">

5242NTHL1</em>

5243.[<a href="#cit/section_4.252">

5244252</a>

5245] These individuals had CRC, multiple adenomas (8&#8211;50), none of which were either hyperplastic or serrated, and in three affected females, there was either endometrial cancer or endometrial complex hyperplasia. There were two other individuals who developed duodenal adenomas and duodenal cancer. All <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44868&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044868&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5246pedigrees</a>

5247 were consistent with autosomal recessive inheritance. Upon examining three cancers and five adenomas from different affected individuals, none showed MSI. These neoplasms did show enrichment of cytosine to thymine transitions. Additional studies are needed to further define the phenotype. A subsequent study of 863 families with CRC and 1,600 families without CRC confirmed an association between biallelic <em class="gene-name">

5248NTHL1</em>

5249 pathogenic variants and inherited CRC risk.[<a href="#cit/section_4.253">

5250253</a>

5251] Currently, there is no known increased risk of cancer for individuals harboring a single monoallelic pathogenic germline <em class="gene-name">

5252NTHL1</em>

5253 variant.</p>

5254<p id="_3482" tabindex="-1">

5255Another study ran whole-exome and whole-genome sequencing on 309 individuals with one of the following: (1) a multigene panel that did not find a pathogenic variant in adenomatous polyposis genes, or (2) a family history of multiple individuals with CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.254">

5256254</a>

5257] This study demonstrated that patients with a biallelic loss of the base excision repair gene, <em class="gene-name">

5258MBD4</em>

5259, presented with oligopolyposis. Cancers observed in affected individuals included uveal melanoma, CRC, and acute myeloid leukemia. The majority of adenomas in these individuals had an accumulation of CpG to TpG transitions in well-known CRC driver genes like <em class="gene-name">

5260APC</em>

5261, <em class="gene-name">

5262KRAS</em>

5263, and <em class="gene-name">

5264AMER1</em>

5265.</p>

5266<p id="_3333" tabindex="-1">

5267Hereditary mixed polyposis, characterized by histology that often includes adenomatous and hyperplastic polyps, has been associated with <em class="gene-name">

5268GREM1</em>

5269 pathogenic variants in a small number of Ashkenazi Jewish families. Polyp number in this syndrome is highly variable but is often in the spectrum consistent with oligopolyposis. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_649">

5270Hereditary mixed polyposis syndrome [HMPS]</a>

5271 section of this summary for more information.)</p>

5272<p id="_3334" tabindex="-1">

5273<em class="gene-name">

5274NTHL1</em>

5275, <em class="gene-name">

5276POLE</em>

5277, <em class="gene-name">

5278POLD1</em>

5279, and <em class="gene-name">

5280GREM1</em>

5281 pathogenic variant testing is being incorporated into the multigene (panel) tests for CRC susceptibility offered commercially along with <em class="gene-name">

5282APC</em>

5283 and <em class="gene-name">

5284MUTYH</em>

5285 so that a polyposis panel can be ordered up front for the patients with oligopolyposis. There are minimal data on the optimal surveillance approach for individuals found to have pathogenic germline variants in <em class="gene-name">

5286NTHL1</em>

5287 (biallelic carriers only), <em class="gene-name">

5288POLE</em>

5289, or <em class="gene-name">

5290POLD1</em>

5291, although it is presumed that the risk of CRC is comparable to what is seen in Lynch syndrome, and some guidelines are endorsing similarly early and frequent colonoscopic screening.</p>

5292<p id="_2651" tabindex="-1">

5293Oligopolyposis caused by other polyposis histologies can be distinguished from adenomatous polyposis on simple endoscopic and histologic grounds. For example, individuals with juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS), PJS, or <em class="gene-name">

5294PTEN</em>

5295 hamartoma tumor syndrome (Cowden syndrome) can all manifest oligopolyposis, often inclusive of hamartomatous polyps, as well as other more common polyp histologies (e.g., adenomas). </p>

5296<p id="_3335" tabindex="-1">

5297Serrated polyposis can likewise present in highly variable fashion. The World Health Organization (WHO) criteria for serrated polyposis (&#8805;5 serrated polyps proximal to sigmoid with 2 polyps &#8805;1 cm, or any number of polyps proximal to sigmoid if there is a relative with serrated polyposis, or &#8805;20

5298serrated polyps anywhere in the colon) have never been validated. Rarely, families with serrated polyposis can be identified to harbor pathogenic germline <em class="gene-name">

5299RNF43</em>

5300 variants, but most cases of serrated polyposis cannot be linked to an underlying genetic basis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.255">

5301255</a>

5302-<a href="#cit/section_4.257">

5303257</a>

5304] Consequently, such patients are increasingly being referred for genetic counseling and for consideration of genetic testing. Occasional cases of <em class="gene-name">

5305MUTYH</em>

5306 biallelic pathogenic variants have been found in patients with at least some features of serrated polyposis and serrated polyps can be seen in Lynch syndrome. However, germline evaluation of individuals with serrated polyposis is typically unrevealing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.258">

5307258</a>

5308-<a href="#cit/section_4.262">

5309262</a>

5310]</p>

5311<p id="_3336" tabindex="-1">

5312Two very small case series have described oligopolyposis with varying polyp histologies (e.g., adenomas, serrated, inflammatory, and hamartomatous polyps) in individuals previously treated with chemotherapy and radiation therapy for a prior childhood malignancy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.263">

5313263</a>

5314,<a href="#cit/section_4.264">

5315264</a>

5316] This phenomenon, termed <em>

5317therapy-associated polyposis</em>

5318 (TAP), may be an acquired, nonfamilial phenotype caused by prior antineoplastic therapy, and is on the differential diagnosis when nonfamilial oligopolyposis is identified in individuals previously treated with chemotherapy and/or radiation. Another recent study identified oligopolyposis fulfilling WHO criteria for serrated polyposis syndrome (SPS) in 6% of a cohort of 101 Hodgkin lymphoma survivors treated with prior chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy, suggesting that Hodgkin lymphoma survivors may be a particularly important population in whom TAP can manifest.[<a href="#cit/section_4.265">

5319265</a>

5320]</p>

5321</section>

5322<section id="_2986">

5323<h3 id="_2986_toc">

5324Lynch Syndrome</h3>

5325<section id="_1094">

5326<h4 id="_1094_toc">

5327Introduction</h4>

5328<p id="_1095" tabindex="-1">

5329Lynch syndrome is the most common inherited CRC syndrome and accounts for approximately 3% of all newly diagnosed cases of CRC. It is an autosomal dominant condition caused by pathogenic variants in the MMR genes <em class="gene-name">

5330MLH1</em>

5331 (mutL homolog 1), <em class="gene-name">

5332MSH2</em>

5333 (mutS homolog 2), <em class="gene-name">

5334MSH6</em>

5335 (mutS homolog 6), and <em class="gene-name">

5336PMS2</em>

5337 (postmeiotic segregation 2), as well as the gene <em class="gene-name">

5338EPCAM</em>

5339 (epithelial cellular adhesion molecule, formerly known as <em class="gene-name">

5340TACSTD1</em>

5341), in which deletions in <em class="gene-name">

5342EPCAM</em>

5343 cause <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=717443&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000717443&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5344epigenetic</a>

5345 silencing of <em class="gene-name">

5346MSH2</em>

5347. Lynch syndrome is also associated with a predisposition for developing several extracolonic manifestations, including sebaceous adenomas and cancers of the endometrium and ovaries, stomach, small intestine, transitional cell carcinoma of the ureters and renal pelvis, hepatobiliary system, pancreas, and brain. Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated cancers exhibit MSI; therefore, tumor testing is a key component in the diagnosis of Lynch syndrome, in addition to family history. Universal tumor testing of all CRCs is now recommended as a strategy to screen for Lynch syndrome and identify those individuals who may subsequently benefit from germline genetic testing. Intensive cancer screening and surveillance strategies, including frequent colonoscopy, along with risk-reducing surgeries, are mainstays in patients with Lynch syndrome. </p>

5348<section id="_1096">

5349<h5 id="_1096_toc">

5350History of Lynch syndrome</h5>

5351<p id="_1097" tabindex="-1">

5352Between 1913 and 1993, numerous case reports of families with apparent increases in CRC were reported. As series of such reports accumulated, certain characteristic clinical features emerged: early age at onset of CRC; high risk of synchronous (and metachronous) colorectal tumors; preferential involvement of the right colon; improved clinical outcome; and a range of associated extracolonic sites including the endometrium, ovaries, other sites in the GI tract, uroepithelium, brain, and skin (sebaceous tumors). Terms such as <strong>

5353cancer family syndrome</strong>

5354, and <strong>

5355hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer</strong>

5356 (<strong>

5357HNPCC</strong>

5358) were used to describe this entity.[<a href="#cit/section_4.266">

5359266</a>

5360]</p>

5361<p id="_3079" tabindex="-1">

5362The term <strong>

5363Lynch syndrome</strong>

5364 replaced HNPCC and is applied to cases in which the genetic basis can be confidently linked to a germline pathogenic variant in a DNA MMR gene. Moreover, HNPCC is misleading as many patients have polyps and many have tumors other than CRC. </p>

5365<p id="_1099" tabindex="-1">

5366With the increased recognition of families that were considered to have a genetic predisposition to the development of CRC, research for a causative etiology led to the development of the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1124">

5367Amsterdam criteria</a>

5368 in 1990.[<a href="#cit/section_4.267">

5369267</a>

5370] The Amsterdam criteria were originally used for the identification of high-risk families and included fulfillment of all of the following: three or more cases of CRC over two or more generations, with at least one diagnosed before age 50 years, and no evidence of FAP.</p>

5371<p id="_3044" tabindex="-1">

5372In 1987, a chromosomal deletion of a small segment of 5q led to the detection of a genetic linkage between FAP and this genomic region,[<a href="#cit/section_4.268">

5373268</a>

5374] from which the <em class="gene-name">

5375APC</em>

5376 gene was eventually cloned in 1991.[<a href="#cit/section_4.269">

5377269</a>

5378] This led to searches for similar linkage in families suspected of having Lynch syndrome who had multiple cases of CRC inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion and young onset of cancer development. The <em class="gene-name">

5379APC</em>

5380 gene was one of several genes (along with <em class="gene-name">

5381DCC</em>

5382 and <em class="gene-name">

5383MCC</em>

5384) evaluated in families that fulfilled Amsterdam criteria, but no linkage was found among the Lynch kindreds. In 1993, an extended genome-wide search resulted in the recognition of a candidate chromosome 2 susceptibility locus in large families. Once <em class="gene-name">

5385MSH2</em>

5386, the first Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated gene, was sequenced, it was evident from the somatic mutation patterns in the CRC tumors that the MMR family of genes was likely involved. Additional MMR genes were subsequently linked to Lynch syndrome, including <em class="gene-name">

5387MLH1</em>

5388, <em class="gene-name">

5389MSH6</em>

5390, and <em class="gene-name">

5391PMS2</em>

5392. Lynch syndrome now refers to the genetic disorder caused by a germline variant in one of these DNA MMR genes, distinguishing it from other familial clusters of CRC.</p>

5393<p id="_3032" tabindex="-1">

5394In 2009, a germline deletion in the <em class="gene-name">

5395EPCAM</em>

5396 gene was identified as another cause of <em class="gene-name">

5397MSH2</em>

5398 inactivation in the absence of a germline pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

5399MSH2</em>

5400. The variant in <em class="gene-name">

5401EPCAM</em>

5402 led to hypermethylation of the <em class="gene-name">

5403MSH2</em>

5404 promoter. Thus, <em class="gene-name">

5405EPCAM</em>

5406, which is not a DNA MMR gene, is also implicated in Lynch syndrome and is now routinely tested in at-risk patients along with the DNA MMR genes listed above.</p>

5407</section>

5408<section id="_1100">

5409<h5 id="_1100_toc">

5410Defining Lynch syndrome families</h5>

5411<p id="_3029" tabindex="-1">

5412Families with a preponderance of CRC and a possible genetic predisposition were initially categorized as having Lynch syndrome based on family history criteria, as well as personal history of young-onset CRC. With the advent of molecular tumor diagnostic testing and the discovery of the germline alterations associated with Lynch syndrome, the clinical criteria have currently fallen out of favor due to their underperformance. However, their use, or the risk estimates provided by the Lynch syndrome prediction models, may be applicable among individuals without personal history of cancer but with a family history suggestive of Lynch syndrome, or for those individuals with CRC but without available tumor for molecular diagnostic testing. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1110">

5413Universal tumor testing to screen for Lynch syndrome</a>

5414 and the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1101">

5415Clinical risk assessment models that predict the likelihood of an MMR gene pathogenic variant</a>

5416 sections of this summary for more information.)</p>

5417<p id="_1123" tabindex="-1">

5418The first criteria for defining Lynch syndrome

5419families were established by the

5420International Collaborative Group meeting in Amsterdam in 1990 and are

5421known as the Amsterdam criteria.[<a href="#cit/section_4.267">

5422267</a>

5423] These research criteria were limited to diagnoses of familial CRC. In 1999, the Amsterdam criteria were revised to include some extracolonic cancers, predominantly endometrial cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.270">

5424270</a>

5425] These criteria provide a general approach to identifying Lynch syndrome families, but they are not considered comprehensive; nearly half of families meeting the Amsterdam criteria do not have detectable pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.271">

5426271</a>

5427]</p>

5428<div class="pdq-content-list">

5429<p class="pdq-list-title">

5430Amsterdam criteria I (1990):</p>

5431<ol id="_1124">

5432<li>

5433One family member diagnosed with CRC before age 50 years.</li>

5434<li>

5435Two affected generations.</li>

5436<li>

5437Three affected relatives, one of them an FDR of the other two.</li>

5438<li>

5439 FAP should be excluded.</li>

5440<li>

5441Tumors should be verified by pathological examination.</li>

5442</ol>

5443</div>

5444<div class="pdq-content-list">

5445<p class="pdq-list-title">

5446Amsterdam criteria II (1999):</p>

5447<ul id="_1127">

5448<li>

5449Same as Amsterdam criteria I, but tumors of the endometrium, small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis can be used to substitute an otherwise qualifying CRC.</li>

5450</ul>

5451</div>

5452<p id="_1128" tabindex="-1">

5453These criteria were subsequently used beyond research purposes to identify potential candidates for <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=285938&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000285938&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5454microsatellite</a>

5455 and germline testing. However, the Amsterdam criteria failed to identify a substantial proportion of Lynch syndrome kindreds; families that fulfilled Amsterdam criteria I but did not have evidence of MSI and were without a pathogenic germline variant in a DNA MMR gene, were referred to as familial colorectal cancer type X (FCCX). (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3006">

5456FCCX</a>

5457 section of this summary for more information.)</p>

5458<p id="_1129" tabindex="-1">

5459With the hallmark feature of MSI associated with Lynch syndrome tumors, and the limitations of the Amsterdam criteria related to low sensitivity, the Bethesda guidelines were introduced in 1997. The Bethesda guidelines are a combination of clinical, histopathologic, and family cancer history features that identify cases of CRC that warrant MSI tumor screening. The Bethesda guidelines (with a subsequent revision in 2004) were formulated to target patients in whom evaluation of CRC tumors for MMR deficiency should be considered, and to improve the sensitivity of clinical criteria used to identify individuals who are candidates for <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460195&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460195&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5460mutational DNA analysis</a>

5461.[<a href="#cit/section_4.272">

5462272</a>

5463,<a href="#cit/section_4.273">

5464273</a>

5465] (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1103">

5466Genetic and molecular testing for Lynch syndrome</a>

5467 section of this summary for more information about testing for MSI and IHC.)</p>

5468<div class="pdq-content-list">

5469<p class="pdq-list-title">

5470Bethesda guidelines (1997): </p>

5471<ol id="_2718">

5472<li>

5473Cancer in families that meet the Amsterdam criteria.</li>

5474<li>

5475The presence of two Lynch syndrome&#8211;related cancers, including synchronous and

5476metachronous CRCs or associated extracolonic cancers. [<em>

5477Note: Endometrial, ovarian, gastric, hepatobiliary, or small-bowel cancer or transitional

5478cell carcinoma of the renal pelvis or ureter.</em>

5479]</li>

5480<li>

5481The presence of CRC and an FDR with

5482CRC and/or Lynch syndrome&#8211;related extracolonic cancer and/or a

5483colorectal adenoma; one of the cancers diagnosed before age 45 years, and the

5484adenoma diagnosed before age 40 years.</li>

5485<li>

5486CRC or endometrial cancer diagnosed before age 45 years.</li>

5487<li>

5488Right-sided CRC with an undifferentiated

5489pattern (solid/cribriform) on histopathology diagnosed before age 45 years. [<em>

5490Note: Solid/cribriform defined as poorly differentiated or undifferentiated carcinoma

5491composed of irregular, solid sheets of large eosinophilic cells and containing

5492small gland-like spaces.</em>

5493]</li>

5494<li>

5495Signet-ring&#8211;cell CRC diagnosed before age 45 years. [<em>

5496Note: Composed of more than 50% signet ring cells.</em>

5497]</li>

5498<li>

5499Adenomas diagnosed before age 40 years.</li>

5500</ol>

5501</div>

5502<div class="pdq-content-list">

5503<p class="pdq-list-title">

5504Revised Bethesda guidelines (2004)*:</p>

5505<ol id="_3038">

5506<li>

5507CRC diagnosed in an individual younger than 50 years.</li>

5508<li>

5509Presence of synchronous, metachronous colorectal, or other Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated tumors.** </li>

5510<li>

5511CRC with MSI-high (MSI-H) pathologic associated features diagnosed in an individual younger than 60 years. [<em>

5512Note: Presence of tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=681114&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000681114&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5513Crohn-like lymphocytic reaction</a>

5514, mucinous/signet-ring differentiation, or medullary growth pattern.</em>

5515]</li>

5516<li>

5517CRC or Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated tumor** diagnosed in at least one FDR younger than 50 years.</li>

5518<li>

5519CRC or Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated tumor** diagnosed at any age in two FDRs or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=485395&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000485395&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5520second-degree relatives</a>

5521 (SDRs).</li>

5522</ol>

5523</div>

5524<p id="_2721" tabindex="-1">

5525*One criterion must be met for the tumor to be considered for MSI testing.</p>

5526<p id="_1131" tabindex="-1">

5527**Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated tumors include colorectal, endometrial, stomach, ovarian, pancreatic, ureter and renal pelvis, biliary tract, and brain tumors; sebaceous gland adenomas and keratoacanthomas in Muir-Torre syndrome; and carcinoma of the small bowel.[<a href="#cit/section_4.273">

5528273</a>

5529,<a href="#cit/section_4.274">

5530274</a>

5531] </p>

5532<p id="_3033" tabindex="-1">

5533Although the Bethesda guidelines were able to identify a higher proportion of Lynch syndrome carriers than the Amsterdam criteria, they still missed approximately 30% of Lynch syndrome families.[<a href="#cit/section_4.275">

5534275</a>

5535] Furthermore, the Bethesda guidelines were not consistently used in clinical practice to identify the subset of individuals with CRC who should have MSI tumor testing; the guidelines were deemed cumbersome and difficult to remember by health care providers and the opportunity to refer for genetic evaluation was missed.[<a href="#cit/section_4.276">

5536276</a>

5537]</p>

5538<p id="_2952" tabindex="-1">

5539With the advent of alternative approaches, including universal testing of all newly diagnosed cases of CRC for MSI (regardless of age at diagnosis or family history of cancer), clinical criteria for Lynch syndrome have been rendered obsolete. While the Bethesda guidelines were intended for individuals with cancer, their performance in individuals unaffected by cancer may still be of use. Given the limited modalities available to assess unaffected individuals for Lynch syndrome, family history and the use of clinical criteria may be appropriate in identifying those who warrant further genetic evaluation and testing.</p>

5540<section id="_1101">

5541<h6 id="_1101_toc">

5542Clinical risk assessment models that predict the likelihood of an MMR gene pathogenic variant</h6>

5543<p id="_2953" tabindex="-1">

5544Because health care providers ineffectively use clinical criteria to select individuals with CRC for genetic referral and evaluation for Lynch syndrome, computer-based clinical prediction models were developed and introduced in 2006 as alternative modalities to provide systematic genetic <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460214&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460214&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5545risk assessment</a>

5546 for Lynch syndrome. The risk models include the <a href="https://premm.dfci.harvard.edu/" title="https://premm.dfci.harvard.edu/">

5547PREMM (PREdiction Model for gene Mutations) models</a>

5548, <a href="http://hnpccpredict.hgu.mrc.ac.uk" title="http://hnpccpredict.hgu.mrc.ac.uk">

5549MMRpredict</a>

5550, and <a href="https://projects.iq.harvard.edu/bayesmendel/mmrpro" title="https://projects.iq.harvard.edu/bayesmendel/mmrpro">

5551MMRpro</a>

5552.[<a href="#cit/section_4.277">

5553277</a>

5554-<a href="#cit/section_4.280">

5555280</a>

5556]</p>

5557<p id="_3056" tabindex="-1">

5558Four models (PREMM[1,2,6], PREMMplus, MMRpredict, and MMRpro) quantify an individual&#8217;s probability of carrying a pathogenic variant in one of the following MMR genes: <em class="gene-name">

5559MLH1</em>

5560, <em class="gene-name">

5561MSH2</em>

5562, and <em class="gene-name">

5563MSH6</em>

5564. The PREMM(1,2,6) model was subsequently extended to include prediction of pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

5565PMS2</em>

5566 and <em class="gene-name">

5567EPCAM</em>

5568 variants (PREMM5).[<a href="#cit/section_4.280">

5569280</a>

5570] While PREMM5, MMRpredict, and MMRpro are specific to Lynch syndrome, PREMMplus quantifies an individual&#8217;s risk of having a pathogenic variant in one of 19 genes (including all five Lynch syndrome genes).[<a href="#cit/section_4.281">

5571281</a>

5572] However, it is unclear if one of these models is preferred for predicting when an individual has Lynch syndrome.</p>

5573<p id="_3057" tabindex="-1">

5574While the models were all created for the same purpose, they differ in the way they were developed and the variables used to predict risk. In addition, the populations in which they were validated reveal each model&#8217;s specific characteristics that may impact accuracy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.281">

5575281</a>

5576-<a href="#cit/section_4.291">

5577291</a>

5578] Deciding on which model to use in the risk assessment process depends on both the clinical setting in which it is applied and the patient population that is being evaluated. MMRpro&#8217;s predictions account for family size and unaffected relatives, the possibility of including molecular tumor data in the risk analysis, and the option of predicting pathogenic variant carrier status following germline testing. The major limitation in the widespread use of MMRpro in routine practice is the need to input data from the entire pedigree (including individuals without cancer), which is relatively time-consuming. Its best use is likely to be as a genetic counseling tool in a specialized high-risk clinic or research setting, as its accessibility is also limited. PREMM&#8217;s major advantages include that it is easy to use, available as an online tool, and has been extensively validated, including in a self-administered setting in a GI clinic.[<a href="#cit/section_4.292">

5579292</a>

5580] It includes risk prediction based on personal and family cancer history up to SDRs for a broad spectrum of extracolonic cancers. However, the model does not consider family size and may overestimate the likelihood of a pathogenic variant in a pedigree that includes multiple elderly family members who are unaffected by CRC or endometrial cancer. Given the ease with which one can use the PREMM model (it has been deemed less time-consuming than MMRpro in validation studies),[<a href="#cit/section_4.287">

5581287</a>

5582] it may be used by diverse health care providers whose primary aim is to identify patients who should be referred for genetic evaluation, and is likely to be most useful in the pretesting decision-making process. MMRpredict&#8217;s use may be limited overall because of its less accurate risk estimates [<a href="#cit/section_4.293">

5583293</a>

5584] when used to evaluate families with Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated cancers and older individuals affected by CRC; the model was developed using data from young-onset CRC cases (patients diagnosed at age &lt;55 y) and did not include extracolonic malignancies. Furthermore, the model does not incorporate tumor testing results or provide post-hoc risk estimates based on gene sequencing results. Lastly, PREMMplus assesses the likelihood of finding a pathogenic variant on a multigene panel of 19 high- and moderate-penetrance genes, and it is not limited to genes associated with CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.281">

5585281</a>

5586]</p>

5587<p id="_3058" tabindex="-1">

5588Overall, there is ample evidence that each of the models has superior performance characteristics of sensitivity, specificity, and positive and negative predictive values that support their use when compared with the existing clinical guidelines for diagnosis and evaluation of Lynch syndrome. Because of the diverse clinical settings in which a health care provider has the opportunity to assess an individual for Lynch syndrome, prediction models offer a potentially feasible and useful strategy to systematically identify at-risk individuals, whether or not they are affected with CRC.</p>

5589</section>

5590</section>

5591<section id="_2962">

5592<h5 id="_2962_toc">

5593Summary</h5>

5594<p id="_2813" tabindex="-1">

5595In conclusion, the presence of tumor MSI in CRCs, along with a compelling personal and family history of cancer, warrants germline genetic testing for Lynch syndrome, and most clinical practice guidelines provide for such an approach. These guidelines combine genetic counseling and testing strategies with clinical screening and treatment measures. Providers and patients alike can use these guidelines to better understand available options and key decisions. (Refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3427">

5596Table 13</a>

5597 for more information about practice guidelines for diagnosis and colon surveillance in Lynch syndrome.)</p>

5598</section>

5599</section>

5600<section id="_1102">

5601<h4 id="_1102_toc">

5602Genetics of Lynch syndrome</h4>

5603<p id="_3080" tabindex="-1">

5604The genetics of both the tumor and the germline have an important role in the development and diagnosis of Lynch syndrome. Tumor DNA in Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated tumors exhibits characteristic MSI, and in these cases, there is typically loss of IHC expression for one or more of the proteins associated with the MMR genes. Molecular testing with MSI and/or IHC has been adopted as a universal screen for diagnosis of Lynch syndrome in newly diagnosed patients with CRC and endometrial cancer. IHC testing results can potentially direct gene-specific germline testing. Many genetic testing laboratories offer multigene (panel) tests that simultaneously test for pathogenic variants in all of the Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated genes (and often additional genes associated with inherited cancer susceptibility).</p>

5605<section id="_1103">

5606<h5 id="_1103_toc">

5607Genetic and molecular testing for Lynch syndrome</h5>

5608<section id="_3119">

5609<h6 id="_3119_toc">

5610MSI</h6>

5611<p id="_2814" tabindex="-1">

5612The presence of MSI in colorectal tumor specimens is a hallmark feature of Lynch syndrome and can be cause for suspicion of a germline pathogenic MMR gene variant. Microsatellites are short, repetitive sequences of DNA (mononucleotides, dinucleotides, trinucleotides, or tetranucleotides) located throughout the genome, primarily in intronic or intergenic sequences.[<a href="#cit/section_4.294">

5613294</a>

5614,<a href="#cit/section_4.295">

5615295</a>

5616] The term MSI is used when colorectal, endometrial, or metastatic tumor DNA [<a href="#cit/section_4.296">

5617296</a>

5618] shows insertions or deletions in microsatellite regions when compared with normal tissue. MSI indicates probable defects in MMR genes, which may be due to somatic mutations, germline variants, or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=717446&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000717446&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5619epigenetic alterations</a>

5620.[<a href="#cit/section_4.297">

5621297</a>

5622] In most instances, MSI is associated with absence of protein expression of one or more of the MMR proteins (MSH2, MLH1, MSH6, and PMS2). However, loss of protein expression may not be seen in all tumors with MSI and not all tumors with loss of protein expression on IHC will be microsatellite unstable.</p>

5623<p id="_1154" tabindex="-1">

5624Certain histopathologic features are strongly suggestive of MSI phenotype, including the presence of tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3123">

5625Figure 4</a>

5626), Crohn-like reaction, mucinous histology, absence of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=580966&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000580966&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5627dirty necrosis</a>

5628, and histologic heterogeneity.[<a href="#cit/section_4.298">

5629298</a>

5630]</p>

5631<figure id="figure_3123" class="image-center">

5632<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/789557.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

5633Enlarge</a>

5634<img id="_3123" alt="Histopathology slide of a colorectal tumor under a microscope, showing lymphocytes and cell nuclei in the tumor." title="Histopathology slide of a colorectal tumor under a microscope, showing lymphocytes and cell nuclei in the tumor." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/789557-750.jpg">

5635<figcaption class="caption-container">

5636Figure 4. Tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes are a histopathologic feature suggestive of microsatellite instability.</figcaption>

5637</figure>

5638<p id="_3081" tabindex="-1">

5639Initial designation of a colorectal adenocarcinoma as microsatellite unstable was based on the detection of a specified percentage of unstable loci from a panel of three dinucleotide and two mononucleotide repeats that were selected at a National Institutes of Health (NIH) Consensus Conference and referred to as the Bethesda panel. If more than 30% of a tumor's <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46129&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046129&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5640markers</a>

5641 were unstable, it was scored as MSI-H; if at least one, but fewer than 30% of markers were unstable, the tumor was designated MSI-low (MSI-L). If no loci were unstable, the tumor was designated microsatellite stable (MSS). Most tumors arising in the setting of Lynch syndrome will be MSI-H.[<a href="#cit/section_4.299">

5642299</a>

5643] The clinical relevance of MSI-L tumors remains controversial; the probability is very small that these tumors are associated with a germline pathogenic variant in an MMR gene.</p>

5644<p id="_3082" tabindex="-1">

5645The original Bethesda panel has been replaced by a pentaplex panel of five mononucleotide repeats,[<a href="#cit/section_4.299">

5646299</a>

5647] which has improved the detection of MSI-H tumors.</p>

5648<p id="_2954" tabindex="-1">

5649(Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3065">

5650Prognostic and therapeutic implications of MSI</a>

5651 section of this summary for more information about the treatment implications of MSI testing.)</p>

5652<p id="_1155" tabindex="-1">

5653(Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1110">

5654Universal tumor testing to screen for Lynch syndrome</a>

5655 section of this summary for information about the utilization of MSI status in the diagnostic workup of a patient with suspected Lynch syndrome.)</p>

5656</section>

5657<section id="_1105">

5658<h6 id="_1105_toc">

5659IHC</h6>

5660<p id="_1012" tabindex="-1">

5661IHC methods are cheaper, easier to understand, and more widely available as a surrogate for MSI and, for these reasons, have replaced <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44798&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044798&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5662polymerase chain reaction</a>

5663 (PCR)&#8211;based MSI testing in most institutions. IHC is performed in the colorectal or endometrial tumor (or metastatic sites) [<a href="#cit/section_4.296">

5664296</a>

5665] for protein expression using monoclonal antibodies for the MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 proteins. Isolated loss of expression of any one of these proteins may suggest which specific MMR gene is

5666altered in a particular patient.[<a href="#cit/section_4.300">

5667300</a>

5668-<a href="#cit/section_4.303">

5669303</a>

5670] However, certain proteins can form heterodimers (or have other binding partners) and yield loss of two proteins expressed on IHC.</p>

5671<p id="_2918" tabindex="-1">

5672MSI can lead to nucleotide-pairing slippage (looping) in which single nucleotide mispairs are introduced. Heterodimers of MMR proteins are formed to identify the errors and bind the DNA at these sites.[<a href="#cit/section_4.297">

5673297</a>

5674,<a href="#cit/section_4.304">

5675304</a>

5676] For example, MSH2 protein complexes with MSH6 protein to form MutS&#945;, which has the main ability to repair single <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460130&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460130&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5677base pair</a>

5678 mismatches and single base pair loop-out lesions that can occur during the replication of a mononucleotide repeat sequence. In the absence of MSH6 protein, the MSH2 protein will dimerize with the MSH3 protein forming the MutS&#946; complex, which has the ability to trigger repair of larger loop-out DNA mismatches, but also has some overlapping activity to repair lesions usually repaired by MutS&#945;.</p>

5679<figure id="figure_3124" class="image-center">

5680<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/789558.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

5681Enlarge</a>

5682<img id="_3124" alt="Protein stains of normal and colorectal tumor tissue are shown for a single patient. The stains from the tumor (in four insets) show the presence of MSH2 and MSH6 (the dark stain is visible) and absence of MLH1 and PMS2 (the dark stain is not visible)." title="Protein stains of normal and colorectal tumor tissue are shown for a single patient. The stains from the tumor (in four insets) show the presence of MSH2 and MSH6 (the dark stain is visible) and absence of MLH1 and PMS2 (the dark stain is not visible)." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/789558-750.jpg">

5683<figcaption class="caption-container">

5684Figure 5. Immunohistochemical tumor testing for protein expression of the mismatch repair genes associated with Lynch syndrome, depicted for a single patient with colorectal cancer. Protein expression is preserved for MSH2 and MSH6 (inset) and absent for MLH1 and PMS2 (inset). Absence of MMR protein expression is suggestive of Lynch syndrome and warrants additional evaluation.</figcaption>

5685</figure>

5686<p id="_3045" tabindex="-1">

5687As a result, when the germline pathogenic variant is in the <em class="gene-name">

5688MSH2</em>

5689 gene, the tumor IHC may not express both MSH2 and MSH6, as the latter protein requires binding to MSH2 for stability. In this case, if no pathogenic variant is found in either gene, germline pathogenic variant testing for <em class="gene-name">

5690EPCAM</em>

5691 should be considered if it was not already included. Approximately 20% of patients with absence of MSH2 and MSH6 protein expression by IHC and no <em class="gene-name">

5692MSH2</em>

5693 or <em class="gene-name">

5694MSH6</em>

5695 pathogenic variant identified will have germline deletions in <em class="gene-name">

5696EPCAM</em>

5697.[<a href="#cit/section_4.305">

5698305</a>

5699] The latter mechanism accounts for approximately 5% of all Lynch syndrome cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.305">

5700305</a>

5701] A deletion of one exon 9 allele in the <em class="gene-name">

5702EPCAM</em>

5703 (<em class="gene-name">

5704TACSTD1</em>

5705) gene, which is immediately upstream of <em class="gene-name">

5706MSH2</em>

5707's start site and in the same orientation, can lead to <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=390290&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000390290&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5708transcriptional</a>

5709 read-through and methylation of the <em class="gene-name">

5710MSH2</em>

5711 promoter. This can lead to subsequent silencing of <em class="gene-name">

5712MSH2</em>

5713 in any tissue that expresses <em class="gene-name">

5714EPCAM</em>

5715. The presence of <em class="gene-name">

5716EPCAM</em>

5717 pathogenic variants showing similar methylation-mediated MSH2 loss has been reported in numerous families.[<a href="#cit/section_4.306">

5718306</a>

5719] On the strength of these observations, germline <em class="gene-name">

5720EPCAM</em>

5721 testing is performed in patients with loss of MSH2 protein expression on IHC testing of their CRCs but who lack a detectable <em class="gene-name">

5722MSH2</em>

5723 germline pathogenic variant and is included with <em class="gene-name">

5724MSH2</em>

5725 testing in all colon cancer gene panels. For more information, see the <em class="gene-name">

5726<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1130">

5727EPCAM </a>

5728</em>

5729section.</p>

5730<p id="_3048" tabindex="-1">

5731In patients with no variants in any of these genes, tumor sequencing may reveal biallelic, somatic <em class="gene-name">

5732MSH2</em>

5733 mutations. For more information, see the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3501">

5734Somatic biallelic mismatch repair deficiency (sometimes called Lynch-like syndrome)</a>

5735 section.</p>

5736<p id="_3034" tabindex="-1">

5737Similarly, the loss of <em class="gene-name">

5738MLH1</em>

5739 (either by germline pathogenic variant or hypermethylation of the <em class="gene-name">

5740MLH1</em>

5741 promoter) results in the absence of expression of both MLH1 and PMS2 proteins in the tumor. The most common abnormal IHC pattern for DNA MMR proteins in colorectal adenocarcinomas is loss of expression of MLH1 and PMS2. PMS2 and MLH1 function as a stable heterodimer known as MutL&#945;. MutL&#945; binds to MutS&#946; and guides excision repair of the newly synthesized DNA strand.[<a href="#cit/section_4.297">

5742297</a>

5743] A functional defect in <em class="gene-name">

5744MLH1</em>

5745 results in degradation of both MLH1 and PMS2, while a defect in <em class="gene-name">

5746PMS2</em>

5747 negatively affects only PMS2 expression. Thus, a loss of MLH1 and PMS2 indicates that there is an alteration in <em class="gene-name">

5748MLH1</em>

5749 (promoter hypermethylation or germline variant), while loss of PMS2 expression often indicates that there is a germline <em class="gene-name">

5750PMS2</em>

5751 variant. However, among 88 individuals with PMS2-deficient CRC, <em class="gene-name">

5752PMS2</em>

5753 germline pathogenic variant testing followed by <em class="gene-name">

5754MLH1</em>

5755 germline pathogenic variant testing revealed pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

5756PMS2</em>

5757 variants in 49 individuals (74%) and <em class="gene-name">

5758MLH1</em>

5759 pathogenic variants in 8 individuals (12%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.307">

5760307</a>

5761] Eighty-three percent of the alterations in <em class="gene-name">

5762MLH1</em>

5763 were missense variants, but two relatives carried identical <em class="gene-name">

5764MLH1</em>

5765 variants, and one individual, who developed two tumors with retained MLH1 expression, carried an intronic variant that led to skipping of exon 8.[<a href="#cit/section_4.307">

5766307</a>

5767] Therefore, in CRCs with solitary loss of PMS2 expression, an <em class="gene-name">

5768MLH1</em>

5769 germline pathogenic variant should be sought if no <em class="gene-name">

5770PMS2</em>

5771 germline variant is found. Tumors with MSI and loss of MSH2 and MSH6 protein expression are generally indicative of an underlying <em class="gene-name">

5772MSH2</em>

5773 germline variant (inferred <em class="gene-name">

5774MSH2</em>

5775 pathogenic variant). Unlike the case with <em class="gene-name">

5776MLH1</em>

5777, MSI with MSH2 loss is rarely associated with somatic hypermethylation of the promoter.</p>

5778<p id="_2815" tabindex="-1">

5779Unlike MLH1 and MSH2 (which both dimerize with other proteins or have other binding partners), germline pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

5780MSH6</em>

5781 and <em class="gene-name">

5782PMS2</em>

5783 result in the isolated loss of those specific proteins by IHC. However, tumors from <em class="gene-name">

5784MSH6</em>

5785 pathogenic variant carriers may not display the MSI phenotype at a frequency as high as <em class="gene-name">

5786MLH1</em>

5787 and <em class="gene-name">

5788MSH2</em>

5789 carriers (despite an inactive DNA MMR system), as there are pathogenic missense variants that do not completely abrogate protein expression yielding false negative results by IHC testing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.286">

5790286</a>

5791,<a href="#cit/section_4.308">

5792308</a>

5793] In a study that reported tumor testing results among MMR germline carriers enrolled through the Colon Cancer Family Registry, 7 of 24 carriers (28%) with <em class="gene-name">

5794MSH6</em>

5795 pathogenic variants had tumors that displayed normal protein expression on IHC staining. IHC tumor testing was more <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460156&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460156&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5796informative</a>

5797 for <em class="gene-name">

5798MLH1</em>

5799 and <em class="gene-name">

5800MSH2</em>

5801 pathogenic variant carriers in which 93% of <em class="gene-name">

5802MLH1</em>

5803 carriers had correlating loss of MLH1 protein expression and 96% of <em class="gene-name">

5804MSH2</em>

5805 carriers had loss of MSH2 protein expression.[<a href="#cit/section_4.286">

5806286</a>

5807] </p>

5808<p id="_2987" tabindex="-1">

5809In some cases, tumors manifest MSI and/or IHC shows loss of DNA MMR protein expression, but no germline pathogenic variant is identified. This tumor phenotype is predominantly due to biallelic somatic inactivation of the DNA MMR genes and is not a pathogenic germline alteration. This phenomenon has been labeled Lynch-like syndrome (sometimes called LLS in the literature), although this terminology may cause confusion since this term represents a mechanism of sporadic carcinogenesis, rather than a stand-alone genetic syndrome. For more information, see the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3501">

5810Somatic biallelic mismatch repair deficiency (sometimes called Lynch-like syndrome)</a>

5811 section.</p>

5812<table id="_3122" class="table-default expandable-container">

5813<caption>

5814Table 9. Protein Loss and Potential Germline Defect(s)</caption>

5815<colgroup>

5816<col width="16.66%">

5819<col width="16.66%">

5820<col width="16.66%">

5821<col width="16.66%">

5822</colgroup>

5829</tr>

5922X</td>

5932<tr>

5934MSH2</td>

5935<td>

5945</tr>

5946</tbody>

5947</table>

5948<section id="_3089">

5949<h6 id="_3089_toc">

5950Somatic <em class="gene-name">

5951MLH1</em>

5952 hypermethylation</h6>

5953<p id="_2817" tabindex="-1">

5954It is important to recognize that hypermethylation of the <em class="gene-name">

5955MLH1</em>

5956 promoter, a somatic event confined to the tumor, can lead to abnormal protein expression of MLH1 on IHC. Approximately 10% to 15% of sporadic CRC cases have a microsatellite unstable tumor phenotype due to <em class="gene-name">

5957MLH1</em>

5958 hypermethylation and are not heritable. These sporadic MSI colon cancers [<a href="#cit/section_4.309">

5959309</a>

5960] have a generalized excess of DNA methylation referred to as CIMP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.310">

5961310</a>

5962] (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1337">

5963CIMP and the serrated polyposis pathway</a>

5964 section in the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1">

5965Introduction</a>

5966 section of this summary for more information.) Because loss of MLH1 protein expression on IHC occurs in both Lynch syndrome and sporadic tumors, its specificity for predicting germline MMR gene variants is lower than for the other MMR proteins, and additional molecular testing is often necessary to clarify the etiology of MLH1 absence. </p>

5967<p id="_1010" tabindex="-1">

5968<em class="gene-name">

5969BRAF</em>

5970 pathogenic variants have been detected in 68% of CRC tumors with <em class="gene-name">

5971MLH1</em>

5972 promoter hypermethylation and very rarely, if ever, in CRC from patients with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.311">

5973311</a>

5974-<a href="#cit/section_4.314">

5975314</a>

5976] This suggests that detection of somatic <em class="gene-name">

5977BRAF</em>

5978 V600E mutation detection in CRC may be useful in excluding individuals from germline variant testing. As a result, <em class="gene-name">

5979BRAF</em>

5980 V600 testing and/or <em class="gene-name">

5981MLH1</em>

5982 hypermethylation assays are increasingly utilized in universal Lynch syndrome&#8211;testing algorithms in an attempt to distinguish between an absence of MLH1 protein expression caused by hypermethylation and germline <em class="gene-name">

5983MLH1</em>

5984 pathogenic variants. Making such a distinction is also a more cost-effective approach in excluding individuals from germline testing. </p>

5985</section>

5986<section id="_3501">

5987<h6 id="_3501_toc">

5988Somatic biallelic mismatch repair deficiency (sometimes called Lynch-like syndrome)</h6>

5989<p id="_3502" tabindex="-1">

5990Prior to the widespread use of somatic tumor sequencing, somatic <em class="gene-name">

5991MLH1</em>

5992 hypermethylation was thought to be the only major sporadic pathway for a tumor to have MSI-H/MMR-deficient (MMR-D) biology. It was presumed that any MSI-H/MMR-D CRC or endometrial cancer with patterns of MMR deficiency (other than <em class="gene-name">

5993MLH1</em>

5994/<em class="gene-name">

5995PMS2</em>

5996 loss) was due to Lynch syndrome, even if a germline pathogenic variant in an MMR gene could not be identified. However, as IHC is more routinely performed for all CRCs and endometrial cancers, it has become clear that other patterns of MMR deficiency can arise via sporadic mechanisms, typically by somatic biallelic MMR gene inactivation.[<a href="#cit/section_4.315">

5997315</a>

5998] This phenomenon has been labeled Lynch-like syndrome (sometimes called LLS in the literature), although this terminology may cause confusion since this term represents a mechanism of sporadic carcinogenesis, rather than a stand-alone genetic syndrome.</p>

5999<p id="_3503" tabindex="-1">

6000Work from the Ohio Colorectal Cancer Prevention Initiative found that 88.4% of CRCs and 100% of endometrial cancers with unexplained MMR-D statuses (i.e., cancers did not have a germline pathogenic variant in an MMR gene or <em class="gene-name">

6001MLH1</em>

6002 promoter hypermethylation) had somatic biallelic MMR deficiency found on somatic tumor sequencing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.316">

6003316</a>

6004,<a href="#cit/section_4.317">

6005317</a>

6006] In an additional series of MMR-D cancers (mostly CRCs and endometrial cancers) that underwent paired germline and somatic MMR mutation analyses, somatic biallelic genetic alterations were found in 49% of the tumors that lacked causal germline pathogenic variants, <em class="gene-name">

6007MLH1</em>

6008 promoter hypermethylation, and <em class="gene-name">

6009BRAF</em>

6010 V600E mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.318">

6011318</a>

6012]</p>

6013<p id="_3504" tabindex="-1">

6014When CRCs, endometrial cancers, or other tumors have unexplained MMR-deficiency, in which somatic sequencing fails to identify somatic biallelic MMR deficiency, it is possible that a small fraction of these cases could represent occult Lynch syndrome (or other forms of unidentifiable inherited cancer risk). In these cases, it is recommended that patients' clinical and family histories be carefully examined for possible inherited cancer risk. This will help determine if patients and their families will be clinically managed as if they have suspected Lynch syndrome. In these cases, careful scrutiny of any germline MMR gene VUS is also warranted to assess whether these VUSs could harbor pathogenicity. For more information about VUS genetic test results, see the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_316">

6015Value of testing an affected family member first</a>

6016 section in Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling.</p>

6017<p id="_3505" tabindex="-1">

6018Some studies have attempted to define the risk of CRC and other Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated malignancies in cohorts of individuals with Lynch-like syndrome. However, the ability to clinically interpret these data may be limited since these populations presumably include a mix of individuals with sporadic MMR-D cancers and others with inherited cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_4.319">

6019319</a>

6020,<a href="#cit/section_4.320">

6021320</a>

6022]</p>

6023</section>

6024<section id="_3012">

6025<h6 id="_3012_toc">

6026IHC in constitutional mismatch repair deficiency (CMMRD) syndrome</h6>

6027<p id="_3013" tabindex="-1">

6028In contrast with Lynch syndrome (which is defined by the presence of a single, germline, heterozygous, deleterious variant in an MMR gene), rarely, individuals can have deleterious germline variants in both alleles of the same MMR gene. These cases can present with homozygous or compound heterozygous genotypes. This is termed <strong>

6029biallelic mismatch repair deficiency</strong>

6030 (BMMRD) or <strong>

6031constitutional mismatch repair deficiency</strong>

6032 (CMMRD). The likelihood of CMMRD involving homozygous MMR gene pathogenic variants will inevitably be higher among <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460138&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460138&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6033consanguineous</a>

6034 unions. Rates of consanguinity may be higher in rural and geographically and/or culturally isolated populations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.321">

6035321</a>

6036]</p>

6037<p id="_3014" tabindex="-1">

6038Tumor studies yield characteristic abnormalities. In a series of 28 patients with CMMRD,[<a href="#cit/section_4.114">

6039114</a>

6040] 17 brain tumors showed loss of staining for MMR protein in normal stromal cells and in neoplastic cells. This differs from tumors in patients with Lynch syndrome, in which normal staining is retained in nontumor cells. In contrast to this characteristic feature seen with IHC, PCR-based MSI analysis was not reliable, as 20 of 28 tumors from patients with CMMRD were MSS. Essentially all of the MSI-H tumors were colon cancers.</p>

6041<p id="_2807" tabindex="-1">

6042The <em class="gene-name">

6043PMS2</em>

6044 gene is markedly overrepresented in cases of CMMRD. It has been suggested that the presence of homozygosity in other MMR gene variants is a prenatally lethal state, while milder expression of <em class="gene-name">

6045PMS2</em>

6046 variants is consistent with survival when present in both parental alleles.</p>

6047<p id="_3015" tabindex="-1">

6048For more information about CMMRD's clinical phenotype, see the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3105">

6049CMMRD</a>

6050 section.</p>

6051<table id="_3022" class="table-default expandable-container">

6052<caption>

6053Table 10. Hereditary Colorectal Cancer (CRC) Syndromes and Associated Tumor Phenotypes<span class="sup">

6054a</span>

6055</caption>

6056<colgroup>

6057<col width="25.00%">

6058<col width="25.00%">

6059<col width="25.00%">

6060<col width="25.00%">

6061</colgroup>

6062<THead>

6063<tr>

6064<th>

6065Clinical Phenotype</th>

6066<th>

6067Pathogenic Germline Variant in DNA MMR</th>

6068<th>

6069Somatic Inactivation of DNA MMR</th>

6070<th>

6071Tumor Phenotype</th>

6072</tr>

6073</THead>

6086</tr>

6087</TFoot>

6088<tbody>

6102MLH1</em>

6130<td>

6131MSI</td>

6135FCCX</td>

6138<td>

6142</tr>

6143</tbody>

6144</table>

6145</section>

6146<section id="_3090">

6147<h6 id="_3090_toc">

6148Constitutional epimutation</h6>

6149<p id="_2818" tabindex="-1">

6150While somatic hypermethylation of the <em class="gene-name">

6151MLH1</em>

6152 promoter is acquired and not uncommon, examples of <em class="gene-name">

6153MLH1</em>

6154 promoter hypermethylation have been described in the germline and are generally not associated with a stable Mendelian inheritance. This constitutional methylation of MMR genes occurs most often in <em class="gene-name">

6155MLH1</em>

6156 and, to a lesser extent, <em class="gene-name">

6157MSH2</em>

6158 and is termed <em>

6159constitutional <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=717445&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000717445&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6160epimutation</a>

6161</em>

6162.[<a href="#cit/section_4.322">

6163322</a>

6164] A constitutional epimutation (also referred to as a primary epimutation) is an acquired alteration in normal tissue that silences an active gene or activates an inactive gene.[<a href="#cit/section_4.323">

6165323</a>

6166] Such epimutations occur most often in maternal alleles. In some cases all somatic cells appear involved, while in others there is evidence of mosaicism. Tumors in patients with primary epimutations are generally indistinguishable from those otherwise typical of Lynch syndrome germline variant carriers, including age at onset, tumor spectrum, and presence of abnormal MSI and IHC. Since these are not inherited in a Mendelian fashion, antecedent family history of tumors is minimal, and risk to offspring somewhat unpredictable. Epimutations present in a de novo case seem to typically be "erased" in the process of gametogenesis and to not be passed to the next generation. Very rare cases of inherited <em class="gene-name">

6167MLH1</em>

6168 epimutations have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_4.324">

6169324</a>

6170,<a href="#cit/section_4.325">

6171325</a>

6172]</p>

6173<p id="_3083" tabindex="-1">

6174Interpreting molecular alterations in tumors and distinguishing the likely primary epimutation cases from those of sporadic MSI poses significant challenges. Most instances of absence of MLH1 expression are caused by the sporadic hypermethylation of the <em class="gene-name">

6175MLH1</em>

6176 promoter. Rare instances of a de novo constitutional epimutation in <em class="gene-name">

6177MLH1</em>

6178 [<a href="#cit/section_4.326">

6179326</a>

6180] or an inherited germline <em class="gene-name">

6181MLH1</em>

6182 methylation [<a href="#cit/section_4.327">

6183327</a>

6184] add some complexity to the interpretation of MSI associated with absence of MLH1 expression. Akin to sporadic MSI, primary epimutation tumors show methylation of the <em class="gene-name">

6185MLH1</em>

6186 promotor and may show <em class="gene-name">

6187BRAF</em>
