6188 variants as well. As noted above, family history of cancer in such cases tends to be minimal or absent, as in true sporadic MSI. Distinguishing such cases from sporadic cases may call for assaying normal tissue (e.g., blood or normal colon mucosa) for evidence of <em class="gene-name">

6189MLH1</em>

6190 methylation, which will be absent from true sporadic cases and absent from carriers of conventional Lynch syndrome MMR pathogenic variants.</p>

6191<p id="_2913" tabindex="-1">

6192Such <em class="gene-name">

6193MLH1</em>

6194-predominant primary epimutations are to be distinguished from secondary epimutations such as those occurring when <em class="gene-name">

6195MSH2 </em>

6196is methylated as a consequence of inherited variants in the upstream <em class="gene-name">

6197EPCAM</em>

6198 gene. (Refer to the <em class="gene-name">

6199<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1130">

6200EPCAM</a>

6201</em>

6202 section of this summary for more information.)</p>

6203</section>

6204</section>

6205<section id="_1109">

6206<h6 id="_1109_toc">

6207Molecular diagnostic tumor testing to screen for Lynch syndrome in clinical practice</h6>

6208<p id="_3084" tabindex="-1">

6209While many molecular pathology laboratories can assess both MSI and IHC, an approach that uses IHC testing as the initial screen for defective MMR activity has been favored because it is less labor intensive and more cost-effective.[<a href="#cit/section_4.328">

6210328</a>

6211,<a href="#cit/section_4.329">

6212329</a>

6213] Part of this rationale is that the information provided by IHC may target germline genetic testing toward one specific MMR gene (with the exception of loss of MLH1 expression) as opposed to a comprehensive testing strategy of all Lynch syndrome&#8211;related MMR genes that would be directed by the use of MSI alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.275">

6214275</a>

6215,<a href="#cit/section_4.328">

6216328</a>

6217,<a href="#cit/section_4.330">

6218330</a>

6219-<a href="#cit/section_4.333">

6220333</a>

6221] While MSI testing was originally favored in the oncologic evaluation of individuals with CRC for its prognostic and therapeutic implications, screening for Lynch syndrome can be more effectively directed by IHC testing. </p>

6222</section>

6223<section id="_1110">

6224<h6 id="_1110_toc">

6225Universal tumor testing to screen for Lynch syndrome</h6>

6226<p id="_3085" tabindex="-1">

6227Use of MSI and/or IHC testing in all newly diagnosed cases of CRC, regardless of the age at diagnosis or family history of cancer, increases the sensitivity of the initial screen for Lynch syndrome. This approach is more sensitive than existing clinical criteria, as many individuals with Lynch syndrome are diagnosed at older ages (&gt;50 y) and have less striking family histories of CRC than previously appreciated. This universal testing of colorectal (and <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1322">

6228endometrial</a>

6229) tumors using either MSI or IHC testing has been recommended by many professional organizations and is being widely adopted.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

6230122</a>

6231,<a href="#cit/section_4.334">

6232334</a>

6233-<a href="#cit/section_4.337">

6234337</a>

6235]</p>

6236<p id="_910" tabindex="-1">

6237Genetic risk assessment and MMR gene variant testing in individuals with newly diagnosed CRC can lead to improved outcomes for the patient and at-risk family members. Dating back to 2009, the Evaluation of Genomic Applications in Practice and Prevention (EGAPP), a project developed by the Office of Public Health Genomics at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), reported that there was sufficient evidence to recommend offering tumor screening for Lynch syndrome to individuals with newly diagnosed CRC to reduce morbidity and mortality in relatives.[<a href="#cit/section_4.338">

6238338</a>

6239,<a href="#cit/section_4.339">

6240339</a>

6241] At that time, there was insufficient evidence to recommend a specific testing strategy between MSI and IHC.</p>

6242<p id="_2662" tabindex="-1">

6243Several studies have demonstrated the feasibility of universal screening for Lynch syndrome. Initial experience from one institution found that among 1,566 patients screened using MSI and IHC, 44 patients (2.8%) had Lynch syndrome. For each proband, an average of three additional family members were subsequently diagnosed with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.275">

6244275</a>

6245] A subsequent pooled analysis of 10,206 incident CRC patients tested with MSI/IHC as part of four large studies revealed a pathogenic variant detection rate of 3.1%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.340">

6246340</a>

6247] This study compared four strategies for tumor testing for the diagnosis of Lynch syndrome: (1) testing all individuals meeting at least one criterion of the Bethesda guidelines; (2) testing all individuals meeting Jerusalem recommendations;[<a href="#cit/section_4.341">

6248341</a>

6249] (3) testing all individuals with CRC aged 70 years or younger, or older than 70 and meeting at least one criterion of the Bethesda guidelines; and (4) universal testing of all individuals with CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.340">

6250340</a>

6251] Tumor testing with MSI involved panels individualized at each institution and IHC involved testing all four of the DNA MMR genes involved with Lynch syndrome, across all institutions. The strategy of tumor testing in all individuals diagnosed with CRC at age 70 years or younger and testing individuals over age 70 who met one of the revised Bethesda guidelines yielded a sensitivity of 95.1%, a specificity of 95.5%, and a diagnostic yield of 2.1%. This strategy missed 4.9% of Lynch syndrome cases, but 34.8% fewer cases required IHC/MSI testing, and 28.6% fewer cases underwent germline testing than in the universal approach.</p>

6252<p id="_3086" tabindex="-1">

6253The consideration to further stratify the recommendation for molecular tumor testing by age (i.e., 70 y) warrants attention as it influences the cost-effectiveness of universal screening strategy.</p>

6254<p id="_2919" tabindex="-1">

6255Loss of MLH1 and PMS2 due to somatic hypermethylation is not uncommon, and is more frequently detected with increasing age at CRC diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.342">

6256342</a>

6257] Therefore, additional molecular tumor testing including <em class="gene-name">

6258BRAF</em>

6259 and <em class="gene-name">

6260MLH1</em>

6261 hypermethylation testing is recommended in cases in which there is loss of MLH1 and PMS2 expression on IHC, thereby decreasing the number of individuals referred for unnecessary germline genetic testing. A testing strategy including <em class="gene-name">

6262MLH1</em>

6263 hypermethylation analyses in individuals aged 70 years or younger with CRC who had loss of MLH1 on IHC was shown to be cost-effective in a population-based study of 1,117 individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_4.343">

6264343</a>

6265]</p>

6266<p id="_3064" tabindex="-1">

6267Screening individuals with CRC for Lynch syndrome is most often performed in a stepwise fashion based on IHC tumor testing results that evaluate protein expression for the four MMR genes related to Lynch syndrome. One proposed strategy is summarized in <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3125">

6268Figure 6</a>

6269. This framework does not incorporate a germline testing approach that simultaneously evaluates multiple cancer susceptibility genes (multigene [panel] testing), which may be useful in select patient populations. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1112">

6270Multigene [panel] testing</a>

6271 section of this summary for more information.)</p>

6272<figure id="figure_3125" class="image-center-full">

6273<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/789559.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

6274Enlarge</a>

6275<img id="_3125" alt="Flowchart showing a multi-step process for evaluating an individual with colorectal cancer for Lynch syndrome." title="Flowchart showing a multi-step process for evaluating an individual with colorectal cancer for Lynch syndrome." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/789559-750.jpg">

6276<figcaption class="caption-container">

6277Figure 6. A proposed strategy to evaluate individuals with colorectal cancer for Lynch syndrome based on immunohistochemical tumor testing results. Adapted from Geiersbach KB, Samowitz WS. Microsatellite instability and cancer. Arch Pathol Lab Med 135(10):1269-77, 2011.</figcaption>

6278</figure>

6279<p id="_3317" tabindex="-1">

6280Clinicians are increasingly utilizing tumor sequencing to advance therapeutic decisions in a more personalized approach, particularly in patients with metastatic disease. The performance of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=763024&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000763024&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6281next-generation tumor sequencing</a>

6282 (NGS) of CRCs for the detection of Lynch syndrome was compared with existing screening protocols that include MSI testing and IHC staining (with <em class="gene-name">

6283BRAF</em>

6284 p.V600E testing) in 419 CRC cases recruited in a multicenter, population-based study.[<a href="#cit/section_4.344">

6285344</a>

6286] Twelve participants were identified as Lynch syndrome carriers by germline DNA testing and all were correctly identified by tumor sequencing, while MSI plus <em class="gene-name">

6287BRAF</em>

6288 testing and IHC plus <em class="gene-name">

6289BRAF </em>

6290testing missed five and six Lynch syndrome cases, respectively. Tumor sequencing had a higher sensitivity than IHC plus <em class="gene-name">

6291BRAF</em>

6292 testing (100% vs. 89.7%; <em>

6293P</em>

6294 = .04) and MSI plus <em class="gene-name">

6295BRAF</em>

6296 testing (100% vs. 91.4%; <em>

6297P</em>

6298 = .07) while specificity was comparable across all strategies (95.3% for tumor sequencing, 94.6% for IHC plus <em class="gene-name">

6299BRAF</em>

6300, and 94.8% for MSI plus <em class="gene-name">

6301BRAF</em>

6302; <em>

6303P</em>

6304 = not significant). In a validation cohort of 46 known Lynch syndrome pathogenic variant carriers with CRC, tumor sequencing yielded similar results and correctly identified 100% of carriers. In addition, the authors highlighted potential therapeutic implications by reporting on somatic alterations identified by tumor sequencing in 283 participants. This study suggested that tumor sequencing is a highly effective mode of identifying Lynch syndrome; however, the cost-effectiveness of this strategy remains to be determined. </p>

6305<p id="_3372" tabindex="-1">

6306A 2019 retrospective study using data from a large, community-based, integrated U.S. health care system compared the diagnostic performance of age-restricted screening strategies for Lynch syndrome by reflex MMR IHC of all CRCs versus a universal screening strategy without an upper age limit.[<a href="#cit/section_4.345">

6307345</a>

6308] Lynch syndrome identification decreased substantially after age 70 years to age 75 years, with minimal incremental gain after age 80 years. The number of CRCs needed to be screened to identify one Lynch syndrome case was 20 among patients diagnosed with CRC at age 50 years or younger but increased to 208 for those with CRC at age 71 years to age 80 years, and 668 for those diagnosed after age 80 years. </p>

6309<section id="_3091">

6310<h6 id="_3091_toc">

6311Cost-effectiveness of universal tumor screening for Lynch syndrome</h6>

6312<p id="_1248" tabindex="-1">

6313Results are available from a Markov model that incorporated the risks of colorectal, endometrial, and ovarian cancers to estimate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of strategies to identify Lynch syndrome among individuals aged 70 years or younger with newly diagnosed CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.329">

6314329</a>

6315] The strategies incorporated in the model were based on clinical criteria, prediction algorithms, and tumor testing or up-front germline pathogenic variant testing followed by directed screening and risk-reducing surgery. IHC followed by <em class="gene-name">

6316BRAF</em>

6317 pathogenic variant testing was the preferred strategy in this study. An incremental cost-effectiveness ratio of $36,200 per life-year gained resulted from this strategy. In this model, the number of relatives tested (3&#8211;4) per proband was a critical determinant of both effectiveness and cost-effectiveness. These results were similar to earlier analyses conducted by EGAPP which found that the most cost-effective approach was to test all tumors for absence of protein expression of MSH2, MLH1, MSH6, and PMS2 followed by targeted germline testing of <em class="gene-name">

6318MSH2</em>

6319, <em class="gene-name">

6320MLH1</em>

6321, or <em class="gene-name">

6322MSH6</em>

6323 offered depending on which protein was absent. If there was absence of MLH1, testing was offered for <em class="gene-name">

6324BRAF</em>

6325 variant-negative tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.339">

6326339</a>

6327]</p>

6328<p id="_2921" tabindex="-1">

6329NCCN 2022 guidelines support using universal screening on all CRCs to help identify individuals who may have Lynch syndrome. Universal screening can include the following testing methods: IHC testing, MSI testing, comprehensive tumor NGS panel testing, and germline multigene panel testing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

6330122</a>

6331] Universal screening in all individuals irrespective of age was associated with a doubling of incremental cost per life-year saved compared with screening only those younger than 70 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.329">

6332329</a>

6333] The authors of this analysis conclude that screening individuals younger than 70 years appears reasonable, while screening all individuals regardless of age might also be acceptable, depending on willingness to pay.</p>

6334<p id="_2922" tabindex="-1">

6335However, it is important to note that the conclusions from this study were contingent upon the number of at-risk relatives who underwent germline testing (through a process known as <em>

6336<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=791164&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000791164&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6337cascade screening</a>

6338</em>

6339) based on the identification of a germline MMR gene variant in the index case of CRC in the family. In their model, to meet the accepted $50,000 cost-effective threshold, testing a minimum of three to four relatives was necessary.[<a href="#cit/section_4.329">

6340329</a>

6341] This emphasizes the importance of provider-to-patient communication, family communication, and the need to ensure improved uptake of germline testing in Lynch syndrome families with a known causative gene. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_189">

6342Psychosocial Issues in Hereditary Colon Cancer Syndromes</a>

6343 section of this summary for more information about family communication and uptake of genetic testing in families with Lynch syndrome.)</p>

6344<p id="_2930" tabindex="-1">

6345Another study addressed the cost-effectiveness of testing for pathogenic variants in the Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated genes and evaluated 21 screening strategies, including clinical criteria, use of clinical Lynch syndrome prediction models, and molecular tumor testing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.346">

6346346</a>

6347] The model included two steps: (1) measurement of the newly identified number of Lynch syndrome diagnoses; and (2) measurement of the life-years gained as a result of confirming Lynch syndrome in a healthy carrier. Among all of the strategies modeled, screening the proband with a predictive model such as PREMM(1,2,6) followed by IHC for MMR protein expression and germline genetic testing was the best approach, with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio of $35,143 per life-year gained. Germline genetic testing on all probands was the most effective approach, but at a cost of $996,878 per life-year gained. The authors concluded that the initial step of Lynch syndrome screening should utilize a predictive model in the proband, and that both universal testing and general population screening strategies were not cost-effective screening strategies for Lynch syndrome.</p>

6348<p id="_3092" tabindex="-1">

6349Establishment of an upper age limit for universal tumor testing remains controversial. Some experts have endorsed testing only individuals with CRC who are younger than 70 years (reserving testing in individuals &#8805;70 y for only those meeting the revised Bethesda criteria; with this strategy, 5% of carriers would be missed).[<a href="#cit/section_4.347">

6350347</a>

6351] However, others have advocated against an upper age limit for testing given the potential benefit to younger generations via cascade screening and the opportunity for increased surveillance and other prophylactic interventions in individuals found to carry a known familial pathogenic variant.</p>

6352<p id="_3164" tabindex="-1">

6353Another cost-effectiveness analysis was performed using data from 179 consecutive endometrial cancer patients diagnosed at or before age 70 years and screened with MMR IHC and reflex <em class="gene-name">

6354MLH1</em>

6355 promoter hypermethylation, among whom seven Lynch syndrome carriers (3.9%) were identified.[<a href="#cit/section_4.348">

6356348</a>

6357] Only one of the seven Lynch syndrome probands was age 50 years or younger at endometrial cancer diagnosis. The authors calculated that screening women diagnosed with endometrial cancer at age 51 to 70 years resulted in an additional 29.3 life-years gained (on top of the 45.4 life-years gained by screening women diagnosed at age &#8804;50 y), and the incremental cost-effectiveness ratio for screening all diagnoses at age 70 years or younger versus diagnoses at age 50 years or younger was 5,252 euro per life-year gained. Universal tumor-based screening of all women age 70 years or younger was also cost-effective, compared with strategies using the Bethesda guidelines to guide MMR and MSI testing with an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio of 6,668 euro per life-year gained.

6358</p>

6359<p id="_3165" tabindex="-1">

6360The cost-effectiveness of universal tumor testing in both CRC and endometrial cancer is largely driven by the assumption of cascade screening through which other at-risk family members will be identified, tested, and subsequently pursue their own cancer risk reduction.[<a href="#cit/section_4.329">

6361329</a>

6362]</p>

6363<p id="_3093" tabindex="-1">

6364The cost of germline genetic testing continues to decrease with advancements in DNA mutational analyses, including simultaneous testing of multiple germline variants associated with malignancy, through multigene (panel) tests. As a result, additional cost-effective analyses using more updated data related to germline testing will need to be conducted. Multigene (panel) testing may become a more favorable and cost-effective approach in the future.</p>

6365</section>

6366<section id="_3094">

6367<h6 id="_3094_toc">

6368Considerations and limitations related to universal tumor testing for Lynch syndrome</h6>

6369<p id="_3095" tabindex="-1">

6370While universal screening continues to be adopted nationally, there is significant variability in the uptake and approach to molecular testing. A 2011 survey of the National Society of Genetic Counselors revealed that more than 25% of respondents had some form of universal screening implemented at their center. Tumor screening methods varied; 34 (64.2%) of 53 centers started with IHC, 11 (20.8%) of 53 centers started with MSI testing, and 8 (15.1%) of 53 centers performed both tests on newly diagnosed colorectal tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.349">

6371349</a>

6372] A 2012 survey suggested that some form of universal screening was being routinely performed at 71% of the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Comprehensive Cancer Centers, but utilization dropped to 15% among a random sample of community hospital cancer programs.[<a href="#cit/section_4.350">

6373350</a>

6374]</p>

6375<p id="_2955" tabindex="-1">

6376Because adherence to universal screening for Lynch syndrome may be poor (many patients are not referred for genetic evaluation and testing), a prospective quality improvement study utilizing the Six Sigma conceptual framework was conducted to improve the implementation of universal genetic screening among young patients with CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.351">

6377351</a>

6378] The main aim of the study was to increase the proportion of tumor studies for deficient MMR among patients with early-onset CRC (aged 18&#8211;50 y). The intervention involved patient and provider education, in addition to visual cues provided at point of care. The study demonstrated an improvement of 21.5% in the rate of IHC testing in young adults with CRC over the 12-month postintervention period compared with the preintervention period.</p>

6379<p id="_2871" tabindex="-1">

6380Studies reporting uptake of genetic testing for Lynch syndrome have largely focused on individuals and families who were selected for potential risk of Lynch syndrome based on family history or clinical characteristics. While universal tumor screening is increasingly being adopted to identify newly diagnosed patients who may have a germline variant, few studies have examined the uptake of genetic testing after universal tumor testing. An important implication of universal screening for Lynch syndrome is that it does not result in automatic germline testing in appropriate individuals. In the clinical setting, more follow-up by health care teams to facilitate referral to genetic counseling for patients with abnormal tumor screening results may improve completion of genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.352">

6381352</a>

6382] Higher levels of patient completion of genetic testing after abnormal tumor screening may be associated with having genetic counselors involved in this process to disclose screen-positive results, provide counseling after tumor testing, or facilitate referrals.[<a href="#cit/section_4.353">

6383353</a>

6384]</p>

6385<p id="_2667" tabindex="-1">

6386Subsequent genetic counseling requires coordination between the pathologist, the referring surgeon or oncologist, and a cancer genetics service. As an illustration, a population-based screening study found that only 54% of patients with an IHC-deficient tumor (that was <em class="gene-name">

6387BRAF</em>

6388 pathogenic variant&#8211;negative) ultimately consented to and proceeded with germline MMR testing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.354">

6389354</a>

6390] One institution found 21 pathogenic variants among 1,100 patients who underwent routine MSI and IHC testing after a diagnosis of CRC. This study found markedly increased uptake of genetic counseling and germline MMR gene testing when both the surgeon and a genetic counselor received a copy of abnormal MSI/IHC results, especially when the genetic counselor played an active role in patient follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_4.352">

6391352</a>

6392]</p>

6393<p id="_2550" tabindex="-1">

6394In contrast to tumor testing, which is commonly performed without a patient's prior knowledge, germline genetic testing, such as germline testing for MMR pathogenic variants, generally includes genetic counseling and requires patient permission before it is performed. A cross-sectional survey of U.S. cancer programs (20 NCI&#8211;designated Comprehensive Cancer Centers and 49 community hospital cancer programs) found that, of those that performed MSI and/or IHC testing as part of standard pathologic evaluation at the time of colon cancer diagnosis in all or select cases, none required written <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44677&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044677&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6395informed consent</a>

6396 before tumor testing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.350">

6397350</a>

6398]</p>

6399</section>

6400<section id="_1322">

6401<h6 id="_1322_toc">

6402Diagnostic strategies for all individuals diagnosed with endometrial cancer</h6>

6403<p id="_3096" tabindex="-1">

6404Given the increased prevalence of endometrial cancer among carriers of MMR pathogenic variants, there is a growing consensus to screen patients with endometrial cancer for Lynch syndrome.</p>

6405<p id="_2988" tabindex="-1">

6406In a study that examined the feasibility and desirability of performing tumor screening of all endometrial cancers, regardless of age at diagnosis or family history of cancer, at least 2.3% (95% CI, 1.3%&#8211;4.0%) of newly diagnosed patients had Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.355">

6407355</a>

6408,<a href="#cit/section_4.356">

6409356</a>

6410] Eight of thirteen cases diagnosed with Lynch syndrome were aged 50 years or older, eight did not meet published family history criteria for Lynch syndrome, and two would have been missed by MSI testing. Because of the increased prevalence of endometrial cancer and the results of this study, the authors support universal screening of endometrial cancers for Lynch syndrome. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1105">

6411IHC</a>

6412 section of this summary for more information about performing IHC for MMR protein expression.) </p>

6413<p id="_3166" tabindex="-1">

6414Another smaller study of 242 consecutive endometrial cases demonstrated a 4.5% (11/242) prevalence of MMR-deficient cases lacking somatic <em class="gene-name">

6415MLH1</em>

6416 promoter hypermethylation, including four cases (1.7%) with germline MMR mutations, four cases (1.7%) with two somatic MMR alterations on NGS, and two cases (0.8%) with otherwise unexplained MMR-deficiency.[<a href="#cit/section_4.357">

6417357</a>

6418] Such findings demonstrate that universal MMR tumor screening of endometrial cancers will identify individuals with underlying Lynch syndrome and a spectrum of non-Lynch syndrome cases with various forms of MMR-deficiency.</p>

6419<p id="_3263" tabindex="-1">

6420Another study prospectively evaluated universal IHC-based screening of both CRC and endometrial cancer cases, irrespective of age at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.358">

6421358</a>

6422] In both the tertiary and community settings, 1,290 CRC and 484 endometrial cancer cases were screened between 2011 and 2013. The study additionally calculated PREMM(1,2,6) and PREMM5 scores for all patients in whom a germline pathogenic variant was detected. Abnormal staining was observed in 22% of endometrial cancers and 18.8% of CRCs. After excluding those cases felt to be sporadic because of the presence of <em class="gene-name">

6423BRAF</em>

6424 and/or hypermethylation of <em class="gene-name">

6425MLH1</em>

6426, 10.8 % of patients with CRC and 6.6% of patients with endometrial cancer were referred for genetic counseling. Lynch syndrome was diagnosed in 24 individuals (1.4%), 66% of whom had CRC. The overall detection rate of Lynch syndrome was 1.7% in endometrial cancer cases and 1.2% in CRC cases. Among Amsterdam criteria, Bethesda guidelines, PREMM(1,2,6), and PREMM5, the best performing model was PREMM5, which would have detected 82% of cases identified by universal screening.</p>

6427<p id="_1323" tabindex="-1">

6428The cost-effectiveness of tumor testing of women diagnosed with endometrial cancer was examined in a model-based simulation study and included IHC testing in the following scenarios: (1) diagnosis before age 50 years; (2) diagnosis before age 60 years; (3) any age at diagnosis with the presence of an FDR with any Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated cancer; and (4) all cases irrespective of diagnosis age and family history. Women fulfilling Amsterdam II criteria or those diagnosed before age 50 years with at least one FDR with any Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated cancer were directly referred for genetic counseling and genetic testing without IHC testing. A strategy of IHC testing for MMR protein expression in all patients with endometrial cancer and an FDR with any Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated cancer was reported to be cost-effective in the detection of Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.359">

6429359</a>

6430] This strategy had an incremental cost ratio of $9,126 per life-year gained relative to the least-costly strategy, which was genetic testing on all women diagnosed with endometrial cancer before age 50 years with at least one FDR with a Lynch syndrome&#8211;related cancer. Life expectancy was highest with the most inclusive testing strategy of IHC testing of all women with endometrial cancer irrespective of age at diagnosis or family history but had the least favorable incremental cost ratio of $648,494 per life-year gained. NCCN recommends tumor testing with IHC and/or MSI, a comprehensive tumor NGS panel, or germline multigene (panel) testing of all endometrial cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

6431122</a>

6432] Despite these recommendations, the uptake of universal screening in women newly diagnosed with endometrial cancer is unclear.</p>

6433<p id="_2933" tabindex="-1">

6434(Refer to the PDQ summary on <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq">

6435Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers</a>

6436 for more information about endometrial cancer as a component of Lynch syndrome.)</p>

6437</section>

6438<section id="_3330">

6439<h6 id="_3330_toc">

6440MSI in all cancers</h6>

6441<p id="_3331" tabindex="-1">

6442Use of MSI testing across all tumor types has become an important screening tool to select cases that may have a favorable response to immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy. These results may potentially be used to screen for Lynch syndrome in tumors other than CRC. A study evaluated MSI across a wide variety of malignancies and evaluated its use as a potential means to identify Lynch syndrome, regardless of tumor type.[<a href="#cit/section_4.360">

6443360</a>

6444] In a study of more than 15,000 patients with more than 50 types of cancers evaluated in a single-center study, data on well-annotated tumor and matched normal DNA sequencing results with paired germline MMR gene testing, were used to determine MSI status. MSI was determined using a software tool that reports the percentage of unstable microsatellites as a score from paired tumor-normal genome sequencing data and allows for comprehensive investigation of MSI sites simultaneously. The approach used has been reported to be more sensitive across cancers not typically screened for MMR-deficiency (dMMR) than MSI testing of five mononucleotide microsatellite foci using PCR.[<a href="#cit/section_4.361">

6445361</a>

6446] CRC and endometrial cancer comprised the majority of cancers with MSI-H in this study, but 38% (125 of 326) of MSI-H tumors and more than 90% of those with intermediate-level MSI were other cancer types. Germline testing confirmed a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome in 16.3% and 1.9% of tumors with MSI-H and intermediate-level MSI, respectively, in addition to 0.3% of cases that lacked MSI. Importantly, half of all Lynch syndrome carriers with MSI-H/intermediate tumors had primary cancers other than CRC or endometrial cancer, with many malignancies not associated with Lynch syndrome. Among those individuals with a noncanonical Lynch syndrome cancer, nearly half failed to meet clinical criteria for Lynch syndrome testing on the basis of their cancer diagnosis or family cancer history. Furthermore, intermediate-level MSI and MSS phenotypes were most often observed in cancers not classically related to Lynch syndrome and in individuals with germline <em class="gene-name">

6447PMS2</em>

6448 variants. This study supports other findings related to the variable phenotypic expression of Lynch syndrome on the basis of the altered MMR gene and its broad constellation of associated malignancies that make it difficult to be identified by clinical criteria alone.

6449In addition, the investigators further analyzed a unique gene variant signature in every tumor and correlated results to the observed MSI phenotype and germline MMR status to provide some indirect data on whether a gene variant carrier&#8217;s cancer was caused by Lynch syndrome and MMR deficiency or possibly an incidental finding. This is pertinent in evaluating those cancers whose association with Lynch syndrome is unclear and debatable, such as breast and prostate cancer. The authors&#8217; finding that none of the breast cancer patients with Lynch syndrome in this very large cohort had tumors with MSI lends support to the hypothesis that these individuals&#8217; germline MMR gene variants may simply be incidental findings and not etiologic to their cancer diagnosis.

6450</p>

6451</section>

6452</section>

6453<section id="_3097">

6454<h6 id="_3097_toc">

6455Germline genetic testing</h6>

6456<p id="_3087" tabindex="-1">

6457Genetic testing for germline pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

6458MLH1</em>

6459, <em class="gene-name">

6460MSH2</em>

6461, <em class="gene-name">

6462MSH6</em>

6463, <em class="gene-name">

6464PMS2</em>

6465, and <em class="gene-name">

6466EPCAM</em>

6467 can help formulate appropriate intervention strategies for the affected variant-positive individual and at-risk family members, many of whom may be unaffected by cancer.</p>

6468<p id="_1021" tabindex="-1">

6469If a pathogenic variant is identified in an affected person, then testing for that same

6470pathogenic variant should be offered to all at-risk family members. At-risk relatives who test negative for the identified pathogenic variant in the family are not at increased risk of CRC or other Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated malignancies and can follow surveillance recommendations applicable to the general population. Family members who carry the familial pathogenic variant are referred to surveillance and management guidelines for Lynch syndrome. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1142">

6471Management of Lynch syndrome</a>

6472 section of this summary for more information.)</p>

6473<p id="_1045" tabindex="-1">

6474If no pathogenic variant is identified in the affected family member, then testing is considered negative for Lynch syndrome in that individual. With advances made in DNA sequencing technologies, it is unlikely that current gene testing is not sensitive enough to detect a pathogenic variant in the genes tested. Advances in testing, including the common use of NGS by most commercial testing laboratories have improved upon the detection of certain alterations such as large deletions or genomic rearrangements as well as the presence of a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=775793&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000775793&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6475pseudogene</a>

6476 <em class="gene-name">

6477PMSCL</em>

6478 in <em class="gene-name">

6479PMS2</em>

6480.</p>

6481<p id="_1022" tabindex="-1">

6482Possible reasons why a pathogenic variant may not be detected include the following: </p>

6483<div class="pdq-content-list">

6484<ul id="_3126">

6485<li>

6486The family could have a variant in a yet-unidentified gene that causes Lynch syndrome or a predisposition to colon cancer.</li>

6487<li>

6488The individual tested in the family may have

6489developed colon cancer through a nongenetic mechanism (i.e., it is a sporadic

6490case also known as a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=538227&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000538227&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6491phenocopy</a>

6492), while the other cases in the family are really the result of a germline

6493variant. If this scenario is suspected, testing another affected individual who has had a Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated cancer is recommended.</li>

6494<li>

6495In cases in which a CRC tumor displayed MSI and/or abnormal IHC, but no germline pathogenic variant was detected, biallelic somatic mutations may be the resulting etiology. These are sometimes, confusingly, called Lynch-like syndrome cases, even though they are typically not considered to be familial.</li>

6496</ul>

6497</div>

6498<p id="_3129" tabindex="-1">

6499Failure to detect a pathogenic variant could mean that the family

6500truly is not at genetic risk despite a clinical presentation that suggests

6501a genetic basis (e.g., the patient may have biallelic somatic mutations in an MMR gene). If no variant can be identified in an affected family

6502member, testing should not be offered to at-risk members because results would be uninformative for the relatives. They would remain at

6503increased risk of CRC by virtue of their family history and

6504should continue with recommended intensive screening.</p>

6505<p id="_3127" tabindex="-1">

6506(Refer to the

6507<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1142">

6508Management of Lynch syndrome</a>

6509 section of this summary for more information.)</p>

6510</section>

6511<section id="_1112">

6512<h6 id="_1112_toc">

6513Multigene (panel) testing</h6>

6514<p id="_3088" tabindex="-1">

6515 Germline mutation analysis of <em class="gene-name">

6516MLH1</em>

6517, <em class="gene-name">

6518MSH2</em>

6519 (including <em class="gene-name">

6520EPCAM</em>

6521), <em class="gene-name">

6522MSH6</em>

6523, and <em class="gene-name">

6524PMS2</em>

6525 may be considered in instances in which tumor tissue is not available from individuals to test for MSI and/or MMR protein IHC. This approach has become less expensive with the advent of multigene (panel) testing, which is now offered by several clinical laboratories at a cost that may be comparable to single-gene testing. The cost of multigene testing may also approach the cost of tumor screening and may prove to be a cost-effective approach in individuals affected by CRC. At present, multigene tests are not routinely recommended for universal screening for Lynch syndrome among all newly diagnosed CRC patients, but they may be very useful in select populations, such as those with early-onset CRC [<a href="#cit/section_4.362">

6526362</a>

6527] or from familial, high-risk clinic-based populations. It is also important to note that pathogenic variants may be detected in other cancer-associated genes beyond Lynch syndrome. In a study of 1,112 individuals who met NCCN criteria for Lynch syndrome testing and who underwent multigene testing with a 25-gene panel, as expected, 114 individuals (9.0%) were found to have pathogenic variants in MMR genes; however, 71 individuals (5.6%) were found to have a pathogenic variant in non-Lynch syndrome cancer predisposition genes, such as <em class="gene-name">

6528BRCA1</em>

6529, <em class="gene-name">

6530BRCA2</em>

6531, <em class="gene-name">

6532APC</em>

6533, <em class="gene-name">

6534MUTYH</em>

6535 (biallelic), and <em class="gene-name">

6536STK11</em>

6537. Lastly, multigene tests yield a high proportion of VUS. In the aforementioned study, a total of 479 patients (38%) had one or more VUS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.363">

6538363</a>

6539]</p>

6540<p id="_2934" tabindex="-1">

6541Individuals with early-onset CRC have been shown to have a high frequency and wide spectrum of germline pathogenic variants, indicating that panel testing in this population may be beneficial. In a study of 450 patients with early-onset CRC (mean age at diagnosis, 42.5 y) and a family history including at least one FDR with colon, endometrial, breast, ovarian, and/or pancreatic cancer, 75 germline pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants were identified in 72 patients (16%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.362">

6542362</a>

6543] The spectrum of variants identified included Lynch syndrome and non-Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated genes, including several genes that have not traditionally been associated with CRC (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

6544BRCA1</em>

6545/<em class="gene-name">

6546BRCA2</em>

6547, <em class="gene-name">

6548ATM</em>

6549, <em class="gene-name">

6550CHEK2</em>

6551, <em class="gene-name">

6552PALB2</em>

6553, and <em class="gene-name">

6554CDKN2A</em>

6555). Given the high frequency and variety of hereditary cancer syndromes identified, the authors suggested that multigene testing in this population may be warranted. Similarly, another smaller single-institution analysis of 151 individuals with CRC identified pathogenic germline variants in 9.9% of individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_4.364">

6556364</a>

6557] </p>

6558<p id="_3098" tabindex="-1">

6559Multigene testing has also been examined in a larger study of 1,058 individuals with CRC who were unselected for age at diagnosis, personal or family history, or MSI/MMR test results.[<a href="#cit/section_4.365">

6560365</a>

6561] Germline pathogenic variants in cancer susceptibility genes were identified in 105 individuals (9.9%). While 33 individuals (3.1%) carried pathogenic variants in Lynch syndrome genes, 74 (7.0%) had pathogenic variants in non-Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated genes, including <em class="gene-name">

6562APC</em>

6563, <em class="gene-name">

6564MUTYH</em>

6565, <em class="gene-name">

6566BRCA1/<em class="gene-name">

6567BRCA2</em>

6568</em>

6569, <em class="gene-name">

6570PALB2</em>

6571, <em class="gene-name">

6572CDKN2A</em>

6573, <em class="gene-name">

6574TP53</em>

6575, and <em class="gene-name">

6576CHEK2</em>

6577. These data illustrate the breadth of variants that may be identified in unselected CRC patients; thus, use of a comprehensive multigene test may be warranted.</p>

6578<p id="_3137" tabindex="-1">

6579A 2017 study examined the frequency of pathogenic Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated gene variants in individuals undergoing multigene testing at a single commercial United States laboratory between 2012 and 2015, and reported on the characteristics of those carriers identified with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.366">

6580366</a>

6581] The study reports on the largest cohort of individuals tested through multigene testing to date; data was reported on 34,980 individuals who had undergone various multigene panel tests that included the MMR and <em class="gene-name">

6582EPCAM</em>

6583 genes, where the indication for testing was not limited to Lynch syndrome. A total of 618 pathogenic variants were identified in 612 individuals (1.7%) and analyses were conducted on 579 subjects (after exclusion of 33 individuals who had a Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated variant and a second MMR variant or other pathogenic alteration in another cancer predisposition gene). The majority of carriers were affected by cancer, including non-Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated malignancies, where breast cancer was most frequently reported (124/423, 23.5%). <em class="gene-name">

6584MSH6</em>

6585 variants were most prevalent (29.3%), followed by <em class="gene-name">

6586PMS2</em>

6587 (24.2%), <em class="gene-name">

6588MSH2</em>

6589 (23.7%), <em class="gene-name">

6590MLH1</em>

6591 (21.6%), and <em class="gene-name">

6592EPCAM</em>

6593 (1.2%). This finding differs from previous data where <em class="gene-name">

6594MSH2</em>

6595 and <em class="gene-name">

6596MLH1</em>

6597 variants were more prevalent, as individuals were more often selected for Lynch syndrome&#8211;specific testing due to a personal and/or family history of CRC.</p>

6598<p id="_3138" tabindex="-1">

6599The study reports on genotype-phenotype correlations on 528 Lynch syndrome carriers, the majority of whom had CRC (186, 35.2%) and endometrial cancer (136, 25.8%), followed by breast cancer (124, 23.5%) and ovarian cancer (74, 14%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.366">

6600366</a>

6601] One hundred forty-five carriers presented with breast or ovarian cancer as their sentinel tumor and did not carry a prior diagnosis of CRC or endometrial cancer prior to the time of multigene testing. When examining MMR gene variant distribution among tumor-specific subgroups, a higher frequency of <em class="gene-name">

6602MSH6</em>

6603 and <em class="gene-name">

6604PMS2</em>

6605 variants were detected in carriers with breast cancer only than <em class="gene-name">

6606MLH1</em>

6607 and <em class="gene-name">

6608MSH2</em>

6609, where the latter pathogenic variants were more frequent in subjects with CRC only. For patients with breast cancer only, the frequency of <em class="gene-name">

6610PMS2</em>

6611 gene variants was significantly higher than population estimates, which was not the case for <em class="gene-name">

6612MLH1</em>

6613, <em class="gene-name">

6614MSH2</em>

6615, or <em class="gene-name">

6616MSH6</em>

6617. A comparable retrospective study reported similar findings. Standardized incidence ratios (SIRs) of breast cancer were calculated by comparing observed breast cancer frequencies in a population of 423 women with pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants in MMR genes with those in the general population. The authors reported a statistically significant age-standardized risk of breast cancer for <em class="gene-name">

6618MSH6</em>

6619 carriers (SIR = 2.11; 95% CI, 1.56&#8211;2.86) and <em class="gene-name">

6620PMS2</em>

6621 carriers (SIR = 2.92; 95% CI, 2.17&#8211;3.92).[<a href="#cit/section_4.367">

6622367</a>

6623] A critical limitation of both of these studies was the excess of breast cancer cases in the overall referral population as well as the known high background population prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

6624MSH6</em>

6625 and <em class="gene-name">

6626PMS2</em>

6627 germline pathogenic variants. </p>

6628<p id="_3139" tabindex="-1">

6629Clinical criteria for the identification of Lynch syndrome, including the Amsterdam criteria, revised Bethesda guidelines, or the PREMM(1,2,6) risk prediction model, would have failed to identify 27.3% of Lynch syndrome carriers in this study.[<a href="#cit/section_4.366">

6630366</a>

6631] Given the increased prevalence of breast and ovarian cancers, 58.9% met the NCCN guidelines for <em class="gene-name">

6632BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

6633 testing and of these, 36.7% also met NCCN guidelines for Lynch syndrome testing. Lastly, there were limited data on tumor testing results, available only on 18.8% of pathogenic variant carriers, where results were often discordant with the altered gene, which was most often reported in <em class="gene-name">

6634MSH6</em>

6635 and <em class="gene-name">

6636PMS2</em>

6637 carriers. Results of this study support the use of multigene testing for Lynch syndrome and further study of the respective cancer risks, as current testing strategies limit identification of Lynch syndrome carriers and associated malignancies.</p>

6638<p id="_3031" tabindex="-1">

6639Lastly, germline MMR genes have been detected unexpectedly among individuals undergoing multigene testing for cancers not commonly associated with Lynch syndrome, such as breast and prostate cancer. As a result, the cancer spectrum associated with Lynch syndrome may be wider than previously appreciated. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2989">

6640Breast cancer</a>

6641 and <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2990">

6642Prostate cancer</a>

6643 sections of this summary and the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-genetics-pdq">

6644Genetics of Prostate Cancer</a>

6645 summary for more information.)</p>

6646<p id="_3099" tabindex="-1">

6647(Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_1320">

6648Multigene [panel] testing</a>

6649 section in the PDQ summary on <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq">

6650Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling</a>

6651 for more information about multigene testing, including genetic education and counseling considerations, and research examining the use of multigene testing.)</p>

6652</section>

6653<section id="_1134">

6654<h6 id="_1134_toc">

6655Cost-effectiveness of multigene (panel) testing</h6>

6656<p id="_2849" tabindex="-1">

6657As genetic testing becomes routine rather than the exception, questions regarding the cost of testing are inevitable. Historically, a cost-effectiveness ratio of $50,000 per quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) has been utilized as the benchmark for good value for care.[<a href="#cit/section_4.368">

6658368</a>

6659]

6660 Over time it has been suggested that this threshold is too low and that other thresholds such as $100,000 or $150,000 be utilized.[<a href="#cit/section_4.368">

6661368</a>

6662]</p>

6663<p id="_2850" tabindex="-1">

6664A 2015 study evaluated the cost-effectiveness of multigene testing for CRC and polyposis syndromes in patients referred to a cancer genetics clinic.[<a href="#cit/section_4.369">

6665369</a>

6666] These authors developed a decision model to estimate the immediate and downstream costs for patients referred for evaluation and of CRC surveillance in family members identified as carriers of pathogenic variants. The costs were estimated on the basis of published models from the CDC and from an academic molecular genetics laboratory. They classified the syndromes on the basis of inheritance pattern and penetrance of CRC. Four custom panels were compared with the standard of care. The four panels tested for (1) Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated genes only (<em class="gene-name">

6667MLH1</em>

6668,

6669<em class="gene-name">

6670MSH2</em>

6671,

6672<em class="gene-name">

6673MSH6</em>

6674,

6675<em class="gene-name">

6676PMS2</em>

6677,

6678and

6679<em class="gene-name">

6680EPCAM</em>

6681); (2) genes in panel 1 and additional genes associated with autosomal dominant inheritance and high CRC penetrance (<em class="gene-name">

6682APC</em>

6683, <em class="gene-name">

6684BMPR1A</em>

6685, <em class="gene-name">

6686SMAD4</em>

6687, and <em class="gene-name">

6688STK11</em>

6689); (3) genes in panels 1 and 2 and those associated with autosomal recessive inheritance with high CRC penetrance (<em class="gene-name">

6690MUTYH</em>

6691); or (4) all genes in the first three panels and those associated with autosomal dominant conditions with low penetrance (<em class="gene-name">

6692PTEN</em>

6693, <em class="gene-name">

6694TP53</em>

6695, <em class="gene-name">

6696CDH1</em>

6697, <em class="gene-name">

6698GALNT12</em>

6699, <em class="gene-name">

6700POLE</em>

6701, <em class="gene-name">

6702POLD1</em>

6703, <em class="gene-name">

6704GREM1</em>

6705, <em class="gene-name">

6706AKT1</em>

6707, and <em class="gene-name">

6708PIK3CA</em>

6709). The respective costs were as follows: panel 1, $144,235 per QALY; panel 2, $37,467 per QALY; panel 3, $36,500 per QALY; and panel 4, $77,300 per QALY when compared with panel 3. The authors concluded that the use of an NGS multigene test that includes highly penetrant CRC and polyposis syndromes and Lynch syndrome cancer genes was the approach most likely to provide clinically meaningful results in a cost-effective fashion. </p>

6710<p id="_3100" tabindex="-1">

6711The cost of germline genetic testing continues to decrease with advancements in technology since the time this model analysis was conducted; additional studies are needed to continue to assess the cost-effectiveness of this testing approach.</p>

6712</section>

6713</section>

6714</section>

6715<section id="_1113">

6716<h4 id="_1113_toc">

6717Prevalence, clinical manifestations, and cancer risks associated with Lynch syndrome</h4>

6718<p id="_2557" tabindex="-1">

6719Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by an early age of onset of CRC, excess synchronous and metachronous colorectal neoplasms, right-sided predominance, and extracolonic tumors, notably endometrial cancer. Lynch syndrome is caused by pathogenic variants in the DNA MMR genes, namely <em class="gene-name">

6720MLH1</em>

6721 (mutL homolog 1) on chromosome 3p21;[<a href="#cit/section_4.370">

6722370</a>

6723,<a href="#cit/section_4.371">

6724371</a>

6725] <em class="gene-name">

6726MSH2</em>

6727 (mutS homolog 2) on

6728chromosome 2p22-21;[<a href="#cit/section_4.372">

6729372</a>

6730,<a href="#cit/section_4.373">

6731373</a>

6732] <em class="gene-name">

6733MSH6</em>

6734 on chromosome 2p16;[<a href="#cit/section_4.374">

6735374</a>

6736]

6737and <em class="gene-name">

6738PMS2</em>

6739 (postmeiotic segregation 2) on chromosome 7p22.[<a href="#cit/section_4.370">

6740370</a>

6741-<a href="#cit/section_4.373">

6742373</a>

6743,<a href="#cit/section_4.375">

6744375</a>

6745-<a href="#cit/section_4.378">

6746378</a>

6747] The function of these genes is to maintain the fidelity of DNA during replication. Lynch syndrome is also associated with pathogenic variants of the <em class="gene-name">

6748EPCAM</em>

6749 (epithelial cellular adhesion molecule, formerly known as <em class="gene-name">

6750TACSTD1</em>

6751) gene on chromosome 2p21, which causes epigenetic silencing of <em class="gene-name">

6752MSH2</em>

6753, located immediately downstream of this gene.[<a href="#cit/section_4.379">

6754379</a>

6755,<a href="#cit/section_4.380">

6756380</a>

6757]</p>

6758<p id="_2935" tabindex="-1">

6759Lynch syndrome accounts for about 3% of all newly diagnosed cases of CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.328">

6760328</a>

6761] In earlier studies, the average age of CRC diagnosis in Lynch syndrome pathogenic variant carriers was as young as 44 to 52 years. [<a href="#cit/section_4.275">

6762275</a>

6763,<a href="#cit/section_4.328">

6764328</a>

6765,<a href="#cit/section_4.381">

6766381</a>

6767] In contrast, from 2015 to 2019, the median age of CRC diagnosis was 66 years in individuals with sporadic CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.382">

6768382</a>

6769] In subsequent studies that corrected for ascertainment bias to determine cancer-related risk estimates and genotype-phenotype correlations, the average age at CRC diagnosis was 61 years among Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated pathogenic variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.383">

6770383</a>

6771]</p>

6772<p id="_2936" tabindex="-1">

6773Original reports related to overall and gene-specific prevalence estimates in Lynch syndrome relied heavily on retrospective data from familial cancer registries worldwide. Earlier risk estimates of CRC (and endometrial cancer) reported in Lynch syndrome were subject to ascertainment bias and overestimation, given that data were derived largely from familial cancer registries and cases were often ascertained based on young-onset CRC or an increased number of CRC cases among relatives. Correction of these cancer risk estimates has been made possible through modified <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=712689&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000712689&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6774segregation analyses</a>

6775, where statistical methodology provides more accurate estimates and adjusts for ascertainment bias. Conversely, risk estimates related to extracolonic malignancies, with the exception of endometrial cancer, may be prone to underestimation because many families may have underreported these cancers in relatives, and Lynch syndrome&#8211;related tumors may have occurred later in life.</p>

6776<p id="_2937" tabindex="-1">

6777In a large population-based study of 5,744 CRC cases who were recruited irrespective of family cancer history from the United States, Australia, and Canada, it was estimated that 1 in 279 individuals in the population carry an MMR pathogenic variant associated with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.384">

6778384</a>

6779]</p>

6780<p id="_2915" tabindex="-1">

6781In another population-based study of 450 individuals with CRC but limited to young onset with diagnoses occurring before age 50 years, germline pathogenic variants were identified in 72 of 450 individuals (16%), as detected by multigene (panel) testing for inherited cancer susceptibility genes. As expected, the majority of identified variants were in genes known to be associated with CRC, predominantly Lynch syndrome (37 of 72 patients, 51.4%). However, 13 of 72 patients (18.1%) had pathogenic variants

6782in genes not traditionally associated with CRC, including but not limited to <em class="gene-name">

6783BRCA1</em>

6784/<em class="gene-name">

6785BRCA2</em>

6786, which accounted for 8% of the identified variants. Because of the high frequency and wide variety of pathogenic variants identified, the authors suggested consideration of multigene testing for all individuals with early-onset CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.362">

6787362</a>

6788]</p>

6789<section id="_2938">

6790<h5 id="_2938_toc">

6791Gene-specific considerations and associated CRC risk</h5>

6792<p id="_2939" tabindex="-1">

6793The <em class="gene-name">

6794MLH1</em>

6795 and <em class="gene-name">

6796MSH2</em>

6797 genes were originally thought to account for most pathogenic variants of the MMR genes found in Lynch syndrome. However, the prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

6798MSH6</em>

6799 and <em class="gene-name">

6800PMS2</em>

6801 pathogenic variants has been increasing with improved DNA mutational analyses and universal tumor screening of all CRCs.[<a href="#cit/section_4.384">

6802384</a>

6803] <em class="gene-name">

6804MSH6</em>

6805 and <em class="gene-name">

6806PMS2</em>

6807 variants may be more common in unselected cases of CRC (and endometrial cancer),[<a href="#cit/section_4.384">

6808384</a>

6809] compared with <em class="gene-name">

6810MLH1</em>

6811 and <em class="gene-name">

6812MSH2</em>

6813 variants which were more commonly identified in individuals from high-risk CRC clinics.[<a href="#cit/section_4.385">

6814385</a>

6815,<a href="#cit/section_4.386">

6816386</a>

6817] A series of papers from the Prospective Lynch Syndrome Database (PLSD) describe the cancer outcomes in patients prospectively followed by (mainly European) registries. Among the key findings was a low risk of CRC in <em class="gene-name">

6818PMS2</em>

6819 carriers, especially among those below age 50 years, leading the authors to conclude that surveillance in <em class="gene-name">

6820PMS2</em>

6821 carriers could safely be scaled back. A later initiation of colonoscopy and perhaps at longer intervals, is gradually being adopted in light of these findings.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

6822122</a>

6823,<a href="#cit/section_4.181">

6824181</a>

6825,<a href="#cit/section_4.387">

6826387</a>

6827] The relative risk of extracolonic cancers in <em class="gene-name">

6828PMS2</em>

6829 carriers was no greater or only slightly greater than population expectations, which led the authors to generally recommend against any extracolonic surveillance in <em class="gene-name">

6830PMS2</em>

6831 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.388">

6832388</a>

6833] The approach to screening individuals with <em class="gene-name">

6834PMS2</em>

6835 pathogenic variants, and to a lesser extent those with <em class="gene-name">

6836MSH6</em>

6837 pathogenic variants, are matters of ongoing clinical debate. </p>

6838<section id="_1114">

6839<h6 id="_1114_toc">

6840<em class="gene-name">

6841MLH1</em>

6842</h6>

6843<p id="_2909" tabindex="-1">

6844In early studies, the prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

6845MLH1</em>

6846 pathogenic variants in individuals with Lynch syndrome was reported to be between 41.7% [<a href="#cit/section_4.389">

6847389</a>

6848] and 50%,[<a href="#cit/section_4.390">

6849390</a>

6850] making <em class="gene-name">

6851MLH1</em>

6852 the most commonly altered MMR gene in Lynch syndrome families. It was not until a report on the population-based prevalence of Lynch syndrome that the <em class="gene-name">

6853MLH1</em>

6854 pathogenic variant was estimated to be 1 in 1,946, ranking third after <em class="gene-name">

6855PMS2</em>

6856 (1 in 714) and <em class="gene-name">

6857MSH6</em>

6858 (1 in 758), as estimated in a large international study of 5,744 CRC cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.384">

6859384</a>

6860]</p>

6861<p id="_1047" tabindex="-1">

6862<em class="gene-name">

6863MLH1</em>

6864 pathogenic variants are associated with the entire spectrum of malignancies associated with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.390">

6865390</a>

6866] The lifetime risk of any Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated cancer by age 70 years has been found to range between 59% and 65% in <em class="gene-name">

6867MLH1</em>

6868 pathogenic variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.304">

6869304</a>

6870] The highest risk among carriers of pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

6871MLH1</em>

6872 variants is for CRC, which is estimated to be between 41% and 68%,[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

68733</a>

6874,<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

68754</a>

6876,<a href="#cit/section_4.383">

6877383</a>

6878] and the mean age at diagnosis of CRC was 42.8 years (range, 16&#8211;81 y) in one study that included 137 affected individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_4.391">

6879391</a>

6880] In a more recent prospective study using pooled European registry data of 944 <em class="gene-name">

6881MLH1</em>

6882 carriers without cancer, the cumulative CRC incidence was 46% at age 70 years, despite colonoscopic surveillance (albeit at various intervals).[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

68835</a>

6884] </p>

6885<p id="_3407" tabindex="-1">

6886Unlike the <em class="gene-name">

6887APC</em>

6888 gene of FAP, in which several phenotypes of differing severity and spectrum of disease occur, genotype-phenotype relationships have been elusive in the MMR genes. In a large series of <em class="gene-name">

6889MLH1</em>

6890 pathogenic variant carriers, women with truncating <em class="gene-name">

6891MLH1</em>

6892 pathogenic variants had significantly later onset of endometrial cancer than did those with nontruncating variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.392">

6893392</a>

6894] A nonsignificant trend toward later CRC onset in those with truncating <em class="gene-name">

6895MLH1</em>

6896 pathogenic variants was also identified. As no other correlations were found with specific types of variants in <em class="gene-name">

6897MLH1</em>

6898 or other MMR genes, these associations could be artifactual and warrant further validation.</p>

6899</section>

6900<section id="_1118">

6901<h6 id="_1118_toc">

6902<em class="gene-name">

6903MSH2</em>

6904</h6>

6905<p id="_3036" tabindex="-1">

6906The prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

6907MSH2</em>

6908 pathogenic variants in individuals or families with Lynch syndrome has varied across studies. <em class="gene-name">

6909MSH2</em>

6910 pathogenic variants were reported in 38% to 54% of Lynch syndrome families in studies including large cancer registries and among cohorts of early-onset CRC (younger than age 55 y).[<a href="#cit/section_4.277">

6911277</a>

6912,<a href="#cit/section_4.393">

6913393</a>

6914] The reported prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

6915MSH2</em>

6916 pathogenic variants was 32.8% in 2012 in the database of the International Society for Gastrointestinal Hereditary Tumors (InSiGHT), a large professional organization devoted to the collaborative study of familial GI cancer,[<a href="#cit/section_4.389">

6917389</a>

6918] with families readily ascertained based on the presence of extracolonic cancers in <em class="gene-name">

6919MSH2</em>

6920-associated Lynch syndrome. However, the prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

6921MSH2</em>

6922 pathogenic variants was estimated to be 1 in 2,841 in a population-based cohort of 5,744 CRC cases recruited from the United States, Australia, and Canada;[<a href="#cit/section_4.384">

6923384</a>

6924] <em class="gene-name">

6925MSH2</em>

6926 was the least prevalent of the MMR gene variants associated with Lynch syndrome.</p>

6927<p id="_1048" tabindex="-1">

6928The risk of any Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated cancer by age 70 years has been found to range between 57% to nearly 80% in <em class="gene-name">

6929MSH2</em>

6930 pathogenic variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.304">

6931304</a>

6932] The lifetime risk of colon cancer associated with <em class="gene-name">

6933MSH2</em>

6934 pathogenic variants is estimated to be between 48% and 68%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

69353</a>

6936,<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

69374</a>

6938,<a href="#cit/section_4.383">

6939383</a>

6940] In a case series of Lynch syndrome patients, those carrying germline <em class="gene-name">

6941MSH2</em>

6942 pathogenic variants (49 individuals, 45% women) had a lifetime (cutoff age, 60 y) risk of extracolonic cancers of 48% compared with 11% for <em class="gene-name">

6943MLH1</em>

6944 carriers (56 individuals, 50% women).[<a href="#cit/section_4.394">

6945394</a>

6946] In a more recent prospective study using pooled European registry data of 616 <em class="gene-name">

6947MSH2</em>

6948 carriers without cancer, the cumulative CRC incidence was 35% at age 70 years, despite colonoscopic surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

69495</a>

6950]</p>

6951<p id="_3101" tabindex="-1">

6952The mean age at diagnosis of CRC in <em class="gene-name">

6953MSH2</em>

6954 carriers has been comparable to <em class="gene-name">

6955MLH1</em>

6956 carriers. One study that included 143 affected individuals with <em class="gene-name">

6957MSH2</em>

6958 pathogenic variants found a mean age at CRC diagnosis of 43.9 years (range, 16&#8211;90 y). The same study reported a mean age at CRC diagnosis of 42.8 years (range, 16&#8211;81 y) in 137 <em class="gene-name">

6959MLH1</em>

6960 pathogenic variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.391">

6961391</a>

6962]</p>

6963</section>

6964<section id="_3102">

6965<h6 id="_3102_toc">

6966<em class="gene-name">

6967MSH6</em>

6968</h6>

6969<p id="_1050" tabindex="-1">

6970Most series have reported a prevalence of germline <em class="gene-name">

6971MSH6</em>

6972 pathogenic variants in approximately 10% of Lynch syndrome families from high-risk clinics and a higher proportion of unselected CRC patients, at approximately 50%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.374">

6973374</a>

6974,<a href="#cit/section_4.395">

6975395</a>

6976-<a href="#cit/section_4.400">

6977400</a>

6978] The reported prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

6979MSH6</em>

6980 pathogenic variants in the InSiGHT database was 18% in 2012.[<a href="#cit/section_4.389">

6981389</a>

6982] The wide range of prevalence estimates for pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

6983MSH6</em>

6984 variants was a result of small sample sizes, ascertainment bias, and the later age of CRC onset and less striking family histories in <em class="gene-name">

6985MSH6</em>

6986-associated Lynch syndrome families compared with <em class="gene-name">

6987MLH1-</em>

6988 and <em class="gene-name">

6989MSH2</em>

6990-associated Lynch syndrome families.[<a href="#cit/section_4.395">

6991395</a>

6992] This is in line with findings from a population-based study of 42 carriers of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=556486&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000556486&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6993deleterious</a>

6994 <em class="gene-name">

6995MSH6</em>

6996 germline pathogenic variants, 30 (71%) of whom had a family cancer history that did not meet the Amsterdam II criteria.[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

69976</a>

6998] In a recent, international, population-based study of 5,744 CRC cases, the prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

6999MSH6</em>

7000 pathogenic variants was estimated to be 1 in 758, ranking as the second most prevalent of the MMR genes following <em class="gene-name">

7001PMS2</em>

7002.[<a href="#cit/section_4.384">

7003384</a>

7004]</p>

7005<p id="_1075" tabindex="-1">

7006The lifetime risk of any Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated cancer among <em class="gene-name">

7007MSH6</em>

7008 pathogenic variant carriers is approximately 25% [<a href="#cit/section_4.304">

7009304</a>

7010] with CRC lifetime risk estimated to be between 12% and 22% [<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

70114</a>

7012,<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

70136</a>

7014] with <em class="gene-name">

7015MSH6</em>

7016 carriers diagnosed with CRC at a later age than <em class="gene-name">

7017MLH1</em>

7018 and <em class="gene-name">

7019MSH2</em>

7020 carriers. In an earlier study of 146 <em class="gene-name">

7021MSH6</em>

7022 carriers (59 men and 87 women) from 20 families, all of whom had truncating pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7023MSH6</em>

7024, there was a similar prevalence of CRC by age 70 years among <em class="gene-name">

7025MLH1</em>

7026, <em class="gene-name">

7027MSH2</em>

7028, and <em class="gene-name">

7029MSH6</em>

7030 carriers (<em>

7031P</em>

7032 = .0854). However, the mean age at diagnosis for colorectal carcinoma was (a) 55 years for male <em class="gene-name">

7033MSH6</em>

7034 carriers (n = 21; range, 26&#8211;84 y) versus 43 years and 44 years in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7035MLH1</em>

7036 and <em class="gene-name">

7037MSH2</em>

7038 pathogenic variants, respectively; and (b) 57 years for female <em class="gene-name">

7039MSH6</em>

7040 carriers (n = 15; range, 41&#8211;81 y) versus 43 years and 44 years in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7041MLH1</em>

7042 and <em class="gene-name">

7043MSH2</em>

7044 pathogenic variants, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_4.401">

7045401</a>

7046] </p>

7047<p id="_1115" tabindex="-1">

7048The largest series of carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7049MSH6</em>

7050 pathogenic variants reported to date includes 113 families from five countries who were ascertained through family cancer clinics and population-based cancer registries.[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

70516</a>

7052] Compared with the incidence for the general population, <em class="gene-name">

7053MSH6</em>

7054 pathogenic variant carriers had an eightfold increased incidence of CRC (HR, 7.6; 95% CI, 5.4&#8211;10.8), which was independent of sex and age. By age 70 years, 22% (95% CI, 14%&#8211;32%) of male carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7055MSH6</em>

7056 pathogenic variants developed CRC compared with 10% (95% CI, 5%&#8211;17%) of female carriers. By age 80 years, the CRC prevalence doubled to 44% (95% CI, 28%&#8211;62%) of male carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7057MSH6</em>

7058 pathogenic variants diagnosed with CRC compared with 20% (95% CI, 11%&#8211;35%) among female carriers.</p>

7059<p id="_3059" tabindex="-1">

7060In a more recent prospective study using pooled European registry data of 305 <em class="gene-name">

7061MSH6</em>

7062 carriers without cancer, the cumulative CRC incidence was 20% at age 70 years despite colonoscopic surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

70635</a>

7064]</p>

7065</section>

7066<section id="_1126">

7067<h6 id="_1126_toc">

7068<em class="gene-name">

7069PMS2</em>

7070</h6>

7071<p id="_2889" tabindex="-1">

7072<em class="gene-name">

7073PMS2</em>

7074 was the last of the genes in the MMR family of genes to be identified. This was because lower penetrance among families made it more difficult to identify [<a href="#cit/section_4.402">

7075402</a>

7076] using clinical criteria, and also because of limitations of DNA mutational analysis that result from pseudogene interference.</p>

7077<p id="_1039" tabindex="-1">

7078 In earlier studies of individuals with CRC and suspected Lynch syndrome, the prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

7079PMS2</em>

7080 pathogenic variants was variable from 2.2% to 5%,[<a href="#cit/section_4.275">

7081275</a>

7082,<a href="#cit/section_4.403">

7083403</a>

7084] with an increase to 7.5% as reported in the InSiGHT database in 2012.[<a href="#cit/section_4.389">

7085389</a>

7086] From a study examining universal tumor testing results from unselected cases of CRC in Switzerland, IHC evaluation of 1,000 consecutive cases found isolated absence of PMS2 expression in 1.5% of all tumors. If this frequency of PMS2-deficient CRCs were representative of all <em class="gene-name">

7087PMS2</em>

7088-associated Lynch syndrome, <em class="gene-name">

7089PMS2</em>

7090 would be the most common gene associated with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.404">

7091404</a>

7092] Results from a large, population-based CRC cohort found that the prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

7093PMS2</em>

7094 pathogenic variants was the highest among all MMR variants, in which 1 person in 714 carried a pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

7095PMS2</em>

7096 gene variant.[<a href="#cit/section_4.384">

7097384</a>

7098] </p>

7099<p id="_2793" tabindex="-1">

7100The lifetime risk of any cancer has been found to range between 25% and 32% for heterozygous <em class="gene-name">

7101PMS2</em>

7102 pathogenic variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.304">

7103304</a>

7104] A meta-analysis of three population-based studies and one clinic-based study estimated that for carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7105PMS2</em>

7106 pathogenic variants, the risk of CRC to age 70 years was 20% among men and 15% among women, and the risk of endometrial cancer was 15%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.405">

7107405</a>

7108] Similarly, a European consortium of clinic-based registries, taking care to correct for ascertainment bias, found a cumulative lifetime (to age 70 y) CRC risk of only 19% in men and 11% in women with <em class="gene-name">

7109PMS2</em>

7110 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.406">

7111406</a>

7112] In addition, patients with <em class="gene-name">

7113PMS2</em>

7114 pathogenic variants presented with CRC 7 to 8 years later than did those with <em class="gene-name">

7115MLH1</em>

7116 and <em class="gene-name">

7117MSH2</em>

7118 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.403">

7119403</a>

7120] In a prospective study using pooled European registry data of 77 <em class="gene-name">

7121PMS2</em>

7122 carriers without cancer, the cumulative CRC incidence was 10% at age 70 years despite colonoscopic surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

71235</a>

7124] An analysis of nearly 5,000 patients from 284 <em class="gene-name">

7125PMS2</em>

7126 families from the European consortium, supplemented by data from two more registries, was intended to provide more robust <em class="gene-name">

7127PMS2</em>

7128-associated cancer risk estimates.[<a href="#cit/section_4.388">

7129388</a>

7130] The risk of CRC up to age 80 years was 13% (95% CI, 7.9%&#8211;22%) for men and 12% (95% CI, 6.7%&#8211;21%) for women, compared with general population risk estimates of 6.6% and 4.7%, respectively. Endometrial cancer risk was found to be 13% (95% CI, 7%&#8211;24%). No excess risk of other Lynch syndrome&#8211;spectrum tumors was identified in these cohorts. The authors concluded that these data justify consideration of delaying initiation of colonoscopy until age 35 to 40 years, and with longer follow-up intervals (2&#8211;3 y), although this was not specifically studied. As with the original reports from the European Prospective Lynch Syndrome Database, it was not possible to assess the extent to which such colonoscopies and polypectomies might have reduced the rate of detected CRCs.</p>

7131<p id="_3304" tabindex="-1">

7132The PLSD is a major ongoing initiative to assess cancer risks in Lynch syndrome. Although it lacks specific details regarding screening practices, it includes outcome data from many European programs, classified by age, gender, and MMR gene.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

71335</a>

7134,<a href="#cit/section_4.407">

7135407</a>

7136,<a href="#cit/section_4.408">

7137408</a>

7138]

7139Recognizing limitations in the larger PLSD, a subset with more detailed surveillance data has been provided.[<a href="#cit/section_4.409">

7140409</a>

7141] These prospective colonoscopy data from Germany, Holland, and Finland included 2,747 patients of whom 62 had no prior cancer at surveillance initiation. Because of differences in surveillance practices, the colonoscopy interval approximated 1 year in Germany, 2 years in Holland, and 3 years in Finland. The median number of colonoscopies was five and the median per-patient observation time was approximately 8 years. Despite the differences in surveillance intervals, similar adenoma detection rates were found in those patients with a history of cancer (14%) and those without (15.6%). At 10 years of follow-up, rates of first cancer were 8.4% and 14% for metachronous tumors. Factors increasing risk were male sex, prior CRC, presence of <em class="gene-name">

7142MLH1</em>

7143 or <em class="gene-name">

7144MSH2</em>

7145 pathogenic variants, age older than 40 years, and adenoma at index colonoscopy. Notably, no significant difference in CRC detection or in stage at detection was noted between screening intervals of 1, 2, or 3 years.

7146</p>

7147<p id="_3103" tabindex="-1">

7148It is important to note that a more severe phenotype is seen among carriers of biallelic <em class="gene-name">

7149PMS2</em>

7150 pathogenic variants. For more information, see the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3012">

7151IHC in constitutional mismatch repair deficiency (CMMRD) syndrome</a>

7152 section.</p>

7153</section>

7154<p id="_2940" tabindex="-1">

7155The lifetime risk of CRC and endometrial cancer in carriers of these pathogenic variants is summarized in <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3023">

7156Table 11</a>

7157.</p>

7158<table id="_3023" class="table-default expandable-container">

7159<caption>

7163<col width="27.59%">

7164<col width="18.51%">

7165<col width="30.92%">

7179<tbody>

7183MLH1</em>

7184</td>

7185<td>

718641&#8211;50</td>

7187<td>

718834&#8211;54</td>

7189<td>

7190[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

71913</a>

7192,<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

71935</a>

7194,<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

71954</a>

7196]</td>

7198<tr>

7201MSH2</em>

720435&#8211;56</td>

72093</a>

7210-<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

72115</a>

7212]</td>

7213</tr>
