7217MSH6</em>

7218</td>

722010&#8211;22</td>

722216&#8211;49</td>

7223<td>

7224[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

72255</a>

7226,<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

72274</a>

7228,<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

72296</a>

7230]</td>

7231</tr>

7232<tr>

7233<td>

7234<em class="gene-name">

7235PMS2</em>

7236</td>

7237<td>

723810</td>

7239<td>

724024</td>

7241<td>

7242[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

72435</a>

7244]</td>

7245</tr>

7246</tbody>

7247</table>

7248<section id="_1130">

7249<h6 id="_1130_toc">

7250<em class="gene-name">

7251EPCAM</em>

7252</h6>

7253<p id="_3104" tabindex="-1">

7254A subset of individuals with Lynch syndrome (approximately 1%) have a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

7255EPCAM</em>

7256, which leads to hypermethylation and inactivation of the <em class="gene-name">

7257MSH2</em>

7258 promoter.[<a href="#cit/section_4.410">

7259410</a>

7260] In a European study of 194 <em class="gene-name">

7261EPCAM</em>

7262 deletion carriers, the cumulative risk of CRC up to age 70 years was 75% with the average age at onset of 43 years. This is comparable to the risk in <em class="gene-name">

7263MSH2</em>

7264 carriers (up to 68% by age 70 y). However, the risk of endometrial cancer among women with an <em class="gene-name">

7265EPCAM</em>

7266 deletion was only 12% in this study, compared with a risk of up to 71% in <em class="gene-name">

7267MSH2</em>

7268 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.411">

7269411</a>

7270] The associated phenotype is dependent on the location of the deletion variant in the 3&#8217; end of the <em class="gene-name">

7271EPCAM</em>

7272 gene; if the deletion is large and includes parts of the promoter of <em class="gene-name">

7273MSH2</em>

7274, the phenotype will be similar to other <em class="gene-name">

7275MSH2</em>

7276-associated Lynch syndrome families.[<a href="#cit/section_4.411">

7277411</a>

7278] When the deletion involves the termination signal of <em class="gene-name">

7279EPCAM</em>

7280 but spares all of the <em class="gene-name">

7281MSH2</em>

7282 gene and promoter, the phenotype is mainly confined to CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.412">

7283412</a>

7284]</p>

7285<p id="_2951" tabindex="-1">

7286One study of two families with the same <em class="gene-name">

7287EPCAM</em>

7288 deletion limited to the 3&#8217; end of the gene and not extending into the promoter of <em class="gene-name">

7289MSH2</em>

7290 found few extracolonic cancers and no endometrial cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.412">

7291412</a>

7292] However, a subsequent study demonstrated that women with MSH2 protein expression loss caused by <em class="gene-name">

7293EPCAM</em>

7294 variants are also at risk of endometrial cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.411">

7295411</a>

7296] </p>

7297</section>

7298<section id="_3105">

7299<h6 id="_3105_toc">

7300CMMRD</h6>

7301<p id="_2804" tabindex="-1">

7302As described above, patients may carry MMR gene variants in both parental alleles, in a condition known as CMMRD. For more information, see the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3012">

7303IHC in constitutional mismatch repair deficiency (CMMRD) syndrome</a>

7304 section.</p>

7305<p id="_2805" tabindex="-1">

7306The occurrence of such biallelic variants is associated with a characteristic but not diagnostic clinical phenotype. Clinical features include hematologic malignancies and brain tumors in children. When GI tumors occur, the age of onset is strikingly low, sometimes before age 20 years. Caf&#233; au lait spots and features otherwise suggesting neurofibromatosis are characteristic. Occasionally, patients present with multiple adenomas.</p>

7307</section>

7308<section id="_3222">

7309<h6 id="_3222_toc">

7310Ethnic variation and founder pathogenic variants in Lynch syndrome</h6>

7311<p id="_3223" tabindex="-1">

7312The frequency of MMR variants does not differ markedly from population to population, with similar frequencies identified in a host of different countries. As with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer (HBOC), there are certain variants that occur at higher frequencies within a particular ethnic group. Notable in HBOC are the commonly recurring Ashkenazi Jewish variants, so common that direct-to-consumer testing is offered for these common variants. (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3457">

7313Prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

7314BRCA1/2</em>

7315 Pathogenic Variants</a>

7316 section in BRCA1 and BRCA2: Cancer Risks and Management and the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_362">

7317Direct-to-Consumer [DTC] Genetic Tests</a>

7318 section in <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq">

7319Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling</a>

7320 for more information.) The ancientness of apparent founder variants is generally established by <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=485392&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000485392&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7321haplotype</a>

7322 analysis. In some instances, what may appear to be a founder variant is simply a frequently recurring de novo variant.[<a href="#cit/section_4.413">

7323413</a>

7324]</p>

7325<p id="_3224" tabindex="-1">

7326Among the first population findings regarding the MMR genes of Lynch syndrome was the recognition of two very common <em class="gene-name">

7327MLH1</em>

7328 variants in Finland, accounting for most cases of Lynch syndrome in this country.[<a href="#cit/section_4.414">

7329414</a>

7330,<a href="#cit/section_4.415">

7331415</a>

7332] Since that time, founder variants have been identified in most populations in which relatively unselected series of patients with CRC have undergone variant testing. Many of the reports originate in Europe. As in Finland, these may be straightforward to identify in the setting of fairly homogeneous ethnicity with low immigration. Founder variants in Europe have been found in the United Kingdom, Sweden, Switzerland, Italy,[<a href="#cit/section_4.416">

7333416</a>

7334] Portugal, France, Spain, and Hungary, and are likely present in all ethnic groups. Fewer such reports have come from Asia,[<a href="#cit/section_4.417">

7335417</a>

7336] Latin America, the Middle East, and Africa.</p>

7337<p id="_3225" tabindex="-1">

7338In the United States, a deletion in exons 1&#8211;6 of the <em class="gene-name">

7339MSH2</em>

7340 gene has been estimated to account for as much as 20% of variants in that gene. This so-called <em>

7341American Founder Mutation</em>

7342 has been determined by haplotype analysis to date back about 500 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.418">

7343418</a>

7344]</p>

7345<p id="_3226" tabindex="-1">

7346A South American study combining data from Uruguay, Colombia, Brazil, Argentina, and Chile also selected cases of interest according to Amsterdam and Bethesda features, yielding a 60% frequency of <em class="gene-name">

7347MLH1</em>

7348 and 40% frequency of <em class="gene-name">

7349MSH2</em>

7350. <em class="gene-name">

7351MSH6</em>

7352 and <em class="gene-name">

7353PMS2</em>

7354 were not evaluated. Selection bias likely influenced the frequency of variants and perhaps the relative contributions by <em class="gene-name">

7355MLH1</em>

7356 and <em class="gene-name">

7357MSH2</em>

7358. A possible founder variant in Colombia was noted.[<a href="#cit/section_4.419">

7359419</a>

7360]</p>

7361<p id="_3227" tabindex="-1">

7362Although testing for commonly recurring founder variants in a given ethnic/geographic area has been considered to be a cost-effective first step when a stepwise strategy is employed, it is likely not necessary when the increasingly common approach of broad panel testing is undertaken as a basic strategy.</p>

7363<p id="_3228" tabindex="-1">

7364Some ethnic groups have increased rates of consanguinity and a subsequent risk of CMMRD. For more information, see the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3012">

7365IHC in constitutional mismatch repair deficiency (CMMRD) syndrome</a>

7366 section.</p>

7367<section id="_3229">

7368<h6 id="_3229_toc">

7369Ethnic variation in the United States</h6>

7370<p id="_3230" tabindex="-1">

7371In this section, the data exploring the distribution of MMR gene variants amongst differing ethnic groups in the United States are presented. The interpretation of these studies is challenging given the presence of selection and ascertainment bias. In addition, even population-based studies are limited by small sample sizes for many ethnic groups and self-reporting of ethnicity/race. </p>

7372<p id="_3231" tabindex="-1">

7373There are few data suggesting the presence of much variation in Lynch syndrome frequency according to geography or ethnicity. Within a small and/or homogeneous ethnic group the presence of founder variants may seem to increase the prevalence of variants in that particular gene. Slight differences in the proportion of <em class="gene-name">

7374MLH1</em>

7375 and <em class="gene-name">

7376MSH2</em>

7377 variants exist from one population to another. <em class="gene-name">

7378MSH6</em>

7379 and <em class="gene-name">

7380PMS2</em>

7381 have been insufficiently studied at the population level as to enable inferences about their relative frequencies.</p>

7382<p id="_3232" tabindex="-1">

7383The most representative population-based studies in the United States, such as that in Columbus, Ohio, have been overrepresented by White individuals, in accordance with their greater overall numbers. Consequently, data on minorities such as Hispanic and African American individuals suffer from smaller and less rigorously representative samples.</p>

7384<p id="_3233" tabindex="-1">

7385 A study conducted in Puerto Rico considered variants in 89 Caribbean Hispanic patients with Lynch syndrome suspected on the grounds of Amsterdam criteria or Bethesda guidelines.[<a href="#cit/section_4.420">

7386420</a>

7387] Patients underwent either immediate germline testing or step-wise evaluation beginning with tumor MSI/IHC. Frequencies of variants by gene were 67% for <em class="gene-name">

7388MSH2</em>

7389, 25% for <em class="gene-name">

7390MLH1</em>

7391, and 8% for <em class="gene-name">

7392MSH6</em>

7393. No definite founder variants were evident. Clearly, the selection of participants according to clinical family history criteria would have led to an underreporting of the less penetrant <em class="gene-name">

7394MSH6</em>

7395 and <em class="gene-name">

7396PMS2</em>

7397 genes.</p>

7398<p id="_3234" tabindex="-1">

7399Clinic-based series from California, Texas, and Puerto Rico yielded an overall variant prevalence similar to those described, with somewhat more <em class="gene-name">

7400MLH1</em>

7401 than <em class="gene-name">

7402MSH2</em>

7403, but also including <em class="gene-name">

7404MSH6</em>

7405 and <em class="gene-name">

7406PMS2</em>

7407. Presence of potential founder variants traceable back to Spain and Europe were noted.[<a href="#cit/section_4.421">

7408421</a>

7409]</p>

7410<p id="_3235" tabindex="-1">

7411The closest population-based information on Lynch syndrome in Hispanic individuals is a Southern California study based on the California Tumor Registry, in which 265 patients were identified.[<a href="#cit/section_4.422">

7412422</a>

7413] Of those with MSI-H tumors, 13 (62%) had MMR variants. Frequencies of MMR variants were 46% for <em class="gene-name">

7414MLH1</em>

7415 (6 of 13), 31% for <em class="gene-name">

7416MSH2</em>

7417 (4 of 13), 15% for <em class="gene-name">

7418MSH6</em>

7419 (2 of 13), and 8% for <em class="gene-name">

7420PMS2</em>

7421 (1 of 13).</p>

7422<p id="_3236" tabindex="-1">

7423The problem of small numbers is highlighted by the findings from the more truly population-based studies that have been done in the United States. In a study from Columbus, Ohio, only 8% of the consecutive series patients were African American and the proportion of Hispanic individuals as a subset of White individuals was not stated.[<a href="#cit/section_4.362">

7424362</a>

7425] In another study involving panel testing of nearly all CRC patients treated at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, less than 5% were Black and less than 3% were Hispanic, underscoring the challenge of extracting meaningful data from small subsets.[<a href="#cit/section_4.365">

7426365</a>

7427] </p>

7428</section>

7429<section id="_3237">

7430<h6 id="_3237_toc">

7431Lynch syndrome in African Americans</h6>

7432<p id="_3238" tabindex="-1">

7433The issues in evaluating prevalence of Lynch syndrome and cancer risks associated with MMR variants in African American individuals are similar to those in Hispanic individuals: a heterogeneous population that has been understudied. A study of clinic-based data from 13 referral centers in the United States identified 51 families with Lynch syndrome with frequencies of MMR gene variants as follows: 61% <em class="gene-name">

7434MLH1</em>

7435, 21% <em class="gene-name">

7436MSH2</em>

7437, 6% <em class="gene-name">

7438MSH6</em>

7439, and 12% <em class="gene-name">

7440PMS2</em>

7441. Age of cancer onset distribution curves were very similar to those seen in White populations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.423">

7442423</a>

7443] As with most of the studies in Hispanic individuals, cases were not identified according to any consistent, programmatic evaluation such as universal tumor testing.</p>

7444</section>

7445</section>

7446</section>

7447<section id="_3106">

7448<h5 id="_3106_toc">

7449Risk of metachronous CRC</h5>

7450<p id="_3107" tabindex="-1">

7451A hallmark feature of Lynch syndrome is that carriers of pathogenic MMR gene variants have an increased risk of development of synchronous and metachronous colorectal neoplasms.[<a href="#cit/section_4.407">

7452407</a>

7453,<a href="#cit/section_4.424">

7454424</a>

7455,<a href="#cit/section_4.425">

7456425</a>

7457] In one study of 382 individuals with Lynch syndrome from the Colon Cancer Family Registry, the incidence of metachronous CRCs was 16% at 10 years, 41% at 20 years, and 63% at 30 years after segmental colectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.424">

7458424</a>

7459] The risk of metachronous CRC decreased in a stepwise fashion by 31% for every 10 cm of the colon that was removed, with none of the 50 individuals who had extensive colectomies diagnosed with metachronous CRC. Another prospective study of 1,273 patients with Lynch syndrome who had prior cancer reported a cumulative incidence of subsequent CRC of 46% for <em class="gene-name">

7460MLH1</em>

7461 carriers, 48% for <em class="gene-name">

7462MSH2</em>

7463 carriers, and 23% for <em class="gene-name">

7464MSH6</em>

7465 carriers. This represents only a slightly greater risk of new cancers than pathogenic variant carriers with no previous cancer diagnosis. Excellent survival was again seen and was regarded as a combination of favorable tumor pathology and the effect of surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.407">

7466407</a>

7467]</p>

7468</section>

7469<section id="_3108">

7470<h5 id="_3108_toc">

7471Risk of extracolonic malignancies associated with Lynch syndrome</h5>

7472<p id="_2768" tabindex="-1">

7473Patients with Lynch syndrome are at an increased risk of other cancers, especially those of the endometrium. The cumulative risk of extracolonic cancer has been estimated to be 20% by age 70 years in 1,018 women in 86 families, compared with 3% in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.426">

7474426</a>

7475] There is some evidence that the rate of individual cancers varies from kindred to kindred.[<a href="#cit/section_4.427">

7476427</a>

7477-<a href="#cit/section_4.429">

7478429</a>

7479]</p>

7480<section id="_2950">

7481<h6 id="_2950_toc">

7482Endometrial cancer</h6>

7483<p id="_1042" tabindex="-1">

7484The most common extracolonic malignancy in Lynch syndrome is endometrial adenocarcinoma, which affects at least one female member in about 50% of Lynch syndrome families. In addition, 50% of women with an MMR gene pathogenic variant will present with endometrial cancer as her first malignancy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.430">

7485430</a>

7486]</p>

7487<p id="_2681" tabindex="-1">

7488The lifetime risk of endometrial cancer has been estimated to be from 44% in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7489MLH1</em>

7490 pathogenic variants to 71% in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7491MSH2</em>

7492 pathogenic variants, although some earlier studies may have overestimated risk due to ascertainment bias.[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

74936</a>

7494,<a href="#cit/section_4.279">

7495279</a>

7496,<a href="#cit/section_4.383">

7497383</a>

7498,<a href="#cit/section_4.393">

7499393</a>

7500,<a href="#cit/section_4.431">

7501431</a>

7502] Lifetime risk of endometrial cancer in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7503MSH6</em>

7504 pathogenic variants in 113 families was estimated to be 26% at age 70 years and 44% at age 80 years;[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

75056</a>

7506] overall, female carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7507MSH6</em>

7508 pathogenic variants had an endometrial cancer risk that was 25 times higher than women in the general population (HR, 25.5; 95% CI, 16.8&#8211;38.7; <em>

7509P</em>

7510 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

75116</a>

7512] In another study, the cumulative lifetime risk of uterine cancer was higher in <em class="gene-name">

7513MSH6</em>

7514 carriers (71%) than in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7515MLH1</em>

7516 (27%) and <em class="gene-name">

7517MSH2</em>

7518 (40%) pathogenic variants (<em>

7519P</em>

7520 = .02), with an older mean age at diagnosis of 54 years in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7521MSH6</em>

7522 pathogenic variants (n = 29; range, 43&#8211;65 y) versus 48 years in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7523MLH1</em>

7524 and 49 years in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7525MSH2</em>

7526 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.401">

7527401</a>

7528] In carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7529PMS2</em>

7530 pathogenic variants, the endometrial cancer risk at age 70 years has been reported to be 15%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.405">

7531405</a>

7532] Prospective data collected in the Colon Cancer Family Registry program yielded 5-year endometrial cancer risks of about 3% and 10-year endometrial cancer risks of about 10% among women with MMR gene pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.432">

7533432</a>

7534] A prospective study using pooled European registry data of 1,942 MMR carriers without prior cancer reported a cumulative incidence of endometrial cancer of 34% in <em class="gene-name">

7535MLH1</em>

7536 carriers, 51% in <em class="gene-name">

7537MSH2</em>

7538 carriers, 49% in <em class="gene-name">

7539MSH6</em>

7540 carriers, and 24% in <em class="gene-name">

7541PMS2</em>

7542 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

75435</a>

7544] Women with loss of MSH2 protein expression caused by an <em class="gene-name">

7545EPCAM</em>

7546 pathogenic variant are also at risk of endometrial cancer depending upon the location of the variant in <em class="gene-name">

7547EPCAM</em>

7548. One study found a 12% (95% CI, 0%&#8211;27%) cumulative risk of endometrial cancer in <em class="gene-name">

7549EPCAM</em>

7550 deletion carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.411">

7551411</a>

7552] </p>

7553<p id="_3037" tabindex="-1">

7554A study of 127 women with Lynch syndrome who had endometrial cancer as their index cancer were found to be at significantly increased risk of other cancers. The following elevated risks were reported: CRC, 48% (95% CI, 27.2%&#8211;58.3%); kidney, renal pelvis, and ureter cancer, 28% (95% CI, 11.9%&#8211;48.6%); urinary bladder cancer, 24.3% (95% CI, 8.56%&#8211;42.9%; and breast cancer, 2.51% (95% CI, 1.17%&#8211;4.14%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.433">

7555433</a>

7556]</p>

7557<p id="_2956" tabindex="-1">

7558In a study of 113 families that carried <em class="gene-name">

7559MSH6</em>

7560 pathogenic variants from the Colon Cancer Family Registry, female <em class="gene-name">

7561MSH6</em>

7562 carriers had a 26-fold increased incidence of endometrial cancer (HR, 25.5; 95% CI, 16.8&#8211;38.7) compared with the general population. A sixfold increased incidence of other cancers associated with Lynch syndrome (HR, 6.0; 95% CI, 3.4&#8211;10.7) was observed compared with the general population, but not among male <em class="gene-name">

7563MSH6</em>

7564 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

75656</a>

7566]</p>

7567<p id="_2666" tabindex="-1">

7568Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated endometrial cancer is not limited to the endometrioid

7569subtype, and the spectrum of uterine tumors in Lynch syndrome may include clear cell carcinoma, uterine papillary serous carcinoma, and malignant mixed M&#252;llerian tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.434">

7570434</a>

7571] Also, endometrial cancer most commonly arises from the lower uterine segment. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3112">

7572Endometrial cancer screening in Lynch syndrome</a>

7573 section of this summary for information about screening methods.)</p>

7574</section>

7575<section id="_1141">

7576<h6 id="_1141_toc">

7577Cancer risk in Lynch syndrome beyond CRC and endometrial cancer</h6>

7578<p id="_2791" tabindex="-1">

7579Multiple studies demonstrate an increased risk of additional malignancies associated with Lynch syndrome, including cancers of the stomach, pancreas, ovary, small intestine, and brain, transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder, ureters, and renal pelvis, and sebaceous adenomas of the skin.[<a href="#cit/section_4.426">

7580426</a>

7581,<a href="#cit/section_4.427">

7582427</a>

7583,<a href="#cit/section_4.435">

7584435</a>

7585-<a href="#cit/section_4.438">

7586438</a>

7587] In addition, some studies have suggested an association with breast, prostate, and adrenal cortex cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.432">

7588432</a>

7589,<a href="#cit/section_4.436">

7590436</a>

7591,<a href="#cit/section_4.439">

7592439</a>

7593-<a href="#cit/section_4.441">

7594441</a>

7595] The strength of the association for many of these malignancies is limited by the majority of studies having a small sample size (and consequently, wide CIs associated with relative risk [RR]), the retrospective nature of the analyses, and referral or ascertainment bias. </p>

7596<p id="_2792" tabindex="-1">

7597The largest prospective study to date is of 446 unaffected carriers of pathogenic variants from the Colon Cancer Family Registry.[<a href="#cit/section_4.432">

7598432</a>

7599] The Colon Cancer Family Registry is an international cohort with both population-based and clinic-based recruitment from six centers in North America and Australia. Control subjects were noncarriers from families with a known MMR pathogenic variant. Three subcohorts were used to analyze the risk of CRC (365 carriers, 903 noncarriers), endometrial cancer (215 carriers, 523 noncarriers), and other cancers (446 carriers, 1,029 noncarriers). Participants who were followed for up to 10 years demonstrated an increased SIR for CRC (SIR, 20.48; 95% CI, 11.71&#8211;33.27; <em>

7600P</em>

7601 &lt; .01), endometrial cancer (SIR, 30.62; 95% CI,

760211.24&#8211;66.64; <em>

7603P</em>

7604 &lt; .001), ovarian cancer (SIR, 18.81; 95% CI, 3.88&#8211;54.95; <em>

7605P</em>

7606 &lt; .001), gastric cancer (SIR, 9.78; 95% CI, 1.18&#8211;35.30; <em>

7607P</em>

7608 = .009), renal cancer (SIR, 11.22; 95% CI, 2.31&#8211;32.79; <em>

7609P</em>

7610 &lt; .001), bladder cancer (SIR, 9.51; 95% CI, 1.15&#8211;34.37; <em>

7611P</em>

7612 = .009), pancreatic cancer (SIR, 10.68; 95% CI, 2.68&#8211;47.70; <em>

7613P</em>

7614 = .001), and female breast cancer (SIR, 3.95; 95% CI,

76151.59&#8211;8.13; <em>

7616P</em>

7617 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.432">

7618432</a>

7619]</p>

7620<p id="_371" tabindex="-1">

7621A well-described variant of Lynch syndrome whose phenotype includes multiple cutaneous neoplasms (including sebaceous adenomas, sebaceous carcinomas, and keratoacanthomas) and CRC is Muir-Torre syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.442">

7622442</a>

7623,<a href="#cit/section_4.443">

7624443</a>

7625] Pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

7626MLH1</em>

7627, <em class="gene-name">

7628MSH2</em>

7629, and <em class="gene-name">

7630MSH6</em>

7631 genes have been found in Muir-Torre families with an increased prevalence described among <em class="gene-name">

7632MSH2</em>

7633 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.444">

7634444</a>

7635-<a href="#cit/section_4.451">

7636451</a>

7637] A study of 1,914 unrelated <em class="gene-name">

7638MLH1</em>

7639 and <em class="gene-name">

7640MSH2</em>

7641 probands found <em class="gene-name">

7642MSH2</em>

7643 to be more common in individuals with the Muir-Torre syndrome phenotype. Of 15 individuals with sebaceous skin tumors, 13 (87%) had <em class="gene-name">

7644MSH2</em>

7645 pathogenic variants compared with two individuals who had <em class="gene-name">

7646MLH1</em>

7647 pathogenic variants (<em>

7648P</em>

7649 = .05).[<a href="#cit/section_4.452">

7650452</a>

7651] Evidence of defective DNA MMR activity using IHC or MSI testing was reported in 69 of 163 randomly collected sebaceous neoplasms (42%), suggesting that this is a common mechanism for the development of these lesions, and that testing for defective MMR in sebaceous neoplasms would be an ineffective means to screen for Lynch syndrome or Muir-Torre syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.453">

7652453</a>

7653] (Refer to the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_439">

7654Sebaceous Carcinoma</a>

7655 section in the PDQ summary on <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq">

7656Genetics of Skin Cancer</a>

7657 for more information about cutaneous neoplasms in Muir-Torre syndrome.)</p>

7658<table id="_3024" class="table-default expandable-container">

7741391</a>

7763391</a>

7771459</a>

7780Hepatobiliary tract</td>

7781<td>

7782&lt;1</td>

7783<td>

77840.02&#8211;4</td>

7785<td>

7786[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

77874</a>

7788,<a href="#cit/section_4.459">

7789459</a>

7790,<a href="#cit/section_4.461">

7791461</a>

7792-<a href="#cit/section_4.463">

7793463</a>

7794]</td>

7795</tr>

7796<tr>

7797<td>

7798Urinary tract</td>

7799<td>

7800&lt;1</td>

7801<td>

78020.2&#8211;25.5</td>

7803<td>

7804[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

78054</a>

7806,<a href="#cit/section_4.391">

7807391</a>

7808,<a href="#cit/section_4.405">

7809405</a>

7810,<a href="#cit/section_4.457">

7811457</a>

7812-<a href="#cit/section_4.459">

7813459</a>

7814,<a href="#cit/section_4.461">

7815461</a>

7816,<a href="#cit/section_4.462">

7817462</a>

7818,<a href="#cit/section_4.464">

7819464</a>

7820]</td>

7821</tr>

7822<tr>

7823<td>

7824Small bowel</td>

7825<td>

7826&lt;1</td>

7827<td>

78280.4&#8211;12</td>

7829<td>

7830[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

78314</a>

7832,<a href="#cit/section_4.391">

7833391</a>

7834,<a href="#cit/section_4.456">

7835456</a>

7836-<a href="#cit/section_4.459">

7837459</a>

7838]</td>

7839</tr>

7840<tr>

7841<td>

7842Brain/CNS</td>

7843<td>

7844&lt;1</td>

7845<td>

78461.2&#8211;3.7</td>

7847<td>

7848[<a href="#cit/section_4.391">

7849391</a>

7850,<a href="#cit/section_4.457">

7851457</a>

7852,<a href="#cit/section_4.459">

7853459</a>

7854,<a href="#cit/section_4.461">

7855461</a>

7856]</td>

7857</tr>

7858<tr>

7859<td>

7860Sebaceous neoplasms</td>

7861<td>

7862&lt;1</td>

7863<td>

78649.0</td>

7865<td>

7866[<a href="#cit/section_4.446">

7867446</a>

7868,<a href="#cit/section_4.465">

7869465</a>

7870,<a href="#cit/section_4.466">

7871466</a>

7872]</td>

7873</tr>

7874<tr>

7875<td>

7876Pancreas</td>

7877<td>

78781.6</td>

7879<td>

78800.4&#8211;3.7</td>

7881<td>

7882[<a href="#cit/section_4.457">

7883457</a>

7884,<a href="#cit/section_4.467">

7885467</a>

7886,<a href="#cit/section_4.468">

7887468</a>

7888]</td>

7889</tr>

7890</tbody>

7891</table>

7892<section id="_2963">

7893<h6 id="_2963_toc">

7894Additional cancers potentially associated with Lynch syndrome</h6>

7895<p id="_3030" tabindex="-1">

7896Additional tumors are being considered as part of the spectrum of Lynch syndrome, but this is controversial. Breast and prostate cancers have been raised as possible Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated tumors such that MMR genes are now included on multigene (panel) tests for these cancers.</p>

7897<section id="_2989">

7898<h6 id="_2989_toc">

7899Breast cancer</h6>

7900<section id="_sm_CDR0000743132_1">

7901<p id="_sm_CDR0000743132_2" tabindex="-1">

7902The issue of breast cancer risk in Lynch syndrome has been controversial.</p>

7903<p id="_sm_CDR0000743132_2" tabindex="-1">

7904 Retrospective studies have been inconsistent, but several have demonstrated microsatellite instability in a proportion of breast cancers from individuals with Lynch syndrome;[<a href="#cit/section_4.469">

7905469</a>

7906-<a href="#cit/section_4.472">

7907472</a>

7908] one of these studies evaluated breast cancer risk in individuals with Lynch syndrome and found that it is not elevated.[<a href="#cit/section_4.472">

7909472</a>

7910] However, the largest prospective study to date of 446 unaffected carriers of pathogenic variants from the Colon Cancer Family Registry [<a href="#cit/section_4.432">

7911432</a>

7912] who were followed for up to 10 years reported an elevated SIR of 3.95 for breast cancer (95% CI, 1.59&#8211;8.13; <em>

7913P</em>

7914 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.432">

7915432</a>

7916] The same group subsequently analyzed data on 764 carriers of MMR gene pathogenic variants with a prior diagnosis of colorectal cancer. Results showed that the 10-year risk of breast cancer following colorectal cancer was 2% (95% CI, 1%&#8211;4%) and that the SIR was 1.76 (95% CI, 1.07&#8211;2.59).[<a href="#cit/section_4.473">

7917473</a>

7918] A series from the United Kingdom composed of clinically referred Lynch syndrome kindreds, with efforts to correct for ascertainment, showed a twofold increased risk of breast cancer in 157 <em class="gene-name">

7919MLH1</em>

7920 carriers but not in carriers of other MMR variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.474">

7921474</a>

7922] Results from a meta-analysis of breast cancer risk in Lynch syndrome among 15 studies with molecular tumor testing results revealed that 62 of 122 breast cancers (51%; 95% CI, 42%&#8211;60%) in MMR pathogenic variant carriers were MMR-deficient. In addition, breast cancer risk estimates among a total of 21 studies showed an increased risk of twofold to 18-fold in eight studies that compared MMR variant carriers with noncarriers, while 13 studies did not observe statistical evidence for an association of breast cancer risk with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.475">

7923475</a>

7924]</p>

7925<p id="_sm_CDR0000743132_8" tabindex="-1">

7926A number of subsequent studies have suggested the presence of higher breast cancer risks than previously published,[<a href="#cit/section_4.366">

7927366</a>

7928,<a href="#cit/section_4.367">

7929367</a>

7930,<a href="#cit/section_4.476">

7931476</a>

7932,<a href="#cit/section_4.477">

7933477</a>

7934] although this has not been consistently observed.[<a href="#cit/section_4.360">

7935360</a>

7936] Through a study of 325 Canadian families with Lynch syndrome, primarily encompassing <em class="gene-name">

7937MLH1</em>

7938 and <em class="gene-name">

7939MSH2</em>

7940 carriers, the lifetime cumulative risk for breast cancer among <em class="gene-name">

7941MSH2</em>

7942 carriers was reported to be 22%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.476">

7943476</a>

7944] Similarly, breast cancer risks were elevated in a study of 423 women with Lynch syndrome, with substantially higher risks among those with <em class="gene-name">

7945MSH6</em>

7946 and <em class="gene-name">

7947PMS2</em>

7948 pathogenic variants, compared with <em class="gene-name">

7949MLH1</em>

7950 and <em class="gene-name">

7951MSH2</em>

7952 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.367">

7953367</a>

7954] In fact, breast cancer risk to age 60 years was 37.7% for <em class="gene-name">

7955PMS2</em>

7956, 31.1% for <em class="gene-name">

7957MSH6</em>

7958, 16.1% for <em class="gene-name">

7959MSH2</em>

7960, and 15.5% for <em class="gene-name">

7961MLH1</em>

7962. These findings are consistent with another study of 528 patients with Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated pathogenic variants (including <em class="gene-name">

7963MLH1</em>

7964, <em class="gene-name">

7965MSH2</em>

7966, <em class="gene-name">

7967MSH6</em>

7968, <em class="gene-name">

7969PMS2</em>

7970, and <em class="gene-name">

7971EPCAM</em>

7972) in which <em class="gene-name">

7973PMS2</em>

7974 and <em class="gene-name">

7975MSH6</em>

7976 variants were much more frequent among patients with only breast cancer, compared with those with only colorectal cancer (<em>

7977P</em>

7978 = 2.3 x 10<span class="sup">

7979-5</span>

7980).[<a href="#cit/section_4.366">

7981366</a>

7982]

7983Additional data to support an association of <em class="gene-name">

7984MSH6</em>

7985 with breast cancer were provided through a study of over 10,000 cancer patients across the United States who had genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.477">

7986477</a>

7987] Findings indicated that <em class="gene-name">

7988MSH6</em>

7989 was associated with breast cancer with an odds ratio (OR) of 2.59 (95% CI, 1.35&#8211;5.44). Taken together, these studies highlight how the risk profile among patients with Lynch syndrome is continuing to evolve as more individuals are tested through multigene panel testing, with representation of larger numbers of individuals with <em class="gene-name">

7990PMS2</em>

7991 and <em class="gene-name">

7992MSH6</em>

7993 pathogenic variants compared with prior studies.

7994In the absence of definitive risk estimates, individuals with Lynch syndrome are screened for breast cancer on the basis of family history.[<a href="#cit/section_4.478">

7995478</a>

7996]</p>

7997</section>

7998</section>

7999<section id="_2990">

8000<h6 id="_2990_toc">

8001Prostate cancer</h6>

8002<p id="_3" tabindex="-1">

8003Prostate cancer was found to be associated with Lynch syndrome in a study of 198 families from two U.S. Lynch syndrome registries in which prostate cancer had not originally been part of the family selection criteria. Prostate cancer risk in relatives of carriers of MMR gene pathogenic variants was 6.3% at age 60 years and 30% at age 80 years, versus a population risk of 2.6% at age 60 years and 18% at age 80 years, with an overall HR of 1.99 (95% CI, 1.31&#8211;3.03).[<a href="#cit/section_4.439">

8004439</a>

8005] A 2014 meta-analysis supports this association, finding an estimated RR of 3.67 (95% CI, 2.32&#8211;6.67) for prostate cancer in men with a known MMR pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_4.479">

8006479</a>

8007] This risk is possibly increased in those with <em class="gene-name">

8008MSH2</em>

8009 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.441">

8010441</a>

8011,<a href="#cit/section_4.479">

8012479</a>

8013] Notwithstanding prevalent controversy surrounding routine prostate-specific antigen (PSA) screening, the authors suggested that screening by means of PSA and digital rectal exam beginning at age 40 years in male MMR gene carriers would be &#8220;reasonable to consider.&#8221;[<a href="#cit/section_4.439">

8014439</a>

8015] A study of 692 men with metastatic prostate cancer unselected for family history of cancer or age at diagnosis identified germline MMR pathogenic variants in four men (0.5%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.480">

8016480</a>

8017] Currently, molecular and epidemiological evidence supports prostate cancer as one of the Lynch syndrome cancers. As with breast cancer,[<a href="#cit/section_4.479">

8018479</a>

8019] additional studies are needed to define absolute risks and age distribution before surveillance guidelines for prostate cancer can be developed for carriers of MMR pathogenic variants. (Refer to the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-genetics-pdq#_947">

8020MMR Genes</a>

8021 section in the PDQ summary on <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-genetics-pdq">

8022Genetics of Prostate Cancer</a>

8023 for more information about prostate cancer and Lynch syndrome.)</p>

8024</section>

8025<section id="_2991">

8026<h6 id="_2991_toc">

8027Adrenocortical cancer</h6>

8028<p id="_4" tabindex="-1">

8029In a series of 114 ACC cases, of which 94 patients had a detailed family history assessment and Li-Fraumeni syndrome was excluded, three patients had family histories that were suggestive of Lynch syndrome. The prevalence of MMR gene pathogenic variants in 94 families was 3.2%, similar to the proportion of Lynch syndrome among unselected colorectal and endometrial cancer patients. In a retrospective review of 135 MMR gene pathogenic variant&#8211;positive Lynch syndrome families from the same program, two probands were found to have had a history of ACC. Of the four ACCs in which MSI testing could be performed, all were MSS. These data suggest that if Lynch syndrome is otherwise suspected in an ACC index case, an initial evaluation of the ACC using MSI or IHC testing may be misleading.[<a href="#cit/section_4.440">

8030440</a>

8031]</p>

8032</section>

8033<section id="_2992">

8034<h6 id="_2992_toc">

8035Other cancers</h6>

8036<p id="_2993" tabindex="-1">

8037Several additional cancers have been found to be associated with Lynch syndrome in some studies, but further investigation is warranted. <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3024">

8038Table 12</a>

8039 compares the risk of these cancers in the general population with that of individuals with Lynch syndrome.</p>

8040</section>

8041</section>

8042</section>

8043</section>

8044</section>

8045<section id="_1142">

8046<h4 id="_1142_toc">

8047Management of Lynch syndrome</h4>

8048<section id="_3109">

8049<h5 id="_3109_toc">

8050Screening and surveillance in Lynch syndrome</h5>

8051<section id="_1144">

8052<h6 id="_1144_toc">

8053Colon cancer screening and surveillance in Lynch syndrome</h6>

8054<p id="_271" tabindex="-1">

8055Several aspects of the biologic behavior of CRC and its precursor lesion, the adenomatous polyp, in individuals with Lynch syndrome support a different approach to

8056CRC screening in this population as compared with those recommendations for average-risk people in the general population. At present, the recommendations for cancer screening and surveillance in Lynch syndrome take into account the differences in cancer risks as compared with those in the general population due to the causative germline deficiency in the MMR system. The following biological differences form the basis of the currently implemented screening strategies in Lynch syndrome:</p>

8057<div class="pdq-content-list">

8058<ul id="_2761">

8059<li>

8060<strong>

8061CRC and adenomas present at a younger age.</strong>

8062 <p id="_3054" tabindex="-1">

8063CRCs in Lynch syndrome occur earlier in life than do sporadic cancers; however, the age of onset varies based on which of the MMR genes is altered. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1113">

8064Prevalence, clinical manifestations, and cancer risks associated with Lynch syndrome</a>

8065 section of this summary for more information about gene-specific age of onset of CRC.)</p>

8066<p id="_2965" tabindex="-1">

8067Carriers of Lynch syndrome pathogenic variants have an increased risk of developing colon adenomas and the onset of adenomas appears to occur at a younger age than in pathogenic variant&#8211;negative individuals from the same families.[<a href="#cit/section_4.481">

8068481</a>

8069] The risk of a carrier of MMR pathogenic variants developing adenomas has been reported to be 3.6 times higher than the risk in noncarriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.481">

8070481</a>

8071] By age 60 years, 70% of the carriers developed adenomas, compared with 20% of noncarriers. Most of the adenomas in carriers had absence of MMR protein expression and were more likely to have dysplastic features, compared with adenomas from control subjects.[<a href="#cit/section_4.481">

8072481</a>

8073]</p>

8074<p id="_2966" tabindex="-1">

8075In one study, the mean age at diagnosis of adenoma in carriers was 43.3 years (range, 23&#8211;63.2 y), and the mean age at diagnosis of carcinoma was 45.8 years (range, 25.2&#8211;57.6 y).[<a href="#cit/section_4.481">

8076481</a>

8077]</p>

8078</li>

8079<li>

8080<strong>

8081There is a right-sided predominance of colon cancer.</strong>

8082 <p id="_2763" tabindex="-1">

8083A larger proportion of Lynch syndrome CRCs (60%&#8211;70%) occur in the right colon, suggesting that sigmoidoscopy alone is not an appropriate screening strategy and that a colonoscopy provides a more complete structural examination of the colon. Evidence-based reviews of surveillance colonoscopy in Lynch syndrome have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_4.124">

8084124</a>

8085,<a href="#cit/section_4.482">

8086482</a>

8087,<a href="#cit/section_4.483">

8088483</a>

8089] The incidence of CRC throughout life is substantially higher in patients with Lynch syndrome, suggesting that the most-sensitive test available should be used. (Refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3427">

8090Table 13</a>

8091 for available colon surveillance recommendations.)</p>

8092</li>

8093<li>

8094<strong>

8095The adenoma-carcinoma sequence is accelerated.</strong>

8096<p id="_2769" tabindex="-1">

8097The progression from normal mucosa to adenoma to cancer is accelerated,[<a href="#cit/section_4.484">

8098484</a>

8099,<a href="#cit/section_4.485">

8100485</a>

8101] suggesting that screening should be performed at shorter intervals (every 1&#8211;2 years) and with colonoscopy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.485">

8102485</a>

8103-<a href="#cit/section_4.488">

8104488</a>

8105] It has been demonstrated that carriers of MMR gene pathogenic variants develop detectable adenomas at an earlier age than do noncarriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.481">

8106481</a>

8107,<a href="#cit/section_4.481">

8108481</a>

8109] It is not known whether this reflects a greater prevalence of adenomas or the presence of larger adenomas with better detection in Lynch syndrome. </p>

8110 </li>

8111</ul>

8112</div>

8113<section id="_2967">

8114<h6 id="_2967_toc">

8115Evidence for the use of colonoscopy for CRC screening and surveillance in Lynch syndrome</h6>

8116<p id="_3039" tabindex="-1">

8117The risk of CRC in Lynch syndrome has been studied and updated in a Finnish screening trial, which spans from the early 1980s to present.[<a href="#cit/section_4.485">

8118485</a>

8119,<a href="#cit/section_4.489">

8120489</a>

8121] Over the course of this trial, the design of the longitudinal study has evolved. In the earliest period, information about each individual's variant status was unknown and study participants were eligible based on fulfillment of clinical criteria; the study consisted of some people with a previous cancer or adenoma diagnosis and others without such history who were undergoing asymptomatic screening while the comparison group was composed of individuals from those same families who refused screening. Many of these people (68%) had screening with x-ray contrast/barium enema. Colonoscopy was the approach used for carriers of MMR pathogenic variants when this information was obtainable and the interval between exams was shortened from 5 years to 3 years to 2 years, based on results from the study over time.</p>

8122<p id="_2994" tabindex="-1">

8123A 15-year controlled screening trial conducted in this series demonstrated a reduction in the incidence of CRC, CRC-specific mortality, and overall mortality with colonoscopy in individuals from Lynch syndrome families.[<a href="#cit/section_4.485">

8124485</a>

8125] Colonic screening was provided at 3-year intervals in 133 individuals from Lynch syndrome families and 119 controls from these families had no screening. Among those screened, 8 individuals (6%) developed CRC compared with 19 control subjects (16%), for a risk reduction of 62% with screening. Furthermore, all CRCs in the screened group were local, causing no deaths, while there were 9 deaths caused by CRC in the control group. There was also a benefit in overall mortality in the screened group with 10 deaths in the screened group and 26 deaths in the control group (<em>

8126P</em>

8127 = .003).</p>

8128<p id="_3040" tabindex="-1">

8129The series subsequently limited its attention to subjects without prior diagnosis of adenoma or cancer. The eligible 420 carriers of pathogenic variants had a mean age of 36 years and underwent an average of 2.1 colonoscopies, with a median follow-up of 6.7 years. Adenomas were detected in 28% of subjects. Cumulative risk of one or more adenomas by age 60 years was 68.5% in men and 48.3% in women. Notably, risk of detecting cancer in those free of cancer at baseline exam, and thus regarded as interval cancers, by age 60 years was 34.6% in men and 22.1% in women. The combined cumulative risk of adenoma or cancer by age 60 years was 81.8% in men and 62.9% in women. For both adenomas and carcinomas, about one-half were located proximal to the splenic flexure. While the rates for CRC despite colonoscopy surveillance appear high, the recommended short intervals were not regularly adhered to in this nonrandomized series. These authors recommended surveillance at 2-year intervals. This is in line with most consensus guidelines (refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3427">

8130Table 13</a>

8131), in which the appropriate colonoscopy screening interval remains every 1 to 2 years. Analysis of colonoscopic surveillance data in 242 carriers of pathogenic variants 10 years after testing shows 95% compliance in surveillance procedures for CRC and endometrial cancer. Although not all CRCs were prevented, mortality was comparable with variant-negative relatives. However, this may be attributable to the modest sample size of the study.[<a href="#cit/section_4.489">

8132489</a>

8133]</p>

8134<p id="_3390" tabindex="-1">

8135Individuals with Lynch syndrome are at an increased risk of developing synchronous CRC. Of 5,304 CRC cases in the Danish HNPCC

8136Register, including 774 with Lynch syndrome, the relative risks of synchronous CRC (&gt;1 CRC) diagnosed within 1 year of primary CRC for Lynch syndrome, familial CRC (cases meeting Amsterdam I

8137or II criteria) and metachronous CRC (1 CRC at age &lt;50 y or &gt;2 CRCs at age &gt;50 y) were 5.6, 3.2, and 1.9,

8138respectively, compared with sporadic CRC. Thus, the increased risk of synchronous CRC in

8139patients with a strong family history of CRC, and especially Lynch syndrome, should be

8140considered in preoperative colonoscopic examinations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.490">

8141490</a>

8142]</p>

8143<p id="_2948" tabindex="-1">

8144 Given that colonoscopy is the accepted measure for colon cancer surveillance, preliminary data suggest that the use of chromoendoscopy, such as with indigo carmine, may increase the detection of diminutive, histologically advanced adenomas.[<a href="#cit/section_4.491">

8145491</a>

8146,<a href="#cit/section_4.492">

8147492</a>

8148]</p>

8149<p id="_1244" tabindex="-1">

8150When an adenoma is detected, the question of whether to test the adenoma for MSI/IHC is raised. One study of patients with prior CRC and known MMR pathogenic variants found eight of 12 adenomas to have both MSI and IHC protein loss.[<a href="#cit/section_4.493">

8151493</a>

8152] However, the study authors emphasized that normal MSI/IHC testing in an adenoma does not exclude Lynch syndrome. Abnormal MSI/IHC are uncommon in the smallest adenomas, and more prevalent in adenomas larger than 8 mm, which also suggests that the MMR defect is acquired in the growing adenoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.494">

8153494</a>

8154]</p>

8155<p id="_2770" tabindex="-1">

8156<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531811&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531811&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8157Level of evidence (colon surveillance): 2ai</a>

8158</p>

8159</section>

8160<section id="_2973">

8161<h6 id="_2973_toc">

8162Special considerations: The impact of gene-specific variability in cancer risk on CRC screening recommendations in Lynch syndrome</h6>

8163<p id="_1077" tabindex="-1">

8164Because of the variability of gene-specific CRC risks, experts in the field have proposed gene-specific screening and surveillance recommendations. For example, a European consortium [<a href="#cit/section_4.406">

8165406</a>

8166] made a clinical recommendation for delaying the onset of colorectal and endometrial cancer screening to age 30 years, in line with their recommendation for later initiation of screening for carriers of <em class="gene-name">

8167MSH6</em>

8168 pathogenic variants.

8169Additionally, a 2015 review by an ad hoc American virtual workgroup involved in the care of Lynch syndrome patients and families concluded that despite multiple studies indicating reduced penetrance in monoallelic <em class="gene-name">

8170PMS2</em>

8171 carriers, they could not recommend any changes to Lynch syndrome cancer surveillance guidelines for this group.[<a href="#cit/section_4.402">

8172402</a>

8173]</p>

8174<p id="_3414" tabindex="-1">

8175Available recommendations for colon surveillance in individuals with Lynch syndrome are summarized in <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3427">

8176Table 13</a>

8177. Most organizations tailor surveillance recommendations for each specific gene.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

8178122</a>

8179,<a href="#cit/section_4.495">

8180495</a>

8181-<a href="#cit/section_4.497">

8182497</a>

8183] All of the screening recommendations assume findings are normal. A more aggressive screening schedule might be considered on an individualized basis.

8184</p>

8185<table id="_3427" class="table-default expandable-container">

8186<caption>

8187Table 13. Gene-Specific Practice Guidelines for Colon Surveillance of Lynch Syndrome<span class="sup">

8188a</span>

8189</caption>

8190<colgroup>

8191<col width="14.45%">

8192<col width="15.02%">

8193<col width="15.31%">

8194<col width="17.19%">

8195<col width="15.60%">

8196<col width="22.39%">

8197</colgroup>

8198<THead>

8199<tr>

8200<th>

8201Organization</th>

8202<th>

8203<em class="gene-name">

8204MLH1</em>

8205</th>

8206<th>

8207<em class="gene-name">

8208MSH2</em>

8209</th>

8210<th>

8211<em class="gene-name">

8212MSH6</em>

8213</th>

8214<th>

8215<em class="gene-name">

8216PMS2 </em>

8217</th>

8218<th>

8219<em class="gene-name">

8220EPCAM</em>

8221</th>

8222</tr>

8223</THead>

8224<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

8225<tr>

8226<td colspan="6">

8227CRC = colorectal cancer; EHTG = European Hereditary Tumor Group; ESCP = European Society of Coloproctology; ESMO = European Society for Medical Oncology; MMR = mismatch repair; NCCN = National Comprehensive Cancer Network.</td>

8228</tr>

8229<tr>

8230<td colspan="6">

8231<span class="sup">

8232a</span>

8233This table summarizes available guidelines from 2014 and later. Other organizations, including the American Cancer Society, have published guidelines before 2014.[<a href="#cit/section_4.498">

8234498</a>

8235]</td>

8236</tr>

8237<tr>

8238<td colspan="6">

8239<span class="sup">

8240b</span>

8241U.S. Multi-Society Task Force on Colorectal Cancer includes the following organizations: American Academy of Family Practice, American College of Gastroenterology, American College of Physicians-American Society of Internal Medicine, American College of Radiology, American Gastroenterological Association, American Society of Colorectal Surgeons, and American Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy.</td>

8242</tr>

8243<tr>

8244<td colspan="6">

8245<span class="sup">

8246c</span>

8247Consider later age for <em class="gene-name">

8248MSH6</em>

8249 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.497">

8250497</a>

8251] </td>

8252</tr>

8253<tr>

8254<td colspan="6">

8255<span class="sup">

8256d</span>

8257Consider repeating colonoscopy every 5 years for <em class="gene-name">

8258PMS2</em>

8259 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.496">

8260496</a>

8261] </td>

8262</tr>

8263<tr>

8264<td colspan="6">

8265<span class="sup">

8266e</span>

8267Consider starting at age 30 for <em class="gene-name">

8268MSH6</em>

8269 carriers and 35 for <em class="gene-name">

8270PMS2</em>

8271 carriers. Consider annual colonoscopy for MMR carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.335">

8272335</a>

8273]</td>

8274</tr>

8275</TFoot>

8276<tbody>

8277<tr>

8278<td>

8279NCCN (2022) [<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

8280122</a>

8281] </td>

8282<td>

8283Colonoscopy at age 20&#8211;25 y or 2&#8211;5 y prior to earliest CRC in the family if it was diagnosed before age 25 y; repeat colonoscopy every 1&#8211;2 y </td>

8284<td>

8285Colonoscopy at age 20&#8211;25 y or 2&#8211;5 y prior to earliest CRC in the family if it was diagnosed before age 25 y; repeat colonoscopy every 1&#8211;2 y </td>

8286<td>

8287Colonoscopy at age 30&#8211;35 y or 2&#8211;5 y prior to earliest CRC in the family if it was diagnosed before age 30 y; repeat colonoscopy every 1&#8211;3 y </td>

8288<td>

8289Colonoscopy at age 30&#8211;35 y or 2&#8211;5 y prior to earliest CRC in the family if it was diagnosed before age 30 y; repeat colonoscopy every 1&#8211;3 y </td>

8290<td>

8291NCCN recommends that <em class="gene-name">

8292EPCAM</em>

8293 carriers be managed the same as <em class="gene-name">

8294MSH2</em>

8295 carriers. Colonoscopy at age 20&#8211;25 y or 2&#8211;5 y prior to the earliest CRC in the family if it was diagnosed before age 25 y; repeat colonoscopy every 1&#8211;2 y </td>

8296</tr>

8297<tr>

8298<td>

8299ESMO (2020) [<a href="#cit/section_4.497">

8300497</a>

8301]</td>

8302<td>

8303Colonoscopy at age 25 y or 5 y prior to earliest CRC if diagnosed before age 25 y; repeat every 1&#8211;2 y</td>

8304<td>

8305Colonoscopy at age 25 y or 5 y prior to earliest CRC if diagnosed before age 25 y; repeat every 1&#8211;2 y</td>

8306<td>

8307Colonoscopy at age 35 y or 5 y prior to earliest CRC if diagnosed before age 25 y<span class="sup">

8308c</span>

8309; repeat every 1&#8211;2 y</td>

8310<td>

8311Colonoscopy at age 35 y or 5 y prior to earliest CRC if diagnosed before age 25 y; repeat every 1&#8211;2 y</td>

8312<td>

8313Not addressed</td>

8314</tr>

8315<tr>

8316<td>

8317British Society of Gastroenterology (BSG)/ Association of Coloproctology of Great Britain and Ireland (ACPGBI)/ United Kingdom Cancer Genetics Group (UKCGG) (2020) [<a href="#cit/section_4.495">

8318495</a>

8319]</td>

8320<td>

8321Colonoscopy at age 25 y; repeat every 2 y until age 75 y</td>

8322<td>

8323Colonoscopy at age 25 y; repeat every 2 y until age 75 y</td>

8324<td>

8325Colonoscopy at age 35 y; repeat every 2 y until age 75 y</td>

8326<td>

8327Colonoscopy at age 35 y; repeat every 2 y until age 75 y</td>

8328<td>

8329<em class="gene-name">

8330EPCAM</em>

8331 carriers should be managed as those with <em class="gene-name">

8332MSH2</em>

8333 pathogenic variants</td>

8334</tr>

8335<tr>

8336<td>

8337European guidelines from the EHTG and ESCP; updated Mallorca group guidelines (2021) [<a href="#cit/section_4.496">

8338496</a>

8339]</td>

8340<td>

8341Colonoscopy at age 25 y; repeat every 2&#8211;3 y</td>

8342<td>

8343Colonoscopy at age 25 y; repeat every 2&#8211;3 y</td>

8344<td>

8345Colonoscopy at age 35 y; repeat every 2&#8211;3 y</td>

8346<td>

8347Colonoscopy at age 35 y; repeat every 2&#8211;3 y<span class="sup">

8348d</span>

8349</td>

8350<td>

8351Not addressed</td>

8352</tr>

8353<tr>

8354<td>

8355U.S. Multi-Society Task Force on Colorectal Cancer (2014)<span class="sup">

8356b</span>

8357 [<a href="#cit/section_4.335">

8358335</a>

8359] </td>

8360<td colspan="5">

8361Colonoscopy beginning at age 20&#8211;25 y for 2&#8211;5 y prior to earliest CRC if before age 25 y; repeat every 1&#8211;2 y<span class="sup">

8362e</span>

8363</td>

8364</tr>

8365</tbody>

8366</table>

8367</section>

8368</section>

8369<section id="_2975">

8370<h6 id="_2975_toc">

8371Extracolonic cancer screening in Lynch syndrome</h6>

8372<section id="_3112">

8373<h6 id="_3112_toc">

8374Endometrial cancer screening in Lynch syndrome</h6>

8375<p id="_280" tabindex="-1">

8376Note: A separate PDQ summary on <a href="/types/uterine/hp/endometrial-screening-pdq">

8377Endometrial Cancer Screening</a>

8378 in the general

8379population is also available.

8380</p>

8381<p id="_281" tabindex="-1">

8382Cancer of the endometrium is the most common extracolonic cancer observed in Lynch syndrome

8383families, affecting at least one female in about 50% of Lynch syndrome families. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2950">

8384Endometrial cancer</a>

8385 section of this summary for more information about gene-specific risks of endometrial cancer in carriers of MMR pathogenic variants.) </p>

8386<p id="_755" tabindex="-1">

8387In the general population, the diagnosis of endometrial cancer is generally made when women present with symptoms like abnormal or postmenopausal bleeding. Endometrial sampling is performed to provide a histological specimen for diagnosis. Eighty percent of women with endometrial cancer present with stage I disease, and there are no data to suggest that the clinical presentation in women with Lynch syndrome differs from that in the general population.</p>

8388<p id="_3041" tabindex="-1">

8389Given their substantial increased risk of endometrial cancer, endometrial cancer screening has been suggested for women with Lynch syndrome who have not had risk-reducing hysterectomies. Proposed screening methods include transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) and/or endometrial biopsy. However, current NCCN guidelines suggest that these screening methods may not benefit women with Lynch syndrome. Screening via endometrial biopsy can be considered in patients with Lynch syndrome, due to its high levels of sensitivity and specificity. Screening may begin at age 30 to 35 years and can be repeated every 1 to 2 years. TVUS, on the other hand, is not sensitive or specific at detecting endometrial cancer. However, this screening method can be considered in women with Lynch syndrome based on a provider's judgment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

8390122</a>

8391]</p>

8392<p id="_3467" tabindex="-1">

8393Two studies have examined the use of TVUS in endometrial screening for women with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.499">

8394499</a>

8395,<a href="#cit/section_4.500">

8396500</a>

8397] In one study of 292 women from Lynch syndrome families or "Lynch syndrome-like/HNPCC-like" families, TVUS did not detect any endometrial cancer cases. However, two interval cancers developed in symptomatic women.[<a href="#cit/section_4.499">

8398499</a>

8399] In a second study, 41 women with Lynch syndrome were enrolled in a TVUS screening program. Of 179 TVUS procedures performed, 17 scans were abnormal. Three of the 17 women with abnormal scans had complex atypical hyperplasia on endometrial sampling, while 14 had normal endometrial sampling. However, TVUS failed to identify one patient who presented with abnormal bleeding 8 months after a normal TVUS was performed; this patient was diagnosed with stage IB endometrial cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.500">

8400500</a>

8401] Both of these studies concluded that TVUS is neither sensitive nor specific.</p>

8402<p id="_282" tabindex="-1">

8403A study of 175 women with Lynch syndrome, which included both endometrial sampling and TVUS, showed that endometrial sampling improved sensitivity when compared with TVUS. Endometrial sampling found 11 of the 14 cases of endometrial cancer. Two of these cases were interval cancers that developed in symptomatic women, and one case was an occult endometrial cancer found at the time of hysterectomy. Endometrial sampling also identified 14 additional cases of endometrial hyperplasia. Among the group of 14 women with endometrial cancer, ten also had TVUS screening with endometrial sampling. Four of the ten women had abnormal TVUS, while six women had normal TVUS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.501">

8404501</a>

8405] While this cohort study demonstrated that endometrial sampling may have benefits over TVUS for endometrial screening, there are no data that predict that screening with any other modality has benefits for endometrial cancer survival in women with Lynch syndrome.</p>

8406<p id="_2979" tabindex="-1">

8407Some studies suggest that women with a clinical or genetic diagnosis of Lynch syndrome do not participate in intensive gynecologic screening.[<a href="#cit/section_4.502">

8408502</a>

8409,<a href="#cit/section_4.503">

8410503</a>

8411] (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_558">

8412Gynecologic cancer screening in Lynch syndrome</a>

8413 section in the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_189">

8414Psychosocial Issues in Hereditary Colon Cancer Syndromes</a>

8415 section of this summary for more information.) </p>

8416<p id="_286" tabindex="-1">

8417<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8418Level of evidence: 5</a>

8419</p>

8420</section>

8421<section id="_3113">

8422<h6 id="_3113_toc">

8423Ovarian cancer screening in Lynch syndrome</h6>

8424<p id="_2978" tabindex="-1">

8425Estimates of the cumulative lifetime risk of ovarian cancer in Lynch syndrome patients range from 3.4% to 22%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

84264</a>

8427,<a href="#cit/section_4.383">

8428383</a>

8429,<a href="#cit/section_4.457">

8430457</a>

8431-<a href="#cit/section_4.459">

8432459</a>

8433] TVUS and/or CA-125 can be used to screen for ovarian cancer in women with Lynch syndrome who have not had risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomies. However, NCCN does not recommend routine ovarian cancer screening with TVUS or CA-125, since these tests lack sensitivity and specificity. In addition, studies examining the effectiveness of ovarian cancer screening in women with Lynch syndrome are not currently available. Therefore, TVUS and/or CA-125 can be considered based on a provider's judgment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

8434122</a>

8435]</p>

8436<p id="_3016" tabindex="-1">

8437Level of evidence: None assigned</p>

8438</section>

8439<section id="_2980">

8440<h6 id="_2980_toc">

8441Risk-reducing surgeries for the prevention of gynecologic cancers in Lynch syndrome</h6>

8442<p id="_2981" tabindex="-1">

8443Risk-reducing surgery is an effective strategy for preventing endometrial and ovarian cancers in Lynch syndrome families. A retrospective study of 315 women with pathogenic MMR gene variants compared the rate of endometrial and ovarian cancers among women who did and did not have hysterectomies and oophorectomies. The mean follow-up periods for endometrial cancer were 13.3 years in the surgical group and 7.4 years in the nonsurgical group. The mean follow-up periods for ovarian cancer were 11.2 years in the surgical group and 10.6 years in the nonsurgical group. In the surgical group, no cancers were diagnosed. In contrast, 33% of women were diagnosed with endometrial cancer, and 5.5% of women were diagnosed with ovarian cancer in the nonsurgical group.[<a href="#cit/section_4.504">

8444504</a>

8445] Cost-effectiveness&#8211;analysis modeling of risk-reducing surgeries (prophylactic hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy) versus nonsurgical screening was conducted in a theoretical population of 30-year old MMR pathogenic variant carriers. This analysis revealed that prophylactic surgery was cost-effective and yielded higher QALY.[<a href="#cit/section_4.464">

8446464</a>

8447] A subsequent modeling study evaluated multiple screening and surgical strategies. This study found that annual screening beginning at age 30 years followed by risk-reducing surgery at age 40 years was the most effective strategy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.505">

8448505</a>

8449]</p>

8450<p id="_3017" tabindex="-1">

8451<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531815&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531815&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8452Level of evidence: 3aii</a>

8453</p>

8454</section>

8455<section id="_3114">

8456<h6 id="_3114_toc">

8457Additional extracolonic cancer screening in Lynch syndrome</h6>

8458<p id="_2995" tabindex="-1">

8459The decision to screen for other Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated cancers is done on an individual basis and relies on the cancers reported among FDRs and SDRs with Lynch syndrome.</p>

8460<section id="_2996">

8461<h6 id="_2996_toc">

8462Gastric and small bowel cancers</h6>

8463<p id="_2997" tabindex="-1">

8464The lifetime risk of gastric cancer is approximately 8% for male Lynch syndrome carriers and 5% for female Lynch syndrome carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.460">

8465460</a>

8466] Recent epidemiological data report a decreasing trend in the diagnosis of gastric cancer than was previously reported, which was as high as 13%. The histological characterization of most Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated gastric cancers are of the intestinal type and may therefore be detected using screening esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD).[<a href="#cit/section_4.460">

8467460</a>

8468,<a href="#cit/section_4.506">

8469506</a>

8470] NCCN recommends that EGD with random biopsy of the proximal and distal stomach be initiated at age 30 to 40 years in individuals with Lynch syndrome. This screening can be repeated every 2 to 4 years. Screening can be initiated before age 30 years if any of the following are present: a family history of cancers in the upper GI system, gastric intestinal metaplasia, gastric/duodenal adenomas, or Barrett's esophagus with dysplasia. Other risk factors for gastric cancer include the following: male sex, older age, an <em class="gene-name">

8471MLH1</em>

8472 or <em class="gene-name">

8473MSH2</em>

8474 pathogenic variant, Asian ethnicity, residing in or emigrating from countries with a high background incidence of gastric cancer, autoimmune gastritis, and <em>

8475H. pylori.</em>

8476 infection.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

8477122</a>

8478]</p>

8479<p id="_2999" tabindex="-1">

8480There are variable reports on the lifetime risk of small bowel cancer associated with Lynch syndrome, ranging from less than 1% to 12%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

84814</a>

8482,<a href="#cit/section_4.391">

8483391</a>

8484,<a href="#cit/section_4.456">

8485456</a>

8486-<a href="#cit/section_4.458">

8487458</a>

8488,<a href="#cit/section_4.461">

8489461</a>

8490] Most small bowel malignancies are confined to the duodenum and the ileum, which are within endoscopic reach using EGD and colonoscopy (with dedicated ileal intubation), respectively. Other modalities to assess for small bowel lesions include CT enterography and capsule endoscopy but cost-effectiveness analyses do not support use of these evaluations for routine screening in Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.459">

8491459</a>

8492] </p>

8493<p id="_3479" tabindex="-1">

8494In a single-center retrospective study, researchers analyzed the prevalence of clinically actionable endoscopic findings in 323 asymptomatic Lynch syndrome carriers undergoing EGD for upper GI cancer surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.507">

8495507</a>

8496] Sixty-five clinically actionable findings were identified in 57 patients (17.6%), including five individuals with upper GI cancers (1.5%)&#8211;which were all detected at an early stage. Cancers were diagnosed at a mean age of 60.2 years (range, 50&#8211;73 y). Three of the individuals with upper GI cancers were women. Four out of five individuals with upper GI cancers had an <em class="gene-name">

8497MSH2</em>

8498 pathogenic variant, and one had an <em class="gene-name">

8499MLH1</em>

8500 pathogenic variant. One patient had Barrett's esophagus&#8211;related esophageal adenocarcinoma, one patient had a type 3 gastric neuroendocrine tumor, one patient had a gastric adenocarcinoma, and two patients had duodenal adenocarcinomas. These malignancies were detected in Lynch syndrome carriers on baseline EGDs or up to 16 months after surveillance EGDs. The study&#8217;s investigators concluded that additional research is needed to investigate the upper GI cancers that developed in the short interval between EGDs.</p>

8501<p id="_3480" tabindex="-1">

8502Esophageal findings in this study included Barrett&#8217;s esophagus, which was detected in 6.5% of participants. This percentage is similar to the prevalence of Barrett's esophagus in North American individuals with gastroesophageal reflux disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.507">

8503507</a>

8504]</p>

8505<p id="_3485" tabindex="-1">

8506In addition, 261 subjects underwent gastric biopsy sampling, and the following findings were observed:</p>

8507<div class="pdq-content-list">

8508<ul id="_3486">

8509<li>

8510Ten patients had <em>

8511H. pylori</em>

8512 (3.8%).</li>

8513<li>

8514Fifteen patients had gastric intestinal metaplasia (5.7%).</li>

8515<li>

8516Five patients had duodenal adenomas (1.5%) at a mean age of 55.8 years (range, 27&#8211;75 y). One patient had an adenoma with high-grade dysplasia, and one patient had an adenoma with tubulovillous histology. Four adenomas were found in the third part of the duodenum, and one adenoma was found in the second part of the duodenum.</li>

8517<li>

8518Two patients had gastric adenomas (0.6%). One of these patients had an adenoma with high-grade dysplasia. Patients had gastric adenomas at a mean age of 71.6 years (range, 70&#8211;73 y).</li>

8519</ul>

8520</div>

8521<p id="_3481" tabindex="-1">

8522EGD surveillance is strongly recommended in patients with Lynch syndrome, given the high prevalence and high incidence of clinically actionable findings on EGD and the favorable benefit of identifying these findings at an early stage.</p>

8523<p id="_3042" tabindex="-1">

8524<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8525Level of evidence: 5</a>

8526</p>

8527</section>

8528<section id="_3000">

8529<h6 id="_3000_toc">

8530Urinary tract cancer</h6>

8531<p id="_3001" tabindex="-1">

8532Urinary tract malignancies include those of the transitional cell type of the renal pelvis and ureters, and the bladder. The associated lifetime risk of these malignancies is variable, ranging from less than 1% to as high as 25%, with higher estimates related to pooling the cancers found in different locations within the urinary tract and including the bladder.[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

85334</a>

8534,<a href="#cit/section_4.391">

8535391</a>

8536,<a href="#cit/section_4.457">

8537457</a>

8538,<a href="#cit/section_4.458">

8539458</a>

8540,<a href="#cit/section_4.461">

8541461</a>

8542,<a href="#cit/section_4.462">

8543462</a>

8544] Studies that have evaluated urinary cytology as a potential screening modality revealed that it was associated with low sensitivity and a high false-positive rate and ultimately leads to additional evaluation that is often invasive (i.e., cystoscopy). Screening for renal pelvis,

8545ureter, and/or

8546bladder cancers is generally not recommended in individuals with Lynch syndrome. However, NCCN suggests considering urothelial cancer surveillance for individuals with a family history of urothelial cancer or for individuals (especially men) with an <em class="gene-name">

8547MSH2</em>

8548 pathogenic variant. Annual urinalysis can begin at age 30 to 35 years in individuals with an <em class="gene-name">

8549MSH2</em>

8550 pathogenic variant.</p>

8551<p id="_3046" tabindex="-1">

8552<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8553Level of evidence: 5</a>

8554</p>

8555</section>

8556<section id="_3002">

8557<h6 id="_3002_toc">

8558Pancreatic cancer</h6>

8559<p id="_3003" tabindex="-1">

8560An elevated risk of pancreatic cancer among Lynch syndrome carriers has been supported by two cohort studies that adjust for ascertainment bias. One study reported a cumulative risk of pancreatic cancer of 3.7% by age 70 years and an 8.6-fold increase compared with the general population. [<a href="#cit/section_4.468">

8561468</a>

8562] Another prospective study using data from the Colon Cancer Family Registry reported an SIR of 10.7 with cumulative risk of 0.95%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.432">

8563432</a>

8564] Results of these studies have supported an expert consensus that recommended screening for pancreatic cancer in individuals with Lynch syndrome and an FDR with pancreatic cancer, similar to other high-risk populations with comparable risk.[<a href="#cit/section_4.508">

8565508</a>

8566]</p>

8567<p id="_3004" tabindex="-1">

8568 Pancreatic cancer screening may be considered in individuals with <em class="gene-name">

8569MLH1</em>

8570, <em class="gene-name">

8571MSH2</em>

8572, or <em class="gene-name">

8573MSH6</em>

8574 pathogenic variants if they have one or more FDRs or SDRs with exocrine pancreatic cancer (if these family members are on the same side of the family as the individual with Lynch syndrome). Pancreatic cancer screening can begin at age 50 years or 10 years prior to youngest pancreatic cancer diagnosis in the family. Screening typically consists of annual contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging/magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) and/or endoscopic ultrasound (EUS). However, screening can be done more frequently if abnormal findings are found on MRCP/EUS. NCCN recommends that MRCP/EUS occur at a high-volume center that has experience screening individuals with Lynch syndrome. Health care providers are encouraged to have a discussion with patients about pancreatic screening limitations, including the following: the cost of annual pancreatic cancer screening, the high occurrence of benign and indeterminate pancreatic lesions, and the uncertainty regarding the effectiveness of pancreatic cancer screening.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

8575122</a>

8576]</p>

8577<p id="_3047" tabindex="-1">

8578<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8579Level of evidence: 5</a>

8580</p>

8581</section>

8582</section>

8583</section>

8584</section>

8585<section id="_1148">

8586<h5 id="_1148_toc">

8587Chemoprevention in Lynch syndrome</h5>

8588<p id="_1413" tabindex="-1">

8589The Colorectal Adenoma/Carcinoma Prevention Programme (CAPP2) was a double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomized trial to determine the role of aspirin in preventing CRC in patients with Lynch syndrome who were in surveillance programs at a number of international centers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.509">

8590509</a>

8591] The study randomly assigned 861 participants (mean age, 45 y) to receive aspirin (600 mg/day), aspirin-placebo, resistant starch (30 g/day), or starch-placebo for up to 4 years. Initial CAPP2 trial results for 746 Lynch syndrome patients enrolled in the study were published in 2008 [<a href="#cit/section_4.510">

8592510</a>

8593] and failed to show a significant preventive effect on incident colonic adenomas or carcinomas (relative risk, 1.0; 95% CI, 0.7&#8211;1.4) with a short-term follow-up (mean, 29 months; range, 7&#8211;74 months). In 2011 (mean follow-up, 55.7 months), subsequent data were published on 861 individuals randomly assigned to receive aspirin versus aspirin-placebo, which demonstrated that participants who completed at least 2 years of aspirin (per-protocol analysis) had significantly fewer incident CRCs than individuals randomly assigned to receive aspirin-placebo (HR, 0.41; 95% CI, 0.19&#8211;0.86, <em>

8594P</em>

8595 = .02; incidence rate ratio [IRR], 0.37; 95% CI, 0.18&#8211;0.78, <em>

8596P</em>

8597 = .008), although there was no significant difference by intention-to-treat analysis (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.35&#8211;1.13, <em>

8598P</em>

8599 = .12).[<a href="#cit/section_4.509">

8600509</a>

8601] </p>

8602<p id="_3408" tabindex="-1">

8603In 2020, long-term follow-up data with all participants having surpassed 10 years of follow-up demonstrated a significant reduction in CRC incidence for participants randomly assigned to receive aspirin both by per-protocol analysis (HR, 0.56; 95% CI, 0.34&#8211;0.91) and intention-to-treat analysis (HR, 0.65; 95% CI, 0.43&#8211;0.97).[<a href="#cit/section_4.511">

8604511</a>

8605] These long-term data showed that the protective effects of aspirin did not emerge until approximately 5 years after initiation of aspirin and, intriguingly, the protective effects of aspirin (taken in this study for only a finite period of time, although the data on aspirin use post unblinding do not exist) persisted to at least 20 years of follow-up. These data demonstrated that only 24 Lynch syndrome carriers needed to be treated with this finite course of aspirin to prevent one incident CRC. Female CAPP2 participants randomly assigned to receive aspirin versus aspirin-placebo also developed fewer incident endometrial cancers (7 vs. 17 cases), although this difference did not reach statistical significance (HR, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.22&#8211;1.11, <em>

8606P</em>

8607 = .09). There was no significant difference seen in the incidence of cancers other than CRC and endometrial cancer in individuals randomly assigned to receive aspirin versus aspirin-placebo. There were no significant differences in adverse events between the aspirin and placebo groups, and no serious adverse effects were noted with any treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.509">

8608509</a>

8609] The CAPP2 investigators concluded that aspirin 600 mg/day has a clear benefit for protecting against CRC in individuals with Lynch syndrome. A key limitation of the CAPP2 trial is that the frequency of surveillance studies at the various centers was not reported as being standardized.</p>

8610<p id="_3409" tabindex="-1">
