8611To date, there has been no significant preventive benefit identified in CAPP2 participants randomly assigned to receive resistant starch versus starch-placebo (HR for incident CRC, 1.40; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;2.56, <em>

8612P</em>

8613 = .26).[<a href="#cit/section_4.512">

8614512</a>

8615]</p>

8616<p id="_3410" tabindex="-1">

8617Experts have speculated that certain Lynch syndrome carriers with lower risks of future incident CRCs (e.g., those with germline <em class="gene-name">

8618PMS2</em>

8619 pathogenic variants, those with prior colectomy, or older individuals) may be less likely to derive benefit from aspirin chemoprevention and may be appropriate for lower dosing.[<a href="#cit/section_4.513">

8620513</a>

8621] Furthermore, a subgroup analysis of the CAPP2 study also suggested that the chemopreventive effects may be primarily in obese individuals,[<a href="#cit/section_4.514">

8622514</a>

8623] suggesting that efforts to personalize aspirin chemoprevention recommendations may be appropriate in Lynch syndrome.</p>

8624<p id="_3411" tabindex="-1">

8625The CAPP3 trial, which is evaluating the effect of lower doses of aspirin (blinded 100 mg, 300 mg, and 600 mg enteric-coated aspirin) completed accrual of 1,882 Lynch syndrome carriers in 2019 and data are not expected until at least 5 years of follow-up is complete.[<a href="#cit/section_4.515">

8626515</a>

8627]</p>

8628<p id="_3412" tabindex="-1">

8629Because of the <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526277&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526277&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8630level 1 evidence</a>

8631 in support of aspirin chemoprevention, clinical practice guidelines consistently recommend that individuals with Lynch syndrome consider taking aspirin daily. Optimal aspirin dosage can be determined by the patient's provider, after having a discussion with the patient about his/her personal risk factors (including pregnancy, in which aspirin use may be contraindicated). NCCN also recommends that providers explain potential advantages and disadvantages of aspirin use to the patient.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

8632122</a>

8633]</p>

8634<p id="_3413" tabindex="-1">

8635For Lynch syndrome carriers unable to take aspirin, it is unclear whether NSAIDs may have a comparable chemopreventive benefit. A 2015 survey of 1,858 participants in the Colon Cancer Family Registry suggested that aspirin and ibuprofen might both reduce incident CRC in Lynch syndrome carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.516">

8636516</a>

8637] Additionally, a recent translational study demonstrated that Lynch syndrome carriers randomly assigned to take naproxen for 6 months had significantly lower colorectal mucosal prostaglandin E2 (versus those randomly assigned to take placebo), and that this was accompanied by immune cell activation and gene expression patterns consistent with epithelial differentiation, suggesting the potential underlying mechanism for CRC chemoprevention in Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.517">

8638517</a>

8639]</p>

8640<p id="_3019" tabindex="-1">

8641<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526277&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526277&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8642Level of evidence: 1aii</a>

8643</p>

8644</section>

8645<section id="_2985">

8646<h5 id="_2985_toc">

8647Management of Lynch syndrome-associated CRC</h5>

8648<section id="_1147">

8649<h6 id="_1147_toc">

8650Surgical management of CRC in Lynch syndrome</h6>

8651<p id="_3049" tabindex="-1">

8652One of the hallmark features of Lynch syndrome is the presence of synchronous and metachronous CRCs. The incidence of metachronous CRCs has been reported to be 16% at 10 years, 41% at 20 years, and 63% at 30 years after segmental colectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.424">

8653424</a>

8654] Because of the increased incidence of synchronous and metachronous neoplasms, the recommended surgical treatment for a patient with Lynch syndrome with neoplastic colonic lesions is generally an extended colectomy (total or subtotal). Nevertheless, treatment has to be individualized and has often included segmental colectomy. Mathematical models suggest that there are minimal benefits of extended procedures in individuals older than 67 years, compared with the benefits seen in younger individuals with early-onset cancer. In one Markov decision analysis model, the survival advantage for a young individual with early-onset CRC undergoing an extended procedure could be up to 4 years longer than that seen in the same individual undergoing a segmental resection.[<a href="#cit/section_4.518">

8655518</a>

8656] The recommendation for an extended procedure must be balanced with the comorbidities of the patient, the clinical stage of the disease, the wishes of the patient, and surgical expertise. No prospective or retrospective study has shown a survival advantage for patients with Lynch syndrome who underwent an extended resection versus a segmental procedure.</p>

8657<p id="_3050" tabindex="-1">

8658Two studies have shown that patients who undergo extended procedures have fewer metachronous CRCs and additional surgical procedures related to CRC than do patients who undergo segmental resections.[<a href="#cit/section_4.424">

8659424</a>

8660,<a href="#cit/section_4.519">

8661519</a>

8662] Balancing functional results of an extended procedure versus a segmental procedure is of paramount importance. Although the majority of patients adapt well after an abdominal colectomy, some patients will require antidiarrheal medication. A decision model compared QALYs for a patient aged 30 years undergoing an abdominal colectomy versus a segmental colectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.520">

8663520</a>

8664] In this model, there was not much difference between the extended and segmental procedure, with QALYs being 0.3 years more in patients undergoing a segmental procedure than in those undergoing an extended procedure.[<a href="#cit/section_4.520">

8665520</a>

8666]</p>

8667<p id="_3404" tabindex="-1">

8668A retrospective study from the Creighton University Hereditary Cancer Center evaluated the incidence of metachronous CRC and survival in 64 Lynch syndrome pathogenic variant carriers with right-sided colon cancer undergoing either proximal colectomy or total or subtotal colectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.521">

8669521</a>

8670] Disease incidence was lower in those undergoing a more extensive resection, with one of 16 patients (6.3%) developing metachronous CRC. In those undergoing proximal colectomy, metachronous CRC developed in 13 of 48 patients (27%). There was no statistical difference in survival within a 25-year period after initial surgery. The authors concluded that the treatment of Lynch syndrome patients with right-sided colon cancer at presentation should be individualized to consider quality of life, functional outcomes, and patient preferences. </p>

8671<p id="_2683" tabindex="-1">

8672When considering surgical options, it is important to recognize that a subtotal or total colectomy will not eliminate the rectal cancer risk. The lifetime risk of developing cancer in the rectal remnant after an abdominal colectomy has been reported to be 12% at 12 years post-colectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.522">

8673522</a>

8674] In addition to the general complications of surgery are the potential risks of urinary and sexual dysfunction and diarrhea after an extended colectomy; these risks increase as the anastomosis becomes more distal. Therefore, the choice of surgery must be made on an individual basis by the surgeon and the patient.</p>

8675<p id="_2684" tabindex="-1">

8676In patients with Lynch syndrome and rectal cancer, similar surgical options (extended vs. segmental resection) and considerations must be given. Extended procedures include restorative proctocolectomy and IPAA if the sphincter can be saved, or proctocolectomy with loop ileostomy if the sphincter cannot be saved. The risk of metachronous colon cancer after segmental resection for an index rectal cancer has been reported to be between 15% and 27%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.473">

8677473</a>

8678,<a href="#cit/section_4.523">

8679523</a>

8680] Two retrospectives studies reported a 15% and 18% incidence of metachronous colon cancer after segmental rectal cancer&#8211;resection in patients with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.524">

8681524</a>

8682,<a href="#cit/section_4.525">

8683525</a>

8684] In one of the studies, the combined risk of metachronous high-risk adenomas and cancers was 51% at a median follow-up of 101.7 months after proctectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.525">

8685525</a>

8686]</p>

8687<p id="_2686" tabindex="-1">

8688There are no data about fertility after surgery in Lynch syndrome patients. In female FAP patients, no difference in fecundity after abdominal colectomy and IRA has been reported, whereas there is a 54% decrease in fecundity in patients who undergo restorative proctocolectomy with IPAA compared with the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.526">

8689526</a>

8690] Another study in which a questionnaire was sent to FAP patients reported a similar prevalence of fertility problems among patients who had undergone IRA, IPAA, and proctocolectomy with end ileostomy. In that study, it was reported that earlier age at the time of surgery was associated with more fertility problems.[<a href="#cit/section_4.527">

8691527</a>

8692] </p>

8693<p id="_3392" tabindex="-1">

8694In a large Danish registry study, the incidence rate for

8695metachronous CRC was fivefold higher in Lynch syndrome patients, but not significantly higher

8696in familial CRC and moderate familial risk CRC cases when compared with sporadic CRC,

8697demonstrating that the risk of metachronous CRC occurred almost exclusively in Lynch

8698syndrome cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.490">

8699490</a>

8700] The IRRs for metachronous CRC were highest in Lynch

8701syndrome patients with <em class="gene-name">

8702MLH1</em>

8703 and <em class="gene-name">

8704MSH2</em>

8705 germline alterations, intermediate in <em class="gene-name">

8706MSH6</em>

8707 carriers, but not in

8708<em class="gene-name">

8709PMS2</em>

8710 carriers when compared with sporadic CRC cases. Furthermore, when comparing the extent of the

8711colon resections performed for primary CRC in Lynch syndrome cases, the IRRs

8712for metachronous CRC were 5.5 for total and subtotal colectomies and 0.9 for segmental colon

8713resections. The absolute risk reduction of metachronous CRC in Lynch syndrome cases with a

8714primary CRC diagnosed before age 60 years and total/subtotal versus segmental

8715colectomies was 63.5% in men and 40.9% in women. These results strongly support subtotal or

8716total versus segmental colectomies for resectable CRC in Lynch syndrome patients with

8717underlying <em class="gene-name">

8718MLH1</em>

8719 or <em class="gene-name">

8720MSH2</em>

8721, and possibly <em class="gene-name">

8722MSH6</em>

8723 germline alterations.</p>

8724<p id="_2685" tabindex="-1">

8725Most clinicians who treat patients with Lynch syndrome will favor an extended procedure at the time of CRC diagnosis. However, as stated above, the choice of surgery must be made on an individual basis by the surgeon and the patient.[<a href="#cit/section_4.528">

8726528</a>

8727-<a href="#cit/section_4.530">

8728530</a>

8729]</p>

8730<p id="_2692" tabindex="-1">

8731<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531845&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531845&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8732Level of Evidence: 4</a>

8733</p>

8734</section>

8735<section id="_3065">

8736<h6 id="_3065_toc">

8737Prognostic and therapeutic implications of MSI</h6>

8738<p id="_3066" tabindex="-1">

8739As discussed in previous sections, MSI is not only a molecular feature of Lynch syndrome but is also present in 10% to 15% of sporadic cases of CRC (largely due to <em class="gene-name">

8740MLH1</em>

8741 hypermethylation or biallelic somatic mutations in an MMR gene). Although MSI testing was initially utilized to screen patients who might harbor pathogenic MMR gene variants, it has been increasingly recognized that MSI has important prognostic and therapeutic implications. The utility of MSI testing beyond identifying Lynch syndrome has made the case for universal MSI screening more compelling and has contributed to its widespread adoption. Several studies have suggested that stage-specific survival is better for MSI-H CRC compared with MSS cancers. Additionally, the chemotherapeutic agent fluorouracil (5-FU) appears ineffective in the adjuvant treatment of resected MSI-H CRC, in contrast to MSS CRC in which this agent is widely utilized for this purpose. Finally, immunomodulation with agents such as checkpoint inhibitors appears effective in the treatment of advanced MSI-H CRC based on early phase 1 and phase 2 studies, while these agents, at least when utilized as monotherapy, show little activity in MSS CRC.</p>

8742<section id="_3067">

8743<h6 id="_3067_toc">

8744Prognosis of MSI</h6>

8745<p id="_3068" tabindex="-1">

8746Although MSI-H tumors account for 15% of all sporadic CRC, they appear to be more frequent in stage II compared with stage III CRC,[<a href="#cit/section_4.531">

8747531</a>

8748] and are even less common in metastatic disease, being present in only 3% to 4% of metastatic cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.532">

8749532</a>

8750] This stage distinction alludes to the possibility of a better prognosis associated with underlying MSI-H status.</p>

8751<p id="_3069" tabindex="-1">

8752Several studies subsequently confirmed the improved survival of stage II MSI-H CRC compared with MSS cases. A meta-analysis of 32 studies of 7,642 cases, including 1,277 with MSI-H, showed a combined HR estimate for overall survival (OS) associated with MSI of 0.65 (95% CI, 0.59&#8211;0.71; heterogeneity <em>

8753P</em>

8754 = .16; I<span class="sup">

87552</span>

8756 [a measure of the percentage of variation across studies that is due to heterogeneity rather than chance] = 20%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.533">

8757533</a>

8758] However, while data were limited, tumors with MSI derived no benefit from adjuvant 5-FU (HR, 1.24; 95% CI, 0.72&#8211;2.14). Subsequent data from several large randomized clinical trials confirmed the favorable prognosis associated with MSI-H. These included the QUick And Simple And Reliable (QUASAR) trial, which explored the benefit of adjuvant 5-FU&#8211;based chemotherapy compared with surgery alone in 1,900 patients with resected stage II CRC. In this study, MSI-H tumors were associated with a recurrence risk of half that of MSS tumors (risk ratio [RR], 0.53; 95% CI, 0.40&#8211;0.70).[<a href="#cit/section_4.534">

8759534</a>

8760] Similar results were seen in the Pan European Trial Adjuvant Colon Cancer (PETACC)-3 trial, a randomized trial of 5-FU with or without irinotecan in resected stage II or stage III CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.535">

8761535</a>

8762] MSI-H status was associated with an OS odds ratio (OR) of 0.39 (95% CI, 0.24&#8211;0.65) and this advantage was seen in both stage II and stage III disease.</p>

8763<p id="_3243" tabindex="-1">

8764Consistent with other prior data, clinicopathologic analysis of 85 Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated CRCs and 67 sporadic dMMR CRCs demonstrated a significantly superior survival among patients with Lynch syndrome, as well as younger ages at diagnosis and higher numbers of tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs).[<a href="#cit/section_4.536">

8765536</a>

8766] Exome sequencing and neoantigen data from a subset of 16 CRC tumors (eight Lynch syndrome CRCs and eight sporadic dMMR CRCs) from this cohort suggest that somatic mutational burden and neoantigen load is significantly higher among Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated CRCs than sporadic dMMR CRCs; this was speculated to be the source of the improved survival outcomes and increased TILs.</p>

8767<p id="_3070" tabindex="-1">

8768Given the predilection for MSI-H tumors to involve the right side of the colon, there is a paucity of data on the outcome and prognosis of MSI-H tumors involving the rectum. One study suggested only 2% of rectal cancers are MSI-H.[<a href="#cit/section_4.534">

8769534</a>

8770] A study of 62 patients with MSI-H rectal cancers from a single institution were followed for a median of 6.8 years. The 5-year rectal cancer&#8211;specific survival was 100% for stage I and stage II, 85.1% for stage III, and 60.0% for stage IV disease, suggesting the favorable prognosis associated with MSI-H may also apply to cancers involving the rectum.[<a href="#cit/section_4.523">

8771523</a>

8772] The authors additionally reported a favorable 26% pathologic complete response rate with 5-FU combined with radiation therapy, suggesting that 5-FU given with radiation for the locoregional treatment of rectal cancer may still be effective in the setting of MSI-H tumors. The substantial rate of pathologic complete responses demonstrated in this study also reinforces the need for adequate biopsies to assess MSI status prior to commencing treatment.</p>

8773</section>

8774<section id="_3071">

8775<h6 id="_3071_toc">

8776The use of adjuvant chemotherapy after surgery for CRC in Lynch syndrome</h6>

8777<p id="_3072" tabindex="-1">

8778The finding of MSI in a CRC has been shown in several studies to predict the lack of benefit of adjuvant chemotherapy with 5-FU in resected stage II or stage III colon cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.537">

8779537</a>

8780] This has been a controversial area historically. It was known that loss of DNA MMR activity in cultured colon cancer cells conferred resistance to DNA-damaging agents (the common mechanism of cytotoxic chemotherapy) through loss of the signal to arrest the cell cycle in response to DNA damage that cannot be repaired.[<a href="#cit/section_4.538">

8781538</a>

8782] This led to the prediction that DNA dMMR tumors may not be fully sensitive to alkylating agents, 5-FU, and platinum-containing drugs.[<a href="#cit/section_4.539">

8783539</a>

8784-<a href="#cit/section_4.541">

8785541</a>

8786] Unexpectedly, in 2000, a paper was published suggesting that patients with Dukes C (stage III) CRC with MSI had a substantial survival benefit when given 5-FU&#8211;based adjuvant chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.542">

8787542</a>

8788] However, the patients in this analysis had not been randomized to therapy; they were selected for adjuvant chemotherapy based upon clinical status, and inadvertently, the median age in the treatment group was 13 years younger than the controls.</p>

8789<p id="_3073" tabindex="-1">

8790In 2003, however, the outcomes in a randomized controlled prospective trial of adjuvant chemotherapy in 570 colon cancer patients demonstrated no benefit from adjuvant 5-FU in the group with MSI. Moreover, there were nonsignificant trends towards increased mortality when colon cancers with MSI were treated: twofold for stage III cancers and threefold for stage II cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.543">

8791543</a>

8792] Subsequently, ten studies confirmed this, as all failed to show benefit when CRC patients were given 5-FU&#8211;based chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.537">

8793537</a>

8794] In contrast, a meta-analysis of randomized trials of 5-FU versus observation suggested a potential benefit of 5-FU in patients with MSI stage III disease. An exploratory subset analysis suggested benefit only in those patients with Lynch syndrome&#8211;related MSI. An analysis of stage II patients was not undertaken in this study.[<a href="#cit/section_4.544">

8795544</a>

8796]</p>

8797<p id="_3074" tabindex="-1">

8798Preclinical data suggests the addition of oxaliplatin to 5-FU can overcome the resistance to 5-FU monotherapy seen in MSI-H tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.545">

8799545</a>

8800] A retrospective analysis of 433 MSI-H stage II and stage III CRC cases (both sporadic and secondary to Lynch syndrome) suggested a benefit in disease-free survival (DFS) with FOLFOX (5-FU and oxaliplatin) compared with surgery alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.546">

8801546</a>

8802] There was a trend towards improved DFS utilizing FOLFOX in the subset of patients with MSI due to Lynch syndrome, however, the result was not statistically significant. Additional studies have demonstrated similar survival outcomes irrespective of MSI status with adjuvant chemotherapy including FOLFOX.[<a href="#cit/section_4.547">

8803547</a>

8804,<a href="#cit/section_4.548">

8805548</a>

8806]</p>

8807<p id="_3020" tabindex="-1">

8808<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531810&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531810&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8809Level of evidence (against the use of adjuvant therapy): 1ai</a>

8810</p>

8811</section>

8812<section id="_3076">

8813<h6 id="_3076_toc">

8814Immunotherapy</h6>

8815<p id="_3077" tabindex="-1">

8816Tumors that develop via the MSI pathway have more somatic mutations than tumors that develop via other pathways. This could imply that dMMR tumors may have more potential antigens (termed <em>

8817neoantigens</em>

8818) and may be more responsive to immune system manipulation than proficient MMR (pMMR) tumors. Microscopically, MSI-H tumors often exhibit abundant tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes, sometimes resulting in a Crohn-like reaction. This histologic feature has long suggested the possibility of increased tumor immune surveillance in MSI-H cancers and is one of the main hypotheses for the better stage-specific survival seen in MSI-H compared with MSS cancers.</p>

8819<p id="_3078" tabindex="-1">

8820To test the hypothesis of efficacy of immunomodulation in MSI-H tumors, a phase 2 trial of programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) inhibition was carried out in a small cohort of patients with MSI-H or MSS cancers. Patients with metastatic disease that had failed various chemotherapy regimens were treated with pembrolizumab, an anti&#8211;PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitor.[<a href="#cit/section_4.549">

8821549</a>

8822] In this small phase 2 study, 32 patients with CRC (11 were dMMR, 21 were pMMR, and 9 others had noncolorectal dMMR tumors) were treated with intravenous pembrolizumab every 14 days. The immune-related response among evaluable patients was 40% (4 of 10) for dMMR CRC tumors, 0% (0 of 18) for pMMR CRC tumors, and 71% (5 of 7) for non-CRC dMMR tumors. The immune-related 20-week progression-free survival was 78% (7 of 9) in patients with dMMR CRC tumors, 11% (2 of 18) in patients with pMMR CRC tumors, and 67% (4 of 6) in patients with non-CRC dMMR tumors. dMMR tumors had a mean of 24-fold more somatic mutations than pMMR tumors. Additionally, in this study somatic mutation load was associated with prolonged PFS. The authors concluded that MMR status predicted clinical benefit to immune checkpoint blockade with pembrolizumab.</p>

8823<p id="_3140" tabindex="-1">

8824A single-arm phase 2 study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02060188">

8825CheckMate 142</a>

8826) of another PD-1 inhibitor, nivolumab, was performed in 74 patients with MSI-H/dMMR CRC that had progressed on prior cytotoxic chemotherapy (including 5-FU, irinotecan, and oxaliplatin).[<a href="#cit/section_4.550">

8827550</a>

8828] Overall, 31% of patients (23 of 74) experienced an objective response to therapy, and 69% (51 of 74) had disease control for at least 12 weeks. Among patients who responded to nivolumab, the median duration of response was not reached at the time of study analysis (median follow up of 12 months). There was no significant difference in the response rates among individuals with Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated metastatic MSI-H/dMMR CRC versus non-Lynch metastatic MSI-H/dMMR CRC in this study. Twenty percent of study participants experienced grade 3 or greater toxicities, most commonly elevations in amylase and/or lipase, and there were no deaths that were attributed to nivolumab.</p>

8829<p id="_3141" tabindex="-1">

8830Based on these data, pembrolizumab 200 mg given intravenously every 3 weeks was approved by the FDA in May 2017 for the treatment of any MSI-H/dMMR metastatic cancer that is refractory to standard therapy and nivolumab 240 mg given intravenously every 2 weeks was granted accelerated approval by the FDA in August 2017 for the treatment of MSI-H/dMMR CRC that is refractory to cytotoxic chemotherapy.</p>

8831<p id="_3436" tabindex="-1">

8832In 2020, treatment-na&#239;ve patients with MSI-H/dMMR CRC were enrolled in a phase III trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02563002">

8833KEYNOTE-177</a>

8834) where they were randomized to receive pembrolizumab or chemotherapy. Patients who received pembrolizumab had an increase in PFS when compared with patients who received chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.551">

8835551</a>

8836,<a href="#cit/section_4.552">

8837552</a>

8838] Subsequently, pembrolizumab became the standard of care for treating metastatic MSI-H/dMMR CRC in the first-line setting. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colon-treatment-pdq">

8839Colon Cancer Treatment</a>

8840 summary for more information.)</p>

8841<p id="_3244" tabindex="-1">

8842In another arm of <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02060188">

8843CheckMate 142</a>

8844, 119 individuals with metastatic dMMR CRC were treated with nivolumab plus ipilimumab.[<a href="#cit/section_4.553">

8845553</a>

8846] The objective response rate was 55% with a 12-week disease control rate of 80%, a 12-month PFS of 71%, and a median duration of response that was not reached. Grade 3 and grade 4 toxicities occurred in 32% of participants (most commonly increased liver function tests) and 13% of all participants discontinued therapy due to toxicity. This was a nonrandomized study, and thus questions remain as to whether the combination of immune checkpoint blockade is superior to PD-1 inhibition alone, especially given the apparent increase in toxicity with combination therapy. On the basis of these data, in July 2018 the FDA granted accelerated approval to nivolumab plus ipilimumab therapy for the treatment of dMMR/MSI-H metastatic CRC that has progressed through prior chemotherapy with a fluoropyrimidine, oxaliplatin, and irinotecan.</p>

8847<p id="_3441" tabindex="-1">

8848A retrospective analysis described the pathological responses of 14 patients with MSI-H tumors after treatment with PD-1 inhibitors (with or without CTLA-4 inhibitors). Eight of the patients in this study had Lynch syndrome and all of the patients had unresectable/metastatic CRCs. Patients underwent resection after they completed treatment. The study demonstrated a pathological complete response (PCR) in 13 of the 14 patients, despite radiographic evidence of persistent disease in 12 of these patients. The discordance between imaging and PCR may be related to significant lymphocyte infiltration in patient tumors. The median duration of treatment was 12 months. However, a PCR was demonstrated in a patient who was treated for only 3 months.[<a href="#cit/section_4.554">

8849554</a>

8850]</p>

8851<p id="_3437" tabindex="-1">

8852There is debate about when immunotherapeutic agents can be used in patients with non-CRC, MSI-H cancers. Many providers question in which line of therapy immunotherapeutics should be initiated. This question is the subject of multiple ongoing clinical trials. (Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

8853advanced clinical trial search</a>

8854 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria.)</p>

8855<p id="_3021" tabindex="-1">

8856<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531837&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531837&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8857Level of evidence: 3b</a>

8858</p>

8859</section>

8860<section id="_3135">

8861<h6 id="_3135_toc">

8862Vaccines in the treatment or prevention of MSI-related CRC</h6>

8863<p id="_3136" tabindex="-1">

8864An alternative approach to immunotherapy in MSI-H CRC involves the use of tumor-directed vaccines. The most promising approaches thus far involve the use of tumor-related neoantigens as epitopes to increase tumor-specific T-cell immunity. Studies are currently under way in the adjuvant treatment of resected stage III CRC (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01461148">

8865NCT01461148</a>

8866), in patients with metastatic disease (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01885702">

8867NCT01885702</a>

8868), and in the prevention of CRC in patients with Lynch syndrome (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01885702">

8869NCT01885702</a>

8870).</p>

8871</section>

8872</section>

8873</section>

8874</section>

8875<section id="_1135">

8876<h4 id="_1135_toc">

8877Lynch syndrome&#8211;related syndromes</h4>

8878<section id="_3007">

8879<h5 id="_3007_toc">

8880Lynch-like or HNPCC-like syndrome</h5>

8881<p id="_3008" tabindex="-1">

8882Somatic biallelic MMR gene inactivation is now recognized as a common cause of sporadic MMR deficiency. The literature variably labels these cases as Lynch-like syndrome (LLS). However, this nomenclature can be confusing, since this is a sporadic form of MMR-deficiency, rather than a stand-alone genetic syndrome. For more information, see the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3501">

8883Somatic biallelic mismatch repair deficiency (sometimes called Lynch-like syndrome)</a>

8884 section and <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3022">

8885Table 10</a>

8886.</p>

8887</section>

8888<section id="_3006">

8889<h5 id="_3006_toc">

8890Familial colorectal cancer type X</h5>

8891<p id="_1255" tabindex="-1">

8892The term <em>

8893familial colorectal cancer type X</em>

8894 or <em>

8895FCCX</em>

8896 was coined to refer to families who meet Amsterdam criteria but lack MSI/IHC abnormalities.[<a href="#cit/section_4.271">

8897271</a>

8898] Approximately 50% of families that fulfill Amsterdam criteria, lack pathogenic MMR gene variants and thereby are characterized as FCCX families. Research is ongoing to determine a genetic etiology for FCCX, but for the most part it remains unknown and is thought to be a heterogeneous condition. However, differentiating between Lynch syndrome and FCCX has important implications regarding cancer risk assessment and screening recommendations for affected individuals and at-risk relatives. While the risk of CRC is increased to twice that in the general population, it is less than that in Lynch syndrome (&gt;sixfold increase) and there is no significant risk of extracolonic malignancy. Cancer screening recommendations are therefore modified and CRC surveillance is recommended every 5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.271">

8899271</a>

8900]</p>

8901</section>

8902</section>

8903</section>

8904<section id="_1211">

8905<h3 id="_1211_toc">

8906Advances in Endoscopic Imaging in Hereditary CRC</h3>

8907<p id="_1212" tabindex="-1">

8908Performance of endoscopic therapies for adenomas in FAP and Lynch syndrome, and decision-making regarding surgical referral and planning, require accurate estimates of the presence of adenomas. In both AFAP and Lynch syndrome the presence of very subtle adenomas poses special challenges&#8212;microadenomas in the case of AFAP and flat, though sometimes large, adenomas in Lynch syndrome.</p>

8909<section id="_1368">

8910<h4 id="_1368_toc">

8911Chromoendoscopy</h4>

8912<p id="_1369" tabindex="-1">

8913The need for sensitive means to endoscopically detect subtle polyps has increased with the recognition of flat adenomas and sessile serrated polyps in otherwise average-risk subjects, very attenuated adenoma phenotypes in AFAP, and subtle flat adenomas in Lynch syndrome. Modern high-resolution endoscopes improve adenoma detection yield, but the use of various vital dyes, especially indigo carmine dye-spray, has further improved detection. Several studies have shown that the improved mucosal contrast achieved with the use of indigo carmine can improve the adenoma detection rate. Whether family history is significant or not, careful clinical evaluation consisting of dye-spray colonoscopy (indigo carmine or methylene blue),[<a href="#cit/section_4.491">

8914491</a>

8915,<a href="#cit/section_4.555">

8916555</a>

8917-<a href="#cit/section_4.560">

8918560</a>

8919] with or without magnification, or possibly newer imaging techniques such as narrow-band imaging,[<a href="#cit/section_4.561">

8920561</a>

8921] may reveal the characteristic right-sided clustering of more numerous microadenomas. Upper GI endoscopy may be informative if duodenal adenomas or fundic gland polyps with surface dysplasia are found. Such findings will increase the likelihood of variant detection if <em class="gene-name">

8922APC</em>

8923 or <em class="gene-name">

8924MUTYH</em>

8925 testing is pursued.</p>

8926<p id="_1371" tabindex="-1">

8927In various large series of average-risk populations, subtle flat lesions were detected in about 5% to 10% of cases, including adenomas with high-grade dysplasia and invasive adenocarcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.562">

8928562</a>

8929] Some of these studies involved tandem procedures&#8212;white-light exam followed by randomization to &#8220;intensive&#8221; (&gt; 20-minute pull-back from cecum) inspection versus chromoendoscopy&#8212;with significantly more adenomas detected in the chromoendoscopy group.[<a href="#cit/section_4.563">

8930563</a>

8931] However, in several randomized trials, no significant difference in yield was seen.[<a href="#cit/section_4.564">

8932564</a>

8933,<a href="#cit/section_4.565">

8934565</a>

8935]</p>

8936<p id="_1372" tabindex="-1">

8937In a randomized trial of subjects with Lynch syndrome,[<a href="#cit/section_4.566">

8938566</a>

8939] standard colonoscopy, with polypectomy as indicated, was followed by either indigo carmine chromoendoscopy or repeat &#8220;intensive&#8221; white-light colonoscopy (a design very nearly identical to the average-risk screening group noted above). In this series, no significant difference in adenoma yield between the chromoendoscopy and intensive white-light groups was detected. However, these patients were younger and, in many cases, had undergone several previous exams that might have resulted in polyp clearing.</p>

8940<p id="_1373" tabindex="-1">

8941In a German study,[<a href="#cit/section_4.567">

8942567</a>

8943] one series of Lynch syndrome patients underwent white-light exam followed by chromoendoscopy, while a second series underwent colonoscopy with narrow-band imaging followed by chromoendoscopy. Significant differences in flat polyp detection favored chromoendoscopy in both series, although some of the detected lesions were hyperplastic. In a French series of Lynch syndrome subjects that also employed white-light exam followed by chromoendoscopy, significantly more adenomas were detected with chromoendoscopy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.492">

8944492</a>

8945]</p>

8946<p id="_1374" tabindex="-1">

8947Fewer evaluations of chromoendoscopy have been performed in AFAP than in Lynch syndrome. One study examined four patients with presumed AFAP and fewer than 20 adenomas upon white-light examination.[<a href="#cit/section_4.568">

8948568</a>

8949] All had more than 1,000 diminutive adenomas found on chromoendoscopy, in agreement with pathology evaluation after colectomy.</p>

8950<p id="_1375" tabindex="-1">

8951A similar role for chromoendoscopy has been suggested to evaluate the duodenum in FAP. One study from Holland that used indigo carmine dye-spray to detect duodenal adenomas showed an increase in the number and size of adenomas, including some large ones. Overall Spigelman score was not significantly affected.[<a href="#cit/section_4.569">

8952569</a>

8953]</p>

8954</section>

8955<section id="_1376">

8956<h4 id="_1376_toc">

8957Small bowel imaging</h4>

8958<p id="_1377" tabindex="-1">

8959Patients with PJS and JPS are at greater risk of disease-related complications in the small bowel (e.g., bleeding, obstruction, intussusception, or cancer). FAP patients, although at great risk of duodenal neoplasia, have a relatively low risk of jejunoileal involvement. The RR of small bowel malignancy is very high in Lynch syndrome, but absolute risk is less than 10%. Although the risks of small bowel neoplasia are high enough to warrant consideration of surveillance in each disease, the technical challenges of doing so have been daunting. Because of the technical challenges and relatively low prevalences, there is virtually no evidence base for small-bowel screening in Lynch syndrome.</p>

8960<p id="_1378" tabindex="-1">

8961Historically, the relative endoscopic inaccessibility of the mid and distal small bowel required radiographic measures for its evaluation, including the barium small bowel series or a variant called tube enteroclysis, in which a nasogastroduodenal tube is placed so that all of the contrast goes into the small intestine quickly and undiluted by gastric juice for more precise imaging. None of these measures were sensitive for small lesions. Previously, therapeutic removal of lesions required laparotomy. However, multiple novel endoscopic approaches have been developed to overcome the technical limitations of small bowel endoscopy, which has enabled jejunal and ileal access for purposes of polypectomy. </p>

8962<p id="_1379" tabindex="-1">

8963For patients with PJS, double-balloon endoscopy or other forms of deep enteroscopy (single-balloon overtube or spiral overtube) are the preferred methods for evaluation of the small bowel.[<a href="#cit/section_4.570">

8964570</a>

8965] This may involve either peroral enteroscopy or retrograde enteroscopy to achieve more complete evaluation of the small bowel. Because these procedures are time-consuming and involve risks of complication, deep enteroscopy is usually preceded by more imaging, including barium exams, capsule endoscopy, CT or magnetic resonance enterography.[<a href="#cit/section_4.75">

896675</a>

8967]</p>

8968<p id="_1380" tabindex="-1">

8969In FAP, data from capsule endoscopy [<a href="#cit/section_4.75">

897075</a>

8971] show a 50% to 100% prevalence of jejunal and/or ileal polyps in patients with Spigelman stage III or stage IV duodenal involvement but virtually no such polyps in Spigelman stage I or stage II disease. Polyps smaller than 10 mm and were not biopsied or removed. Consequently, their clinical significance remains uncertain but is likely limited, given the infrequency of jejunoileal cancer reports in FAP.</p>

8972<p id="_1381" tabindex="-1">

8973Capsule endoscopy in the small series of PJS patients described above [<a href="#cit/section_4.75">

897475</a>

8975] showed the presence of a similar frequency (50%&#8211;100%) of polyps, but the prevalent polyps were much larger than in FAP, were more likely to become symptomatic, and warranted endoscopic or surgical excision. Capsule studies were suggested as an appropriate replacement for radiographic studies because of the sensitivity of capsule endoscopy.</p>

8976</section>

8977</section>

8978<section id="_166">

8979<h3 id="_166_toc">

8980Familial CRC</h3>

8981<p id="_697" tabindex="-1">

8982Genetic studies have demonstrated a common autosomal dominant inheritance pattern for colon tumors, adenomas, and cancers in familial CRC families,[<a href="#cit/section_4.571">

8983571</a>

8984] with a gene frequency of 0.19 for adenomas and colorectal adenocarcinomas.[<a href="#cit/section_4.572">

8985572</a>

8986] A subset of families with MSI-negative familial colorectal neoplasia was found to link to chromosome 9q22.2-31.2.[<a href="#cit/section_4.573">

8987573</a>

8988] A more recent study has linked three potential loci in familial CRC families on chromosomes 11, 14, and 22.[<a href="#cit/section_4.574">

8989574</a>

8990] For more than a decade, little progress has been made on these putative familial cancer loci.</p>

8991<section id="_717">

8992<h4 id="_717_toc">

8993Familial colorectal cancer type X (FCCX)</h4>

8994<p id="_718" tabindex="-1">

8995Families meeting Amsterdam-I criteria for Lynch syndrome who do not show evidence of defective MMR by MSI testing do not appear to have the same risk of colorectal or other cancers as those families with classic Lynch syndrome and clear evidence of defective MMR. These Amsterdam-I criteria families with intact MMR systems have been described as FCCX,[<a href="#cit/section_4.271">

8996271</a>

8997,<a href="#cit/section_4.575">

8998575</a>

8999-<a href="#cit/section_4.579">

9000579</a>

9001] and it has been suggested that these families be classified as a distinct group.</p>

9002<p id="_2743" tabindex="-1">

9003The genetic etiology of FCCX remains unclear. Utilizing whole-genome linkage analysis and exome sequencing, a truncating variant in ribosomal protein S20 (<em class="gene-name">

9004RPS20</em>

9005), a ribosomal protein gene, was identified in four individuals with CRC from an FCCX family.[<a href="#cit/section_4.579">

9006579</a>

9007] The variant cosegregated with CRC in the family, with a logarithm of the odds score of 3. Additionally, the variant was not identified in 292 controls. No LOH was observed in tumor samples, and <em>

9008in vitro</em>

9009 analyses of mature RNA formation confirmed a model of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781846&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781846&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9010haploinsufficiency</a>

9011 for <em class="gene-name">

9012RPS20</em>

9013. No germline variants in <em class="gene-name">

9014RPS20</em>

9015 were found in 25 additional FCCX families studied, suggesting <em class="gene-name">

9016RPS20</em>

9017 variants are an infrequent cause of FCCX. The same group had previously identified variants in the bone morphogenetic protein receptor type 1A (<em class="gene-name">

9018BMPR1A</em>

9019) gene in affected individuals from 2 of 18 families with FCCX.[<a href="#cit/section_4.580">

9020580</a>

9021] Additional studies are necessary to definitively confirm or refute a role for <em class="gene-name">

9022RPS20</em>

9023 or <em class="gene-name">

9024BMPR1A</em>

9025 in FCCX.</p>

9026<p id="_2876" tabindex="-1">

9027Subsequent to these initial studies, several other putative FCCX genes have been found in familial, non-Lynch syndrome clusters of CRC including the polypeptide N-acetylgalactosaminyltransferase 12 (<em class="gene-name">

9028GALNT12</em>

9029) gene,[<a href="#cit/section_4.581">

9030581</a>

9031] <em class="gene-name">

9032BUB1</em>

9033 and <em class="gene-name">

9034BUB3</em>

9035,[<a href="#cit/section_4.582">

9036582</a>

9037] the <em class="gene-name">

9038SEMA4A</em>

9039 gene,[<a href="#cit/section_4.583">

9040583</a>

9041] <em class="gene-name">

9042RINT1,</em>

9043[<a href="#cit/section_4.584">

9044584</a>

9045] <em class="gene-name">

9046FAN1</em>

9047,[<a href="#cit/section_4.585">

9048585</a>

9049] and combined effects of pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

9050HNRNPA0</em>

9051 and <em class="gene-name">

9052WIF1</em>

9053 in one large kindred.[<a href="#cit/section_4.586">

9054586</a>

9055] The list of possible candidate genes will continue to grow, complicating any facile approach to handling these families.</p>

9056<p id="_719" tabindex="-1">

9057Age of CRC onset in Lynch syndrome ranges from 44 years (registry series) to a mean of 52 years (population-based series).[<a href="#cit/section_4.275">

9058275</a>

9059,<a href="#cit/section_4.328">

9060328</a>

9061,<a href="#cit/section_4.381">

9062381</a>

9063] There are no corresponding population-based data for FCCX because FCCX by definition requires at least one early-onset case, is almost certainly very heterogeneous, and is not likely to lend itself to any population-based figures in the foreseeable future. Studies that have directly compared age of onset between FCCX and Lynch syndrome have suggested that the age of onset is slightly older in FCCX,[<a href="#cit/section_4.271">

9064271</a>

9065,<a href="#cit/section_4.575">

9066575</a>

9067,<a href="#cit/section_4.577">

9068577</a>

9069] and the lifetime risk of CRC is substantially lower. The SIR for CRC among families with intact MMR (FCCX families) was 2.3 (95% CI, 1.7&#8211;3.0) in one large study, compared with 6.1 (95% CI, 5.7&#8211;7.2) in families with defective MMR (Lynch syndrome families).[<a href="#cit/section_4.271">

9070271</a>

9071] The risk of extracolonic tumors was also not found to be elevated in the FCCX families, suggesting that enhanced surveillance for CRC would be sufficient. Although further studies are required, tumors arising within FCCX families also appear to have a different pathologic phenotype, with fewer tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes than those in families with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.576">

9072576</a>

9073]</p>

9074</section>

9075</section>

9076<section id="_182">

9077<h3 id="_182_toc">

9078Rare Syndromes With Associated Colorectal Cancer Susceptibility</h3>

9079<section id="_2559">

9080<h4 id="_2559_toc">

9081 <em class="gene-name">

9082PTEN</em>

9083 hamartoma tumor syndromes (including Cowden syndrome)</h4>

9084<section id="_sm_CDR0000766497_2721">

9085<p id="_sm_CDR0000766497_2560" tabindex="-1">

9086Cowden syndrome and Bannayan-Riley-Ruvalcaba syndrome (BRRS) are part of a spectrum of conditions known collectively as <em class="gene-name">

9087PTEN</em>

9088 hamartoma tumor syndromes (PHTS). Approximately 85% of patients diagnosed with Cowden syndrome, and approximately 60% of patients with BRRS have an identifiable <em class="gene-name">

9089PTEN</em>

9090 pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_4.587">

9091587</a>

9092] In addition, <em class="gene-name">

9093PTEN</em>

9094 pathogenic variants have been identified in patients with very diverse clinical phenotypes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.588">

9095588</a>

9096] The term PHTS refers to any patient with a <em class="gene-name">

9097PTEN</em>

9098 pathogenic variant, irrespective of clinical presentation.</p>

9099<p id="_sm_CDR0000766497_2561" tabindex="-1">

9100<em class="gene-name">

9101PTEN</em>

9102 functions as a dual-specificity phosphatase that removes phosphate groups from tyrosine, serine, and threonine. <em class="gene-name">

9103PTEN</em>

9104 pathogenic variants are diverse and can present as <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783965&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783965&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9105nonsense</a>

9106, missense, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9107frameshift</a>

9108, or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783968&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783968&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9109splice-site variants</a>

9110. Approximately 40% of variants are found in exon 5, which encodes the phosphatase core motif; several recurrent pathogenic variants have been observed at this location.[<a href="#cit/section_4.589">

9111589</a>

9112] Pathogenic variants in the 5&#8217; end of <em class="gene-name">

9113PTEN </em>

9114or within the phosphatase core of <em class="gene-name">

9115PTEN</em>

9116 tend to affect more organ systems.[<a href="#cit/section_4.590">

9117590</a>

9118]</p>

9119<p id="_sm_CDR0000766497_2605" tabindex="-1">

9120Operational criteria for the diagnosis of Cowden syndrome have been published and subsequently updated.[<a href="#cit/section_4.591">

9121591</a>

9122,<a href="#cit/section_4.592">

9123592</a>

9124] These include major, minor, and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=454769&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000454769&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9125pathognomonic</a>

9126 criteria that consist of certain mucocutaneous manifestations and adult-onset dysplastic gangliocytoma of the cerebellum (Lhermitte-Duclos disease). An updated set of criteria based on a systematic literature review has been suggested [<a href="#cit/section_4.593">

9127593</a>

9128] and is currently utilized in the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines.[<a href="#cit/section_4.594">

9129594</a>

9130] Contrary to previous criteria, the authors concluded that there was insufficient evidence for any features to be classified as pathognomonic. Increased genetic testing (especially <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=763019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000763019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9131multigene panels</a>

9132) has identified individuals with germline <em class="gene-name">

9133PTEN</em>

9134 pathogenic variants who do not meet diagnostic criteria for PHTS. Diagnostic criteria will need to be reconciled with these recently discovered phenotypes. Hence, it is unclear whether PHTS diagnoses should be based on clinical features or a positive <em class="gene-name">

9135PTEN</em>

9136 genetic test result. The American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics (ACMG) suggests that referral for genetics consultation be considered for individuals with a personal history of or a first-degree relative with the following: 1) adult-onset Lhermitte-Duclos disease or 2) any three of the major or minor criteria that have been established for the diagnosis of Cowden syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.595">

9137595</a>

9138] Detailed recommendations, including <a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/gim2014147/tables/4" title="https://www.nature.com/articles/gim2014147/tables/4">

9139diagnostic criteria</a>

9140 for Cowden syndrome, can be found in the NCCN and ACMG guidelines.[<a href="#cit/section_4.594">

9141594</a>

9142,<a href="#cit/section_4.595">

9143595</a>

9144] Additionally, a predictive <a href="http://www.lerner.ccf.org/gmi/ccscore/" title="http://www.lerner.ccf.org/gmi/ccscore/">

9145model</a>

9146 that uses clinical criteria to estimate the probability of a <em class="gene-name">

9147PTEN</em>

9148 pathogenic variant is available; a cost-effectiveness analysis suggests that germline <em class="gene-name">

9149PTEN</em>

9150 testing is cost effective if the probability of a variant is greater than 10%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.596">

9151596</a>

9152]</p>

9153<p id="_sm_CDR0000766497_2720" tabindex="-1">

9154Over a 10-year period, the International Cowden Consortium (ICC) prospectively recruited a consecutive series of adult and pediatric patients meeting relaxed ICC criteria for <em class="gene-name">

9155PTEN</em>

9156 testing in the United States, Europe, and Asia.[<a href="#cit/section_4.597">

9157597</a>

9158] Most individuals did not meet the clinical criteria for a diagnosis of Cowden syndrome or BRRS. Of the 3,399 individuals recruited and tested, 295 probands (8.8%) and an additional 73 family members carried a germline <em class="gene-name">

9159PTEN</em>

9160 pathogenic variant. The authors concluded that melanoma, kidney cancer, and colorectal cancer should be added to the spectrum of cancers associated with <em class="gene-name">

9161PTEN</em>

9162 germline pathogenic variants (in addition to breast cancer, thyroid cancer, and endometrial cancer). This conclusion was based on the high melanoma, kidney, and colorectal cancer lifetime risk estimates found in individuals with <em class="gene-name">

9163PTEN</em>

9164 pathogenic variants. A second study of approximately 100 patients with a germline <em class="gene-name">

9165PTEN</em>

9166 pathogenic variant confirmed these findings and suggested a cumulative cancer risk of 85% by age 70 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.598">

9167598</a>

9168]</p>

9169</section>

9170<p id="_2720" tabindex="-1">

9171 The age-adjusted risk of CRC was increased in carriers of pathogenic variants in both studies (SIR, 5.7&#8211;10.3).[<a href="#cit/section_4.597">

9172597</a>

9173,<a href="#cit/section_4.598">

9174598</a>

9175] In addition, one study found that 93% of individuals with <em class="gene-name">

9176PTEN</em>

9177 pathogenic variants who had undergone at least one colonoscopy had polyps.[<a href="#cit/section_4.597">

9178597</a>

9179] The most common histology was hyperplastic, although adenomas and sessile serrated polyps were also observed. The increased risk of CRC among carriers of <em class="gene-name">

9180PTEN</em>

9181 pathogenic variants has led to the recommendation of surveillance colonoscopy in these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.598">

9182598</a>

9183,<a href="#cit/section_4.599">

9184599</a>

9185] However, both the age at which to begin (30&#8211;40 y) and the subsequent frequency of colonoscopies (biennial to every 3&#8211;5 y) vary considerably and are based on expert opinion.</p>

9186<table id="_2606" class="table-default expandable-container">

9187<caption>

9189PTEN</em>

9190 Pathogenic Variants<span class="sup">

9226593</a>

9227] (Refer to the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3778">

9228<em class="gene-name">

9229PTEN</em>

9256<td>

9258<td>

9260</tr>

9261<tr>

9262<td>

9263Kidney</td>

9264<td>

9266<td>

926734% starting around age 40 y</td>

9268</tr>

9269<tr>

9270<td>

9271Melanoma</td>

9272<td>

92738.5 (4.1&#8211;15.6)</td>

9274<td>

92756% with earliest age of onset at 3 y</td>

9276</tr>

9277<tr>

9278<td>

9279Thyroid</td>

9280<td>

928151.1 (38.1&#8211;67.1)</td>

9282<td>

928335% at birth and throughout life</td>

9284</tr>

9285</tbody>

9286</table>

9287</section>

9288<section id="_2920">

9289<h4 id="_2920_toc">

9290Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS)</h4>

9291<section id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1248">

9292<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1249" tabindex="-1">

9293PJS is an early-onset autosomal dominant disorder

9294characterized by melanocytic macules on the lips, the perioral region, and buccal region;

9295and multiple gastrointestinal polyps, both hamartomatous and

9296adenomatous.[<a href="#cit/section_4.600">

9297600</a>

9298-<a href="#cit/section_4.602">

9299602</a>

9300] Germline pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

9301STK11</em>

9302 gene at chromosome 19p13.3 have been identified in the vast majority of PJS families.[<a href="#cit/section_4.603">

9303603</a>

9304-<a href="#cit/section_4.607">

9305607</a>

9306] The most common cancers in PJS are gastrointestinal. However, other organs are at increased risk of developing malignancies. For example, the cumulative risks have been estimated to be 32% to 54% for breast cancer [<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

93078</a>

9308,<a href="#cit/section_4.608">

9309608</a>

9310,<a href="#cit/section_4.609">

9311609</a>

9312] and 21% for ovarian cancer (mainly ovarian sex-cord tumors).[<a href="#cit/section_4.608">

9313608</a>

9314] The risk for pancreatic cancer has been estimated to be more than 100-fold higher than that in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.608">

9315608</a>

9316] A systematic review found a lifetime cumulative cancer risk, all sites combined, of up to 93% in patients with PJS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.608">

9317608</a>

9318,<a href="#cit/section_4.610">

9319610</a>

9320] <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_sm_CDR0000738176_1250">

9321Table 15</a>

9322 shows the cumulative risk of these tumors. </p>

9323<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1255" tabindex="-1">

9324Females with PJS are also predisposed to the development of cervical adenoma malignum, a rare and very aggressive adenocarcinoma of the cervix.[<a href="#cit/section_4.611">

9325611</a>

9326] In addition, females with PJS commonly develop benign ovarian sex-cord tumors with annular tubules, whereas males with PJS are predisposed to development of Sertoli-cell testicular tumors;[<a href="#cit/section_4.612">

9327612</a>

9328] although neither of these two tumor types is malignant, they can cause symptoms related to increased estrogen production. </p>

9329<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1247" tabindex="-1">

9330Although the risk of malignancy appears to be exceedingly high in individuals with PJS based on the published literature, the possibility that selection and referral biases have resulted in overestimates of these risks should be considered. </p>

9331<table id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1250" class="table-default expandable-container">

9332<caption>

9333Table 15. Cumulative Cancer Risks in Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome Up To Specified Age<span class="sup">

9334a</span>

9335</caption>

9336<colgroup>

9337<col width="25.00%">

9338<col width="25.00%">

9339<col width="25.00%">

9340<col width="25.00%">

9341</colgroup>

9342<THead>

9343<tr>

9344<th>

9345Site</th>

9346<th>

9347Age (y)</th>

9348<th>

9349Cumulative Risk (%)<span class="sup">

9350b</span>

9351</th>

9352<th>

9353Reference(s)</th>

9354</tr>

9355</THead>

9356<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

9357<tr>

9358<td colspan="4">

9359GI = gastrointestinal.</td>

9360</tr>

9361<tr>

9362<td colspan="4">

9363<span class="sup">

9364a</span>

9365Reprinted with permission from Macmillan Publishers Ltd: Gastroenterology [<a href="#cit/section_4.610">

9366610</a>

9367], copyright 2010.</td>

9368</tr>

9369<tr>

9370<td colspan="4">

9371<span class="sup">

9372b</span>

9373All cumulative risks were increased compared with the general population (<em>

9374P</em>

9375 &lt; .05), with the exception of cervix and testes.</td>

9376</tr>

9377<tr>

9378<td colspan="4">

9379<span class="sup">

9380c</span>

9381GI cancers include colorectal, small intestinal, gastric, esophageal, and pancreatic.</td>

9382</tr>

9383<tr>

9384<td colspan="4">

9385<span class="sup">

9386d</span>

9387Westerman et al.: GI cancer does not include pancreatic cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.613">

9388613</a>

9389]</td>

9390</tr>

9391<tr>

9392<td colspan="4">

9393<span class="sup">

9394e</span>

9395Did not include adenoma malignum of the cervix or Sertoli cell tumors of the testes.</td>

9396</tr>

9397</TFoot>

9398<tbody>

9399<tr>

9400<td>

9401Any cancer</td>

9402<td>

940360&#8211;70</td>

9404<td>

940537&#8211;93</td>

9406<td>

9407[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

94088</a>

9409,<a href="#cit/section_4.607">

9410607</a>

9411-<a href="#cit/section_4.609">

9412609</a>

9413,<a href="#cit/section_4.613">

9414613</a>

9415,<a href="#cit/section_4.614">

9416614</a>

9417]</td>

9418</tr>

9420<td>

9421GI cancer<span class="sup">

9422c,d</span>

9423</td>

9424<td>

942560&#8211;70</td>

9426<td>

942738&#8211;66</td>

9428<td>

9429[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

94308</a>

9431,<a href="#cit/section_4.609">

9432609</a>

9433,<a href="#cit/section_4.613">

9434613</a>

9435,<a href="#cit/section_4.614">

9436614</a>

9437]</td>

9438</tr>

9439<tr>

9440<td>

9441Gynecological cancer</td>

9442<td>

944360&#8211;70</td>

9444<td>

944513&#8211;18</td>

9446<td>

9447[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

94488</a>

9449,<a href="#cit/section_4.609">

9450609</a>

9451]</td>

9452</tr>

9453<tr>

9458</strong>

9459</td>

9476608</a>

9477]</td>

9488608</a>

9489]</td>

9490</tr>

9492<td>

9493Colorectum</td>

9494<td>

949565</td>

9496<td>

949739</td>

9498<td>

9499[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

95008</a>

9501,<a href="#cit/section_4.608">

9502608</a>

9503]</td>

9504</tr>

9507Pancreas</td>

9508<td>

950965&#8211;70</td>

9510<td>

951111&#8211;36</td>

9512<td>

9513[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

95148</a>

9515,<a href="#cit/section_4.608">

9516608</a>

9517]</td>

9518</tr>

9522<td>

952365&#8211;70</td>

9524<td>

95257&#8211;17</td>

9526<td>

9527[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

95288</a>

9529,<a href="#cit/section_4.608">

9530608</a>

9531,<a href="#cit/section_4.609">

9532609</a>

9533]</td>

9534</tr>

9538<td>

953960&#8211;70</td>

9540<td>

954132&#8211;54</td>

95448</a>

9546608</a>

9548609</a>

958165</td>

9585[<a href="#cit/section_4.608">

9586608</a>

9587]</td>

9592e</span>

9593</td>

9594<td>

959565</td>

95979</td>

9600608</a>
