9602</tr>

9603</tbody>

9604</table>

9605<section id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1251">

9606<h6 id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1251_toc">

9607Peutz-Jeghers gene(s)</h6>

9608<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1252" tabindex="-1">

9609PJS is caused by pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

9610STK11</em>

9611 (also called <em class="gene-name">

9612LKB1</em>

9613) tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 19p13.[<a href="#cit/section_4.604">

9614604</a>

9615,<a href="#cit/section_4.605">

9616605</a>

9617] Unlike the adenomas seen in familial adenomatous polyposis, the polyps arising in PJS are hamartomas. Studies of the hamartomatous polyps and cancers of PJS show allelic imbalance (LOH) consistent with the two-hit hypothesis, demonstrating that <em class="gene-name">

9618STK11</em>

9619 is a tumor suppressor gene.[<a href="#cit/section_4.615">

9620615</a>

9621,<a href="#cit/section_4.616">

9622616</a>

9623] However, heterozygous <em class="gene-name">

9624STK11</em>

9625 knockout mice develop hamartomas without inactivation of the remaining wild-type allele, suggesting that <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781846&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781846&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9626haploinsufficiency</a>

9627 may be sufficient for initial tumor development in PJS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.617">

9628617</a>

9629] Subsequently, the cancers that develop in <em class="gene-name">

9630STK11</em>

9631 +/- mice do show LOH;[<a href="#cit/section_4.618">

9632618</a>

9633] indeed, compound mutant mice heterozygous for pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

9634STK11</em>

9635 +/- and homozygous for pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

9636TP53</em>

9637 -/- have accelerated development of both hamartomas and cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.619">

9638619</a>

9639]</p>

9640<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1253" tabindex="-1">

9641Germline variants of the <em class="gene-name">

9642STK11</em>

9643 gene represent a spectrum of nonsense, frameshift, and missense variants, and splice-site variants and large deletions.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

96448</a>

9645,<a href="#cit/section_4.603">

9646603</a>

9647] </p>

9648<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_2855" tabindex="-1">

9649Approximately 85% of variants are localized to regions of the kinase domain of the expressed protein. No strong genotype-phenotype correlations have been identified.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

96508</a>

9651] Up to 30% of variants are large deletions involving one or more exons of <em class="gene-name">

9652STK11</em>

9653, underscoring the importance of deletion analysis in suspected cases of PJS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.603">

9654603</a>

9655]</p>

9656<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1254" tabindex="-1">

9657<em class="gene-name">

9658STK11</em>

9659 has been unequivocally demonstrated to cause PJS. Although earlier estimates using direct DNA sequencing showed a 50% pathogenic variant detection rate in <em class="gene-name">

9660STK11</em>

9661, studies adding techniques to detect large deletions have found pathogenic variants in up to 94% of individuals meeting clinical criteria for PJS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.603">

9662603</a>

9663,<a href="#cit/section_4.610">

9664610</a>

9665,<a href="#cit/section_4.620">

9666620</a>

9667] Given the results of these studies, it is unlikely that other major genes cause PJS.</p>

9668</section>

9669<section id="_sm_CDR0000738176_2853">

9670<h6 id="_sm_CDR0000738176_2853_toc">

9671Clinical management</h6>

9672<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_2854" tabindex="-1">

9673The high cumulative risk of cancers in PJS has led to the various screening recommendations summarized in the table of <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_873">

9674Published Recommendations for Diagnosis and Surveillance of Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (PJS)</a>

9675 in the PDQ summary on <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq">

9676Genetics of Colorectal Cancer</a>

9677.</p>

9678</section>

9679</section>

9680</section>

9681<section id="_647">

9682<h4 id="_647_toc">

9683Juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS)</h4>

9684<p id="_648" tabindex="-1">

9685JPS is a genetically heterogeneous, rare, childhood- to early adult-onset,

9686autosomal dominant disease that presents characteristically as hamartomatous

9687polyposis throughout the GI tract, although colorectal polyps predominate.[<a href="#cit/section_4.621">

9688621</a>

9689] JPS can present with diarrhea, GI tract hemorrhage, protein-losing enteropathy, and prolapsing polyps.[<a href="#cit/section_4.621">

9690621</a>

9691-<a href="#cit/section_4.623">

9692623</a>

9693]

9694

9695 JPS is defined by the presence of a specific type of hamartomatous polyp called a juvenile polyp, often in the setting of a family history of JPS. The diagnosis of a juvenile polyp is based on its histologic appearance, rather than age at onset. Solitary juvenile polyps of the colon or rectum are seen sporadically in infants and young children and do not imply a diagnosis of JPS. A clinical diagnosis of JPS is met by individuals fulfilling one or more of the following criteria:[<a href="#cit/section_4.624">

9696624</a>

9697]</p>

9698<div class="pdq-content-list">

9699<ol id="_2616">

9700<li>

9701More than five juvenile polyps of the colon or rectum.</li>

9702<li>

9703Juvenile polyps in other parts of the GI tract.</li>

9704<li>

9705Any number of juvenile polyps and a positive family history of JPS.</li>

9706</ol>

9707</div>

9708<p id="_2617" tabindex="-1">

9709JPS is caused by

9710germline pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

9711SMAD4</em>

9712 gene, also known as <em class="gene-name">

9713MADH4/DPC4</em>

9714, at chromosome

971518q21 [<a href="#cit/section_4.625">

9716625</a>

9717] in approximately 15% to 60% of cases,[<a href="#cit/section_4.621">

9718621</a>

9719] and by pathogenic variants in the gene encoding the <em class="gene-name">

9720bone morphogenic protein receptor 1A</em>

9721 (<em class="gene-name">

9722BMPR1A</em>

9723) residing on chromosome <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460129&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460129&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9724band</a>

9725 10q22 in approximately 25% to 40% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.626">

9726626</a>

9727,<a href="#cit/section_4.627">

9728627</a>

9729] Because pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

9730SMAD4</em>

9731 and <em class="gene-name">

9732BMPR1A</em>

9733 are known to account for juvenile polyposis, clinicians have referred young patients with fewer than five polyps for genetic testing. A study conducted on 77 patients with a total of 84 polyps found that the yield of genetic testing in patients with a limited number of polyps is minimal; of the germline variants detected, none were classified as definitely pathogenic or likely pathogenic.[<a href="#cit/section_4.628">

9734628</a>

9735] </p>

9736<p id="_3204" tabindex="-1">

9737Genotype/phenotype correlations suggest <em class="gene-name">

9738SMAD4</em>

9739 variants may be associated with a greater risk of severe gastric polyposis [<a href="#cit/section_4.629">

9740629</a>

9741] and features of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) (refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2604">

9742features of HHT</a>

9743 below).[<a href="#cit/section_4.621">

9744621</a>

9745] The lifetime risk of CRC in JPS has been reported to be 39%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.630">

9746630</a>

9747] There appears to be an increased risk of gastric cancer, albeit much lower than the risk of CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.621">

9748621</a>

9749] Cardiac valvular abnormalities were present in 12% of individuals with JPS who were followed through a single-institution&#8211;based polyposis registry,[<a href="#cit/section_4.621">

9750621</a>

9751] and all those with identifiable pathogenic variants had <em class="gene-name">

9752SMAD4</em>

9753 variants.</p>

9754<p id="_2604" tabindex="-1">

9755JPS patients with <em class="gene-name">

9756SMAD4</em>

9757 pathogenic variants may also have signs and symptoms of HHT, such as arteriovenous malformations, mucocutaneous telangiectasias, digital clubbing, osteoarthropathy, hepatic arteriovenous malformations, and cerebellar cavernous hemangioma, suggesting that the two syndromes overlap.[<a href="#cit/section_4.631">

9758631</a>

9759] When a patient is found clinically to have features of both JPS and HHT, the pathogenic variant will be in the <em class="gene-name">

9760SMAD4</em>

9761 gene. Most patients with isolated HHT will have a pathogenic variant in the activin receptor-like kinase 1 (<em class="gene-name">

9762ALK1</em>

9763) gene or in the endoglin (<em class="gene-name">

9764ENG</em>

9765) gene, but <em class="gene-name">

9766SMAD4</em>

9767 pathogenic variants have also been reported, although they are quite rare (approximately 1%&#8211;2% of patients with HHT).[<a href="#cit/section_4.632">

9768632</a>

9769] One series suggested a slightly higher incidence of <em class="gene-name">

9770SMAD4</em>

9771 pathogenic variants in unselected patients with HHT. In this study, 3 of 30 patients (10%) with HHT without a clinical diagnosis of JPS were found to have germline variants in <em class="gene-name">

9772SMAD4</em>

9773.[<a href="#cit/section_4.633">

9774633</a>

9775] Conversely, features of HHT were noted in 21% to 22% of carriers of <em class="gene-name">

9776SMAD4</em>

9777 pathogenic variants in two studies of individuals with a clinical diagnosis of JPS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.621">

9778621</a>

9779,<a href="#cit/section_4.634">

9780634</a>

9781] In a study of 21 carriers of <em class="gene-name">

9782SMAD4</em>

9783 pathogenic variants from nine JPS families, 81% (17 of 21) of patients had HHT manifestations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.635">

9784635</a>

9785] The high prevalence in this study may have been a result of the inclusion of several relatives from a single family and the inclusion of several families with the same pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_4.635">

9786635</a>

9787] </p>

9788<p id="_2618" tabindex="-1">

9789Surveillance for HHT has been suggested in JPS patients with germline <em class="gene-name">

9790SMAD4</em>

9791 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.621">

9792621</a>

9793,<a href="#cit/section_4.635">

9794635</a>

9795] On the other hand, patients with HHT without germline variants in <em class="gene-name">

9796ALK1</em>

9797 or <em class="gene-name">

9798ENG</em>

9799 may be considered for <em class="gene-name">

9800SMAD4</em>

9801 germline genetic testing; the GI tract should be evaluated if a <em class="gene-name">

9802SMAD4</em>

9803 germline pathogenic variant is confirmed.[<a href="#cit/section_4.636">

9804636</a>

9805] (Refer to <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2622">

9806Table 17</a>

9807, Published Recommendations for Diagnosis and Surveillance of JPS, for more information.)</p>

9808<p id="_1441" tabindex="-1">

9809A severe form of JPS, in which polyposis develops in the first few years of life, is referred to as JPS of infancy. JPS of infancy is often caused by microdeletions of chromosome 10q22-23, a region that includes <em class="gene-name">

9810BMPR1A</em>

9811 and <em class="gene-name">

9812PTEN</em>

9813. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2559">

9814PTEN hamartoma tumor syndromes [including Cowden syndrome]</a>

9815 section of this summary for more information about <em class="gene-name">

9816PTEN</em>

9817.) The phenotype often includes features such as macrocephaly and developmental delay, possibly as a result of loss of <em class="gene-name">

9818PTEN</em>

9819 function.[<a href="#cit/section_4.637">

9820637</a>

9821] Recurrent GI bleeding, diarrhea, exudative enteropathy, in addition to associated developmental delay, are associated with a very high rate of morbidity and mortality in these infants, thereby limiting the heritability of such cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.637">

9822637</a>

9823]</p>

9824<section id="_2563">

9825<h5 id="_2563_toc">

9826Juvenile polyposis gene(s)</h5>

9827<p id="_2619" tabindex="-1">

9828JPS is caused by germline pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

9829SMAD4</em>

9830 gene in approximately 15% to 60% of cases, and to pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

9831BMPR1A</em>

9832 in approximately 25% to 40% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.621">

9833621</a>

9834,<a href="#cit/section_4.626">

9835626</a>

9836,<a href="#cit/section_4.627">

9837627</a>

9838] The large variability in variant frequency likely reflects the relatively small number of patients reported in individual studies. A subset of individuals meeting clinical criteria for JPS will not have an identified pathogenic variant in either <em class="gene-name">

9839SMAD4 </em>

9840or <em class="gene-name">

9841BMPR1A</em>

9842. </p>

9843<p id="_2565" tabindex="-1">

9844<em class="gene-name">

9845SMAD4</em>

9846 encodes a protein that is a component of the transforming growth factor (TGF)-beta signaling pathway, which mediates growth inhibitory signals from the cell surface to the nucleus. Germline pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

9847SMAD4</em>

9848 predispose individuals to forming juvenile polyps and cancer,[<a href="#cit/section_4.625">

9849625</a>

9850] and germline variants have been found in 6 of 11 exons. Most variants are unique, but several recurrent pathogenic variants have been identified in multiple independent families.[<a href="#cit/section_4.634">

9851634</a>

9852,<a href="#cit/section_4.638">

9853638</a>

9854] Patients with <em class="gene-name">

9855SMAD4</em>

9856 pathogenic variants are also at high risk for developing extracolonic GI cancers such as gastric cancers, often in the context of gastric polyposis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.634">

9857634</a>

9858] </p>

9859<p id="_2566" tabindex="-1">

9860<em class="gene-name">

9861BMPR1A</em>

9862 is a serine-threonine kinase type I receptor of the TGF-beta superfamily that, when activated, leads to phosphorylation of SMAD4. The <em class="gene-name">

9863BMPR1A</em>

9864 gene was first identified by linkage analysis in families with JPS who did not have identifiable pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

9865SMAD4</em>

9866. Variants in <em class="gene-name">

9867BMPR1A</em>

9868 include nonsense, frameshift, missense, and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783968&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783968&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9869splice-site variants</a>

9870.[<a href="#cit/section_4.626">

9871626</a>

9872] Large genomic deletions detected by MLPA have been reported in both <em class="gene-name">

9873BMPR1A</em>

9874 and <em class="gene-name">

9875SMAD4</em>

9876 in patients with JPS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.634">

9877634</a>

9878,<a href="#cit/section_4.638">

9879638</a>

9880] Rare JPS families have demonstrated variants in the <em class="gene-name">

9881ENG</em>

9882 and <em class="gene-name">

9883PTEN</em>

9884 genes, but these have not been confirmed in other studies.[<a href="#cit/section_4.639">

9885639</a>

9886,<a href="#cit/section_4.640">

9887640</a>

9888]</p>

9889</section>

9890</section>

9891<section id="_651">

9892<h4 id="_651_toc">

9893<em class="gene-name">

9894CHEK2</em>

9895</h4>

9896<p id="_652" tabindex="-1">

9897Several studies initially suggested that a subset of families with hereditary breast and colon cancers may have a cancer family syndrome caused by a pathogenic variant in the <em class="gene-name">

9898CHEK2</em>

9899 gene.[<a href="#cit/section_4.641">

9900641</a>

9901-<a href="#cit/section_4.643">

9902643</a>

9903] However, subsequent studies have suggested that <em class="gene-name">

9904CHEK2</em>

9905 variants are associated with only a modest increase in CRC risk (i.e., low penetrance). One large study showed that truncating variants in <em class="gene-name">

9906CHEK2</em>

9907 were not significantly associated with CRC; however, a specific missense pathogenic variant (I157T) was associated with modest increased risk (OR, 1.5; 95% CI, 1.2&#8211;3.0) of CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.644">

9908644</a>

9909]</p>

9910<p id="_1133" tabindex="-1">

9911Similar results were obtained in another study conducted in Poland.[<a href="#cit/section_4.645">

9912645</a>

9913] In this study, 463 probands from Lynch syndrome and Lynch syndrome&#8211;related families and 5,496 controls were <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=793548&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000793548&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9914genotyped</a>

9915 for four <em class="gene-name">

9916CHEK2</em>

9917 pathogenic variants, including I157T. In MMR variant-negative cases, the missense I157T allele was associated with Lynch syndrome&#8211;related cancers (OR, 2.1; 95% CI, 1.4&#8211;3.1). <em class="gene-name">

9918CHEK2</em>

9919 truncating variants were not associated with an increase in Lynch syndrome&#8211;related cancers. Further studies are needed to confirm this finding and to determine if they are related to FCCX.</p>

9920<p id="_2530" tabindex="-1">

9921(Refer to the <em class="gene-name">

9922<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1309">

9923CHEK2</a>

9924</em>

9925 section in Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers for more information.)</p>

9926</section>

9927<section id="_649">

9928<h4 id="_649_toc">

9929Hereditary mixed polyposis syndrome (HMPS)</h4>

9930<p id="_650" tabindex="-1">

9931HMPS is a rare cancer family syndrome characterized by the development of a variety of colon polyp types, including serrated adenomas, atypical juvenile polyps and adenomas, and colon adenocarcinoma. Although initially mapped to a locus between 6q16-q21, the HMPS locus is now believed to map to 15q13-q14.[<a href="#cit/section_4.646">

9932646</a>

9933,<a href="#cit/section_4.647">

9934647</a>

9935] While there is considerable phenotypic overlap between JPS and HMPS, one large family has been linked to a locus on chromosome 15, raising the possibility that this may be a distinct disorder. Linkage analysis of Ashkenazi Jewish families with HMPS revealed shared haplotypes on chromosome 15q13.3.[<a href="#cit/section_4.648">

9936648</a>

9937] An unusual heterozygous 40kb single-copy duplication was discovered upstream of <em class="gene-name">

9938gremlin 1</em>

9939 (<em class="gene-name">

9940GREM1</em>

9941) that segregated perfectly with individuals and family members with HMPS and not with unaffected controls.[<a href="#cit/section_4.648">

9942648</a>

9943] The presence of this duplication in HMPS individuals was associated with increased expression of <em class="gene-name">

9944GREM1</em>

9945 transcript levels in the normal intestinal epithelium.[<a href="#cit/section_4.648">

9946648</a>

9947] <em class="gene-name">

9948GREM1</em>

9949 is a bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) antagonist and thus theoretically would promote the stem cell phenotype in the intestine. Germline variants leading to defective BMP signaling also underlie JPS, thus drawing a potential link between HMPS and JPS.</p>

9950<p id="_3192" tabindex="-1">

9951Although exceedingly rare, <em class="gene-name">

9952GREM1</em>

9953 pathogenic variants have been described in several additional families of Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry, with varying clinical presentations. Although polyposis appears to be a unifying feature in most families, there is a high degree of variability with respect to polyp number, histology, and age of onset. In addition, extracolonic malignancies have been described in several pathogenic variant carriers, although the small number of affected individuals limits the ability to definitively demonstrate a causal link to the <em class="gene-name">

9954GREM1</em>

9955 pathogenic variant. On the basis of relatively limited data, it is reasonable to consider <em class="gene-name">

9956GREM1</em>

9957-variant analysis in Ashkenazi Jewish families presenting with unexplained polyposis and/or familial CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.649">

9958649</a>

9959] In such families, comprehensive variant analysis that includes testing for duplications in noncoding regions of <em class="gene-name">

9960GREM1</em>

9961 is necessary.</p>

9962</section>

9963<section id="_684">

9964<h4 id="_684_toc">

9965Serrated polyposis syndrome (SPS)</h4>

9966<p id="_685" tabindex="-1">

9967Isolated and multiple hyperplastic polyps (HPs) (typically white, flat, and small) are common in the general population, and their presence does not suggest an underlying genetic disorder. Historically, the clinical diagnosis of SPS (also known as hyperplastic polyposis syndrome), as defined by WHO, must satisfy one of the following criteria:</p>

9968<div class="pdq-content-list">

9969<ul id="_794">

9970<li>

9971At least five histologically diagnosed HP occurring proximal to the sigmoid colon (of which at least two are &gt;10 mm in diameter).</li>

9972<li>

9973One HP occurring proximal to the sigmoid colon in an individual who has at least one FDR with hyperplastic polyposis.</li>

9974<li>

9975More than 30 HPs distributed throughout the colon.[<a href="#cit/section_4.650">

9976650</a>

9977]</li>

9978</ul>

9979</div>

9980<p id="_2631" tabindex="-1">

9981[<em>

9982Note: Other groups have included serrated adenomas as part of the revised clinical criteria for SPS.<a href="#cit/citation.651">

9983651</a>

9984</em>

9985]</p>

9986<p id="_795" tabindex="-1">

9987Although the vast majority of cases of SPS lack a family history of HPs, approximately half of the SPS cases have a positive family history of CRC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.652">

9988652</a>

9989,<a href="#cit/section_4.653">

9990653</a>

9991] Several studies show that the prevalence of colorectal adenocarcinoma in patients with formally defined criteria for SPS is 50% or more.[<a href="#cit/section_4.654">

9992654</a>

9993-<a href="#cit/section_4.661">

9994661</a>

9995] One study, using a variation of the WHO criteria for SPS (SPS was defined as at least five histologically diagnosed HPs and/or sessile serrated adenomas (SSAs) proximal to the sigmoid colon, of which two are greater than 10 mm in diameter, or more than 20 HPs and/or SSAs distributed throughout the colon), found an RR for CRC in 347 FDRs (41% male) from 57 pedigrees of 5.4 (95% CI, 3.7&#8211;7.8).[<a href="#cit/section_4.651">

9996651</a>

9997]</p>

9998<p id="_2620" tabindex="-1">

9999The WHO criteria are based on expert opinion; there is no known susceptibility gene or genomic region that has been reproducibly linked to this disorder, so genetic diagnosis is not possible. Two studies have reported potentially causative germline variants in SPS individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_4.652">

10000652</a>

10001,<a href="#cit/section_4.662">

10002662</a>

10003]</p>

10004<p id="_797" tabindex="-1">

10005In a cohort of 40 SPS patients, defined as having more than five HPs or more than three HPs, two of which were larger than 1 cm in diameter, one patient was found to have a germline variant in the <em class="gene-name">

10006EPHB2</em>

10007 gene (D861N).[<a href="#cit/section_4.662">

10008662</a>

10009] The patient had serrated adenomas and more than 100 HPs in her colon at age 58 years, and her mother died of colon cancer at age 36 years. <em class="gene-name">

10010EPHB2</em>

10011 germline variants were not found in 100 additional patients with a personal history of CRC or in 200 population-matched healthy control patients. </p>

10012<p id="_798" tabindex="-1">

10013Far more is known about the somatic molecular genetic alterations found in the colonic tumors occurring in SPS patients. In a study of patients with either more than 20 HPs per colon, more than four HPs larger than 1 cm in diameter, or multiple (5&#8211;10) HPs per colon, a specific somatic <em class="gene-name">

10014BRAF</em>

10015 mutation (V600E) was found in polyp tissue.[<a href="#cit/section_4.663">

10016663</a>

10017] Fifty percent of HPs (20 of 40) from these patients demonstrated the V600E <em class="gene-name">

10018BRAF</em>

10019 pathogenic variant. The HPs from these patients also demonstrated significantly higher CpG island methylation phenotypes (CIMP-high), and fewer <em class="gene-name">

10020KRAS</em>

10021 variants than left-sided sporadic HPs. In a previous study from this group, HPs from patients with SPS showed a loss of chromosome 1p in 21% (16 of 76) versus 0% in HPs from patients with large HPs (&gt;1 cm), or only five to ten HPs.[<a href="#cit/section_4.655">

10022655</a>

10023] </p>

10024<p id="_799" tabindex="-1">

10025Many of the genetic and histological alterations found in HPs of patients with SPS are common with the CIMP pathway of colorectal adenocarcinoma. Sporadic serrated polyps are the precursors to CRCs of the CIMP pathway. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1337">

10026CIMP and the serrated polyposis pathway</a>

10027 section in the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1">

10028Introduction</a>

10029 section of this summary for more information.) </p>

10030</section>

10031<section id="_303">

10032<h4 id="_303_toc">

10033Interventions for rare colon cancer syndromes</h4>

10034<p id="_304" tabindex="-1">

10035Individuals with PJS and JPS are at increased risk of CRC and extracolonic cancers. Because these syndromes are rare, there have been no evidence-based surveillance recommendations. Because of the markedly increased risk of colorectal and other cancers in these syndromes, a number of guidelines have been published based on retrospective and case series (i.e., based exclusively on expert opinion).[<a href="#cit/section_4.664">

10036664</a>

10037-<a href="#cit/section_4.668">

10038668</a>

10039] Clinical judgment must be used in making screening recommendations based on published guidelines.</p>

10040<table id="_873" class="table-default expandable-container">

10041<caption>

10221<p id="_871" tabindex="-1">

10223Level of evidence: 5</a>

10275638</a>

10347122</a>

10350Yes, genetic testing for anyone who meets JPS criteria. Genetic testing at 12&#8211;15 y if there is a known <em class="gene-name">

10351BMPR1A</em>

10352 pathogenic variant in the family or at 6 mo if there is a known <em class="gene-name">

10353SMAD4</em>

10354<span class="sup">

10355b</span>

10356 mutation in the family</td>

10357<td>

1035812&#8211;15 y</td>

10359<td>

103602&#8211;3 y if polyps are found. Screening intervals can be shortened if polyp number, pathology, or size is concerning. If polyps are not found, screening can be suspended until age 18 y. At 18 y, screening can be done every 1&#8211;3 y<span class="sup">

10361c</span>

10362</td>

10363<td>

10364C, EGD</td>

10365<td>

10366Refer to a specialized team. </td>

10367</tr>

10368</tbody>

10369</table>

10370<p id="_872" tabindex="-1">

10371<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

10372Level of evidence: 5</a>

10373</p>

10374</section>

10375</section>

10376<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10377References</h6>

10378<ol>

10379<li id="section_4.1">

10380Bussey HJ: Familial Polyposis Coli: Family Studies, Histopathology, Differential Diagnosis, and Results of Treatment. The Johns Hopkins University Press, 1975.</li>

Gastroenterology 131 (1): 30-9, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16831587&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16831587&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12971[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12972</li>

12973<li id="section_4.653">

12974Lage P, Cravo M, Sousa R, et al.: Management of Portuguese patients with hyperplastic polyposis and screening of at-risk first-degree relatives: a contribution for future guidelines based on a clinical study. Am J Gastroenterol 99 (9): 1779-84, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15330918&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15330918&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12975[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12976</li>

12977<li id="section_4.654">

12978Leggett BA, Devereaux B, Biden K, et al.: Hyperplastic polyposis: association with colorectal cancer. Am J Surg Pathol 25 (2): 177-84, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11176066&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11176066&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12979[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12980</li>

12981<li id="section_4.655">

12982Rashid A, Houlihan PS, Booker S, et al.: Phenotypic and molecular characteristics of hyperplastic polyposis. Gastroenterology 119 (2): 323-32, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10930367&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10930367&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12983[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12984</li>

12985<li id="section_4.656">

12986Place RJ, Simmang CL: Hyperplastic-adenomatous polyposis syndrome. J Am Coll Surg 188 (5): 503-7, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10235578&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10235578&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12987[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12988</li>

12989<li id="section_4.657">

12990Hyman NH, Anderson P, Blasyk H: Hyperplastic polyposis and the risk of colorectal cancer. Dis Colon Rectum 47 (12): 2101-4, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15657661&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15657661&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12991[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12992</li>

12993<li id="section_4.658">

12994Koide N, Saito Y, Fujii T, et al.: A case of hyperplastic polyposis of the colon with adenocarcinomas in hyperplastic polyps after long-term follow-up. Endoscopy 34 (6): 499-502, 2002.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12048637&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12048637&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12995[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

12996</li>

12997<li id="section_4.659">

12998Jeevaratnam P, Cottier DS, Browett PJ, et al.: Familial giant hyperplastic polyposis predisposing to colorectal cancer: a new hereditary bowel cancer syndrome. J Pathol 179 (1): 20-5, 1996.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8691339&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8691339&amp;dopt=Abstract">

12999[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13000</li>

13001<li id="section_4.660">

13002Bengoechea O, Mart&#237;nez-Pe&#241;uela JM, Larr&#237;naga B, et al.: Hyperplastic polyposis of the colorectum and adenocarcinoma in a 24-year-old man. Am J Surg Pathol 11 (4): 323-7, 1987.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3565675&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3565675&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13003[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13004</li>

13005<li id="section_4.661">

13006McCann BG: A case of metaplastic polyposis of the colon associated with focal adenomatous change and metachronous adenocarcinomas. Histopathology 13 (6): 700-2, 1988.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2466756&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2466756&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13007[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13008</li>

13009<li id="section_4.662">

13010Kokko A, Laiho P, Lehtonen R, et al.: EPHB2 germline variants in patients with colorectal cancer or hyperplastic polyposis. BMC Cancer 6: 145, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16740153&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16740153&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13011[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13012</li>

13013<li id="section_4.663">

13014Beach R, Chan AO, Wu TT, et al.: BRAF mutations in aberrant crypt foci and hyperplastic polyposis. 13015[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13016</li>

13017<li id="section_4.664">

13018Burt R, Neklason DW: Genetic testing for inherited colon cancer. Gastroenterology 128 (6): 1696-716, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15887160&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15887160&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13019[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13020</li>

13021<li id="section_4.665">

13022Dunlop MG; British Society for GastroenterologyAssociation of Coloproctology for Great Britain and Ireland: Guidance on gastrointestinal surveillance for hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, familial adenomatous polypolis, juvenile polyposis, and Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Gut 51 (Suppl 5): V21-7, 2002.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12221036&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12221036&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13023[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13024</li>

13025<li id="section_4.666">

13026McGrath DR, Spigelman AD: Preventive measures in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Fam Cancer 1 (2): 121-5, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14574008&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14574008&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13027[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13028</li>

13029<li id="section_4.667">

13030Giardiello FM, Trimbath JD: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and management recommendations. Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol 4 (4): 408-15, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16616343&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16616343&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13031[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13032</li>

13033<li id="section_4.668">

13034Brosens LA, van Hattem WA, Jansen M, et al.: Gastrointestinal polyposis syndromes. Curr Mol Med 7 (1): 29-46, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17311531&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17311531&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13035[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13036</li>

13037<li id="section_4.669">

13038Zbuk KM, Eng C: Hamartomatous polyposis syndromes. Nat Clin Pract Gastroenterol Hepatol 4 (9): 492-502, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17768394&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17768394&amp;dopt=Abstract">

13039[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

13040</li>

13041</ol>

13042</div>

13043

13044 </section>

13045

13046

13047

13048 <section id="_189">

13049

13050 <h2>

13051Psychosocial Issues in Hereditary Colon Cancer Syndromes</h2>

13052

13053 <div id="_section_189" class="pdq-sections">

13054<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

13055<h6>

13056In This Section</h6>

13057<ul>

13058<li>

13059<a href="#_190_toc">

13060Introduction</a>

13061</li>

13062<li>

13063<a href="#_2923_toc">

13064Psychosocial Issues in Lynch Syndrome<ul>

13065<li>

13066<a href="#_2924_toc">

13067Participation in genetic counseling and testing for Lynch syndrome</a>

13068</li>

13069<li>

13070<a href="#_2925_toc">

13071Psychological impact of participating in genetic counseling and testing for Lynch syndrome</a>

13072</li>

13073<li>

13074<a href="#_2926_toc">

13075Psychosocial aspects of screening and risk reduction interventions for Lynch syndrome</a>

13076</li>

13077</ul>

13078</a>

13079</li>

13080<li>

13081<a href="#_2932_toc">

13082Psychosocial Issues in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP)<ul>

13083<li>

13085Participation in genetic counseling and testing for FAP</a>

13090</li>

13094</li>

13095</ul>

13096</a>

13097</li>

13100Reproductive Considerations in Individuals With Lynch Syndrome or FAP<ul>

13101<li>
