14407</tr>

14408</tbody>

14409</table>

14410<p id="_763" tabindex="-1">

14411Studies of risk-reducing surgery for FAP have found that general measures of quality of life have been within normal range, and the majority reported no negative impact on their body image. However, these studies suggest that risk-reducing surgery for FAP may have negative quality-of-life effects for at least some proportion of those affected. </p>

14412</section>

14413<section id="_2947">

14414<h5 id="_2947_toc">

14415Chemoprevention</h5>

14416<p id="_568" tabindex="-1">

14417Chemoprevention trials are currently under way to evaluate the effectiveness of various therapies for individuals at risk of Lynch syndrome and FAP.[<a href="#cit/section_5.73">

1441873</a>

14419,<a href="#cit/section_5.74">

1442074</a>

14421] In a sample of individuals diagnosed with FAP who were invited to take part in a 5-year trial to evaluate the effects of vitamins and fiber on the development of adenomatous polyps, 55% agreed to participate.[<a href="#cit/section_5.75">

1442275</a>

14423] Participants were more likely to be younger, to have been more recently diagnosed with FAP, and to live farther from the trial center, but did not differ from nonparticipants on any other psychosocial variables.</p>

14424</section>

14425</section>

14426</section>

14427<section id="_2958">

14428<h3 id="_2958_toc">

14429Reproductive Considerations in Individuals With Lynch Syndrome or FAP</h3>

14430<section id="_1106">

14431<h4 id="_1106_toc">

14432Assisted reproductive technology (ART)</h4>

14433<p id="_1107" tabindex="-1">

14434The possibility of transmitting a pathogenic variant to a child may pose a concern to families affected by hereditary CRC syndromes to the extent that some carriers may avoid childbearing. These concerns also may prompt individuals to consider using prenatal diagnosis (PND) methods to help reduce the risk of transmission. PND is an encompassing term used to refer to any medical procedure conducted to assess the presence of a genetic disorder in a fetus. Methods include amniocentesis and chorionic villous sampling.[<a href="#cit/section_5.76">

1443576</a>

14436,<a href="#cit/section_5.77">

1443777</a>

14438] Both procedures carry a small risk of miscarriage.[<a href="#cit/section_5.76">

1443976</a>

14440,<a href="#cit/section_5.78">

1444178</a>

14442] Moreover, discovering the fetus is a carrier of a cancer susceptibility variant may impose a difficult decision for couples regarding pregnancy continuation or termination and may require additional professional consultation and support. </p>

14443<p id="_1145" tabindex="-1">

14444An alternative to these tests is preimplantation genetic testing (PGT), a procedure used to test fertilized embryos for genetic disorders before uterine implantation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.79">

1444579</a>

14446,<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

1444780</a>

14448] Using the information obtained from the genetic testing, potential parents can decide whether or not to implant. PGT can be used to detect pathogenic variants in hereditary cancer predisposing genes, including <em class="gene-name">

14449APC</em>

14450.[<a href="#cit/section_5.58">

1445158</a>

14452,<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

1445364</a>

14454,<a href="#cit/section_5.81">

1445581</a>

14456]</p>

14457<p id="_1108" tabindex="-1">

14458From the limited studies published to date, there appears to be interest in the use of ART for FAP, Lynch syndrome, and PJS.[<a href="#cit/section_5.58">

1445958</a>

14460,<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

1446164</a>

14462,<a href="#cit/section_5.82">

1446382</a>

14464-<a href="#cit/section_5.84">

1446584</a>

14466] However, actual uptake rates have not been reported.</p>

14467<table id="_1111" class="table-default expandable-container">

14468<caption>

14469Table 20. Summary of Studies Evaluating Attitudes Toward, Interest in, or Intention to Use Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART) for Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP)<span class="sup">

14470a</span>

14471, Lynch Syndrome <span class="sup">

14472b</span>

14473, and Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (PJS)<span class="sup">

14474a</span>

14475</caption>

14476<colgroup>

14477<col width="23.09%">

14478<col width="23.09%">

14479<col width="23.09%">

14480<col width="30.71%">

14481</colgroup>

14482<THead>

14483<tr>

14484<th>

14485Study Population </th>

14486<th>

14487N<span class="sup">

14488c</span>

14489 </th>

14490<th>

14491Interest or Intention in ART </th>

14492<th>

14493Comments</th>

14494</tr>

14495</THead>

14496<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

14497<tr>

14498<td colspan="4">

14499GT = genetic testing; PGT = preimplantation genetic testing; PND = prenatal diagnosis.</td>

14500</tr>

14501<tr>

14502<td colspan="4">

14503<span class="sup">

14504a</span>

14505Studies used a cross-sectional design and were conducted in the United States,[<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

1450664</a>

14507] and in the Netherlands.[<a href="#cit/section_5.58">

1450858</a>

14509,<a href="#cit/section_5.83">

1451083</a>

14511].</td>

14512</tr>

14513<tr>

14514<td colspan="4">

14515<span class="sup">

14516b</span>

14517Participants were invited to complete questionnaires before clinical genetic testing for Lynch syndrome and at 3 months and 1 year after disclosure of genetic test results.</td>

14518</tr>

14519<tr>

14520<td colspan="4">

14521<span class="sup">

14522c</span>

14523Indicates number of participants older than 18 y, unless otherwise specified.</td>

14524</tr>

14525<tr>

14530APC</em>

14532</tr>

14533<tr>

14534<td colspan="4">

14535<span class="sup">

14536e</span>

14537Represents the number who indicated that they were considering having children in the future, out of a total of 130 individuals who answered a questionnaire before genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_5.82">

1453882</a>

14539]</td>

14540</tr>

14541<tr>

14542<td colspan="4">

14543<span class="sup">

14544f</span>

14545Total number of individuals with a Lynch syndrome pathogenic variant. Not all individuals answered or were eligible to answer each question.</td>

14546</tr>

14547</TFoot>

14548<tbody>

14549<tr>

14550<td>

14551FAP-affected individuals [<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

1455264</a>

14553]</td>

14554<td align="Center" scope="col">

1455520</td>

14556<td>

1455795% (19/20) would consider prenatal GT for FAP; 90% (18/20) would consider PGT; 75% (15/20) would consider amniocentesis or chorionic villous sampling</td>

14558<td>

14559&#160;</td>

14560</tr>

14561<tr>

14562<td>

14563FAP-affected individuals [<a href="#cit/section_5.58">

1456458</a>

14565]</td>

14566<td align="Center" scope="col">

14567341</td>

14568<td>

1456933% (16/64) would consider PND for FAP; 30% (76/256) would consider PGT; 15% (52/341) felt terminating pregnancy for FAP was acceptable </td>

14570<td>

1457124% and 25% of patients did not respond to questions about attitudes toward PND and PGT, respectively</td>

14572</tr>

14573<tr>

14574<td>

14575Individuals with an <em class="gene-name">

14576APC</em>

14577 pathogenic variant associated with FAP [<a href="#cit/section_5.84">

1457884</a>

14579]</td>

14580<td align="Center" scope="col">

1458165<span class="sup">

14582d</span>

14583</td>

14584<td>

1458525% (16/64) were aware of PGT; 78% (50/64) thought PGT should be offered; 55% (31/56) would consider PGT</td>

14586<td>

14587&#160;</td>

14588</tr>

14589<tr>

14590<td>

14591Individuals undergoing genetic testing for Lynch syndrome [<a href="#cit/section_5.82">

1459282</a>

14593]</td>

14594<td align="Center" scope="col">

1459548<span class="sup">

14596e</span>

14597</td>

14598<td>

1459921% 10/48) would consider PND and/or PGT; 19% (9/48) would consider only PND; 2% (1/48) would consider only PGT</td>

14600<td>

14601At 1 year after disclosure of GT results, two of nine carriers reported that they were considering PGT for future pregnancy</td>

14602</tr>

14603<tr>

14604<td>

14605Individuals with an identified Lynch syndrome pathogenic variant [<a href="#cit/section_5.84">

1460684</a>

14607]</td>

14608<td align="Center" scope="col">

1460943<span class="sup">

14610f</span>

14611</td>

14612<td>

1461319% (8/42) were aware of PGT; 69% (29/42) thought PGT should be offered; 41% (16/39) would consider PGT</td>

14614<td>

14615&#160;</td>

14616</tr>

14617<tr>

14618<td>

14619PJS-affected individuals<span class="sup">

14620a</span>

14621 [<a href="#cit/section_5.83">

1462283</a>

14623]</td>

14624<td align="Center" scope="col">

1462552</td>

14626<td>

1462715% (8/52) indicated that pregnancy termination was acceptable if PND identified a fetus with PJS; 52% (27/52) indicated PGT was acceptable for individuals with PJS</td>

14628<td>

14629Ten (19%) individuals, nine of whom were female, reported that they had decided not to conceive a child because of PJS</td>

14630</tr>

14631</tbody>

14632</table>

14633</section>

14949</li>

14950<li id="section_5.80">

14951Ogilvie CM, Braude PR, Scriven PN: Preimplantation genetic diagnosis--an overview. J Histochem Cytochem 53 (3): 255-60, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15749997&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15749997&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14952[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14953</li>

14954<li id="section_5.81">

14955Simpson JL, Carson SA, Cisneros P: Preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) for heritable neoplasia. J Natl Cancer Inst Monogr (34): 87-90, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15784832&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15784832&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14956[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14957</li>

14958<li id="section_5.82">

14959Dewanwala A, Chittenden A, Rosenblatt M, et al.: Attitudes toward childbearing and prenatal testing in individuals undergoing genetic testing for Lynch syndrome. Fam Cancer 10 (3): 549-56, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21567236&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21567236&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14960[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14961</li>

14962<li id="section_5.83">

14963van Lier MG, Korsse SE, Mathus-Vliegen EM, et al.: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and family planning: the attitude towards prenatal diagnosis and pre-implantation genetic diagnosis. Eur J Hum Genet 20 (2): 236-9, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21829227&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21829227&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14964[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14965</li>

14966<li id="section_5.84">

14967Rich TA, Liu M, Etzel CJ, et al.: Comparison of attitudes regarding preimplantation genetic diagnosis among patients with hereditary cancer syndromes. Fam Cancer 13 (2): 291-9, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24072553&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24072553&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14968[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14969</li>

14970</ol>

14971</div>

14972

14973 </section>

14974

14975

14976

14977 <section id="_335">

14978

14979 <h2>

14980Changes to This Summary (09/08/2023)</h2>

14981

14982 <div id="_section_335" class="pdq-sections">

14983<p id="_458" tabindex="-1">

14984The PDQ cancer information summaries are reviewed regularly and updated as new information becomes available. This section describes the latest changes made to this summary as of the date above.</p>

14985<p id="_3506" tabindex="-1">

14986<strong>

14987<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1">

14988Introduction</a>

14989</strong>

14990</p>

14991<p id="_3507" tabindex="-1">

14992Added <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3133">

14993text</a>

14994 to state that National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines are updated regularly to help identify patients who are appropriate for referral to a cancer genetic counseling service (cited NCCN [Genetic/Familial High-Risk Assessment: Colorectal] as reference 51). Historically, guidelines have existed from the American College of Medical Genetics and the National Society of Genetic Counselors, but these are not routinely updated (cited Bashford et al. as reference 53).</p>

14995<p id="_3487" tabindex="-1">

14996<strong>

14997<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_89">

14998Major Genetic Syndromes</a>

14999</strong>

15000</p>

15001<p id="_3508" tabindex="-1">

15002Revised <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3056">

15003text</a>

15004 to state that four models quantify an individual&#8217;s probability of carrying a pathogenic variant in one of the following mismatch repair (MMR) genes: <em class="gene-name">

15005MLH1</em>

15006, <em class="gene-name">

15007MSH2</em>

15008, and <em class="gene-name">

15009MSH6</em>

15010. Added PREMMplus as one of the models. Also added text to state that while PREMM5, MMRpredict, and MMRpro are specific to Lynch syndrome, PREMMplus quantifies an individual&#8217;s risk of having a pathogenic variant in one of 19 genes (cited Yurgelun et al. as reference 281). Also added text to state that it is unclear if one of these models is preferred for predicting when an individual has Lynch syndrome.</p>

15011<p id="_3509" tabindex="-1">

15012Added <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3057">

15013text</a>

15014 to state that PREMMplus assesses the likelihood of finding a pathogenic variant on a multigene panel of 19 high- and moderate-penetrance genes, and it is not limited to genes associated with CRC.</p>

15015<p id="_3511" tabindex="-1">

15016Added <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2987">

15017text</a>

15018 to state that the phenomenon in which tumors have MSI and/or a loss of MMR protein expression on immunohistochemistry (IHC) testing but no germline pathogenic variant has been labeled Lynch-like syndrome, although this terminology may cause confusion since this term represents a mechanism of sporadic carcinogenesis, rather than a stand-alone genetic syndrome. </p>

15019<p id="_3516" tabindex="-1">

15020Added <em class="gene-name">

15021<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3122">

15022PMS2</a>

15023</em>

15024 as a germline MMR defect that can be predicted by the loss of MLH1 protein expression on IHC in <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3122">

15025Table 9</a>

15026, Protein Loss and Potential Germline Defect(s).</p>

15027<p id="_3517" tabindex="-1">

15028Added <em class="gene-name">

15029<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3122">

15030MSH6</a>

15031</em>

15032 as a germline MMR defect that can be predicted by the loss of MSH2 protein expression on IHC in <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3122">

15033Table 9</a>

15034, Protein Loss and Potential Germline Defect(s).</p>

15035<p id="_3512" tabindex="-1">

15036Added <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3501">

15037Somatic biallelic mismatch repair deficiency (sometimes called Lynch-like syndrome)</a>

15038 as a new subsection.</p>

15039<p id="_3513" tabindex="-1">

15040The <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3012">

15041IHC in constitutional mismatch repair deficiency (CMMRD) syndrome</a>

15042 subsection was renamed from Biallelic mismatch repair deficiency (BMMRD) syndrome.</p>

15043<p id="_3514" tabindex="-1">

15044Added <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3013">

15045text</a>

15046 to state that in contrast with Lynch syndrome, rarely, individuals can have deleterious germline variants in both alleles of the same MMR gene. These cases can present with homozygous or compound heterozygous genotypes.</p>

15047<p id="_3515" tabindex="-1">

15048The <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3022">

15049Somatic biallelic MMR deficiency (sometimes called Lynch-like syndrome)</a>

15050 row was renamed from Lynch-like in <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3022">

15051Table 10</a>

15052, Hereditary CRC Syndromes and Associated Tumor Phenotypes.</p>

15053<p id="_3518" tabindex="-1">

15054Revised <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3126">

15055text</a>

15056 to state that cases in which a tumor displayed MSI and/or abnormal IHC but no germline pathogenic variant was detected are sometimes, confusingly, called Lynch-like syndrome cases, even though they are typically not considered to be familial.</p>

15057<p id="_3520" tabindex="-1">

15058The <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3105">

15059CMMRD</a>

15060 subsection was renamed from BMMRD.</p>

15061<p id="_3521" tabindex="-1">

15062The <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_3007">

15063Lynch-like or HNPCC-like syndrome</a>

15064 subsection was extensively revised. </p>

15065<p id="_disclaimerHP_3" tabindex="-1">

15066This summary is written and maintained by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/genetics" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/genetics">

15067PDQ Cancer Genetics Editorial Board</a>

15068, which is

15069editorially independent of NCI. The summary reflects an independent review of

15070the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or NIH. More

15071information about summary policies and the role of the PDQ Editorial Boards in

15072maintaining the PDQ summaries can be found on the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_AboutThis_1">

15073About This PDQ Summary</a>

15074 and <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq">

15075PDQ&#174; Cancer Information for Health Professionals</a>

15076 pages.

15077</p>

15078</div>

15079

15080 </section>

15081

15082

15083

15084 <section id="_AboutThis_1">

15085

15086 <h2>

15087About This PDQ Summary</h2>

15088

15089 <div id="_section_AboutThis_1" class="pdq-sections">

15090<section id="_AboutThis_2">

15091<h3 id="_AboutThis_2_toc">

15092Purpose of This Summary</h3>

15093<p id="_AboutThis_3" tabindex="-1">

15094This PDQ cancer information summary for health professionals provides comprehensive, peer-reviewed, evidence-based information about the genetics of colorectal cancer. It is intended as a resource to inform and assist clinicians in the care of their patients. It does not provide formal guidelines or recommendations for making health care decisions.</p>

15095</section>

15096<section id="_AboutThis_4">

15097<h3 id="_AboutThis_4_toc">

15098Reviewers and Updates</h3>

15099<p id="_AboutThis_5" tabindex="-1">

15100This summary is reviewed regularly and updated as necessary by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/genetics" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/genetics">

15101PDQ Cancer Genetics Editorial Board</a>

15102, which is editorially independent of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The summary reflects an independent review of the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or the National Institutes of Health (NIH).</p>

15103<p id="_AboutThis_22" tabindex="-1">

15104 Board members review recently published articles each month to determine whether an article should:</p>

15105<div class="pdq-content-list">

15106<ul id="_AboutThis_6">

15107<li>

15108be discussed at a meeting,</li>

15109<li>

15110be cited with text, or</li>

15111<li>

15112replace or update an existing article that is already cited.</li>

15113</ul>

15114</div>

15115<p id="_AboutThis_7" tabindex="-1">

15116Changes to the summaries are made through a consensus process in which Board members evaluate the strength of the evidence in the published articles and determine how the article should be included in the summary.</p>

15117<p id="" tabindex="-1">

15118The lead reviewers for Genetics of Colorectal Cancer are:</p>

15119<div class="pdq-content-list">

15120<ul id="">

15121<li>

15122Kathleen A. Calzone, PhD, RN, AGN-BC, FAAN (National Cancer Institute)</li>

15123<li>

15124Fay Kastrinos, MD, MPH (Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center

15125and New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center)</li>

15126<li>

15127Scott Kuwada, MD, AGAF, FACP (University of Hawaii)</li>

15128<li>

15129Gautam Mankaney, MD (Virginia Mason Franciscan Health)</li>

15130<li>

15131Suzanne C. O'Neill, PhD (Georgetown University)</li>

15132<li>

15133Susan K. Peterson, PhD, MPH (University of Texas, M.D. Anderson Cancer Center)</li>

15134<li>

15135John M. Quillin, PhD, MPH, MS (Virginia Commonwealth University)</li>

15136<li>

15137Charite Ricker, MS, CGC (University of Southern California)</li>

15138<li>

15139Danielle Kim Turgeon, MD (University of Michigan Comprehensive Cancer Center)</li>

15140<li>

15141Catharine Wang, PhD, MSc (Boston University School of Public Health)</li>

15142<li>

15143Y. Nancy You, MD, MHSc (University of Texas, M.D. Anderson Cancer Center)</li>

15144<li>

15145Matthew B. Yurgelun, MD (Dana-Farber Cancer Institute)</li>

15146<li>

15147Kevin Zbuk, MD, FRCPC (Margaret and Charles Juravinski Cancer Centre)</li>

15148</ul>

15149</div>

15150<p id="_AboutThis_9" tabindex="-1">

15151Any comments or questions about the summary content should be submitted to Cancer.gov through the NCI website's <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

15152Email Us</a>

15153. Do not contact the individual Board Members with questions or comments about the summaries. Board members will not respond to individual inquiries.</p>

15154</section>

15155<section id="_AboutThis_10">

15156<h3 id="_AboutThis_10_toc">

15157Levels of Evidence</h3>

15158<p id="_AboutThis_11" tabindex="-1">

15159Some of the reference citations in this summary are accompanied by a level-of-evidence designation. These designations are intended to help readers assess the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches. The PDQ Cancer Genetics Editorial Board uses a <a href="/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/genetics">

15160formal evidence ranking system</a>

15161 in developing its level-of-evidence designations.</p>

15162</section>

15163<section id="_AboutThis_12">

15164<h3 id="_AboutThis_12_toc">

15165Permission to Use This Summary</h3>

15166<p id="_AboutThis_13" tabindex="-1">

15167PDQ is a registered trademark. Although the content of PDQ documents can be used freely as text, it cannot be identified as an NCI PDQ cancer information summary unless it is presented in its entirety and is regularly updated. However, an author would be permitted to write a sentence such as &#8220;NCI&#8217;s PDQ cancer information summary about breast cancer prevention states the risks succinctly: [include excerpt from the summary].&#8221;</p>

15168<p id="_AboutThis_14" tabindex="-1">

15169The preferred citation for this PDQ summary is:</p>

15170<p id="_AboutThis_15" tabindex="-1">

15171PDQ&#174; Cancer Genetics Editorial Board. PDQ Genetics of Colorectal Cancer. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Updated &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. Available at: <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq">

15172https://www.cancer.gov/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq</a>

15173. Accessed &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. [PMID: 26389505]</p>

15174<p id="_AboutThis_16" tabindex="-1">

15175Images in this summary are used with permission of the author(s), artist, and/or publisher for use within the PDQ summaries only. Permission to use images outside the context of PDQ information must be obtained from the owner(s) and cannot be granted by the National Cancer Institute. Information about using the illustrations in this summary, along with many other cancer-related images, is available in <a href="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/" title="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/">

15176Visuals Online</a>

15177, a collection of over 2,000 scientific images.

15178

15179</p>

15180</section>

15181<section id="_AboutThis_17">

15182<h3 id="_AboutThis_17_toc">

15183Disclaimer</h3>

15184<p id="_AboutThis_19" tabindex="-1">

15185The information in these summaries should not be used as a basis for insurance reimbursement determinations. More information on insurance coverage is available on Cancer.gov on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care">

15186Managing Cancer Care</a>

15187 page.</p>

15188</section>

15189<section id="_AboutThis_20">

15190<h3 id="_AboutThis_20_toc">

15191Contact Us</h3>

15192<p id="_AboutThis_21" tabindex="-1">

15193More information about contacting us or receiving help with the Cancer.gov website can be found on our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact">

15194Contact Us for Help</a>

15195 page. Questions can also be submitted to Cancer.gov through the website&#8217;s <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

15196Email Us</a>

15197.</p>

15198</section>

15460 >

15461Find a Clinical Trial</a

15462 >

15463

15464 </li>

15465

15466 </ul>

15468 </section>

15469

15470 </div>
